oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmāt karmasu ye yeṣv abhipretās taiḥ saha mantrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence he shall consult such persons as are believed to be capable of giving decisive opinion regarding those works about which he seeks for advice

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tair mantrayamāṇo hi mantrasiddhiṃ guptiṃ ca labhate iti // naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he consults thus, he can secure good advice as well as secrecy of counsel Not so, says Kautilya, for this kind of seeking for advice is infinite and endless

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantribhis tribhiś caturbhir vā saha mantrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall consult three or four ministers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantrayamāṇo hy ekenaarthakṛcchreṣu niścayaṃ naadhigacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Consultation with a single minister may not lead to any definite conclusion in cases of complicated issues

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaś ca mantrī yathāiṣṭam anavagrahaś carati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A single minister proceeds willfully and without restraint

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvābhyāṃ mantrayamāṇo dvābhyāṃ saṃhatābhyām avagṛhyate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In deliberating with two ministers, the king may be overpowered by their combined action, or imperiled by their mutual dissension

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tat triṣu catuṣu vā kṛcchreṇaupapadyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But with three or four ministers he will not come to any serious grief, but will arrive at satisfactory results

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahādoṣam upapannaṃ tu bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: nor will secrecy of counsel be maintained without much trouble

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśakālakāryavaśena tv ekena saha dvābhyām eko vā yathāsāmarthyaṃ mantrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In accordance with the requirements of place, time, and nature of the work in view, he may, as he deems it proper, deliberate with one or two ministers or by himself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karmaṇām ārambhaupāyaḥ puruṣadravyasampad deśakālavibhāgo vinipātapratīkāraḥ kāryasiddhir iti pañcaaṅgo mantraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Means to carry out works, command of plenty of men and wealth, allotment of time and place, remedies against dangers, and final success are the five constituents of every councildeliberation

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tān ekaikaśaḥ pṛcchet samastāṃś ca // hetubhiś caeṣāṃ matipravivekān vidyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The king may ask his ministers for their opinion either individually or collectively, and ascertain their ability by judging over the reasons they assign for their opinions

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avāptaarthaḥ kālaṃ naatikrāmayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall lose no time when the opportunity waited for arrives;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na teṣāṃ pakṣīyair yeṣām apakuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: nor shall he sit long at consultation with those whose parties he intends to hurt

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantripariṣadaṃ dvādaśaamātyān kurvīta iti mānavāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The school of Manu say that the assembly of ministers mantriparishad shall be made to consist of twelve members

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṣoḍaśa iti bārhaspatyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The school of Brihaspathi say that it shall consist of sixteen members

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viṃśatim ity auśanasāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The school of Usanas say that it shall consist of twenty members

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathāsāmarthyam iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But Kautilya holds that it shall consist of as many members as the needs of his dominion require yathásámarthyam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: te hy asya svapakṣaṃ parapakṣaṃ ca cintayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those ministers shall have to consider all that concerns the parties of both the king and his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: akṛtaārambham ārabdhaanuṣṭhānam anuṣṭhitaviśeṣaṃ niyogasampadaṃ ca karmaṇāṃ kuryuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They shall also set themselves to start the work that is not yet begun, to complete what has been begun, to improve what has been accomplished, and to enforce strict obedience to orders niyogasampadam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsannaiḥ saha karmāṇi paśyet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall supervise works in company with his officers that are near ásannaih;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anāsannaiḥ saha pattrasampreṣaṇena mantrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and consult by sending writs patrasampreshanena those that are not near ásanna

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: indrasya hi mantripariṣadṛṣīṇāṃ sahasram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One thousand sages form Indras assembly of ministers mantriparishad

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa tac cakṣuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They are his eyes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād imaṃ dvyakṣaṃ sahasraakṣam āhuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence he is called thousandeyed though he possesses only two eyes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātyayike kārye mantriṇo mantripariṣadaṃ caāhūya brūyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In works of emergency, he shall call both his ministers and Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 the assembly of ministers mantrino mantriparishadam cha, and tell them of the same

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra yadbhūyiṣṭhā brūyuḥ kāryasiddhikaraṃ vā tat kuryāt // kurvataś ca
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall do whatever the majority bhúyishtháh of the members suggest or whatever course of action leading to success káryasiddhikaram va they point out

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naasya guhyaṃ pare vidyuś chidraṃ vidyāt parasya ca /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: And while doing any work, None of his enemies pare shall know his secret, but he shall know the weak points of his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūhet kūrmaivaaṅgāni yat syād vivṛtam ātmanaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Like a tortoise he shall draw in his limbs that are stretched out

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā hy aśrotriyaḥ śrāddhaṃ na satāṃ bhoktum arhati / evam aśrutaśāstraartho na mantraṃ śrotum arhati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Just as balls of meal offered to ancestors by a person not learned in the Vedas are unfit to be eaten by wise men, so whoever is not well versed in sciences shall be unfit to hear of council deliberations CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udvṛttamantro dūtapraṇidhiḥ // amātyasampadāupeto nisṛṣṭaarthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE MISSION OF ENVOYS WHOEVER has succeeded as a councillor is an envoy Whoever possesses ministerial qualifications is a chargédaffaires nisrishtárthah

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ardhaguṇahīnaḥ śāsanaharaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever possesses the same qualifications less by onehalf is a conveyer of royal writs sásanaharah

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suprativihitayānavāhanapuruṣaparivāpaḥ pratiṣṭheta // śāsanam evaṃ vācyaḥ paraḥ, sa vakṣyaty evam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having made excellent arrangements for carriage, Kautilyas Arthashastra conveyance, servants and subsistence, he an envoy shall start on his mission, thinking that the enemy shall be told thus the enemy para will say, thus;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyaidaṃ prativākyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this shall be the reply to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam atisaṃdhātavyam, ity adhīyāno gacchet // aṭavyantapālapurarāṣṭramukhyaiś ca pratisaṃsargaṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and thus he shall be imposed upon The envoy shall make friendship with the enemys officers such as those in charge of wild tracts, of boundaries, of cities, and of country parts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anīkasthānayuddhapratigrahaapasārabhūmīr ātmanaḥ parasya caavekṣeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall also contrast the military stations, sinews of war, and strongholds of the enemy with those of his own master

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgarāṣṭrapramāṇaṃ sāravṛttigupticchidrāṇi caupalabheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall ascertain the size and area of forts and of the state, as well as strongholds of precious things and assailable and unassailable points

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraadhiṣṭhānam anujñātaḥ praviśet // śāsanaṃ ca yathāuktaṃ brūyāt, prāṇaābādheapi dṛṣṭe //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having obtained permission, he shall enter into the capital of the enemy and state the object of the mission as exactly as entrusted to him even at the cost of his own life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya vāci vaktre dṛṣṭyāṃ ca prasādaṃ vākyapūjanam iṣṭaparipraśnaṃ guṇakathāsaṅgam āsannam āsanaṃ satkāram iṣṭeṣu smaraṇaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Brightness in the tone, face, and eyes of the enemy; respectful reception of the mission; enquiry about the health of friends; taking part in the narration of virtues; giving a seat close to the throne;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśvāsagamanaṃ ca lakṣayet tuṣṭasya, viparītam atuṣṭasya //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: closing the mission with satisfaction;all these shall be noted as indicating the good graces of the enemy and the reverse his displeasure

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: taṃ brūyāt dūtamukhā hi rājānaḥ, tvaṃ caanye ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A displeased enemy maybe told Messengers are the mouthpieces of kings, not only of thyself, but of all;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād udyateṣv api śastreṣu yathāuktaṃ vaktāro dūtāḥ // teṣām antaavasāyinoapy avadhyāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: hence messengers who, in the face of weapons raised against them, have to express their mission as exactly as they are entrusted with do not, though outcasts, deserve death;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kim aṅga punar brāhmaṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: where is then reason to put messengers of Bráhman caste to death? This is anothers speech

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasyaetad vākyam // eṣa dūtadharmaḥ iti // vased avisṛṣṭaḥ pūjayā nautsiktaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This ie, delivery of that speech verbatim is the duty of messengers Kautilyas Arthashastra Not puffed up with the respects shown to him, he shall stay there till he is allowed to depart

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pareṣu balitvaṃ na manyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall not care for the mightiness of the enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: striyaḥ pānaṃ ca varjayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall strictly avoid women and liquor;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaḥ śayīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall take bed single;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suptamattayor hi bhāvajñānaṃ dṛṣṭam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it is wellknown that the intentions of envoys are ascertained while they are asleep or under the influence of liquor

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtyapakṣaupajāpam akṛtyapakṣe gūḍhapraṇidhānaṃ rāgaaparāgau bhartari randhraṃ ca prakṛtīnāṃ tāpasavaidehakavyañjanābhyām tayor antevāsibhiś cikitsakapāṣaṇḍavyañjanaubhayavetanair vā // teṣām asambhāṣāyāṃ yācakamattaunmattasuptapralāpaiḥ puṇyasthānadevagṛhacitralekhyasaṃjñābhir vā cāram upalabheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall, through the agency of ascetic and merchant spies or through their disciples or through spies under the disguise of physicians, and heretics, or through recipients of salaries from two states ubhayavétana, ascertain the nature of the intrigue prevalent among parties favourably disposed to his own master, as well as the conspiracy of hostile factions, and understand the loyalty or disloyalty of the people to the enemy besides any assailable points If there is no possibility of carrying on any such conversation conversation with the people regarding their loyalty, he may try to gather such information by observing the talk of beggars, intoxicated and insane persons or of persons babbling in sleep, or by observing the signs made in places of pilgrimage and temples or by deciphering paintings and secret writings chitragúdhalékhyasamjñábhih

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upalabdhasyaupajāpam upeyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whatever information he thus gathers he shall try to test by intrigues

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pareṇa cauktaḥ svāsāṃ prakṛtīnāṃ pramāṇaṃ naācakṣīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall not check the estimate which the enemy makes of the elements of sovereignty of his own master;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvaṃ veda bhavān iti brūyāt, kāryasiddhikaraṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but he shall only say in reply, „All is known to thee‟ Nor shall he disclose the means employed by his master to achieve an end in view

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāryasyaasiddhāv uparudhyamānas tarkayet kiṃ bhartur me vyasanam āsannaṃ paśyan,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he has not succeeded in his mission, but is still detained, he shall proceed to infer thus Kautilyas Arthashastra Whether seeing the imminent danger into which my master is likely to fall and desirous of averting his own danger;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svaṃ vā vyasanaṃ pratikartukāmaḥ, pārṣṇigrāham āsāram antaḥkopam āṭavikaṃ vā samutthāpayitukāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whether in view of inciting against my master an enemy threatening in the rear or a king whose dominion in the rear is separated by other intervening states; whether in view of causing internal rebellion in my masters state, or of inciting a wild chief átavika against my master;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitram ākrandaṃ vā vyāghātayitukāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whether in view of destroying my master by employing a friend or a king whose dominion stretches out in the rear of my masters state ákranda;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svaṃ vā parato vigraham antaḥkopam āṭavikaṃ vā pratikartukāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whether with the intention of averting the internal trouble in his own state or of preventing a foreign invasion or the inroads of a wild chief;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃsiddhaṃ vā me bhartur yātrākālam abhihantukāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whether in view of causing the approaching time of my masters expedition to lapse;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sasyapaṇyakupyasaṃgrahaṃ durgakarma balasamuddānaṃ vā kartukāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whether with the desire of collecting raw materials and merchandise, or of repairing his fortifications, or of recruiting a strong army capable to fight;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svasainyānāṃ vā vyāyāmasya deśakālāv ākāṅkṣamāṇaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whether waiting for the time and opportunity necessary for the complete training of his own army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paribhavapramādābhyāṃ vā, saṃsargaanubandhaarthī vā, mām uparuṇaddhi iti // jñātvā vased apasared vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or whether in view of making a desirable alliance in order to avert the present contempt brought about by his own carelessness, this king detains me thus? Then he may stay or get out as he deems it desirable;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prayojanam iṣṭam avekṣeta vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may demand a speedy settlement of his mission

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śāsanam aniṣṭam uktvā bandhavadhabhayād avisṛṣṭoapy apagacchet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having intimated an unfavourable order sásana to the enemy, and pretending apprehension of imprisonment or death, he may return even without permission;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā niyamyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise he may be punished

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: preṣaṇaṃ saṃdhipālatvaṃ pratāpo mitrasaṃgrahaḥ / upajāpaḥ suhṛdbhedo gūḍhadaṇḍaatisāraṇam // bandhuratnaapaharaṇaṃ cārajñānaṃ parākramaḥ / samādhimokṣo dūtasya karma yogasya caāśrayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Transmission of missions, maintenance of treaties, issue of ultimatum pratápa, gaining of friends, intrigue, sowing dissension among friends, fetching secret force; carrying away by stealth relatives and gems, gathering information about the movements of spies, bravery, breaking of treaties of peace, winning over the favour of the envoy and government officers of the enemy,these are the duties of an envoy dúta

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svadūtaiḥ kārayed etat paradūtāṃś ca rakṣayet / pratidūtaapasarpābhyāṃ dṛśyaadṛśyaiś ca rakṣibhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The king shall employ his own envoys to carry on works of the above description, and guard himself against the mischief of foreign envoys by employing counter envoys, spies, and visible and invisible watchmen

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rakṣito rājā rājyaṃ rakṣaty āsannebhyaḥ parebhyaś ca, pūrvaṃ dārebhyaḥ putrebhyaś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: PROTECTION OF PRINCES Protection of Princes HAVING secured his own personal safety first from his wives and sons, the king can be in a position to maintain the security of his kingdom against immediate enemies as well as foreign kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dārarakṣaṇaṃ niśāntapraṇidhau vakṣyāmaḥ // putrarakṣaṇaṃ tu // janmaprabhṛti rājaputrān rakṣet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: We shall treat of Protection of Wives in connection with Duties towards the Harem Ever since the birth of princes, the king shall take special care of them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karkaṭakasadharmāṇo hi janakabhakṣā rājaputrāḥ // teṣām ajātasnehe pitary upāṃśudaṇḍaḥ śreyān iti bhāradvājaḥ // nṛśaṃsam aduṣṭavadhaḥ kṣatrabījavināśaś ca iti viśālaakṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For, says Bháradvája, princes like crabs have a notorious tendency of eating up their begetter When they are wanting in filial affection, they shall better be punished in secret upámsudandah This is, says Visáláksha, cruelty, destruction of fortune, and extirpation of the seed of the race of Kshattriyas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād ekasthānaavarodhaḥ śreyān iti // ahibhayam etad iti pārāśarāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence it is better to keep them under guard in a definite place This, say the school of Parásara, is akin to the fear from a lurking snake ahibhayam;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kumāro hi vikramabhayān māṃ pitāavaruṇaddhi iti jñātvā tam evaaṅke kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for a prince may think that Kautilyas Arthashastra apprehensive of danger, his father has locked him up, and may attempt to put his own father on his lap

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād antapāladurge vāsaḥ śreyān iti // aurabhraṃ bhayam etad iti piśunaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence it is better to keep a prince under the custody of boundary guards or inside a fort This, says Pisuna, is akin to the fear from a wolf in the midst of a flock of sheep aurabhrakam bhayam;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratyāpatter hi tad eva kāraṇaṃ jñātvāantapālasakhaḥ syāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for after understanding the cause of his rustication, he may avail himself of the opportunity to, make an alliance with the boundary guards against his father

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmāt svaviṣayād apakṛṣṭe sāmantadurge vāsaḥ śreyān iti // vatsasthānam etad iti kauṇapadantaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence it is better to throw him inside a fort belonging to a foreign king far away from his own state This, says Kaunapadanta, is akin to the position of a calf vatsasthánam;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vatsenaiva hi dhenuṃ pitaram asya sāmanto duhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for just as a man milks a cow with the help of its calf, so the foreign king may milk reduce the princes father

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmān mātṛbandhuṣu vāsaḥ śreyān iti // dhvajasthānam etad iti vātavyādhiḥ // tena hi dhvajenaaditikauśikavad asya mātṛbāndhavā bhikṣeran //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence it is better to make a prince live with his maternal relations This, says Vátavyádhi is akin to the position of a flag dhvajasthánamétat for as in the case of Aditi and Kausika, the princes maternal relations may, unfurling this flag, go on begging

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukhauparuddhā hi putrāḥ pitaraṃ naabhidruhyanti iti // jīvanmaraṇam etad iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence princes may be suffered to dissipate their lives by sensual excesses grámyadharma inasmuch as revelling sons do not dislike their indulgent father This, says Kautilya, is death in life;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāṣṭham iva ghuṇajagdhaṃ rājakulam avinītaputram abhiyuktamātraṃ bhajyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for no sooner is a royal family with a prince or princes given to dissipation attacked, than it perishes like a wormeaten piece of wood

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād ṛtumatyāṃ mahiṣyām ṛtvijaś carum aindrābārhaspatyaṃ nirvapeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence when the queen attains the age favourable for procreation, priests shall offer to Indra and Brihaspati the requisite oblations

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prajātāyāḥ putrasaṃskāraṃ purohitaḥ kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When she is big with a child, the king shall observe the instructions of midwifery with regard to gestation and delivery

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samarthaṃ tadvido vinayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: After delivery, the priests shall perform the prescribed purificatory ceremonials

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sattriṇām ekaś caenaṃ mṛgayādyūtamadyastrībhiḥ pralobhayet pitari vikramya rājyaṃ gṛhāṇa iti // tam anyaḥ sattrī pratiṣedhayet ity āmbhīyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the prince attains the necessary age, adepts shall train him under proper discipline Kautilyas Arthashastra Any one of the classmate spies, say politicians known as Ambhíyas, may allure the prince towards hunting, gambling, liquor, and women, and instigate him to attack his own father and snatch the reins of government in his own hands

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahādoṣam abuddhabodhanam it kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Another spy shall prevent him from such acts There can be, says Kautilya, no greater crime or sin than making wicked impressions on an innocent mind;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: navaṃ hi dravyaṃ yena yenaarthajātenaupadihyate tat tad ācūṣati // evam ayaṃ navabuddhir yad yad ucyate tat tatśāstraupadeśam ivaabhijānāti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: just as a fresh object is stained with whatever it is brought in close association, so a prince with fresh mind is apt to regard as scientific injunctions all that he is told of

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād dharmyam arthyaṃ caasyaupadiśen naadharmyam anarthyaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence he shall be taught only of righteousness and of wealth artha, but not of unrighteousness and of nonwealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sattriṇas tv enaṃ tava smaḥ iti vadantaḥ pālayeyuḥ // yauvanautsekāt parastrīṣu manaḥ kurvāṇam āryāvyañjanābhiḥ strībhir amedhyābhiḥ śūnyaāgāreṣu rātrāv udvejayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Classmate spies shall be so courteous towards him as to say thine are we When under the temptation of youth, he turns his eye towards women, impure women under the disguise of Aryas shall, at night and in lonely places, terrify him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madyakāmaṃ yogapānenaudvejayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when fond of liquor, he shall be terrified by making him drink such liquor as is adulterated with narcotics yógapána;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dyūtakāmaṃ kāpaṭikair udvejayeyuḥ // mṛgayākāmaṃ pratirodhakavyañjanais trāsayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when fond of gambling, he shall be terrified by spies under the disguise of fraudulent persons; when fond of hunting, he shall be terrified by spies under the disguise of highway robbers;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pitari vikramabuddhiṃ tathā ity anupraviśya bhedayeyuḥ aprārthanīyo rājā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when desirous of attacking his own father, he shall, under the pretence of compliance, be gradually persuaded of the evil consequences of such attempts, by telling a king is not made by a mere wish;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vipanne ghātaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: failure of thy attempt will bring about thy own death;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sampanne narakapātaḥ, saṃkrośaḥ, prajābhir ekaloṣṭavadhaś ca iti // virāgaṃ vedayeyuḥ // priyam ekaputraṃ badhnīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: success makes thee fall into hell and causes the people to lament for thy father and destroy the only clod ekalóshtavadhascha, ie, thyself When a king has an only son who is either devoid of worldly pleasures or is a favourite child, the king may keep him under chains

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahuputraḥ pratyantam anyaviṣayaṃ vā preṣayed yatra garbhaḥ paṇyaṃ ḍimbo vā na bhavet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If a king has many sons, he may send some of them to where there is no heir apparent, nor a child either just born or in the embryo

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātmasampannaṃ saināpatye yauvarājye vā sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra When a prince is possessed of good and amicable qualities, he may be made the commanderinchief or installed as heir apparent

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: buddhimānāhāryabuddhir durbuddhir iti putraviśeṣāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sons are of three kinds those of sharp intelligence; those of stagnant intelligence; and those of perverted mind

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śiṣyamāṇo dharmaarthāv upalabhate caanutiṣṭhati ca buddhimān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever carries into practice whatever he is taught concerning righteousness and wealth is one of sharp intelligence;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upalabhamāno naanutiṣṭhaty āhāryabuddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever never carries into practice the good instructions he has imbibed is one of stagnant intelligence;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apāyanityo dharmaarthadveṣī caiti durbuddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and whoever entangles himself in dangers and hates righteousness and wealth is one of perverted mind

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa yady ekaputraḥ putrautpattāv asya prayateta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If a king has an only son of the last type, attempts shall be made to procreating a son to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: putrikāputrān utpādayed vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or sons may be begotten on his daughters

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vṛddhas tu vyādhito vā rājā mātṛbandhukulyaguṇavatsāmantānām anyatamena kṣetre bījam utpādayet // na caekaputram avinītaṃ rājye sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king is too old or diseased to beget sons, he may appoint a maternal relation or a blood relation kulya of his or any one of his neighbouring kings possessed of good and amicable qualities to sow the seed in his own field kshétrebíjam, ie, to beget a son on his wife But never shall a wicked and an only son be installed on the royal throne

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahūnām ekasamrodhaḥ pitā putrahito bhavet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A royal father who is the only prop for many people shall be favourably disposed towards his son

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyatraāpada aiśvaryaṃ jyeṣṭhabhāgi tu pūjyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Except in dangers, sovereignty falling to the lot of the eldest son is always respected

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kulasya vā bhaved rājyaṃ kulasaṃgho hi durjayaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sovereignty may sometimes be the property of a clan;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arājavyasanaābādhaḥ śaśvad āvasati kṣitim //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the corporation of clans is invincible in its nature and being free from the calamities of anarchy, can have a permanent existence on earth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vinīto rājaputraḥ kṛcchravṛttir asadṛśe karmaṇi niyuktaḥ pitaram anuvarteta, anyatra prāṇaābādhakaprakṛtikopakapātakebhyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE CONDUCT OF A PRINCE KEPT UNDER RESTRAINT AND THE TREATMENT OF A RESTRAINED PRINCE A PRINCE, though put to troubles and employed in an unequal task, shall yet faithfully follow his father unless that task costs his life, enrages the people, or causes any other serious calamities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puṇye karmaṇi niyuktaḥ puruṣam adhiṣṭhātāraṃ yācet // puruṣaadhiṣṭhitaś ca saviśeṣam ādeśam anutiṣṭhet // abhirūpaṃ ca karmaphalam aupāyanikaṃ ca lābhaṃ pitur upanāyayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is employed in a good or meritorious work, he shall try to win the good graces of the superintendent of that work, carry the work to a profitable end beyond expectation, and present his father with the proportional profit derived from that work as well as with the excessive profit due to his skill

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathāapy atuṣyantam anyasmin putre dāreṣu vā snihyantam araṇyāyaāpṛccheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the king is not still pleased with him and shows undue partiality to another prince and other wives, he may request the king to permit him for a forestlife

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bandhavadhabhayād vā yaḥ sāmanto nyāyavṛttir dhārmikaḥ satyavāgavisaṃvādakaḥ pratigrahītā mānayitā caabhipannānāṃ tam āśrayeta tatrasthaḥ kośadaṇḍasampannaḥ pravīrapuruṣakanyāsambandham aṭavīsambandhaṃ kṛtyapakṣaupagrahaṃ ca kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or if he apprehends imprisonment or death, he may seek refuge under a neighbouring king who is known to be righteous, charitable, truthful, and not given to cunning, but also welcomes and respects guests of good character Residing therein he may provide himself with men and money, contract marriageconnection with influential personages, and not only make alliance with wild tribes, but win over the parties in his fathers state

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekacaraḥ suvarṇapākamaṇirāgahemarūpyapaṇyaākarakarmaantān ājīvet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or moving alone, he may earn his livelihood by working in gold mines or ruby mines or by manufacturing gold and silver ornaments or any other commercial commodities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / pāṣaṇḍasaṃghadravyam aśrotriyaupabhogyaṃ vā devadravyam āḍhyavidhavādravyaṃ vā gūḍham anupraviśya sārthayānapātrāṇi ca madanarasayogenaatisaṃdhāyaapaharet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having acquired close intimacy with heretics páshanda, rich widows, or merchants carrying on ocean traffic he may, by making use of poison madanarasa, rob them of their wealth as well as the wealth of gods unless the latter is enjoyable by Bráhmans learned in the Vedas Or he may adopt such measures as are employed to Kautilyas Arthashastra capture the villages of a foreign king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mātuḥ parijanaupagraheṇa vā ceṣṭeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may proceed against his father with the help of the servants of his mother

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / kāruśilpikuśīlavacikitsakavāgjīvanapāṣaṇḍacchadmabhir vā naṣṭarūpas tadvyañjanasakhaśchidreṣu praviśya rājñaḥ śastrarasābhyāṃ prahṛtya brūyāt aham asau kumāraḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having disguised himself as a painter, a carpenter, courtbard, a physician, a buffoon, or a heretic, and assisted by spies under similar disguise, he may, when opportunity affords itself, present himself armed with weapons and poison before the king, and address him am the heirapparent;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sahabhogyam idaṃ rājyam, eko naarhati bhoktum, ye kāmayante māṃ bhartuṃ tān ahaṃ dviguṇena bhaktavetanenaupasthāsyāmi iti // ity aparuddhavṛttam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: it does not become thee to enjoy the state alone when it is enjoyable by both of us, or when others justly desire such enjoyment; ought not to be kept away by awarding an allowance of double the subsistence and salary These are the measures that a prince kept under restraint has to take

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aparuddhaṃ tu mukhyaputraapasarpāḥ pratipādyaānayeyuḥ, mātā vā pratigṛhītā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies or his mother, natural or adoptive, may reconcile an heirapparent under restraint and bring him to the court

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tyaktaṃ gūḍhapuruṣāḥ śastrarasābhyāṃ hanyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or secret emissaries armed with weapons and poison may kill an abandoned prince

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atyaktaṃ tulyaśīlābhiḥ strībhiḥ pānena mṛgayayā vā prasañjayitvā rātrāv upagṛhyaānayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is not abandoned, he may be caught hold of at night by employing women equal to the occasion, or by making use of liquor, or on the occasion of hunting, and brought back to the court

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upasthitaṃ ca rājyena madūrdhvam iti sāntvayet / ekastham atha samrundhyāt putravāṃs tu pravāsayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When thus brought back, he shall be conciliated by the king with promise of sovereignty „after me‟ ie, after the kings death, and kept under guard, in a definite locality Or if the king has many sons, an unruly prince may be banished

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājānam utthitam anūttiṣṭhante bhṛtyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE DUTIES OF A KING IF a king is energetic, his subjects will be equally energetic

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pramādyantam anupramādyanti // karmāṇi caasya bhakṣayanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is reckless, they will not only be reckless likewise, but also eat into his works

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviṣadbhiś caatisaṃdhīyate /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Besides, a reckless king will easily fall into the hands of his enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād utthānam ātmanaḥ kurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the king shall ever be wakeful

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nālikābhir ahar aṣṭadhā rātriṃ ca vibhajet, chāyāpramāṇena vā // tripauruṣī pauruṣī caturaṅgulā naṣṭacchāyo madhyaahnaiti catvāraḥ pūrve divasasyaaṣṭabhāgāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall divide both the day and the night into eight nálikas ½ hours, or according to the length of the shadow cast by a gnomon standing in the sun the shadow of three purushás angulás or inches, of one purushá inches, of four angulás inches, and absence of shadow denoting midday are the four oneeighth divisions of the forenoon;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: taiḥ paścimā vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: like divisions in the reverse order in the afternoon

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra pūrve divasasyaaṣṭabhāge rakṣāvidhānam āyavyayau ca śṛṇuyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these divisions, during the first oneeighth part of the day, he shall post watchmen and attend to the accounts of receipts and expenditure;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvitīye paurajānapadānāṃ kāryāṇi paśyet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the second part, he shall look to the affairs of both citizens and country people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tṛtīye snānabhojanaṃ seveta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the third, he shall not only bathe and dine, but also study;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturthe hiraṇyapratigraham adhyakṣāṃś ca kurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the fourth, he shall not only receive revenue in gold hiranya, but also attend to the appointments of superintendents;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcame mantripariṣadā pattrasampreṣaṇena mantrayeta, cāraguhyabodhanīyāni ca budhyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the fifth, he shall correspond in writs patrasampreshanena with the assembly of his ministers, and receive the secret information gathered by his spies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṣaṣṭhe svairavihāraṃ mantraṃ vā seveta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the sixth, he may engage himself in his favourite amusements or in selfdeliberation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saptame hastyaśvarathaāyudhīyān paśyet // aṣṭame senāpatisakho vikramaṃ cintayet // pratiṣṭhiteahani saṃdhyām upāsīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the seventh, he shall superintend elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry, and during the eighth part, he shall consider various plans of military operations with his commanderinchief At the close of the day, he shall observe the evening prayer sandhya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prathame rātribhāge gūḍhapuruṣān paśyet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra During the first oneeighth part of the night, he shall receive secret emissaries;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvitīye snānabhojanaṃ kurvīta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the second, he shall attend to bathing and supper and study;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tṛtīye tūryaghoṣeṇa saṃviṣṭaś caturthapañcamau śayīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the third, he shall enter the bedchamber amid the sound of trumpets and enjoy sleep during the fourth and fifth parts;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṣaṣṭhe tūryaghoṣeṇa pratibuddhaḥ śāstram itikartavyatāṃ ca cintayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: having been awakened by the sound of trumpets during the sixth part, he shall recall to his mind the injunctions of sciences as well as the days duties;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saptame mantram adhyāsīta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: during the seventh, he shall sit considering administrative measures and send out spies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṣṭame ṛtvigācāryapurohitasvastyayanāni pratigṛhṇīyāt, cikitsakamāhānasikamauhūrtikāṃś ca paśyet // savastāṃ dhenuṃ vṛṣabhaṃ ca pradakṣiṇīkṛtyaupasthānaṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and during the eighth division of the night, he shall receive benedictions from sacrificial priests, teachers, and the high priest, and having seen his physician, chief cook and astrologer, and having saluted both a cow with its calf and a bull by circumambulating round them, he shall get into his court

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātmabalaānukūlyena vā niśāaharbhāgān pravibhajya kāryāṇi seveta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or in conformity to his capacity, he may alter the timetable and attend to his duties

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upasthānagataḥ kāryaarthinām advāraāsaṅgaṃ kārayet // durdarśo hi rājā kāryaakāryaviparyāsam āsannaiḥ kāryate // tena prakṛtikopam arivaśaṃ vā gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When in the court, he shall never cause his petitioners to wait at the door, for when a king makes himself inaccessible to his people and entrusts his work to his immediate officers, he may be sure to engender confusion in business, and to cause thereby public disaffection, and himself a prey to his enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād devatāāśramapāṣaṇḍaśrotriyapaśupuṇyasthānānāṃ bālavṛddhavyādhitavyasanyanāthānāṃ strīṇāṃ ca krameṇa kāryāṇi paśyet, kāryagauravād ātyayikavaśena vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall, therefore, personally attend to the business of gods, of heretics, of Bráhmans learned in the Vedas, of cattle, of sacred places, of minors, the aged, the afflicted, and the helpless, and of women;all this in order of enumeration or according to the urgency or pressure of those works

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvam ātyayikaṃ kāryaṃ śṛṇuyān naatipātayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: All urgent calls he shall hear at once, but never put off;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛcchrasādhyam atikrāntam asādhyaṃ vāapi jāyate // agnyagāragataḥ kāryaṃ paśyed vaidyatapasvinām /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when postponed, they will prove too hard or impossible to accomplish Having seated himself in the room where the sacred fire has Kautilyas Arthashastra been kept, he shall attend to the business of physicians and ascetics practising austerities;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purohitaācāryasakhaḥ pratyutthāyaabhivādya ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that in company with his high priest and teacher and after preliminary salutation to the petitioners

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tapasvināṃ tu kāryāṇi traividyaiḥ saha kārayet / māyāyogavidāṃ caiva na svayaṃ kopakāraṇāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Accompanied by persons proficient in the three sciences trividya but not alone lest the petitioners be offended, he shall look to the business of those who are practising austerities, as well as of those who are experts in witchcraft and Yóga

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājño hi vratam utthānaṃ yajñaḥ kāryaanuśāsanam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of a king, the religious vow is his readiness to action; satisfactory discharge of duties is his performance of sacrifice;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dakṣiṇā vṛttisāmyaṃ tu dīkṣā tasyaabhiṣecanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: equal attention to all is the offer of fees and ablution towards consecration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prajāsukhe sukhaṃ rājñaḥ prajānāṃ ca hite hitam / naātmapriyaṃ hitaṃ rājñaḥ prajānāṃ tu priyaṃ hitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the happiness of his subjects lies his happiness; in their welfare his welfare; whatever pleases himself he shall not consider as good, but whatever pleases his subjects he shall consider as good

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmān nityautthito rājā kuryād arthaanuśāsanam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the king shall ever be active and discharge his duties;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthasya mūlam utthānam anarthasya viparyayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the root of wealth is activity, and of evil its reverse

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anutthāne dhruvo nāśaḥ prāptasyaanāgatasya ca / prāpyate phalam utthānāl labhate caarthasampadam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of activity acquisitions present and to come will perish; by activity he can achieve both his desired ends and abundance of wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṛegulations for the royal resideñce
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , The Duties of a King in Book

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāstukapraśaste deśe saprākāraparikhādvāram anekakakṣyāparigatam antaḥpuraṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: ON a site naturally best fitted for the purpose, the king shall Kautilyas Arthashastra construct his harem consisting of many compartments, one within the other, enclosed by a parapet and a ditch, and provided with a door

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: KA/ kośagṛhavidhānena madhye vāsagṛham, gūḍhabhittisaṃcāraṃ mohanagṛhaṃ tanmadhye vā vāsagṛham,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall construct his own residential palace after the model of his treasuryhouse; or he may have his residential abode in the centre of the delusive chamber móhanagriha, provided with secret passages made into the walls;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmigṛhaṃ vāāsannacaityakāṣṭhadevatāapidhānadvāram anekasuruṅgāsaṃcāraṃ tasyaupari prāsādaṃ gūḍhabhittisopānaṃ suṣirastambhapraveśaapasāraṃ vā vāsagṛhaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or in an underground chamber provided with the figures of goddesses and of altars chaitya carved on the wooden doorframe, and connected with many underground passages for exit; or in an upper storey provided with a staircase hidden in a wall, with a passage for exit made in a hollow pillar, the whole building being so constructed with mechanical contrivance as to be caused to fall down when necessary

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yantrabaddhatalaavapātaṃ kārayet, āpatpratīkāraartham āpadi vā // atoanyathā vā vikalpayet, sahaadhyāyibhayāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or considering the danger from his own classmates sahádhyáyi, such contrivances as the above, mainly intended as safeguards against danger, may be made on occasions of danger or otherwise as he deems fit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mānuṣeṇaagninā trir apasavyaṃ parigatam antaḥpuram agnir anyo na dahati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No other kind of fire can burn that harem which is thrice circumambulated from right to left by a fire of human make manushénágnina;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na caatraanyoagnir jvalati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: nor can there be kindled any other fire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaidyutena bhasmanā mṛtsamyuktena karakavāriṇāavaliptaṃ ca // jīvantīśvetāmuṣkakapuṣpavandākābhir akṣīve jātasyaaśvatthasya pratānena guptaṃ sarpā viṣāṇi vā na prabhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Nor can fire destroy that harem the walls of which are made of mud mixed with ashes produced by lightning, and wetted in hailwater karakavári Poisonous snakes will not dare to enter into such buildings as are provided with Jívanti Fæderia Fœtida, svéta Aconitum Ferox, mushkakapushpa ?, and vandáka Epidendrum Tesselatum, and as are protected by the branches of péjáta ? and of asvattha Ficus Religiosa

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śukaḥ sārikā bhṛṅgarājo vā sarpaviṣaśaṅkāyāṃ krośati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Parrots, minas sárika, and Malbar birds bhringarája shriek when they perceive the smell of snakepoison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: krauñco viṣaabhyāśe mādyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The heron crauncha swoons in the vicinity of poison;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: glāyati jīvaṃjīvakaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the pheasant jívanjívaka feels distress;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mriyate mattakokilaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the youthful cuckoo mattakókila dies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cakorasyaakṣiṇī virajyete //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the eyes of partridge chakóra are reddened

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity evam agniviṣasarpebhyaḥ pratikurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus remedies shall be applied against fire and poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pṛṣṭhataḥ kakṣyāvibhāge strīniveśo garbhavyādhisaṃsthā vṛkṣaudakasthānaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On one side in the rear of the harem, there shall be made for the residence of women compartments provided not only with all kinds of medicines useful in midwifery and diseases, but also with well known potherbs prakhyátasamsthávriksha, and a waterreservoir;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahiḥ kanyākumārapuram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: outside these compartments, the residences of princes and princesses;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purastād alaṅkārabhūmir mantrabhūmir upasthānaṃ kumāraadhyakṣasthānaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in front of the latter building, the toiletground alankára bhúmih, the councilground mantrabhúmib, the court, and the offices of the heirapparent and of superintendents

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kakṣyaantareṣv antarvaṃśikasainyaṃ tiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the intervening places between two compartments, the army of the officer in charge of the harem shall be stationed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: antargṛhagataḥ sthavirastrīpariśuddhāṃ devīṃ paśyet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When in the interior of the harem, the king shall see the queen only when her personal purity is vouchsafed by an old maidservant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: devīgṛhe līno hi bhrātā bhadrasenaṃ jaghāna,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for hidden in the queens chamber, his own brother slew king Bhadrasena;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mātuḥ śayyāantargataś ca putraḥ kārūṣam // lājān madhunāiti viṣeṇa paryasya devī kāśirājam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: hiding himself under the bed of his mother, the son killed king Kárusa; mixing fried rice with poison, as though with honey, his own queen poisoned Kásirája;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viṣadigdhena nūpreṇa vairantyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: with an anklet painted with poison, his own queen killed Vairantya;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mekhalāmaṇinā sauvīram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: with a gem of her zone bedaubed with poison, his own queen killed Kautilyas Arthashastra Sauvíra;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jālūtham ādarśena, veṇyāṃ gūḍhaṃ śastraṃ kṛtvā devī vidūrathaṃ jaghāna //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: with a looking glass painted with poison, his own queen killed Jálútha; and with a weapon hidden under her tuft of hair, his own queen slew Vidúratha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād etāny āspadāni pariharet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the king shall always be careful to avoid such lurking dangers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: muṇḍajaṭilakuhakapratisaṃsargaṃ bāhyābhiś ca dāsībhiḥ pratiṣedhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall keep away his wives from the society of ascetics with shaved head or braided hair, of buffoons, and of outside prostitutes dási

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na caenāḥ kulyāḥ paśyeyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Nor shall women of high birth have occasion to see his wives except appointed midwives

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rūpaājīvāḥ snānapragharṣaśuddhaśarīrāḥ parivartitavastraalaṃkārāḥ paśyeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Prostitutes rúpájíva with personal cleanliness effected by fresh bath and with fresh garments and ornaments shall attend the harem

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśītikāḥ puruṣāḥ pañcāśatkāḥ striyo vā mātāpitṛvyañjanāḥ sthaviravarṣadharaabhyāgārikāś caavarodhānāṃ śaucaāśaucaṃ vidyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Eighty men and fifty women under the guise of fathers and mothers, and aged persons, and eunuchs shall not only ascertain purity and impurity in the life of the inmates of the harem, but also so regulate the affairs as to be conducive to the happiness of the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthāpayeyuś ca svāmihite, // svabhūmau ca vaset sarvaḥ parabhūmau na saṃcaret /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Every person in the harem shall live in the place assigned to him, and shall never move to the place assigned to others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na ca bāhyena saṃsargaṃ kaścid ābhyantaro vrajet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No one of the harem shall at any time keep company with any outsider

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvaṃ caavekṣitaṃ dravyaṃ nibaddhaāgamanirgamam / nirgacched abhigacched vā mudrāsaṃkrāntabhūmikam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The passage of all kinds of commodities from or into the harem shall be restricted and shall, after careful examination, be allowed to reach their destination either inside or outside the harem as indicated by the sealmark mudrá

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śayanād utthitaḥ strīgaṇair dhanvibhiḥ parigṛhyate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: ON getting up from the bed, the king shall be received by troops of women armed with bows

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvitīyasyāṃ kakṣyāyāṃ kañcukauṣṇīṣibhir varṣadharaabhyāgārikaiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the second compartment, he shall be received by the Kanchuki presenter of the kings coat, the Ushnisi presenter of kings headdress, aged persons, and other harem attendants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tṛtīyasyāṃ kubjavāmanakirātaiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the third compartment, he shall be received by crooked and dwarfish persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturthyāṃ mantribhiḥ sambandhibhir dauvārikaiś ca prāsapāṇibhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the fourth, by prime ministers, kinsmen, and doorkeepers with barbed missiles in their hand

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pitṛpaitāmahaṃ sambandhaanubaddhaṃ śikṣitam anuraktaṃ kṛtakarmāṇaṃ ca janam āsannaṃ kurvīta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king shall employ as his personal attendants those whose fathers and grandfathers had been royal servants, those who bear close relationship to the king, those who are well trained and loyal, and those who have rendered good service

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naanyatodeśīyam akṛtaarthamānaṃ svadeśīyaṃ vāapy apakṛtyaupagṛhītam // antarvaṃśikasainyaṃ rājānam antaḥpuraṃ ca rakṣet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Neither foreigners, nor those who have earned neither rewards nor honour by rendering good service, nor even natives found engaged in inimical works shall form the bodyguard of the king or the troops of the officers in charge of the harem

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gupte deśe māhānasikaḥ sarvam āsvādabāhulyena karma kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In a wellguarded locality, the headcook máhánasika shall supervise the preparation of varieties of relishing dishes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad rajā tathaiva pratibhuñjīta pūrvam agnaye vayobhyaś ca baliṃ kṛtvā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king shall partake of such fresh dishes after making an oblation out of them first to the fire and then to birds

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agner jvālādhūmanīlatā śabdasphoṭanaṃ ca viṣayuktasya, vayasāṃ vipattiś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the flame and the smoke turn blue and crackle, and when birds that eat the oblation die, presence of poison in the dish shall be inferred

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: annasya ūṣmā mayūragrīvaābhaḥ śaityam āśu kliṣṭasyaiva vaivarṇyaṃ saudakatvam aklinnatvaṃ ca vyañjanānām āśu śuṣkatvaṃ ca kvāthadhyāmaphenapaṭalavicchinnabhāvo gandhasparśarasavadhaś ca
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the vapour arising from cooked rice possesses the colour of the neck of a peacock, and appears chill as if suddenly cooled, when vegetables possess an unnatural colour, and are watery and hardened, and appear to have suddenly turned dry, being possessed of broken layers of blackish foam, and being Kautilyas Arthashastra devoid of smell, touch and taste natural to them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: draveṣu hīnaatiriktacchāyādarśanaṃ phenapaṭalasīmantaūrdhvarājīdarśanaṃ ca
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when utensils reflect light either more or less than usual, and are covered with a layer of foam at their edges; when any liquid preparation possesses streaks on its surface;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rasasya madhye nīlā rājī,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when milk bears a bluish streak in the centre of its surface;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madyatoyayoḥ kālī,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when liquor and water possess reddish streaks;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dadhnaḥ śyāmā, madhunaḥ śvetā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when curd is marked with black and dark streaks, and honey with white streaks;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyāṇām ārdrāṇām āśu pramlānatvam utpakvabhāvaḥ kvāthanīlaśyāvatā ca
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when watery things appear parched as if overcooked and look blue and swollen; when dry things have shrinked and changed in their colour;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kaṭhinānāṃ mṛdutvaṃ mṛdūnāṃ ca kaṭhinatvam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when hard things appear soft, and soft things hard; when minute animalculæ die in the vicinity of the dishes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āstaraṇapravaraṇānāṃ dhyāmamaṇḍalatā tanturomapakṣmaśātanaṃ ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when carpets and curtains possess blackish circular spots, with their threads and hair fallen off;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lohamaṇimayānāṃ paṅkamalopadehatā sneharāgagauravaprabhāvavarṇasparśavadhaś ca iti viṣayuktasya liṅgāni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when metallic vessels set with gems appear tarnished as though by roasting, and have lost their polish, colour, shine, and softness of touch, presence of poison shall be inferred

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / viṣapradasya tu śuṣkaśyāvavaktratā vāksaṅgaḥ svedo vijṛmbhaṇaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As to the person who has administered poison, the marks are parched and dry mouth; hesitation in speaking; heavy perspiration; yawning;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caatimātraṃ vepathuḥ praskhalanaṃ vākyaviprekṣaṇam āvegaḥ karmaṇi svabhūmau caanavasthānam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: frequent tumbling; evasion of speech; carelessness in work; and unwillingness to keep to the place assigned to him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād asya jāṅgulīvido bhiṣajaś caāsannāḥ syuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence physicians and experts capable of detecting poison shall ever attend upon the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhiṣagbhaiṣajyaagārād āsvādaviśuddham auṣadhaṃ gṛhītvā pācakapeṣakābhyām ātmanā ca pratisvādya rājñe prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having taken out from the storeroom of medicines that medicine the purity of which has been proved by experiment, and having himself together with the decoctioner and the purveyor páchaka and póshaka tasted it, the physician shall hand over the medicine to the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pānaṃ pānīyaṃ caauṣadhena vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same rule shall apply to liquor and other beverages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalpakaprasādhakāḥ snānaśuddhavastrahastāḥ samudram upakaraṇam antarvaṃśikahastād ādāya paricareyuḥ // snāpakasaṃvāhakaāstarakarajakamālākārakarma dāsyaḥ prasiddhaśaucāḥ kuryuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having cleaned their person and hands by fresh bath and put on newlywashed garment, servants in charge of dresses, and Kautilyas Arthashastra toilets shall serve the king with dresses and toilets received under seal from the officer in charge of the harem

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātmacakṣuṣi niveśya vastramālyaṃ dadyuḥ, snānaanulepanapragharṣacūrṇavāsasnānīyāni ca svavakṣobāhuṣu ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Prostitutes shall do the duty of bathroom servants, shampooers, beddingroom servants, washermen, and flower garlandmakers, while presenting to the king water, scents, fragrant powders, dress and garlands, servants along with the above prostitutes shall first touch these things by their eyes, arms and breast

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena parasmād āgatakaṃ vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same rule shall apply to whatever has been received from an outside person

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kuśīlavāḥ śastraagnirasakrīḍāvarjaṃ narmayeyuḥ // ātodyāni caeṣām antas tiṣṭheyuḥ, aśvarathadvipaalaṃkārāś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Musicians shall entertain the king with those kinds of amusements in which weapons, fire, and poison are not made use of Musical instruments as well as the ornaments of horses, chariots, and elephants shall invariably be kept inside the harem

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āptapuruṣaadhiṣṭhitaṃ yānavāhanam ārohet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king shall mount over chariots or beasts of burden only when they are first mounted over by his hereditary driver or rider

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nāvaṃ caāptanāvikaadhiṣṭhitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall never sail on any ship which had once been weatherbeaten;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyanaupratibaddhāṃ vātavegavaśāṃ ca naupeyāt // udakaante sainyam āsīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and while boating on a good ship his army shall all the while stand on the bank or the shore

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: matsyagrāhaviśuddham udakam avagāheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall get into such water as is free from large fishes matsya and crocodiles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyālagrāhaviśuddham udyānaṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall ramble only in such forests as are freed from snakes and crocodiles gráha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lubdhakaśvagaṇibhir apāstastenavyālaparaābādhabhayaṃ calalakṣyaparicayaarthaṃ mṛgaaraṇyaṃ gacchet // āptaśastragrāhaadhiṣṭhitaḥ siddhatāpasaṃ paśyet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With a view of acquiring efficiency in the skill of shooting arrows at moving objects, he shall engage himself in sports in such forests as are cleared by hunters and houndkeepers from the fear of highwayrobbers, snakes, and enemies Kautilyas Arthashastra Attended by trustworthy bodyguard armed with weapons, he shall give interview to saints and ascetics

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantripariṣadā saha sāmantadūtam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Surrounded by his assembly of minsters, he shall receive the envoys of foreign states

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samnaddhoaśvaṃ hastinaṃ vāārūḍhaḥ samnaddham anīkaṃ paśyet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Attired in military dress and having mounted a horse, a chariot, or an elephant, he shall go see his army equipped in military array

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niryāṇeabhiyāne ca rājamārgam ubhayataḥ kṛtaārakṣaṃ śastribhir daṇḍibhiś caapāstaśastrahastapravrajitavyaṅgaṃ gacchet
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On the occaision of going out of, and coming into the capital, the king‟s road shall on both sides be well guarded by staffbearers and freed from the presence of armed persons, ascetics, and the cripple vyanga

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yātrāsamājautsavaprahavaṇāni ca daśavargikaadhiṣṭhitāni gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall go to witness festive trains, fairs yátra, procession, or sacrificial performances only when they are policed by bands of „The Ten Communities‟ dasavargikadhishthitáni

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā ca yogapuruṣair anyān rājāadhitiṣṭhati / tathāayam anyaābādhebhyo rakṣed ātmānam ātmavān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Just as he attends to the personal safety of others through the agency of spies, so a wise king shall also take care to secure his person from external dangers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūtapūrvam abhūtapūrvaṃ vā janapadaṃ paradeśaapavāhanena svadeśaabhiṣyandavamanena vā niveśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: EITHER by inducing foreigners to immigrate paradesapraváhanena or by causing the thicklypopulated centres of his own kingdom to send forth the excessive population svadésábhishyandavámanéna vá, the king may construct villages either on new sites or on old ruins bhútapúrvama vá

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūdrakarṣakaprāyaṃ kulaśataavaraṃ pañcakulaśataparaṃ grāmaṃ krośadvikrośasīmānam anyonyaārakṣaṃ niveśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Villages consisting each of not less than a hundred families and of not more than fivehundred families of agricultural people of súdra caste, with boundaries extending as far as a krósa 0 yds or two, and capable of protecting each other shall be formed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nalīśailavanabhṛṣṭidarīsetubandhaśamīśālmalīkṣīravṛkṣān anteṣu sīmnāṃ sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Boundaries shall be denoted by a river, a mountain, forests, bulbous plants grishti, caves, artificial buildings sétubandha, or by trees such as sálmali silk cotton tree, samí Acacia Suma, and kshíravriksha milky trees

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṣṭaśatagrāmyā madhye sthānīyam, catuhśatagrāmyā droṇamukham, dviśatagrāmyāḥ kārvaṭikam, daśagrāmīsaṃgraheṇa saṃgrahaṃ sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There shall be set up a stháníya a fortress of that name in the centre of eighthundred villages, a drónamukha in the centre of fourhundred villages, a khárvátika in the centre of twohundred villages and sangrahana in the midst of a collection of ten villages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anteṣv antapāladurgāṇi janapadadvārāṇy antapālaadhiṣṭhitāni sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There shall be constructed in the extremities of the kingdom forts manned by boundaryguards antapála whose duty shall be to guard the entrances into the kingdom

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām antarāṇi vāgurikaśabarapulindacaṇḍālaaraṇyacarā rakṣeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The interior of the kingdom shall be watched by trapkeepers vágurika, archers sábara, hunters pulinda, chandálas, and wild tribes aranyachára

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṛtvigācāryapurohitaśrotriyebhyo brahmadeyāny adaṇḍakarāṇy abhirūpadāyādakāni prayacchet
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Those who perform sacrifices ritvik, spiritual guides, priests, and those learned in the Vedas shall be granted Brahmadaya lands yielding sufficient produce and exempted from taxes and fines adandkaráni

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adhyakṣasaṃkhyāyakaādibhyo gopasthānikaanīkasthacikitsakaaśvadamakajaṅghākārikebhyaś ca vikrayaādhānavarjāni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Superintendents, Accountants, Gopas, Sthánikas, Veterinary Surgeons Aníkastha, physicians, horsetrainers, and messengers shall also be endowed with lands which they shall have no right to alienate by sale or mortgage

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karadebhyaḥ kṛtakṣetrāṇy aikapuruṣikāṇi prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Lands prepared for cultivation shall be given to taxpayers karada only for life ekapurushikáni

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: akṛtāni kartṛbhyo naādeyāni // akṛṣatām āchidyaanyebhyaḥ prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Unprepared lands shall not be taken away from those who are preparing them for cultivation Lands may be confiscated from those who do not cultivate them; and given to others;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: grāmabhṛtakavaidehakā vā kṛṣeyuḥ // akṛṣanto vāavahīnaṃ dadyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may be cultivated by village labourers grámabhritaka and traders vaidehaka, lest those owners who do not properly cultivate them might pay less to the government

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhānyapaśuhiraṇyaiś caetān anugṛhṇīyāt // tāny anu sukhena dadyuḥ // anugrahaparihārau caetebbhyaḥ kośavṛddhikarau dadyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If cultivators pay their taxes easily, they may be favourably supplied with grains, cattle, and money The king shall bestow on cultivators only such favour and remission anugrahaparihárau as will tend to swell the treasury, and shall avoid such as will deplete it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alpakośo hi rājā paurajānapadān eva grasate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A king with depleted treasury will eat into the very vitality of both citizens and country people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niveśasamakālaṃ yathāāgatakaṃ vā parihāraṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Either on the occasion of opening new settlements or on any other emergent occasions, remission of taxes shall be made

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nivṛttaparihārān pitāivaanugṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall regard with fatherly kindness those who have passed the period of remission of taxes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ākarakarmaantadravyahastivanavrajavaṇikpathapracārān vāristhalapathapaṇyapattanāni ca niveśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra He shall carry on mining operations and manufactures, exploit timber and elephant forests, offer facilities for cattlebreeding and commerce, construct roads for traffic both by land and water, and set up market towns panyapattana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sahaudakam āhāryaudakaṃ vā setuṃ bandhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall also construct reservoirs sétu filled with water either perennial or drawn from some other source

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyeṣāṃ vā badhnatāṃ bhūmimārgavṛkṣaupakaraṇaanugrahaṃ kuryāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may provide with sites, roads, timber, and other necessary things those who construct reservoirs of their own accord

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puṇyasthānaārāmāṇāṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Likewise in the construction of places of pilgrimage punyasthána and of groves

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sambhūyasetubandhād apakrāmataḥ karmakarabalīvardāḥ karma kuryuḥ // vyayakarmaṇi ca bhāgī syāt, na caaṃśaṃ labheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever stays away from any kind of cooperative construction sambhúya setubhandhát shall send his servants and bullocks to carry on his work, shall have a share in the expenditure, but shall have no claim to the profit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: matsyaplavaharitapaṇyānāṃ setuṣu rājā svāmyaṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king shall exercise his right of ownership swámyam with regard to fishing, ferrying and trading in vegetables haritapanya in reservoirs or lakes sétushu

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dāsaāhitakabandhūn aśṛṇvato rājā vinayaṃ grāhayet // bālavṛddhavyasanyanāthāṃś ca rājā bibhṛyāt, striyam aprajātāṃ prajātāyaś ca putrān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those who do not heed the claims of their slaves dása, hirelings áhitaka, and relatives shall be taught their duty The king shall provide the orphans, bála, the aged, the infirm, the afflicted, and the helpless with maintenance He shall also provide subsistence to helpless women when they are carrying and also to the children they give birth to

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bāladravyaṃ grāmavṛddhā vardhayeyur ā vyavahāraprāpaṇāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Elders among the villagers shall improve the property of bereaved minors till the latter attain their age;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: devadravyaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: so also the property of Gods

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apatyadāraṃ mātāpitarau bhrātṛṛn aprāptavyavahārān bhaginīḥ kanyā vidhavāś caabibhrataḥ śaktimato dvādaśapaṇo daṇḍaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a capable person other than an apostate patita or mother neglects to maintain his or her child, wife, mother, father, Kautilyas Arthashastra minor brothers, sisters, or widowed girls kanyá vidhaváscha, he or she shall be punished with a fine of twelve panas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: putradāram apratividhāya pravrajataḥ pūrvaḥ sāhasadaṇḍaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, without making provision for the maintenance of his wife and sons, any person embraces ascetism, he shall be punished with the first amercement;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: striyaṃ ca pravrājayataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise any person who converts a woman to ascetism pravrájayatah

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: luptavyāyāmaḥ pravrajed āpṛcchya dharmasthān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever has passed the age of copulation may become an ascetic after distributing the properties of his own acquisition among his sons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā niyamyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise, he will be punished

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vānaprasthād anyaḥ pravrajitabhāvaḥ, sajātād anyaḥ saṃghaḥ, sāmutthāyikād anyaḥ samayaanubandho vā naasya janapadam upaniviśeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No ascetic other than a vánaprastha foresthermit, no company other than the one of local birth sajátádanyassanghah, and no guilds of any kind other than local cooperative guilds sámuttháyikádanyassamayánubandhah shall find entrance into the villages of the kingdom

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na ca tatraārāmā vihāraarthā vā śālāḥ syuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Nor shall there be in villages buildings sáláh intended for sports and plays

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naṭanartakagāyanavādakavāgjīvanakuśīlavā na karmavighnaṃ kuryuḥ // nirāśrayatvād grāmāṇāṃ kṣetraabhiratatvāc ca puruṣāṇāṃ kośaviṣṭidravyadhānyarasavṛddhir bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Nor, in view of procuring money, free labour, commodities, grains, and liquids in plenty, shall actors, dancers, singers, drummers, buffoons vágjívana, and bards kusílava make any disturbance to the work of the villagers; for helpless villagers are always dependent and bent upon their fields

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paracakraaṭavīgrastaṃ vyādhidurbhikṣapīḍitam / deśaṃ parihared rājā vyayakrīḍāś ca vārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king shall avoid taking possession of any country which is liable to the inroads of enemies and wild tribes and which is harassed by frequent visitations of famine and pestilence

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍaviṣṭikaraābādhai rakṣed upahatāṃ kṛṣim /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall protect agriculture from the molestation of oppressive fines, free labour, and taxes dandavishtikarábádhaih;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: stenavyālaviṣagrāhair vyādhibhiś ca paśuvrajān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: herds of cattle from thieves, tigers, poisonous creatures and cattledisease

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vallabhaiḥ kārmikaiḥ stenair antapālaiś ca pīḍitam / śodhayet paśusaṃghaiś ca kṣīyamāṇaṃ vaṇikpatham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall not only clear roads of traffic from the molestations Kautilyas Arthashastra of courtiers vallabha, of workmen kármika, of robbers, and of boundaryguards, but also keep them from being destroyed by herds of cattle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ dravyadvipavanaṃ setubandham athaākarān / rakṣet pūrvakṛtān rājā navāṃś caabhipravartayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the king shall not only keep in good repair timber and elephant forests, buildings, and mines created in the past, but also set up new ones [Thus ends Chapter , Formation of Villages in Book , The Duties of Government Superintendents, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: akṛṣyāyāṃ bhūmau paśubhyo vivītāni prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE King shall make provision for pasture grounds on uncultivable tracts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pradiṣṭaabhayasthāvarajaṅgamāni ca brahmasomaaraṇyāni tapasvibhyo gorutaparāṇi prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Bráhmans shall be provided with forests for sóma plantation, for religious learning, and for the performance of penance, such forests being rendered safe from the dangers from animate or inanimate objects, and being named after the tribal name gótra of the Bráhmans resident therein

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / tāvanmātram ekadvāraṃ khātaguptaṃ svāduphalagulmaguccham akaṇṭakidrumam uttānatoyaāśayaṃ dāntamṛgacatuṣpadaṃ bhagnanakhadaṃṣṭravyālaṃ mārgayukahastihastinīkalabhaṃ mṛgavanaṃ vihāraarthaṃ rājñaḥ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A forest as extensive as the above, provided with only one entrance rendered inaccessible by the construction of ditches all round, with plantations of delicious fruit trees, bushes, bowers, and thornless trees, with an expansive lake of water full of harmless animals, and with tigers vyála, beasts of prey márgáyuka, male and female elephants, young elephants, and bisonsall deprived of their claws and teethshall be formed for the kings sports

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvaatithimṛgaṃ pratyante caanyanmṛgavanaṃ bhūmivaśena vā niveśayet // kupyapradiṣṭānāṃ ca dravyāṇām ekaekaśo vanāni niveśayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On the extreme limit of the country or in any other suitable Kautilyas Arthashastra locality, another gameforest with gamebeasts; open to all, shall also be made In view of procuring all kinds of forestproduce described elsewhere, one or several forests shall be specially reserved

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyavanakarmaantān aṭavīś ca dravyavanaapāśrayāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Manufactories to prepare commodities from forest produce shall also be set up Wild tracts shall be separated from timberforests

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratyante hastivanam aṭavyārakṣaṃ niveśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the extreme limit of the country, elephant forests, separated from wild tracts, shall be formed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nāgavanaadhyakṣaḥ pārvataṃ naādeyaṃ sārasamaanūpaṃ ca nāgavanaṃ viditaparyantapraveśaniṣkāsaṃ nāgavanapālaiḥ pālayet
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The superintendent of forests with his retinue of forest guards shall not only maintain the upkeep of the forests, but also acquaint himself with all passages for entrance into, or exit from such of them as are mountainous or boggy or contain rivers or lakes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastighātinaṃ hanyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever kills an elephant shall be put to death

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dantayugaṃ svayaṃmṛtasyaāharataḥ sapādacatuṣpaṇo lābhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever brings in the pair of tusks of an elephant, dead from natural causes, shall receive a reward of fourandahalf panas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / nāgavanapālā hastipakapādapāśikasaimikavanacarakapārikarmikasakhā hastimūtrapurīṣacchannagandhā bhallātakīśākhāpracchannāḥ pañcabhiḥ saptabhir vā hastibandhakībhiḥ saha carantaḥ śayyāsthānapadyāleṇḍakūlaghātauddeśena
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Guards of elephant forests, assisted by those who rear elephants, those who enchain the legs of elephants, those who guard the boundaries, those who live in forests, as well as by those who nurse elephants, shall, with the help of five or seven female elephants to help in tethering wild ones, trace the whereabouts of herds of elephants by following the course of urine and dungs left by elephants and along foresttracts covered over with branches of Bhallátaki Semicarpus Anacardium, and by observing the spots where elephants slept or sat before or left dungs, or where they had just destroyed the banks of rivers or lakes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastikulaparyagraṃ vidyuḥ // yūthacaram ekacaraṃ niryūthaṃ yūthapatiṃ hastinaṃ vyālaṃ mattaṃ potaṃ bandhamuktaṃ ca nibandhena vidyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They shall also precisely ascertain whether any mark is due to the movements of elephants in herds, of an elephant roaming single, of a stray elephant, of a Kautilyas Arthashastra leader of herds, of a tusker, of a rogue elephant, of an elephant in rut, of a young elephant, or of an elephant that has escaped from the cage

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anīkasthapramāṇaiḥ praśastavyañjanaācārān hastino gṛhṇīyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Experts in catching elephants shall follow the instructions given to them by the elephant doctor aníkastha and catch such elephants as are possessed of auspicious characteristics and good character

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastipradhānaṃ vijayo rājñaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The victory of kings in battles depends mainly upon elephants;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraanīkavyūhadurgaskandhaāvārapramardanā hy atipramāṇaśarīrāḥ prāṇaharakarmāṇo hastinaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for elephants, being of large bodily frame, are capable not only to destroy the arrayed army of an enemy, his fortifications, and encampments, but also to undertake works that are dangerous to life
