oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratyākhyānam upālambhaḥ pratiṣedhoatha codanā // sāntvam abhyupapattiś ca bhartsanaanunayau tathā / eteṣv arthāḥ pravartante trayodaśasu lekhajāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Calumniation nindá, commendation, inquiry, narration request, refusal, censure, prohibition, command, conciliation, promise of help, threat, and persuasion are the thirteen purposes for which writs are issued

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraabhijanaśarīrakarmaṇāṃ doṣavacanaṃ nindā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Calumniation nindá consists in speaking ill of ones family, body and acts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guṇavacanam eteṣām eva praśaṃsā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Commendation prasamsá consists in praising ones family, person, and acts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: katham etad iti pṛcchā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To inquire how is this? is inquiry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam ity ākhyānam // dehi ity arthanā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To point out the way as thus, is narration ákhyána

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na prayacchāmi iti pratyākhyānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To entreat as give, is request To say that do not give, is refusal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ananurūpaṃ bhavataḥ ity upālambhaḥ // mā kārṣīḥ iti pratiṣedhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To say that it is not worthy of thee, is censure upálambhah To say as do not do so, is prohibition pratishedha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: idaṃ kriyatām iti codanā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To say that this should be done, is command chódaná

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yan mama dravyaṃ tad bhavataḥ ity upagrahaḥ sāntvam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To say what am, thou art that; whichever article is mine is thine also, is conciliation sántvam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanasāhāyyam abhyupapattiḥ // sadoṣam āyatipradarśanam abhibhartsanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To hold out help in trouble is promise of help Kautilyas Arthashastra abhyavapattih Pointing out the evil consequences that may occur in future is threat abhibartsanam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anunayas trividhoarthakṛtāv atikrame puruṣaādivyasane caiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Persuasion is of three kinds that made for the purpose of money, that made in case of ones failure to fulfill a promise, and that made on occasion of any trouble

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prajñāpanaājñāparidānalekhās tathā parīhāranisṛṣṭilekhau / prāvṛttikaś ca pratilekha eva sarvatragaś caiti hi śāsanāni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also writs of information, of command, and of gift; likewise writs of remission, of licence, of guidance, of reply, and of general proclamation are other varieties

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anena vijñāpitam evam āha tad dīyatāṃ ced yadi tattvam asti /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: so says the king; if there is any truth in this statement of the messenger, then the thing agreed to should at once be surrendered;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājñaḥ samīpe varakāram āha prajñāpanāeṣā vividhāupadiṣṭā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the messenger has informed the king of all the deeds of the enemy Parakára;this is the writ of information which is held to be of various forms

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhartur ājñā bhaved yatra nigrahaanugrahau prati / viśeṣeṇa tu bhṛtyeṣu tadājñālekhalakṣaṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wherever and especially regarding Government servants the kings order either for punishment or for rewards is issued, it is called writ of command ájnálékha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathāarhaguṇasamyuktā pūjā yatraupalakṣyate / apy ādhau paridāne vā bhavatas tāv upagrahau //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Where the bestowal of honour for deserving merit is contemplated either as help to alleviate affliction ádhi or as gift paridána, there are issued writs of gift upagrahalekha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jāter viśeṣeṣu pareṣu caiva grāmeṣu deśeṣu ca teṣu teṣu / anugraho yo nṛpter nideśāt tajjñaḥ parīhāra iti vyavasyet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whatever favour anugraha to special castes, cities, villages, or countries of various description is announced in obedience to the Kautilyas Arthashastra kings order, it is called writ of remission pariháralékha by those who know it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nisṛṣṭisthāāpanā kāryakaraṇe vacane tathā / eṣa vācikalekhaḥ syād bhaven naisṛṣṭikoapi vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Likewise licence or permission nisrishti shall be enjoined either in word or deed; accordingly it is styled verbal order or writ of licence

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vividhāṃ daivasamyuktāṃ tattvajāṃ caiva mānuṣīm / dvividhāṃ tāṃ vyavasyanti pravṛttiṃ śāsanaṃ prati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Various kinds of providential visitations or well ascertained evils of human make are believed to be the cause for issuing writs of guidance pravrittilékha to attempt remedies against them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dṛṣṭvā lekhaṃ yathātattvaṃ tataḥ pratyanubhāṣya ca / pratilekho bhavet kāryo yathā rājavacas tathā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When having read a letter and discussed as to the form of reply thereto, a reply in accordance with the kings order is made, it is called a writ of reply pratilékha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatraīśvarāṃś caadhikṛtāṃś ca rājā rakṣāupakārau pathikaartham āha / sarvatrago nāma bhavet sa mārge deśe ca sarvatra ca veditavyaḥ // upāyāḥ sāmaupapradānabhedadaṇḍāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the king directs his viceroys isvara and other officers to protect and give material help to travellers either on roads or in the interior of the country, it is termed writ of general proclamation sarvatraga lekha Negotiation, bribery, causing dissension, and open attack are forms of stratagem upáya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra sāma pañcavidhaṃ guṇasaṃkīrtanam, sambandhaupākhyānam, parasparaupakārasaṃdarśanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Negotiation is of five kinds Praising the qualities of an enemy, narrating the mutual relationship, pointing out mutual benefit, showing vast future prospects, and identity of interests

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātmaupanidhānam iti // tatraabhijanaśarīrakarmaprakṛtiśrutadravyaādīnāṃ guṇagrahaṇaṃ praśaṃsā stutir guṇasaṃkīrtanam // jñātiyaunamaukhasrauvakulahṛdayamitrasaṃkīrtanaṃ sambandhaupākhyānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the family, person, occupation, conduct, learning, properties, etc of an enemy are commended with due attention to their worth, it is termed praising the qualities gunasankírthana When the fact of having agnates, bloodrelations, teachers maukha, priestly heirarchy srauva, family, and friends in Kautilyas Arthashastra 00 common is pointed out, it is known as narration of mutual relationship sambandhópakhyána

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svapakṣaparapakṣayor anyonyaupakārasaṃkīrtanaṃ parasparaupakārasaṃdarśanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When both parties, the party of a king and that of his enemy are shown to be helpful to each other, it is known as pointing out mutual benefit parasparópakárasamdarsanam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: asminn evaṃ kṛta idam āvayor bhavati ity āśājananam āyatipradarśanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Inducement such as this being done thus, such result will accrue to both of us, is showing vast future prospects Ayátipradarsanam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yoahaṃ sa bhavān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To say what am, that thou art;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yan mama dravyaṃ tad bhavatā svakṛtyeṣu prayojyatām ity ātmaupanidhānam / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: thou mayest utilize in thy works whatever is mine, is identity of interests átmópanidhánam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upapradānam arthaupakāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Offering money is bribery upapradána

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaṅkājananaṃ nirbhartsanaṃ ca bhedaḥ // vadhaḥ parikleśoarthaharaṇaṃ daṇḍaḥ / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Causing fears and suspicion as well as threatening is known as sowing dissension Killing, harassing, and plundering is attack danda

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: akāntir vyāghātaḥ punaruktam apaśabdaḥ samplava iti lekhadoṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Clumsiness, contradiction, repetition, bad grammar, and misarrangement are the faults of a writ

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra kālapattrakam acāruviṣam avirāgaakṣaratvam akāntiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Black and ugly leaf, kálapatrakamacháru and uneven and uncoloured virága writing cause clumsiness akánti

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūrveṇa paścimasyaanupapattir vyāghātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Subsequent portion disagreeing with previous portion of a letter, causes contradiction vyágháta

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: uktasyaaviśeṣeṇa dvitīyam uccāraṇaṃ punaruktam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Stating for a second time what has already been said above is repetition

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: liṅgavacanakālakārakāṇām anyathāprayogoapaśabdaḥ // avarge vargakaraṇaṃ caavargakriyā guṇaviparyāsaḥ samplavaḥ / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wrong use of words in gender, number, time and case is bad Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 grammar apasabda Division of paragraphs varga in unsuitable places, omission of necessary division of paragraphs, and violation of any other necessary qualities of a writ constitute misarrangement samplava

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvaśāstrāṇy anukramya prayogam upalabhya ca / kauṭilyena naraindraarthe śāsanasya vidhiḥ kṛtaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having followed all sciences and having fully observed forms of writing in vogue, these rules of writing royal writs have been laid down by Kautilya in the interest of kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośaadhyakṣaḥ kośapraveśyaṃ ratnaṃ sāraṃ phalguṃ kupyaṃ vā tajjātakaraṇaadhiṣṭhitaḥ pratigṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE Superintendent of the treasury shall, in the presence of qualified persons, admit into the treasury whatever he ought to, gems ratna and articles of superior or inferior value Támraparnika, that which is produced in the támraparni;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāmraparṇikaṃ pāṇḍyakavāṭakaṃ pāśikyaṃ kauleyaṃ caurṇeyaṃ māhendraṃ kārdamikaṃ srautasīyaṃ hrādīyaṃ haimavataṃ ca mauktikam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pásikya, that which is produced in the Pása; Kauleya, that which is produced in the kúla; Chaurneya, that which is produced in the Chúrna; Mahéndra, that which is obtained near the mountain of Mahéndra; Kárdamika, that which is produced in the Kárdama;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śuktiḥ śaṅkhaḥ prakīrṇakaṃ ca yonayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Oystershells, conchshells, and other miscellaneous things are the wombs of pearls

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: masūrakaṃ tripuṭakaṃ kūrmakam ardhacandrakaṃ kañcukitaṃ yamakaṃ kartakaṃ kharakaṃ siktakaṃ kāmaṇḍalukaṃ śyāvaṃ nīlaṃ durviddhaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is like masúra ervum hirsutam, that which consists of three joints triputaka, that which is like a tortoise kúrmaka, that which is semicircular, that which consists of several coatings, that which is double yámaka, that which is scratched, that which is of rough surface, that which is possessed of spots siktakam, that which is like the waterpot used by an ascetic, that which is of darkbrown or blue colour, and that which is badly perforated are inauspicious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthūlaṃ vṛttaṃ nistalaṃ bhrājiṣṇu śvetaṃ guru snigdhaṃ deśaviddhaṃ ca praśastam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is big, circular, without bottom nistalam, brilliant, white, heavy, soft to the touch, and properly perforated is the best

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śīrṣakam upaśīrṣakaṃ prakāṇḍakam avaghāṭakaṃ taralapratibaddhaṃ caiti yaṣṭiprabhedāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sirshaka, upasirshaka, prakándaka, avaghátaka, and taralapratibandha are several varieties of pearl necklaces

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yaṣṭīnām aṣṭasahasram indracchandaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One thousand and eight strings of pearls form the necklace, Indrachchhanda

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatoardhaṃ vijayacchandaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Half of the above is Vijayachchhanda

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: catuṣṣaṣṭir ardhahāraḥ // catuṣpañcāśad raśmikalāpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sixtyfour strings make up Ardhahára Fiftyfour strings make up Rasmikalápa Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 Thirtytwo strings make up Guchchha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saptaviṃśatir nakṣatramālā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Twentyseven strings make up Nakshatramála

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturviṃśatir ardhagucchaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Twentyfour strings make up Ardhaguchchha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viṃśatir māṇavakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Twenty strings make up Mánavaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatoardham ardhamāṇavakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Half of the above is Ardhamánavaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eta eva maṇimadhyās tanmāṇavakā bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same necklaces with a gem at the centre are called by the same names with the words Mánavaka suffixed to their respective names

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaśīrṣakaḥ śuddho hāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When all the strings making up a necklace are of sirshaka pattern, it is called pure necklace suddhahára;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadvatśeṣāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise with strings of other pattern

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇimadhyoardhamāṇavakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which contains a gem in the centre is also called Ardhamánavaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: triphalakaḥ phalakahāraḥ, pañcaphalako vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which contains three slablike gems triphalaka or five slablike gems panchaphalaka in the centre is termed Phalakahára

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sūtram ekāvalī śuddhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An only string of pearls is called pure Ekávali;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāeva maṇimadhyā yaṣṭiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the same with a gem in the centre is called Yashti;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hemamaṇicitrā ratnāvalī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the same variegated with gold globules is termed Ratnávali

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hemamaṇimuktāantaroapavartakaḥ // suvarṇasūtraantaraṃ sopānakam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A string made of pearls and gold globules alternately put is called Apavartaka Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 Strings of pearls with a gold wire between two strings is called Sopánaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇimadhyaṃ vā maṇisopānakam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same with a gem in the centre is called Manisópánaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena śirohastapādakaṭīkalāpajālakavikalpā vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The above will explain the formation of headstrings, bracelets, anklets, waistbands, and other varieties

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇiḥ kauṭomāleyakaḥ pārasamudrakaś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kauta, that which is obtained in the Kúta; Mauleyaka, that which is found in the Múleya;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saugandhikaḥ padmarāgoanavadyarāgaḥ pārijātapuṣpako bālasūryakaḥ // vaiḍūryam utpalavarṇaḥ śirīṣapuṣpaka udakavarṇo vaṃśarāgaḥ śukapattravarṇaḥ puṣyarāgo gomūtrako gomedakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which possesses such pleasant colour as that of the red lotus flower, or that of the flower of Párijáta Erithrina Indica, or that of the rising sun is the Saugandhika gem That which is of the colour of blue lotus flower, or of sirísha Acacia Sirisa, or of water, or of fresh bamboo, or of the colour of the feathers of a parrot is the Vaidúrya gem Pushyarága, Gómútraka, and Gómédika are other varieties of the same

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: indranīlo nīlaavalīyaḥ kalāyapuṣpako mahānīlo jambvābho jīmūtaprabho nandakaḥ sravanmadhyaḥ // śuddhasphaṭiko mūlāṭavarṇaḥ śītavṛṣṭiḥ sūryakāntaś ca /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Nandaka pleasing gem, Sravanmadhya that which appears to pour water from its centre, Sítavrishti that which appears to pour cold shower, and Súryakánta sunstone are other forms of gems Gems are hexagonal, quadrangular, or circular possessed of dazzling glow, pure, smooth, heavy, brilliant, transparent antargataprabha and illuminating;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti maṇayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: such are the qualities of gems

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mandarāgaprabhaḥ saśarkaraḥ puṣpacchidraḥ khaṇḍo durviddho lekhaākīrṇa iti doṣāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Faint colour, sandy layer, spots, holes, bad perforation, and Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 scratches are the defects of gems

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / vimalakaḥ sasyakoañjanamūlakaḥ pittakaḥ sulabhako lohitaakṣo mṛgaaśmako jyotīrasako māleyakoahicchatrakaḥ kūrpaḥ pratikūrpaḥ sugandhikūrpaḥ kṣīravakaḥ śśukticūrṇakaḥ śilāpravālakaḥ pulakaḥ śuklapulaka ity antarajātayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Vimalaka pure, sasyaka plantlike, Anjanamúlaka deepdark, Pittaka like the bile of a cow Sulabhaka easily procurable, Lohitaka red, Amritámsuka of white rays, Jyótírasaka glowing, Maileyaka, Ahichchhatraka , procured in the country of Ahichchhatra, Kúrpa, Pútikúrpa, and Sugandhikúrpa, Kshírapaka, Suktichúrnaka like the powder of an oystershell, Silápraválaka like coral, Pulaka, Súkrapulaka are varieties of inferior gems

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śeṣāḥ kācamaṇayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The rest are metalic beads káchamani

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sabhārāṣṭrakaṃ tajjamārāṣṭrakaṃ kāstīrarāṣṭrakaṃ śrīkaṭanakaṃ maṇimantakam indravānakaṃ ca vajram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Madhyamaráshtraka, that which is found in the Central Province; Kásmaka, that which is found in the country of Kásmaka; Sríkatanaka, that which is found in the vicinity of the mountain, Vedótkata; Manimantaka, that which is found near the mountain Maniman or Manimanta; and Indravánaká are diamonds

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khaniḥ srotaḥ prakīrṇakaṃ ca yonayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Mines, streams, and other miscellaneous places are their sources

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mārjāraakṣakaṃ śirīṣapuṣpakaṃ gomūtrakaṃ gomedakaṃ śuddhasphaṭikaṃ mūlāṭīvarṇaṃ maṇivarṇānām anyatamavarṇam iti vajravarṇāḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The colour of a diamond may be like that of a cats eye, that of the flower of Sirísha Acacia Sirísa, the urine of a cow, the bile of a cow, like alum sphatika, the flower of Málati, or like that of any of the gems described above

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthūlaṃ guru prahārasahaṃ samakoṭikaṃ bhājanalekhi tarkubhrāmi bhrājiṣṇu ca praśastam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is big, heavy, hard prahárasaham, tolerant of hitting, regular samakóna, capable of scratching on the surface of vessels bhájanalékhi, refractive of light kubrámi, and brilliant is the best

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naṣṭakoṇaṃ nirāśri pārśvaapavṛttaṃ caapraśastam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is devoid of angles, uneven nirasríkam, and Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 bent on one side pársvápavrittam is inauspicious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pravālakam ālakandakaṃ vaivarṇikaṃ ca, raktaṃ padmarāgaṃ ca karaṭagarbhiṇikāvarjam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Alakandaka, and Vaivarnaka are the two varieties of coral which is possessed of rubylike colour, which is very hard, and which is free from the contamination of other substances inside

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: candanaṃ sātanaṃ raktaṃ bhūmigandhi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sátana is red and smells like the earth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gośīrṣakaṃ kālatāmraṃ matsyagandhi // haricandanaṃ śukapattravarṇam āmragandhi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Gósirshaka is dark red and smells like fish; Harichandana is of the colour of the feathers of a parrot and smells like tamarind or mango fruit;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tārṇasaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise Tárnasa;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: grāmerukaṃ raktaṃ raktakālaṃ vā bastamūtragandhi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Grámeruka is red or dark red and smells like the urine of a goat;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivasabheyaṃ raktaṃ padmagandhi, jāpakaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Daivasabheya is red and smells like a lotus flower;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: joṅgakaṃ raktaṃ raktakālaṃ vā snigdham, taurūpaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise Aupaka Jápaka; Jongaka and Taurupa are red or dark red and soft;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: māleyakaṃ pāṇḍuraktam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Maleyaka is reddish white;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kucandanaṃ rūkṣam agurukālaṃ raktaṃ raktakālaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kuchandana is as black as Agaru resin of the aloe or red or dark red and very rough;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośaagāraparvatakaṃ kālaṃ kālacitraṃ vā // śītaudakīyaṃ padmaābhaṃ kālasnigdhaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kálaparvataka is of pleasant appearance; Kosákaraparvataka that which is the product of that mountain which is of the shape of a bud is black or variegated black; Sítódakíya is black and soft, and smells like a lotusflower;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nāgaparvatakaṃ rūkṣaṃ śaivalavarṇaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Nágaparvataka that which is the product of Naga mountain is rough and is possessed of the colour of Saivala Vallisneria;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śākalaṃ kapilam / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and Sákala is brown

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: laghu snigdham aśyānaṃ sarpiḥsnehalepi gandhasukhaṃ tvaganusāry anulbaṇam avirāgy uṣṇasahaṃ dāhagrāhi sukhasparśanam iti candanaguṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Light, soft, moist asyána, not dry, as greasy as ghee, of pleasant smell, adhesive to the skin, of mild smell, retentive of colour and smell, tolerant of heat, absorptive of heat, and comfortable to the skinthese are the characteristics of sandal chandana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aguru joṅgakaṃ kālaṃ kālacitraṃ maṇḍalacitraṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As to Agaru Agallochum, resin of aloe Jongaka is black or variegated black and is possessed of variegated spots;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śyāmaṃ doṅgakam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Dongaka is black;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārasamudrakaṃ citrarūpam uśīragandhi navamālikāgandhi vā / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and Párasamudraka is of variegated colour and smells like cascus or like Navamálika jasminum

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guru snigdhaṃ peśalagandhi nirhāry agnisaham asamplutadhūmaṃ vimardasaham ity aguruguṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 Agaru is heavy, soft, greasy, smells far and long, burns slowly, gives out continuous smoke while burning, is of uniform smell, absorbs heat, and is so adhesive to the skin as not to be removable by rubbing;these are the characteristics of Agaru

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tailaparṇikam aśokagrāmikaṃ māṃsavarṇaṃ padmagandhi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As to Tailaparnika Asókagrámika, the product of Asókagráma, is of the colour of meat and smells like a lotus flower;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: joṅgakaṃ raktapītakam utpalagandhi gomūtragandhi vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Jongaka is reddish yellow and smells like a blue lotus flower or like the urine of a cow;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: grāmerukaṃ snigdhaṃ gomūtragandhi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Grameruka is greasy and smells like a cows urine;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sauvarṇakuḍyakaṃ raktapītaṃ mātuluṅgagandhi // pūrṇakadvīpakaṃ padmagandhi navanītagandhi vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sauvarnakudyaka, product of the country of Suvarnakudya, is reddish yellow and smells like Mátulunga the fruit of citron tree or sweet lime; Púrnadvipaka, the product of the island, Púrnadviipa, smells like a lotus flower or like butter;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhadraśriyaṃ pāralauhityakaṃ jātīvarṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Bhadrasríya and Páralauhityaka are of the colour of nutmeg;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āntaravatyam uśīravarṇam // ubhayaṃ kuṣṭhagandhi ca / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Antarvatya is of the colour of cascus,the last two smell like Kushtha Costus Speciosus;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāleyakaḥ svarṇabhūmijaḥ snigdhapītakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kaleyaka which is a product of Svarnabhúmi, goldproducing land, is yellow and greasy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: auttaraparvatako raktapītakaḥ // iti sārāḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and Auttaraparvataka a product of, the north mountain is reddish yellow The above fragrant substances are commodities of superior value Sára

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: piṇḍakvāthadhūmasaham avirāgi yogaanuvidhāyi ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The smell of the Tailaparnika substances is lasting, no matter whether they are made into a paste or boiled or burnt;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: candanaaguruvac ca teṣāṃ guṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and these substances resemble sandal and Agallochum in their qualities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāntanāvakaṃ praiyakaṃ cauttaraparvatakaṃ carma //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kántanávaka, Praiyaka, and Auttaraparvataka are the varieties of skins

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāntanāvakaṃ mayūragrīvaābham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kántanávaka is of the colour of the neck of the peacock;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: praiyakaṃ nīlapītaśvetalekhābinducitram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Praiyaka is variegated with blue, yellow, and white spots;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadubhayam aṣṭaaṅgulaāyāmam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: these Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 two are eight angulas inches long

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bisī mahābisī ca dvādaśagrāmīye //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also Bisí and Mahábisí are the products of Dvádasagráma, twelve villages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avyaktarūpā duhilitikā citrā vā bisī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is of indistinct colour, hairy, and variegated with spots is called Bisí

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paruṣā śvetaprāyā mahābisī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is rough and almost white is Mahábisí great Bisí;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvādaśaaṅgulaāyāmam ubhayam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: These two are twelve angulas long

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śyāmikā kālikā kadalī candrauttarā śākulā caārohajāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Syámika, Kálika, Kadali, Chandrottara, and Sákulá are other kinds of skins procured from Aroha Arohaja

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kālikā kapilā kapotavarṇā vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kálika is brown or of the colour of a pigeon;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ubhayam aṣṭaaṅgulaāyāmam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: these two are eight angulas long Kadali is rough and two feet long;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paruṣā kadalī hastaāyatā // sāeva candracitrā candrauttarā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when Kadali bears variegated moonlike spots, it is called Chandrottarakadali and is onethird of its length;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kadalītribhāgā śākulā koṭhamaṇḍalacitrā kṛtakarṇikāajinacitrā vā / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sákulá is variegated with large round spots similar to those that manifest themselves in a kind of leprosy kushtha, or is furnished with tendrils and spotted like a deers skin

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmūraṃ cīnasī sāmūlī ca bāhlaveyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sámúra, Chínasi, and Sámúli are skins procured from Báhlava, Bahlaveya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṣaṭtriṃśadaṅgulam añjanavarṇaṃ sāmūram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sámúra is thirtysix angulas long and black;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cīnasī raktakālī pāṇḍukālī vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Chínasi is reddish black or blackish white;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmūlī godhūmavarṇā / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sámúli is of the colour of wheat

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāṃtinā nalatūlā vṛttapṛcchā caudrāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sátina, Nalatúla, and Vrittapuchchha are the skins of aquatic animals Audra

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sātinā kṛṣṇā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sátina is black;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nalatūlā nalatūlavarṇā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Nalatúla is of the colour of the fibre of Nala, a kind of grass;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kapilā vṛttapucchā ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and Vrittapuchchha that which possesses a round tail is brown

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti carmajātayaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 The above are the varieties of skins

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: carmaṇāṃ mṛdu snigdhaṃ bahularoma ca śreṣṭham // śuddhaṃ śuddharaktaṃ pakṣaraktaṃ caāvikam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of skins, that which is soft, smooth and hairy is the best Blankets made of sheeps wool may be white, purely red, or as red as a lotus flower They may be made of worsted threads by sewing khachita;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khacitaṃ vānacitraṃ khaṇḍasaṃghātyaṃ tantuvicchinnaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or may be made of different pieces khandasanghátya; or may be woven of uniform woollen threads tantuvichchhinna

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kambalaḥ kaucapakaḥ kulamitikā saumitikā turagaāstaraṇaṃ varṇakaṃ talicchakaṃ vāravāṇaḥ paristomaḥ samantabhadrakaṃ caāvikam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Woollen blankets are of ten kindsKambala, Kauchapaka, Kulamitika, Saumitika, Turagastarana, Varnaka, Talichchhaka, Váravána, Paristoma, and Samantabhadraka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: picchilam ārdram iva ca sūkṣmaṃ mṛdu ca śreṣṭham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, that which is slippery pichchhila as a wet surface, possessed of fine hair, and soft, is the best

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṣṭaprotisaṃghātyā kṛṣṇā bhiṅgisī varṣavāraṇam apasāraka iti naipālakam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That blanket which is made up of eight pieces and black in colour is called Bhingisi used as rainproof ; likewise is Apasáraka;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sampuṭikā caturaśrikā lambarā kaṭavānakaṃ prāvarakaḥ sattalikāiti mṛgaroma //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: both are the products of Nepal Samputika, Chaturasrika, Lambara, Katavánaka, Praváraka, and Sattalika are blankets made of the wool of wild animals

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāṅgakaṃ śvetaṃ snigdhaṃ dukūlam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is manufactured in the country, Vanga vangaka is a white and soft fabric dukúla;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pauṇḍrakaṃ śyāmaṃ maṇisnigdham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that of Pándya manufacture Paundraka is black and as soft as the surface of a gem;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sauvarṇakuḍyakaṃ sūryavarṇaṃ maṇisnigdhaudakavānaṃ caturaśravānaṃ vyāmiśravānaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that which is the product of the country, Suvarnakudya, is as red as the sun, as soft as the surface of the gem, woven while the threads are very wet, and of uniform chaturasra or mixed texture vyámisravána

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eteṣām ekaaṃśukam adhyardhadvitricaturaṃśukam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 Single, half, double, treble and quadruple garments are varieties of the same

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena kāśikaṃ pauṇḍrakaṃ ca kṣaumaṃ vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The above will explain other kinds of fabrics such as Kásika, Benarese products, and Kshauma which is manufactured in Pándya Paundraka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: māgadhikā pauṇḍrikā sauvarṇakuḍyakā ca pattraūrṇā // nāgavṛkṣo likuco bakulo vaṭaś ca yonayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Mágadhika product of the Magadha country, Paundraka, and Sauvarnakudyaka are fibrous garments Nágavriksha a species of a tree, Likucha Artocarpus Lakucha, and Vakula Mimusops Elengi, and Vata Ficus Indica are the sources of their fibres

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pītikā nāgavṛkṣikā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That of Nágavriksha is yellow pita;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: godhūmavarṇā laikucī // śvetā bākulī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that of Likucha is of the colour of wheat; that of Vakula is white;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śeṣā navanītavarṇā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the rest is of the colour of butter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāsāṃ sauvarṇakuḍyakā śreṣṭhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, that which is produced in the country of Suvarnakudya is the best

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayā kauśeyaṃ cīnapaṭṭāś ca cīnabhūmijā vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The above will explain the fabrics known as kauseya, silkcloth, and chinapatta, fabrics of China manufacture

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mādhuram āparāntakaṃ kāliṅgaṃ kāśikaṃ vāṅgakaṃ vātsakaṃ māhiṣakaṃ ca kārpāsikaṃ śreṣṭham / iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of cotton fabrics, those of Madhura, of Aparánta, western parts, of Kálinga, of Kási, of Vanga, of Vatsa, and of Mahisha are the best

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ataḥ pareṣāṃ ratnānāṃ pramāṇaṃ mūlyalakṣaṇam / jātiṃ rūpaṃ ca jānīyān nidhānaṃ navakarma ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As to other kinds of gems which are not treated of here, the superintendent shall ascertain their size, their value, species, form, utility, their treatment, the repair of old ones, any adulteration that is not easily detected, their wear and tear due to lapse of time and place, as well as remedies against those which are inauspicious himsra

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purāṇapratisaṃskāraṃ karma guhyam upaskarān /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of thirtysecond chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER CONDUCTING MINING OPERATIONS AND MANUFACTURE

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśakālaparībhogaṃ hiṃsrāṇāṃ ca pratikriyām // / ākaraadhyakṣaḥ śulbadhātuśāstrarasapākamaṇirāgajñas tajjñasakho vā tajjātakarmakaraupakaraṇasampannaḥ kiṭṭamūṣaaṅgārabhasmaliṅgaṃ vāākaraṃ bhūtapūrvam abhutapūrvaṃ vā bhūmiprastararasadhātum atyarthavarṇagauravam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: POSSESSED of the knowledge of the science dealing with copper and other minerals Sulbádhátusástra, experienced in the art of distillation and condensation of mercury rasapáka and of testing gems, aided by experts in mineralogy and equipped with mining labourers and necessary instruments, the superintendent of mines shall examine mines which, on account of their containing mineral excrement kitta, crucibles, charcoal, and ashes, may appear to have been once exploited or which may be newly discovered on plains or mountainslopes possessing mineral ores, the richness of which can be ascertained by weight, depth of colour, piercing smell, and taste

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parvatānām abhijñātauddeśānāṃ bilaguhaupatyakaālayanagūḍhakhāteṣv antaḥ prasyandino jambūcūtatālaphalapakvaharidrābhedaguḍa(gūḍa?)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Liquids which ooze out from pits, eaves, slopes, or deep excavations of wellknown mountains; which have the colour of the fruit of roseapple jambu, of mango, and of fanpalm;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: haritālamanaḥśilākṣaudrahiṅgulukapuṇḍarīkaśukamayūrapattravarṇāḥ savarṇaudakaoṣadhiparyantāś cikkaṇā viśadā bhārikāś ca rasāḥ kāñcanikāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: which are as yellow as ripe turmeric, sulphurate of arsenic haritála, honeycomb, and vermilion; which are as resplendent as the petals of a lotus, or the feathers of a parrot or a peacock; which are adjacent to any mass of water or shrubs of similar colour; and which are greasy chikkana, transparent visada, and very heavy are ores of gold kánchanika

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apsu niṣṭhyūtās tailavadvisarpiṇaḥ ṣaṅkamalagrāhiṇaś ca tāmrarūpyayoḥ śatād upari veddhāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Likewise liquids which, when dropped on water, spread like oil to which dirt and filth adhere, and which amalgamate themselves more than cent per cent satádupari Kautilyas Arthashastra veddhárah with copper or silver

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatpratirūpakam ugragandharasaṃ śilājatu vidyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of similar appearance as the above tatpratirúpakam, but of piercing smell and taste is Bitumen

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / pītakāstāmrakās tāmrapītakā vā bhūmiprastaradhātavo bhinnā nīlarājīvanto
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those ores which are obtained from plains or slopes of mountains; which are either yellow or as red as copper or reddish yellow;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mudgamāṣakṛsaravarṇā vā dadhibindupiṇḍacitrā haridrāharītakīpadmapattraśaivalayakṛtplīhaanavadyavarṇā bhinnāś cuñcuvālukaālekhābindusvastikavantaḥ sugulikā arciṣmantas tāpyamānā na
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: which have the colour of black beans masha, Phraseolus Radiatus, green beans mudga, Phraseolus Mungo, and sesamum; which are marked with spots like a drop of curd and resplendent as turmeric, yellow myrobalan, petals of a lotus, acquatic plant, the liver or the spleen; which possess a sandy layer within them and are marked with figures of a circle or a svastika; which contain globular masses sagulika;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhidyante bahuphenadhūmāś ca suvarṇadhātavaḥ pratīvāpaarthās tāmrarūpyavedhanāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and which, when roasted do not split, but emit much foam and smoke are the ores of gold suvarnadhátavah, and are used to form amalgams with copper or silver pratívápárthasté stámrarúpyavedharáh

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / śaṅkhakarpūrasphaṭikanavanītakapotapārāvatavimalakamayūragrīvāvarṇāḥ sasyakagomedakaguḍamatsyaṇḍikāvarṇāḥ kovidārapadmapāṭalīkalāyakṣaumaatasīpuṣpavarṇāḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those ores which have the colour of a conchshell, camphor, alum, butter, a pigeon, turtledove, Vimalaka a kind of precious stone, or the neck of a peacock; which are as resplendent as opal sasyaka, agate gomédaka, canesugar guda, and granulated sugar matsyandika which has the colour of the flower of kovidára Bauhinia Variegata, of lotus, of patali Bignonia Suaveolens, of kalaya a kind of phraseolus, of kshauma flax, and of atasi Dinuin Usitatissimum;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sasīsāḥ saañjanā visrā bhinnāḥ śvetaābhāḥ kṛṣṇāḥ kṛṣṇaābhāḥ śvetāḥ sarve vā lekhābinducitrā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: which may be in combination with lead or iron anjana; which smell like raw meat, are disjoined gray or blackish white, and are marked with lines or spots;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mṛdavo dhmāyamānā na sphuṭanti bahuphenadhūmāś ca rūpyadhātavaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and which, when roasted, do not split, but emit much foam and smoke are silver ores

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvadhātūnāṃ gauravavṛddhau sattvavṛddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The heavier the ores, the greater will be the quantity of metal in them satvavriddhih

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / teṣām aśuddhā mūḍhagarbhā vā tīkṣṇamūtrakṣarabhāvitā rājavṛkṣavaṭapīlugopittarocanāmahiṣakharakarabhamūtraleṇḍapiṇḍabaddhās
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The impurities of ores, whether superficial or inseparably combined with them can be got rid of and the metal melted when the ores are chemically treated with Tikshna urine mútra and alkalies kshára, and are mixed or smeared over with the mixture of the powder of Rajavriksha Clitoria Ternatea, Vata Ficus Indica, and Pelu Carnea Arborea, together with cows bile and the urine and dung of a buffalo, an ass and an elephant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yavamāṣatilapalāśapīlukṣārairgokṣīraajakṣīrair vā kadalīvajrakandapratīvapo mārdavakaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Metals are rendered soft when they are treated with the powder of kandali mushroom, and vajrakanda, Antiquorum together with the ashes of barley, black beans, palása Butea Frondosa, and pelu Carnea Arborea, or with the milk of both the cow and the sheep

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhumadhukam ajāpayaḥ satailaṃ ghṛtaguḍakiṇvayutaṃ sakandalīkam / yad api śatasahasradhā vibhinnaṃ bhavati mṛdu tribhir eva tanniṣekaiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whatever metal is split into a hundred thousand parts is rendered soft when it is thrice soaked in the mixture made up of honey madhu, madhuka Bassia Latifolia, sheeps milk, sesamum oil, clarified butter, jaggery, kinva ferment and mushroom

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: godantaśṛṅgapratīvāpo mṛdustambhanaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Permanent softness mridustambhana is also attained when the metal is treated with the powder of cows teeth and horn

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhārikaḥ snigdho mṛduś ca prastaradhātur bhūmibhāgo vā piṅgalo haritaḥ pāṭalo lohito vā tāmradhātuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those ores which are obtained from plains or slopes of mountains; and which are heavy, greasy, soft, tawny, green, dark, bluishyellow harita, palered, or red are ores of copper

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kākamocakaḥ kapotarocanāvarṇaḥ śvetarājinaddho vā visraḥ sīsadhātuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those ores which have the colour of kákamechaka Solanum Indica, pigeon, or cow‟s bile, and which are marked with white lines and smell like raw meat are the ores of lead

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ūṣarakarburaḥ pakvaloṣṭhavarṇo vā trapudhātuḥ // kharumbaḥ pāṇḍurohitaḥ sinduvārapuṣpavarṇo vā tīkṣṇadhātuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those ores which are as variegated in colour as saline soil or which have the colour of a burnt lump of earth are the ores of tin Those ores which are of orange colour kurumba, or palered pándurohita, or of the colour of the flower of sinduvára Vitex Trifolia are the ores of tíkshna

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kākaaṇḍabhujapattravarṇo vā vaikṛntakadhātuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Those ores which are of the colour of the leaf of kánda Artemisia Indica or of the leaf of birch are the ores of vaikrintaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: acchaḥ snigdhaḥ saprabho ghoṣavān śītas tīvras tanurāgaś ca maṇidhātuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pure, smooth, efflugent, sounding when struck, very hard satatívrah, and of little colour tanurága are precious stones

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhātusamutthaṃ tajjātakarmaanteṣu prayojayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The yield of mines may be put to such uses as are in vogue

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtabhāṇḍavyavahāram ekamukham, atyayaṃ caanyatra kartṛkretṛvikretṛṛṇāṃ sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Commerce in commodities manufactured from mineral products shall be centralized and punishment for manufacturers, sellers, and purchasers of such commodities outside the prescribed locality shall also be laid down

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ākarikam apaharantam aṣṭaguṇaṃ dāpayed anyatra ratnebhyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A minelabourer who steals mineral products except precious stones shall be punished with a fine of eight times their value

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: stenam anisṛṣṭaupajīvinaṃ ca baddhaṃ karma kārayet, daṇḍaupakāriṇaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Any person who steals mineral products or carries on mining operations without license shall be bound with chains and caused to work as a prisoner

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lohaadhyakṣas tāmrasīsatrapuvaikṛntakārakūṭavṛttakaṃsatālalohakarmaantān kārayet, lohabhāṇḍavyavahāraṃ ca // lakṣaṇaadhyakṣaś caturbhāgatāmraṃ rūpyarūpaṃ tīkṣṇatrapusīsaañjanānām anyatamamāṣabījayuktaṃ kārayet paṇam ardhapaṇaṃ pādam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Mines which yield such minerals as are made use of in preparing vessels bhánda as well as those mines which require large outlay to work out may be leased out for a fixed number of the shares of the output or for a fixed rent bhágena prakrayena va Such mines as can be worked out without much outlay shall be directly exploited by Government agency The superintendent of metals lóhádhyakshah shall carry on the manufacture of copper, lead, tin, vaikrintaka mercury , árakúta brass, vritta?;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pādaājīvaṃ tāmrarūpaṃ māṣakam ardhamāṣakaṃ kākaṇīm
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: kamsa bronze or bellmetal, tála sulphurate of arsenic, and lodhra ?, and also of commodities bhánda from them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rūpadarśakaḥ paṇayātrāṃ vyāvahārikīṃ kośapraveśyāṃ ca sthāpayet // rūpikam aṣṭakaṃ śatam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The superintendent of mint lakshnádhyakshah, shall carry Kautilyas Arthashastra on the manufacture of silver coins rúpyarúpa made up of four parts of copper and onesixteenth part másha of any one of the metals, tikshna, trapu, sisa, and anjana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcakaṃ śataṃ vyājīm,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There shall be a pana, half a pana, a quarter and oneeighth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārīkṣikam aṣṭabhāgikam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Copper coins támrarúpa made up of four parts of an alloy pádajívam, shall be a máshaka, half a máshaka, kákani and half a kákani

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcaviṃśatipaṇam atyayaṃ ca anyatrakartṛkretṛvikretṛparīkṣitṛbhyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The examiner of coins rúpadarsaka shall regulate currency both as a medium of exchange vyávahárikim and as legal tender admissible into the treasury kosapravesyám The premia levied on coins paid into the treasury shall be per cent, known as rúpika, per cent known as vyáji, oneeighth pana per cent as páríkshika testing charge, besides cha a fine of pana to be imposed on offenders other than the manufacturer, the seller, the purchaser and the examiner

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khanyadhyakṣaḥ śaṅkhavajramaṇimuktāpravālakṣārakarmaantān kārayet, paṇanavyavahāraṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The superintendent of oceanmines khanyadhyakshah shall attend to the collection of conchshells, diamonds, precious stones, pearls, corals, and salt kshára and also regulate the commerce in the above commodities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lavaṇaadhyakṣaḥ pākamuktaṃ lavaṇabhāgaṃ prakrayaṃ ca yathākālaṃ saṃgṛhṇīyād,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Soon after crystalisation of salt is over, the superintendent of salt shall in time collect both the moneyrent prakraya and the quantity of the shares of salt due to the government;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āgantulavaṇaṃ ṣaḍbhāgaṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Imported salt ágantulavanam shall pay onesixth portion shadbhága to the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcakaṃ śataṃ vyājīṃ rūpaṃ rūpikaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The sale of this portion bhágavibhága shall fetch the premia of five per cent vyáji, of eight per cent rúpika in cash rúpa

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kretā śulkaṃ rājapaṇyacchedaanurūpaṃ ca vaidharaṇaṃ dadyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The purchasers shall pay not only the toll Kautilyas Arthashastra sulka, but also the compensation vaidharana equivalent to the loss entailed on the kings commerce

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyatra kretā ṣaṭchatam atyayaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In default of the above payment, he shall be compelled to pay a fine of 00 panas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vilavaṇam uttamaṃ daṇḍaṃ dadyād,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Adulteration of salt shall be punished with the highest amercement;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aniṣṛṣṭaupajīvī caanyatra vānaprasthebhyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise persons other than hermits vánaprastha manufacturing salt without license

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śrotriyās tapasvino viṣṭayaś ca bhaktalavaṇaṃ hareyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Men learned in the Vedas, persons engaged in penance, as well as labourers may take with them salt for food;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atoanyo lavaṇakṣāravargaḥ śulkaṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: salt and alkalies for purposes other than this shall be subject to the payment of toll

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ mūlyaṃ ca bhāgaṃ ca vyājīṃ parigham atyayam / śulkaṃ vaidharaṇaṃ daṇḍaṃ rūpaṃ rūpikam eva ca // khanibhyo dvādaśavidhaṃ dhātuṃ paṇyaṃ ca saṃharet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus; besides collecting from mines the ten kinds of revenue, such as value of the output múlya, the share of the output vibhága, the premium of five per cent vyáji, the testing charge of coins parigha, fine previously announced atyaya, toll sulka, compensation for loss entailed on the kings commerce vaidharana, fines to be determined in proportion to the gravity of crimes danda, , coinage rúpa, 0 the premium of eight per cent rúpika, the government shall keep as a state monopoly both mining and commerce in minerals

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ sarveṣu paṇyeṣu sthāpayen mukhasaṃgraham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus taxes mukhasangraha on all commodities intended for sale shall be prescribed once for all

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ākaraprabhaḥ kośaḥ kośād daṇḍaḥ prajāyate / pṛthivī kośadaṇḍābhyāṃ prāpyate kośabhūṣaṇā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , Conducting Mining Operations and Manufacture in Book , The Duties of Government Superintendents of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suvarṇaadhyakṣaḥ suvarṇarajatakarmaantānām asambandhaāveśanacatuḥśālām ekadvārām akṣaśālāṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: SUPERINTENDENT OF GOLD IN THE GOLDSMITHS OFFICE Kautilyas Arthashastra IN order to manufacture gold and silver jewellry, each being kept apart, the superintendent of gold shall have a goldsmiths office akshasála consisting of four rooms and one door

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśikhāmadhye sauvarṇikaṃ śilpavantam abhijātaṃ prātyayikaṃ ca sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the centre of the high road a trained, skilful goldsmith of high birth and of reliable character shall be appointed to hold his shop

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jāmbūnadaṃ śātakumbhaṃ hāṭakaṃ vaiṇavaṃ śṛṅgaśuktijaṃ jātarūpaṃ rasaviddham ākaraudgataṃ ca suvarṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Jámbúnada, that which is the product of the river, Jambu; Sátakumbha, that which is extracted from the mountain of Satakumba; Hátaka, that which is extracted from the mines known as Hátaka; Vainava, that which is the product of the mountain, Vénu;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kiñjalkavarṇaṃ mṛdu snigdham anādi bhrājiṣṇu ca śreṣṭham,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is of the colour of the petals of a lotus, ductile, glossy, incapable of making any continuous sound anádi, and glittering is the best;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: raktapītakaṃ madhyamam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is reddish yellow raktapíta is of middle quality;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: raktam avaram // śreṣṭhānāṃ pāṇḍu śvetaṃ caaprāptakam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that which is red is of low quality Impure gold is of whitish colour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad yenaaprāptakaṃ tac caturguṇena sīsena śodhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It shall be fused with lead of four times the quantity of the impurity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sīsaanvayena bhidyamānaṃ śuṣkapaṭalair dhmāpayet // rūkṣatvād bhidyamānaṃ tailagomaye niṣecayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When gold is rendered brittle owing to its contamination with lead, it shall be heated with dry cowdung sushkapatala When it splits into pieces owing to hardness, it shall be drenched after heating into oil mixed with cowdung tailagomaye

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ākaraudgataṃ sīsaanvayena bhidyamānaṃ pākapattrāṇi kṛtvā gaṇḍikāsu kuṭṭayet, kadalīvajrakandakalke vā niṣecayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Mine gold which is brittle owing to its contamination with lead shall be heated wound round with cloth pákapatráni kritvá; and hammered on a wooden anvil Or it may be drenched in the Kautilyas Arthashastra mixture made of mushroom and vajrakhanda Antiquorum

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tutthaudgataṃ gauḍikaṃ kāmbukaṃ cākravālikaṃ ca rūpyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: gaudika, that which is the product of the country known as Gauda; kámbuka, that which is extracted from the mountain, Kambu;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvetaṃ snigdhaṃ mṛdu ca śreṣṭham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Silver which is white, glossy, and ductile is the best;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye sphoṭanaṃ ca duṣṭam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that which is of the reverse quality is bad

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatsīsacaturbhāgena śodhayet // udgatacūlikam acchaṃ bhrājiṣṇu dadhivarṇaṃ ca śuddham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Impure silver shall be heated with lead of onefourth the quantity of the impurity That which becomes full of globules, white, glowing, and of the colour of curd is pure

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śuddhasyaeko hāridrasya suvarṇo varṇakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the streak of pure gold made on touchstone is of the colour of turmeric, it is termed suvarna

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ śulbakākaṇyuttaraapasāritā ācatuḥsīmaantād iti ṣoḍaśa varṇakāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When from one to sixteen kákanis of gold in a suvarna of sixteen máshakas are replaced by from one to sixteen kákanis of copper, so that the copper is inseparably alloyed with the whole mass of the remaining quantity of the gold, the sixteen varieties carats of the standard of the purity of gold shodasavarnakáh will be obtained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suvarṇaṃ pūrvaṃ nikaṣya paścād varṇikāṃ nikaṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having first made a streak with suvarna on a touchstone, then by the side of the streak a streak with a piece of the gold to be compared with it shall be made

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samarāgalekham animnaunnate deśe nikaṣitam, parimṛditaṃ parilīḍhaṃ nakhaantarād vā gairikeṇaavacūrṇitam upadhiṃ vidyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whenever a uniform streak made on the even surface of a touchstone can be wiped off or swept away or when the streak is due to the sprinkling of any glittering powder gairika by the nail on touchstone, then an attempt for deception can be inferred

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jātihiṅgulukena puṣpakāsīsena vā gomūtrabhāvitena digdhenaagrahastena saṃspṛṣṭaṃ suvarṇaṃ śvetībhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra If, with the edge of the palm dipped in a solution, of vermilion játihinguláka or of sulphate of iron pushpakásísa in cows urine, gold suvarna is touched, it becomes white

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāliṅgakas tāpīpāṣāṇo vā mudgavarṇo nikaṣaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The touchstone of the Kálinga country with the colour of green beans is also the best A touchstone of even or uniform colour is good in sale or purchase of gold

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hasticchavikaḥ saharitaḥ pratirāgī vikrayahitaḥ // sthiraḥ paruṣo viṣamavarṇaś caapratirāgī krayahitaḥ // chedaś cikkaṇaḥ samavarṇaḥ ślakṣṇo mṛdur bhājiṣṇuś ca śreṣṭhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which possesses the colour of an elephant, tinged with green colour and capable of reflecting light pratirági is good in selling gold That which is hard, durable, and of uneven colour and not reflecting light, is good for purchasers krayahitah That which is grey, greasy, of uniform colour, soft, and glossy is the best

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāpo bahirantaś ca samaḥ kiñjalkavarṇaḥ kuraṇḍakapuṣpavarṇo vā śreṣṭhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That gold which, when heated, keeps the same colour tápo bahirantascha samah, is as glittering as tender sprouts, or of the colour of the flower of kárandaka ? is the best

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śyāvo nīlaś caaprāptakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is black or blue in gold is the impurity apráptaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulāpratimānaṃ pautavaadhyakṣe vakṣyāmaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: We shall deal with the balance and weights under the Superintendent of Weights and Measures Chap

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tenaupadeśena rūpyasuvarṇaṃ dadyād ādadīta ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In accordance with the instructions given thereunder silver and gold rúpyasuvarnam may be given in exchange

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: akṣaśālām anāyukto naupagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No person who is not an employee shall enter the goldsmiths‟ office

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhigacchann ucchedyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Any person who so enters shall be beheaded uchchhedyah

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āyukto vā sarūpyasuvarṇas tenaeva jīyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Any workman who enters the office with gold or silver shall have to forfeit the same

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vicitavastrahastaguhyāḥ kāñcanapṛṣatatvaṣṭṛtapanīyakāravo dhmāyakacarakapāṃsudhāvakāḥ praviśeyur niṣkaseyuś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Goldsmiths who are engaged to prepare various kinds of Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 ornaments such as kánchana pure gold, prishita hollow ornaments, tvashtri setting gems in gold and tapaníya; as well as blowers and sweepers shall enter into or exit from the office after their person and dress are thoroughly examined

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvaṃ caeṣām upakaraṇam aniṣṭhitāś ca prayogās tatraevaavatiṣṭheran //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: All of their instruments together with their unfinished work shall be left where they have been at work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gṛhītaṃ suvarṇaṃ dhṛtaṃ ca prayogaṃ karaṇamadhye dadyāt // sāyaṃ prātaś ca lakṣitaṃ kartṛkārayitṛmudrābhyāṃ nidadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That amount of gold which they have received and the ornamental work which they were doing shall be put in the centre of the office Finished articles shall be examined both morning and evening and be locked up with the seal of both the manufacturer and the superintendent kárayatri, the owner getting the articles prepared

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣepaṇo guṇaḥ kṣudrakam iti karmāṇi // kṣepaṇaḥ kācaarpaṇaādīni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kshepana, guna, and kshudra ate three kinds of ornamental work Setting jewels kácha, glass bead in gold is termed kshepana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guṇaḥ sūtravānaādīni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Threadmaking or string making is called guna

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ghanaṃ suṣiraṃ pṛṣataādiyuktaṃ kṣudrakam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Solid work ghana, hollow work sushira, and the manufacture of globules furnished with a rounded orifice is what is termed kshudra, low or ordinary work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arpayet kācakarmaṇaḥ pañcabhāgaṃ kāñcanaṃ daśabhāgaṃ kaṭumānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For setting jewels in gold, five parts of káñchana pure gold and ten parts of gold alloyed with four parts of copper or silver shall be the required quantity mána

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād rakṣet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Here the pure gold shall be preserved from the impure gold

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pṛṣatakācakarmaṇaḥ trayo hi bhāgāḥ paribhāṇḍaṃ dvau vāstukam, catvāro vā vāstukaṃ trayaḥ paribhāṇḍam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For setting jewels in hollow ornaments prishitakácha karmanah, three parts of gold to hold the jewel and four parts for the bottom shall be the required quantity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvaṣṭṛkarmaṇaḥ śulbabhāṇḍaṃ samasuvarṇena samyūhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For the work of tvashtri, copper and gold shall be mixed in Kautilyas Arthashastra equal quantities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rūpyabhāṇḍaṃ ghanaṃ suṣiraṃ vā suvarṇaardhenaavalepayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For silver article either solid or hollow, silver may be mixed with half of the amount of gold;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturbhāgasuvarṇaṃ vā vālukāhiṅgulukasya rasena cūrṇena vā vāsayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by making use of the powder or solution of vermilion, gold equal to onefourth the amount of silver of the ornament may be painted vásayet on it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tapanīyaṃ jyeṣṭhaṃ suvarṇaṃ surāgaṃ samasīsaatikrāntaṃ pākapattrapakvaṃ saindhavikayāujjvālitaṃ nīlapītaśvetaharitaśukapattravarṇānāṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pure and glittering gold is tapaníya This combined with an equal quantity of lead and heated with rocksalt saindhavika to melting point under dry cowdung becomes the basis of gold alloys of blue, red, white, yellow harita, parrot and pidgeon colours

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tīkṣṇaṃ caasya mayūragrīvaābhaṃ śvetabhaṅgaṃ cimicimāyitaṃ pītacūrṇitaṃ kākaṇikaḥ suvarṇarāgaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The colouring ingredient of gold is one kákaní of tíkshna which is of the colour of the neck of a peacock, tinged with white, and which is dazzling and full of copper pitapúrnitam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāram upaśuddhaṃ vā asthitutthe catuḥ samasīse catuḥ śuṣkatutthe catuḥ kapāle trir gomaye dvir evaṃ saptadaśatutthaatikrāntaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pure or impure silver tára may be heated four times with asthituttha copper sulphate mixed with powdered bone, again four times with an equal quantity of lead, again four times with dry copper sulphate sushkatuttha again three times in skull kapála, and lastly twice in cowdung

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etasmāt kākaṇyuttaramād vimāṣād iti suvarṇe deyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the silver acted upon seventeen times by tuttha shodasatutthátikrántam and lastly heated to white light with rock salt may be made to alloy with suvarna to the extent of from one kákani to two Máshas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvetatāraṃ bhavati /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then the suvarna attains white colour and is called svetatára

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trayoaṃśās tapanīyasya dvātriṃśadbhāgaśvetatāram ūrcchitāḥ tat śvetalohitakaṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When three parts of tapaníya pure gold are melted with thirtytwo parts of svetatára, the compound becomes reddish white svetalohitakam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāmraṃ pītakaṃ karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When three parts of tapaníya are combined with thirtytwo parts of copper, the compound becomes yellow píta, red!

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tapanīyam ujjvālya rāgatribhāgaṃ dadyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also when three parts of the colouring ingredient rágatribhága, ie, tíkshna referred to above are heated with tapaníya, the compound becomes yellowish red píta

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pītarāgaṃ bhavati // śvetatārabhāgau dvāv ekas tapanīyasya mudgavarṇaṃ karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When two parts of svetatára and one part of tapaníya are heated, Kautilyas Arthashastra the whole mass becomes as green as mudga Phraseolus Mungo

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kālaayasasyaardhabhāgaabhyaktaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When tapaníya is drenched in a solution of half the quantity of black iron káláyasa, it becomes black

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratilepinā rasena dviguṇaabhyaktaṃ tapanīyaṃ śukapattravarṇaṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When tapaníya is twice drenched in the above solution mixed with mercury rasa, it acquires the colour of the feathers of a parrot

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyaārambhe rāgaviśeṣeṣu prativarṇikāṃ gṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Before these varieties of gold are put to use, their test streak shall be taken on touchstone

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tīkṣṇatāmrasaṃskāraṃ ca budhyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The process of assaying tíkshna and copper shall be well understood

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād vajramaṇimuktāpravālarūpāṇām apaneyimānaṃ ca rūpyasuvarṇabhāṇḍabandhapramāṇāni ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the various counterweights avaneyimána used in weighing diamonds, rubies, pearls, corals, and coins, rúpa, as well as the proportional amount of gold and silver necessary for various kinds of ornaments can be well understood

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: supramṛṣṭam asampītaṃ vibhaktaṃ dhāraṇe sukham // abhinītaṃ prabhāyuktaṃ saṃsthānam adhuraṃ samam / manonetraabhirāmaṃ ca tapanīyaguṇāḥ smṛtāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Uniform in colour, equal in the colour of test streak to the standard gold, devoid of hollow bulbs, ductile sthira, very smooth, free from alloys, pleasing when worn as an ornament, not dazzling though glittering, sweet in its uniformity of mass, and pleasing the mind and eyes,these are the qualities of tapaníya, pure gold

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sauvarṇikaḥ paurajānapadānāṃ rūpyasuvarṇam āveśanibhiḥ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra THE State Goldsmith shall employ artisans to manufacture gold and silver coins rúpyasuvarna from the bullion of citizens and country people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nirdiṣṭakālakāryaṃ ca karma kuryuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The artisans employed in the office shall do their work as ordered and in time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anirdiṣṭakālaṃ kāryaapadeśam // kāryasyaanyathākaraṇe vetananāśaḥ, taddviguṇaś ca daṇḍaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When under the excuse that time and nature of the work has not been prescribed, they spoil the work, they shall not only forfeit their wages, but also pay a fine of twice the amount of their wages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kālaatipātane pādahīnaṃ vetanaṃ taddviguṇaś ca daṇḍaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When they postpone work, they shall forfeit onefourth the amount of their wages and pay a fine of twice the amount of the forfeited wages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathāvarṇapramāṇaṃ nikṣepaṃ gṛhṇīyus tathāvidham evaarpayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The goldsmith of the mint shall return to the owners coins or ornaments of the same weight, and of the same quality varna as that of the bullion nikshepa which they received at the mint

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kālaantarād api ca tathāvidham eva pratigṛhṇīyuḥ, anyatra kṣīṇapariśīrṇābhyām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With the exception of those coins which have been worn out or which have undergone diminution kshínaparisírna, they shall receive the same coins back into the mint even after the lapse of a number of years

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āveśanibhiḥ suvarṇapudgalalakṣaṇaprayogeṣu tattaj jānīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The state goldsmith shall gather from the artisans employed in the mint information concerning pure gold, metallic mass pudgala, coins lakshana, and rate of exchange prayóga

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: taptakaladhautakayoḥ kākaṇikaḥ suvarṇe kṣayo deyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In getting a suvarna coin of máshas manufactured from gold or from silver, one kákani onefourth másha weight of the metal more shall be given to the mint towards the loss in manufacture

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tīkṣṇakākaṇī rūpyadviguṇaḥ rāgaprakṣepaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The colouring ingredient rágaprakshépa shall be two kákanis of tíkshna copper sulphate ? onesixth of which will be lost during the manufacture

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya ṣaḍbhāgaḥ kṣayaḥ // varṇahīne māṣaavare pūrvaḥ sāhasadaṇḍaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the quality varna of a coin less than the standard of a másha is lowered, the artisans concerned shall be punished with Kautilyas Arthashastra the first amercement

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pramāṇahīne madhyamaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When its weight is less than the standard weight, they shall be punished with the middlemost amercement

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulāpratimānaupadhāv uttamaḥ, kṛtabhāṇḍaupadhau ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Deception in the exchange of manufactured coins kritabhándopadhau shall also be punished with the highest amercement

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sauvarṇikenaadṛṣṭam anyatra vā prayogaṃ kārayato dvādaśapaṇo daṇḍaḥ // kartur dviguṇaḥ saapasāraś cet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever causes gold or silver articles to be manufactured in any place other than the mint or without being noticed by the state goldsmith shall be fined panás, while the artisan who does that work shall, if found out, be punished with twice the above fine

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anapasāraḥ kaṇṭakaśodhanāya nīyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is not found out, measures such as are described in Book shall be taken to detect him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kartuś ca dviśato daṇḍaḥ paṇacchedanaṃ vā // tulāpratimānabhāṇḍaṃ pautavahastāt krīṇīyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When thus detected, he shall be fined 00 panás or shall have his fingers cut off Weighing balance and counterweights shall be purchased from the superintendent in charge of them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā dvādaśapaṇo daṇḍaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Otherwise a fine of panás shall be imposed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ghanaṃ suṣiraṃ samyūhyam avalepyaṃ saṃghātyaṃ vāsitakaṃ ca kārukarma //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Compact work ghana, compact and hollow work ghanasushira, soldering samyúhya, amalgamation avalepya, enclosing samghátya, and gilding vásitakam are the various kinds of artisan work kárukasma

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulāviṣamam apasāraṇaṃ visrāvaṇaṃ peṭakaḥ piṅkaś caiti haraṇaupāyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: False balances tulávishama, removal apasárana, dropping visrávana, folding petaka, and confounding pinka are the several means employed by goldsmiths to deceive the public

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samnāminy utkīrṇikā bhinnamastakaupakaṇṭhī kuśikyā sakaṭukakṣyā parivelyāayaskāntā ca duṣṭatulāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that of hollow neck upakanthi; that of bad strings kusikya; that of bad cups or pans sakatukakshya; that which is crooked or shaking párivellya; and that which is combined with a magnet ayaskánta

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rūpyasya dvau bhāgāv ekaḥ śulbasya tripuṭakam // tenaakarod gatam apasāryate tattripuṭakaapasāritam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra When, by what is called Triputaka which consists of two parts of silver and one part of copper, an equal portion of pure alluvial gold is replaced, that deceitful act is termed copperremoval triputakávasáritam;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vellakena vellakaapasāritam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when by vellakaan equal portion of gold is replaced, it is termed vellakaremoval;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śulbaardhasāreṇa hemnā hemaapasāritam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A crucible with a base metallic piece hidden in it; metallic excrement;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mūkamūṣā pūtikiṭṭaḥ karaṭukamukhaṃ nālī saṃdaṃśo joṅganī suvarcikālavaṇaṃ tad eva suvarṇam ity apasāraṇamārgāḥ // pūrvapraṇihitā vā piṇḍavālukā mūṣābhedād agniṣṭhād uddhriyante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a pair of tongs; metallic pieces jongani; and borax sauvarchikálavanam,these are the several things which are made use of by goldsmiths in stealing gold When, intentionally causing the crucible containing the bullion to burst, a few sandlike particles of the metal are picked up along with other particles of a base metal previously put therein, and the whole is wrought into a mass for the intended coin or ornament, this act is termed dropping visravana;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paścād bandhane ācitakapattraparīkṣāyāṃ vā rūpyarūpeṇa parivartanaṃ visrāvaṇam, piṇḍavālukānāṃ lohapiṇḍavālukābhir vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when examining the folded or inlaid leaves of an ornament áchitakapatrapariksháyám deception is perpetrated by substituting silver for gold, or when particles of a base metal are substituted for those of gold, it is termed dropping visrávana likewise

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gāḍhaś caabhyuddhāryaś ca peṭakaḥ samyūhyaavalepyasaṃghātyeṣu kriyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Folding petaka either firm gádha or loose abhyuddhárya is practiced in soldering, in preparing amalgams, and in enclosing a piece of base metal with two pieces of a superior metal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sīsarūpaṃ suvarṇapattreṇaavaliptam abhyantaram aṣṭakena baddhaṃ gāḍhapeṭakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a lead piece sísarúpalead coin is firmly covered over with gold leaf by means of wax ashtaka, that act is termed gádhapetaka, firm folding;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa eva paṭalasampuṭeṣv abhyuddhāryaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when the same is loosely folded, it is termed loose folding

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattram āśliṣṭaṃ yamakapattraṃ vāavalepyeṣu kriyate // śulbaṃ tāraṃ vā garbhaḥ pattrāṇāṃ saṃghātyeṣu kriyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra In amalgams, a single or double layer of a superior metal is made to cover a piece of base metal Copper or silver may also be placed between two leaves of a superior metal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śulbarūpaṃ suvarṇapattrasaṃhataṃ pramṛṣṭaṃ supārśvam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A copper piece sulbarúpya may be covered over with gold leaf, the surface and the edges being smoothened;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad eva yamakapattrasaṃhataṃ pramṛṣṭaṃ tāmratārarupaṃ cauttaravarṇakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: similarly a piece of any base metal may be covered over with double leaf of copper or silver, the surface and the edges being smoothened

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ubhayaṃ tāpanikaṣābhyāṃ nihśabdaullekhanābhyāṃ vā vidyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The two forms of folding may be detected by heating, by testing on touchstone nikasha or by observing absence of sound when it is rubbed nissabdollekhana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhyuddhāryaṃ badaraāmle lavaṇaudake vā sādayanti // iti peṭakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They find out loose folding in the acid juice of badarámla Flacourtia Cataphracta or jujube fruit or in salt water;so much for folding petaka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ghane suṣire vā rūpe suvarṇamṛnmālukāhiṅgulukakalpo vā taptoavatiṣṭhate // dṛḍhavāstuke vā rūpe vālukāmiśraṃ jatu gāndhārapaṅko vā taptoavatiṣṭhate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In a compact and hollow piece ghanasushire rúpe, small particles of goldlike mud suvarnamrinválukáh or bit of vermilion hingulakalkah are so heated as to make them firmly adhere to the piece inside Even in a compact piece dridhavástuke rúpe, the waxlike mud of Gándhára mixed with the particles of goldlike sand is so heated as to adhere to the piece

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayos tāpanam avadhvaṃsanaṃ vā śuddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: These two kinds of impurities are got rid of by hammering the pieces when red hot

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saparibhāṇḍe vā rūpe lavaṇam ulkayā kaṭuśarkarayā taptam avatiṣṭhate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In an ornament or a coin saparibhánde vá rúpe salt mixed with hard sand katusarkará is so heated in flame as to make it firmly adhere to the ornament or coin

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya kvāthanaṃ śuddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This salt and sand can be got rid of by boiling kváthana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhrapaṭalam aṣṭakena dviguṇavāstuke vā rūpe badhyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In some pieces, mica may be firmly fixed inside by wax and covered over with a double leaf of gold or silver

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyaapihitakācakasyaudake nimajjata ekadeśaḥ sīdati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When such a piece with mica or glass inside is suspended in water udake one of its sides dips more than the other;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paṭalaantareṣu vā sūcyā bhidyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when pierced by a pin, the pin goes very easily in the layers of mica in the interior Kautilyas Arthashastra patalántareshu

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇayo rūpyaṃ suvarṇaṃ vā ghanasuṣirāṇāṃ piṅkaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spurious stones and counterfeit gold and silver may be substituted for real ones in compact and hollow pieces ghanasushira

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād vajramaṇimuktāpravālarūpāṇāṃ jātirūpavarṇapramāṇapudgalalakṣaṇāny upalabheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the state goldsmith shall have a thorough knowledge of the species, characteristics, colour, weight, and formation pudgalalakshana of diamonds, precious stones mani, pearls, corals and coins rúpa

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtabhāṇḍaparīkṣāyāṃ purāṇabhāṇḍapratisaṃskāre vā catvāro haraṇaupāyāḥ parikuṭṭanam avacchedanam ullekhanaṃ parimardanaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There are four ways of deception perpetrated when examining new pieces or repairing old ones they are hammering, cutting, scratching and rubbing

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: peṭakaapadeśena pṛṣataṃ guṇaṃ piṭakāṃ vā yat pariśātayanti tatparikuṭṭanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, under the excuse of detecting the deception known as folding petaka in hollow pieces or in threads or in cups made of gold or silver, the articles in question are hammered, that act is termed hammering

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yaddviguṇavāstukānāṃ vā rūpe sīsarūpaṃ prakṣipyaābhyantaram avacchindanti tad avacchedanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a lead piece covered over with gold or silver leaf is substituted for a real one and its interior is cut off, it is termed cutting avachchhedanam

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad ghanānāṃ tīkṣṇenaullikhanti tad ullekhanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When compact pieces are scratched by tíkshna copper sulphate ?, that act is termed scratching ullekhana
