Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or a spy, attending as a servant upon a seditious person may not only call for an explanation from another fraudulent spy as to how certain articles necessary for the installation of a king and also the letters of an enemy came into the possession of his master, but also volunteer an explanation himself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ dūṣyeṣv adhārmikeṣu ca varteta, naitareṣu //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Measures such as the above shall be taken only against the seditious and the wicked and never against others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakvaṃ pakvam ivaārāmāt phalaṃ rājyād avāpnuyāt /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Just as fruits are gathered from a garden as often as they become ripe, so revenue shall be collected as often as it becomes ripe

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgajanapadaśaktyā bhṛtyakarma samudayapādena sthāpayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Collection of revenue or of fruits, when unripe, shall never be carried on, lest their source may be injured, causing immense trouble

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāryasādhanasahena vā bhṛtyalābhena // śarīram avekṣeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should look to the bodily comforts of his servants by providing such emoluments as can infuse in them the spirit of enthusiasm to work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na dharmaarthau pīḍayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should not violate the course of righteousness and wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṛtvigācāryamantripurohitasenāpatiyuvarājarājamātṛrājamahiṣyoaṣṭacatvāriṃśatsāhasrāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The sacrificial priest ritvig, the teacher, the minister, the priest purohita, the commander of the army, the heirapparent prince, the mother of the king, and the queen shall each receive ,000 panas per annum

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etāvatā bharaṇenaanāspadyatvam akopakaṃ caeṣāṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With this amount of subsistence, they will scarcely yield themselves to temptation and hardly be discontented

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dauvārikaantarvaṃśikapraśāstṛsamāhartṛsaṃnidhātāraś caturviṃśatisāhasrāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The doorkeeper, the superintendent of the harem antarvamsika the commander prasástri, the collectorgeneral, and the chamberlain, ,000

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etāvatā karmaṇyā bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With this amount they become serviceable

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kumārakumāramātṛnāyakapauravyāvahārikakārmāntikamantripariṣadrāṣṭraantapālāś ca dvādaśasāhasrāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The prince kumára, the nurse of the prince, the chief constable náyaka, the officer in charge of the town paura the superintendent of law or commerce vyávahárika, the superintendent of manufactories karmántika, members of the council of ministers, the superintendents of country parts and of boundaries, ,000

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svāmiparibandhabalasahāyā hy etāvatā bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With this they will be loyal and powerful supporters of the kings cause

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śreṇīmukhyā hastyaśvarathamukhyāḥ pradeṣṭāraś caaṣṭasāhasrāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The chiefs of military corporations, the chiefs of elephants, of horses, of chariots and of infantry and commissioners pradeshtárah, ,000

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svavargaanukarṣiṇo hy etāvatā bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With this amount they can have a good following in their own communities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattyaśvarathahastyadhyakṣā dravyahastivanapālāś ca catuḥsāhasrāḥ // rathikaanīkasthacikitsakaaśvadamakavardhakayo yonipoṣakāś ca dvisāhasrāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The Superintendents of infantry, of cavalry, of chariots and of elephants, the guards of timber and elephant forests, ,000 The chariotdriver, the physician of the army, the trainer of horses, the carpenter, vardhaki, and those who rear animals yoniposhaka, ,000

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kārtāntikanaimittikamauhūrtikapaurāṇikasūtamāgadhāḥ purohitapuruṣāḥ sarvaadhyakṣāś ca sāhasrāḥ // śilpavantaḥ pādātāḥ saṃkhyāyakalekhakaādivargaś ca pañcaśatāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The foreteller, the reader of omens, the astrologer, the reader of Puránas, the storyteller, the bard mágadha, the retinue of the priest, and all superintendents of departments, ,000 Trained soldiers, the staff of accountants and writers, 00 Musicians kusílava, 0

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviguṇavetanāś caeṣāṃ tūryakarāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, the trumpetblowers túryakara shall get twice as much wages as others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāruśilpino viṃśatiśatikāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Artisans and carpenters, 0

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: catuṣpadadvipadaparicārakapārikarmikaaupasthāyikapālakaviṣṭibandhakāḥ ṣaṣṭivetanāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Servants in charge of quadrupeds and bipeds, workmen doing miscellaneous work, attendants upon the royal person, bodyguards, and the procurer of free labourers shall receive a salary of 0 panas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āryayuktaārohakamāṇavakaśailakhanakāḥ sarvaupasthāyinaś ca // ācāryā vidyāvantaś ca pūjāvetanāni yathāarhaṃ labheran pañcaśataavaraṃ sahasraparam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The honourable playmate of the king áryayukta, the elephantdriver, the sorcerer manavaka, miners of mountains sailakhanaka, all kinds of attendants, teachers, and learned men shall have honorarium ranging from 00 to ,000 panas according to their merit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daśapaṇiko yojane dūto madhyamaḥ, daśauttare dviguṇavetana āyojanaśatād iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A messenger of middle quality shall receive 0 panas for Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 each yojana he travels; and twice as much when he travels from 0 to 00 yojanas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samānavidyebhyas triguṇavetano rājā rājasūyaādiṣu kratuṣu //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever represents the king in the rájasúya and other sacrifices shall get three times as much as is paid to others who are equal to him in learning;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājñaḥ sārathiḥ sāhasraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the charioteer of the king in the sacrifices, ,000

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāpaṭikaudāsthitagṛhapatikavaidehakatāpasavyañjanāḥ sāhasrāḥ // grāmabhṛtakasattritīkṣṇarasadabhikṣukyaḥ pañcaśatāḥ // cārasaṃcāriṇoardhatṛtīyaśatāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies such as the fradulent kápatika, the indifferent udásthita, the householder, the merchant, and the ascetic ,000 The villageservant grámabhritaka, fiery spies, poisoners and mendicant women, 00 panas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prayāsavṛddhavetanā vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Servants leading the spies, 0 or in proportion to the work done by them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatavargasahasravargāṇām adhyakṣā bhaktavetanalābham ādeśaṃ vikṣepaṃ ca kuryuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Superintendents of a hundred or a thousand coinmunities varga shall regulate the subsistence, wages, profits, appointinent, and transference vikshepa, of the men under them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avikṣepo rājaparigrahadurgarāṣṭrarakṣaavekṣaṇeṣu ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There shall be no transference of officers employed to guard the royal buildings, forts, and country parts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityamukhyāḥ syur anekamukhyāś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The chief officers employed to superintend the above places shall be many and shall permanently hold the same office

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karmasu mṛtānāṃ putradārā bhaktavetanaṃ labheran // bālavṛddhavyādhitāś caeṣām anugrāhyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The sons and wives of those who die while on duty shall get subsistence and wages Infants, aged persons, or deceased persons related to the deceased servants shall also be shown favour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pretavyādhitasūtikākṛtyeṣu caeṣām arthamānakarma kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On occasions of funerals, sickness, or childbirth, the king shall give presentations to his servants concerned therein

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alpakośaḥ kupyapaśukṣetrāṇi dadyāt, alpaṃ ca hiraṇyam // śūnyaṃ vā niveśayitum abhyutthito hiraṇyam eva dadyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When wanting in money, the king may give forest produce, cattle, or fields along with a small amount of money If he is desirous to colonise waste lands, he shall make payments in money Kautilyas Arthashastra alone;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na grāmaṃ grāmasaṃjātavyavahārasthāpanaartham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and if he is desirous of regulating the affairs of all villages equally, then he shall give no village to any of his servants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena bhṛtānām abhṛtānāṃ ca vidyākarmabhyāṃ bhaktavetanaviśeṣaṃ ca kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the king shall not only maintain his servants, but also increase their subsistence and wages in consideration of their learning and work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṣaṣṭivetanasyaāḍhakaṃ kṛtvā hiraṇyaanurūpaṃ bhaktaṃ kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Substituting one ádhaka for the salar of 0 panas payment in gold may be commuted for that in kind

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattyaśvarathadvipāḥ sūryaudaye bahiḥ saṃdhidivasavarjaṃ śilpayogyāḥ kuryuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Footmen, horses, chariots, and elephants shall be given necessary training in the art of war at sunrise, on all days but those of conjunction of planets

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣu rājā nityayuktaḥ syāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: on these occasions of training, the king shall ever be present and witness their exercise

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtanaraindraaṅkaṃ śastraāvaraṇam āyudhaagāraṃ praveśayet // aśastrāś careyuḥ, anyatra mudrāanujñātāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Weapons and armour shall be entered into the armoury only after they are marked with the kings seal Persons with weapons shall not be allowed to move anywhere unless they are permitted by a passport

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naṣṭaṃvinaṣṭaṃ vā dviguṇaṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When weapons are either lost or spoilt, the superintendent shall pay double their value;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vidhvastagaṇanāṃ ca kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: an account of the weapons that are destroyed shall be kept up

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sārthikānāṃ śastraāvaraṇam antapālā gṛhṇīyuḥ, samudram avacārayeyur vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Boundaryguards shall take away the weapons and armour possessed by caravans unless the latter are provided with a passport to travel with weapons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yātrām abhyutthito vā senām udyojayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When starting on a military tour, the king shall put his army in action

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato vaidehakavyañjanāḥ sarvapaṇyāny āyudhīyebhyo yātrākāle dviguṇapratyādeyāni dadyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On such occasions, spies, under the garb of merchants, shall supply to military stations all kinds of merchandise for double the quantity of the same to be repaid in future

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ rājapaṇyayogavikrayo vetanapratyādānaṃ ca bhavati // evam avekṣitaāyavyayaḥ kośadaṇḍavyasanaṃ naavāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus not only is there afforded an opportunity for the sale of the kings merchandise, but Kautilyas Arthashastra also is there a way opened for a good return for the wages paid Thus, when both the receipts and expenditure are properly cared for, the king will never find himself in financial or military difficulties

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti bhaktavetanavikalpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such are the alternatives with regard to subsistence and wages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sattriṇaś caāyudhīyānāṃ veśyāḥ kārukuśīlavāḥ / daṇḍavṛddhāś ca jānīyuḥ śaucaaśaucam atandritāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, prostitutes, artisans, singers, and aged military officers shall vigilantly examine the pure or impure conduct of military men [Thus ends Chapter , Concerning Subsistence to Government Servants in Book , The Conduct of Courtiers of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lokayātrāvid rājānam ātmadravyaprakṛtisaṃpannaṃ priyahitadvāreṇaāśrayeta // yaṃ vā manyeta yathāaham āśrayaīpsur evam asau vinayaīpsur ābhigāmikaguṇayuktaḥ iti, dravyaprakṛtihīnam apy enam āśrayeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE CONDUCT OF A COURTIER WHOEVER possesses enough experience of the world and its affairs may, through the influence of an interested friend, seek the favour of a king who is endowed with amiable qualities and is possessed of all the elements of sovereignty He may court the favour of any king provided he thinksJust as am in need of a patron, so is this king possessed of a taste for good advice and is of amiable character

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na tv evaanātmasaṃpannam // anātmavā hi nītiśāstradveṣād anarthyasaṃyogād vā prāpyaapi mahad aiśvaryaṃ na bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may even court the favour of such a king as is poor and destitute of the elements of sovereignty, but never, of such a one as is of a depraved character whoever, as a king, is destitute of good temper and amiable character cannot, by reason of his habitual hatred of the science of polity and an inborn proclivity to evil ways, maintain his sovereignty, though he is Kautilyas Arthashastra possessed of immense sovereign power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātmavati labdhaavakāśaḥ śāstraanuyogaṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having obtained admittance to an amiable king, he shall give the king instructions in sciences

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avisaṃvādādd hi sthānasthairyam avāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Absence of contradiction from the king will render his position secure

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: matikarmasu pṛṣṭhas tadātve caāyatyāṃ ca dharmaarthasaṃyuktaṃ samarthaṃ pravīṇavad apariṣadbhīruḥ kathayet // īpsitaḥ paṇeta dharmaarthaanuyogam aviśiṣṭeṣu balavatsaṃyukteṣu daṇḍadhāraṇaṃ matsaṃyoge tadātve ca daṇḍadhāraṇam iti na
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When his opinion is sought about present or future schemes needing much thought and consideration, he may boldly and sensibly, and with no fear of contradiction from the assembly of ministers, pronounce his opinion so as to be in harmony with the principles of righteousness and economy When required, he may answer questions on points of righteousness and economy and tell the king Following the rule that there should be no delay in putting down by force even a strong confederacy of wicked people, you should apply force against the wicked, if they have a strong support;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣaṃ vṛttiṃ guhyaṃ ca me naupahanyāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: do not despise my advice, character and secrets;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃjñayā ca tvāṃ kāmakrodhadaṇḍaneṣu vārayeyam iti // ādiṣṭaḥ pradiṣṭāyāṃ bhūmāv anujñātaḥ praviśet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and by means of gestures, shall prevent you from inflicting punishments on any one, when you are going to do so either willfully or under provocation With such agreements with the king, he a courtier may enter on the duty assigned to him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upaviśec ca pārśvataḥ saṃnikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭaḥ paraāsanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall sit by the side of, and close to, the king and far from the seat of another courtier

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigṛhya kathanam asabhyam apratyakṣam aśraddheyam anṛtaṃ ca vākyam uccair anarmaṇi hāsaṃ vātaṣṭhīvane ca śabdavatī na kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall avoid speaking slyly against the opinion of any member of the assembly; he shall never make incredible or false statements; nor loud laughter with no cause for jest, and loud noise and spittle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājño veṣam uddhatakuhakānāṃ ca, ratnaatiśayaprakāśaabhyarthanam, ekaakṣyoṣṭhanirbhogaṃ bhrukuṭīkarma vākyaavakṣepaṇaṃ ca bruvati, balavat saṃyuktavirodham, strībhiḥ strīdarśibhiḥ sāmantadūtair dveṣyapakṣaavakṣiptān arthyaiś ca pratisaṃsargam ekaarthacaryāṃ saṃghātaṃ ca varjayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall also avoid talking to another in secret, mutual conversation with another in the assembly of ministers, appearing in royal dress in the public, haughtiness, buffoonery, open request for gems and promotions, seeing with one eye, biting the lips, browbeating, interrupting the king while speaking, enmity with a strong party, association with women, pimps, messengers of foreign kings, enemies, inimical parties, dismissed officers, and wicked people, stubborn adherence to a single purpose, and contact with any Kautilyas Arthashastra confederacy of men

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ahīnakālaṃ rājaarthaṃ svaarthaṃ priyahitaiḥ saha /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Without losing the opportune moments, he should speak of the kings interest; of his own interest when in company with persons friendly to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraarthaṃ deśakāle ca brūyād dharmaarthasaṃhitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and of others interests in a suitable time and place, and in conformity to the principles of righteousness and economy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pṛṣṭaḥ priyahitaṃ brūyān na brūyād ahitaṃ priyam / apriyaṃ vā hitaṃ brūyātśṛṇvatoanumato mithaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When asked, he should tell the king what is both good and pleasing, but not what is bad, though pleasing; if the king is pleased to listen, he may secretly tell what, though unpleasant, is good

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tūṣṇīṃ vā prativākye syād veṣyaādīṃś ca na varṇayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may even keep silence, but should never describe what is hateful;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apriyā api dakṣāḥ syus tadbhāvād ye bahiṣkṛtāḥ // anarthyāś ca priyā dṛṣṭāś cittajñānaanuvartinaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by abstaining from talking of what the king hates, even undesirable persons have become powerful when, seeing that the king likes only pleasant things without caring for their evil consequences, they have followed his will

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhihāsyeṣv abhihased ghorahāsāṃś ca varjayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: While laughing in jest, he should avoid loud laughter;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parāt saṃkrāmayed ghoraṃ na ca ghoraṃ pare vadet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he shall avoid evil aspersions against others, nor ascribe evil to others;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: titikṣetaātmanaś caiva kṣamāvān pṛthivīsamaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he shall forgive evil done to himself and have as much forbearance as the earth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātmarakṣā hi satataṃ pūrvaṃ kāryā vijānatā /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Selfprotection shall be the first and constant thought of a wise man;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agnāv iva hi saṃproktā vṛttī rājāupajīvinām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the life of a man under the service of a king is aptly compared to life in fire;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekadeśaṃ dahed agniḥ śarīraṃ vā paraṃ gataḥ / saputradāraṃ rājā tu ghātayed ardhayeta vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whereas fire burns a part or the whole of the body, if at all, the king has the power either to destroy or to advance the whole family, consisting of sons and wives, of his servants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niyuktaḥ karmasu vyayaviśuddham udayaṃ darśayet // ābhyantaraṃ bāhyaṃ guhyaṃ prakāśyam ātyayikam upekṣitavyaṃ vā kāryaṃ idam evam iti viśeṣayec ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra WHEN employed as a minister, he the courtier shall show the net revenue that remains after all kinds of expenditure are met with He shall also give the exact particularsas this is thusof whatever work is external, internal, secret, open, costly, or negligible

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mṛgayādyūtamadyastrīṣu prasaktaṃ naenam anuvarteta praśaṃsābhiḥ // āsannaś caasya vyasanaupaghāte prayateta, paraupajāpaatisaṃdhānaupadhibhyaś ca rakṣet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall follow the king in his pursuits after hunting, gambling, drinking, and sexual pleasures Ever attending upon the king, he shall, by flattery, endeavour to arrest his fall into evil habits and save him from the intrigues, plots and deceptions of enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iṅgitaākārau caasya lakṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall also endeavour to read the mind and appearance of the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāmadveṣaharṣadainyavyavasāyabhayadvandvaviparyāsam iṅgitaākārābhyāṃ hi mantrasaṃvaraṇaartham ācarati prājñaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By way of collecting his wandering thoughts into a resolve, the king exhibits in his appearance and movements his inclination, anger, pleasure, sorrow, determination, fear, and change in the pairs of opposite feelings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: darśane prasīdati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By cognising wisdom in others, he is pleased;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vākyaṃ pratigṛhṇāti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he attends to the speech of others;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsanaṃ dadāti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he gives a seat;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vivikto darśayate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: allows himself to be seen in private;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaṅkāsthāne naatiśaṅkate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: does not suspect in places of suspicion;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kathāyāṃ ramate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: takes delight in conversation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parijñāpyeṣv avekṣate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: spontaneously looks to things without being reminded;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pathyam uktaṃ sahate, smayamāno niyuṅkte,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: tolerates what is said agreeably to reason; orders with smiling face;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastena spṛśati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: touches with the hand;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ślāghye naupahasati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: does not laugh at what is commendable;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parokṣaṃ guṇaṃ bravīti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: commends the qualities of another behind him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhakṣyeṣu smarati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: remembers the courtier while taking luncheon;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saha vihāraṃ yāti, vyasaneabhyupapadyate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: engages himself in sports accompanied by the courtier; consults the courtier when in trouble;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadbhaktīn pūjayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: honours the followers of the courtier;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guhyam ācaṣṭe, mānaṃ vardhayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: reveals the secret; honours the courtier more and more;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthaṃ karoti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: gives him wealth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anarthaṃ pratihanti iti tuṣṭajñānam // etad eva viparītam atuṣṭasya,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and averts his troubles;these are the signs of the kings satisfaction with the courtier The reverse of the above indicates his the kings displeasure

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūyaś ca vakṣyāmaḥ // saṃdarśane kopaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Still, we shall describe them in plain terms Angry appearance when the courtier is in sight;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vākyasyaaśravaṇapratiṣedhau,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: evading or refusal to hear his speech;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsanacakṣuṣor adānam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: no inclination to give him a seat or to see Kautilyas Arthashastra him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: varṇasvarabhedaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: change in syllables and accents while talking to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaakṣibhrukuṭyoṣṭhanirbhogaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: seeing with one eye; browbeating; biting the lips; rise of sweat;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paramantraṇam, akasmādvrajanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: hard breathing and smiling with no palpable cause;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vardhanam anyasya,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: talking to himself;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmigātravilekhanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: sudden bending or raising of the body;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyasyaupatodanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: molestation to another;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vidyāvarṇadeśakutsā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: contempt of learning, caste, and country of the courtier;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samadoṣanindā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: condemnation of a colleague of equal defects;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratidoṣanindā, pratilomastavaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: condemnation of a man of opposite defects; condemnation of his opponent;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukṛtaanavekṣaṇam, duṣkṛtaanukīrtanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: failure to acknowledge his good deeds; enumeration of his bad deeds;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pṛṣṭhaavadhānam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: attention to whoever enters into the chamber;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mithyāabhibhāṣaṇam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: too much gift; uttering falsehood;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājadarśināṃ ca tadvṛttaanyatvam // vṛttivikāraṃ caavekṣetaapy amānuṣāṇām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: change in the conduct and attitude of visitors to the king; nay, the courtier shall also note the change in the life of animals other than men

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ayam uccaiḥ siñcati iti kātyāyanaḥ pravavrāja, krauñcoapasavyam iti kaṇiṅko bhāradvājaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kátyáyana holds that this king showers his favours broadcast Kaninka Bháradvája says that Krauncha a bird has moved from right to left Dírgha Chárayana says that this king is like a grass

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śītā śāṭī iti ghoṭamukhaḥ, hastī pratyaukṣīt iti kiñjalkaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Ghotamukha says that he is like a wet cloth Kinjalka says that he is like an elephant pouring over water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rathaaśvaṃ prāśaṃsīt iti piśunaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pisuna is of opinion that one should declare him to be a chariothorse

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratiravaṇe śunaḥ piśunaputraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The son of Pisuna says that mortification ensues when his opponent is courted

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthamānaavakṣepe ca parityāgaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When wealth and honour are discontinued, such a king may be abandoned;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svāmiśīlam ātmanaś ca kilbiṣam upalabhya vā pratikurvīta // mitram upakṛṣṭaṃ vāasya gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by recognising the character of the king as well as his own defects, he may rectify himself ; or he may seek the Kautilyas Arthashastra protection of one of the best friends of the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatrastho doṣanirghātaṃ mitrair bhartari caācaret / tato bhartari jīve vā mṛte vā punar āvrajet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Living with the kings friend, the courtier has to endeavour to remove, through the medium of his own friends, the defects of his master, and then come back to his original place, no matter whether the king is alive or dead

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājavyasanam evam amātyaḥ pratikurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE minister shall thus avert the calamities in which the king is involved;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / prāg eva maraṇaābādhabhayād rājñaḥ priyahitaupagraheṇa māsadvimāsaantaraṃ darśanaṃ sthāpayed deśapīḍāapaham amitraapaham āyuṣyaṃ putrīyaṃ vā karma rājā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: long before the apprehended death of the king, he shall, in concert with his friends and followers allow visitors to the king once in a month or two and avoid their visits on other occasions under the plea that the king is engaged in performing such rites as are calculated to avert national calamities, or are destructive of enemies, or capable of prolonging life or of procuring a son

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājavyañjanam arūpavelāyāṃ prakṛtīnāṃ darśayet, mitraamitradūtānāṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On appropriate occasions, he may show a pseudoking not only to the people, but also to messengers coming from friends or enemies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: taiś ca yathāucitāṃ saṃbhāṣām amātyamukho gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and this false king shall make the minister his mouthpiece in conversing with them as deserved

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dauvārikaantarvaṃśikamukhaś ca yathāuktaṃ rājapraṇidhim anuvartayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: And through the medium of the gatekeeper and the officer in charge of the harem, the minister shall pretend to receive the orders of the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apakāriṣu ca heḍaṃ prasādaṃ vā prakṛtikāntaṃ darśayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Displeasure or mercy to wrongdoers shall be shown only indirectly

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āptapuruṣaadhiṣṭhitau durgapratyantasthau vā kośadaṇḍāv ekasthau kārayet, kulyakumāramukhyāṃś caanyaapadeśena // yaś ca mukhyaḥ pakṣavān durgaaṭavīstho vā vaiguṇyaṃ bhajeta tam upagrāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Both the treasury and the army shall be kept under the command of two reliable and confidential persons and in a single locality, either within the fort or at the boundary of the kingdom Cognates, princes, and other chiefs of the royal family may be employed in works such as the capture of a chief who, employed as a commander of a fort or the tracts of wilderness, has turned inimical along with a strong band of supporters;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahvābādhaṃ vā yātrāṃ preṣayet, mitrakulaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may be sent on an expedition full of difficulties, or to visit the family of the kings friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yasmāc ca sāmantād ābādhaṃ paśyet tam utsavavivāhahastibandhanaaśvapaṇyabhūmipradānaapadeśenaavagrāhayet, svamitreṇa vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever, among the neighbouring kings, seems to threaten with an invasion may be invited for some festival, marriage, capture of elephants, purchase of horses, or of merchandise, or for taking possession of some lands ceded to him, and captured;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ saṃdhim adūṣyaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or such an enemy may be kept at bay by an ally till an agreement of not condemnable nature is made with him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āṭavikaamitrair vā vairaṃ grāhayet // tatkulīnam aparuddhaṃ vā bhūṃyekadeśenaupagrāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may be made to incur the displeasure of wild tribes or of his enemies; or whoever among his nearest relatives is kept under guard may be promised a portion of his territory and set against him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kulyakumāramukhyaupagrahaṃ kṛtvā vā kumāram abhiṣiktam eva darśayet // dāṇḍakarmikavad vā rājyakaṇṭakān uddhṛtya rājyaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or with the help of nobles and princes of the kings family, the minister may have the heirapparent installed and show him to the public Or having, as pointed out in the chapter concerning the awards of punishments, removed the thorns of the kingdom, he may conduct the administration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā kaścin mukhyaḥ sāmantaādīnām anyatamaḥ kopaṃ bhajeta taṃ ehi, rājānaṃ tvā kariṣyāmi ity āvāhayitvā ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or if a chief among the neighbouring kings seems to give trouble, the minister may invite him, saying come here and shall make thee king, and then put him to death;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āpatpratīkāreṇa vā sādhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may be kept at bay by taking such measures as can ward off dangers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yuvarāje vā krameṇa rājyabhāram āropya rājavyasanaṃ khyāpayet // parabhūmau rājavyasane mitreṇaamitravyañjanena śatroḥ saṃdhim avasthāpyaapagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In case of the kings demise in an enemys land, the minister, having brought about an agreement between the enemy and a friend pretending to be an enemy of the dead king, may withdraw himself; or having installed in the kings fort any one of the neighbouring kings, he may withdraw himself;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kumāram abhiṣicya vā prativyūheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having installed the heirapparent, he may set the army against the enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pareṇaabhiyukto vā yathāuktam āpatpratīkāraṃ kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when attacked by the enemy, he may take, as detailed elsewhere, such measures as can ward off dangers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam ekaaiśvaryam amātyaḥ kārayed iti kauṭilyaḥ // naevam iti bhāradvājaḥ // pramriyamāṇe vā rājany amātyaḥ kulyakumāramukhyān parasparaṃ mukhyeṣu vā vikramayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus, says Kautilya, the minister shall invest himself with the powers of sovereignty Not so, says Bháradvája, the king lying on his deathbed, the minister may set up the princes and other chiefs of the royal family against one another or against other chiefs

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikrāntaṃ prakṛtikopena ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever attacks the kingdom may be put to death under the plea of disturbance and annoyance to the people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kulyakumāramukhyān upāṃśudaṇḍena vā sādhayitvā svayaṃ rājyaṃ gṛhṇīyāt // rājyakāraṇādd hi pitā putrān putrāś ca pitaram abhidruhyanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having secretly punished the chief rebels of the royal family and brought them under his control, the minister shall himself take possession of the kingdom, for on account of the kingdom the father hates his sons, and sons their father;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kim aṅga punar amātyaprakṛtir hy ekapragraho rājyasya // tat svayam upasthitaṃ naavamanyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: why then should the minister who is the sole prop of the kingdom be an exception to it? Therefore he shall never discard what has, of its own accord, fallen into his hands;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svayam ārūḍhā hi strī tyajyamānāabhiśapati iti lokapravādaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it is a general talk among the people that a woman making love of her own accord will, when discarded, curse the man

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durlabhaḥ sa punas tasya kālaḥ karma cikīrṣataḥ // prakṛtikopakam adharmiṣṭham anaikāntikaṃ caetad iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An opportunity will only once offer itself to a man who is waiting for it, and will not come a second time when he may be desirous of accomplishing his work But it is, says Kautilya, unrighteous to do an act which Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 excites popular fury;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājaputram ātmasaṃpannaṃ rājye sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall, therefore, install in the kingdom such a son of the king as is possessed of amiable qualities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃpannaabhāveavyasaninaṃ kumāraṃ rājakanyāṃ garbhiṇīṃ devīṃ vā puraskṛtya mahāmātrān saṃnipātya brūyāt ayaṃ vo nikṣepaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of a prince of good character, he may place before himself a wicked prince, or a princess, or the pregnant queen, and tell the other ministers„This is your caste kshepa;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pitaram asyaavekṣadhvaṃ sattvaabhijanam ātmanaś ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: look to the father of this boy as well as to your own valour and descent;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhvajamātroayaṃ bhavanta eva svāminaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this boy is merely a flag; and yourselves are the lords;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kathaṃ vā kriyatām iti // tathā bruvāṇaṃ yogapuruṣā brūyuḥ koanyo bhavatpurogād asmād rājñaś cāturvarṇyam arhati pālayitum iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: pray, how shall act‟? As he is saying this, others, taken in confidence before, shall say in replyWho else than the one of your lead is capable of protecting the mass of the people of the four castes of the king ? Then the other ministers will certainly agree to it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathā ity amātyaḥ kumāraṃ rājakanyāṃ garbhiṇīṃ devīṃ vāadhikurvīta, bandhusaṃbandhināṃ mitraamitradūtānāṃ ca darśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Accordingly he shall install a prince, a princess, or the pregnant queen, and show him or her to all the royal relations as well as to the messengers coming from friends or enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhaktavetanaviśeṣam amātyānām āyudhīyānāṃ ca kārayet, bhūyaś caayaṃ vṛddhaḥ kariṣyati iti brūyāt // evaṃ durgarāṣṭramukhyān ābhāṣeta, yathāarhaṃ ca mitraamitrapakṣam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall provide the ministers and military officers with increased subsistence and salary, promising them that This boy will, after attaining full age, increase your emolument still more He shall likewise promise the chief officers in charge of the forts and country parts as well as the parties of both the friends and enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vinayakarmaṇi ca kumārasya prayateta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall then take necessary steps to educate and train the prince

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kanyāyāṃ samānajātīyād apatyam utpādya vāabhiṣiñcet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may install a child begotten on the princess by a man of the same caste

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mātuś cittakṣobhabhayāt kulyam alpasattvaṃ chātraṃ ca lakṣaṇyam upanidadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall keep as a representative of the prince one who is of the same family, of little valour and of beautiful appearance, lest the mothers mind may be agitated with wild apprehensions

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṛtau caenāṃ rakṣet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall justly protect her

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na caātmaarthaṃ kaṃcid utkṛṣṭam upabhogaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He shall not provide himself with luxurious means of enjoyment

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājaarthaṃ tu yānavāhanaābharaṇavastrastrīveśmaparivāpān kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As to the king, he may provide him with new chariots, horses, jewels, dress, women and palaces

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yauvanasthaṃ ca yāceta viśramaṃ cittakāraṇāt /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the prince comes of age, he may request the prince to Kautilyas Arthashastra relieve him from the intellectual worry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parityajed atuṣyantaṃ tuṣyantaṃ caanupālayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may abandon the king, if he the king is displeased; and follow him if he is pleased

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nivedya putrarakṣāarthaṃ gūḍhasāraparigrahān / araṇyaṃ dīrghasattraṃ vā sevetaārucyatāṃ gataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is disgusted with the ministerial life, he may go to a forest or a long sacrifice, after having informed the queen of the safeguards and persons that are employed to bring up the prince

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mukhyair avagṛhītaṃ vā rājānaṃ tatpriyaāśritaḥ / itihāsapurāṇābhyāṃ bodhayed arthaśāstravit // siddhavyañjanarūpo vā yogam āsthāya pārthivam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Even if the king is held by the chiefs under their influence, the minister may, through the medium of the kings favourites, teach him the principles of polity with illustrations, taken from the Itihása and Purána Having taken the garb of an accomplished ascetic, the minister may ingratiate himself with the king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: labheta labdhvā dūṣyeṣu dāṇḍakarmikam ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and having brought the king under his influence, he may take coercive measure against the seditious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (ṣaṇṇavatitamaṃ prakaraṇaṃ prakṛtisampadah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Book The Source of Sovereign States CHAPTER THE ELEMENTS OF SOVEREIGNTY

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svāmyamātyajanapadadurgakośadaṇḍamitrāṇi prakṛtayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE king, the minister, the country, the fort, the treasury, the army and the friend are the elements of sovereignty

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra svāmisampat // / mahākulīno daivabuddhisattvasampanno vṛddhadarśī dhārmikaḥ satyavāg avisaṃvādakaḥ kṛtajñaḥ sthūlalakṣo mahāutsāhoadīrghasūtraḥ śakyasāmanto dṛḍhabuddhir akṣudrapariṣatko vinayakāma ity ābhigāmikā guṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, the best qualities of the king are Born of a high family, godly, possessed of valour, seeing through the medium of aged persons, virtuous, truthful, not of a contradictory nature, grateful, having large aims, highly enthusiastic, not addicted to procrastination, powerful to control his neighbouring kings, of resolute mind, having an assembly of ministers of no mean quality, and possessed of a taste for discipline;these are the qualities of an inviting nature

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śuśrūṣāśravaṇagrahaṇadhāraṇavijñānaūhaapohatattvaabhiniveśāḥ prajñāguṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Inquiry, hearing, perception, retention in memory, reflection, deliberation, inference and steadfast adherence to conclusions are the qualities of the intellect

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śauryam amarṣaḥ śīghratā dākṣyaṃ cautsāhaguṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Valour, determination of purpose, quickness, and probity are the aspects of enthusiasm

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / vāgmī pragalbhaḥ smṛtimatibalavān udagraḥ svavagrahaḥ kṛtaśilpoavyasano daṇḍanāyy upakāraapakārayor dṛṣṭapratīkārī hrīmān āpatprakṛtyor viniyoktā dīrghadūradarśī deśakālapuruṣakārakāryapradhānaḥ saṃdhivikramatyāgasamyamapaṇaparacchidravibhāgī saṃvṛtoadīnaabhihāsyajihmabhrukuṭīkṣaṇaḥ kāmakrodhalobhastambhacāpalaupatāpapaiśunyahīnaḥ śaklaḥ smitaudagraabhibhāṣī vṛddhaupadeśaācāra ity ātmasampat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Possessed of a sharp intellect, strong memory, and keen mind, energetic, powerful, trained in all kinds of arts, free from vice, capable of paying in the same coin by way of awarding punishments or rewards, possessed of dignity, capable of taking remedial measures against dangers, possessed of foresight, ready to avail himself of opportunities when afforded in respect of place, Kautilyas Arthashastra time, and manly efforts, clever enough to discern the causes necessitating the cessation of treaty or war with an enemy, or to lie in wait keeping treaties, obligations and pledges, or to avail himself of his enemys weak points, making jokes with no loss of dignity or secrecy, never browbeating and casting haughty and stern looks, free from passion, anger, greed, obstinacy, fickleness, haste and backbiting habits, talking to others with a smiling face, and observing customs as taught by aged persons;such is the nature of selfpossession

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amātyasampad uktā purastāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The qualifications of a minister have been described in the beginning, middle, and at the close of the work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / madhye caante ca sthānavān ātmadhāraṇaḥ paradhāraṇaś caāpadi svaārakṣaḥ svaājīvaḥ śatrudveṣī śakyasāmantaḥ paṅkapāṣāṇauṣaraviṣamakaṇṭakaśreṇīvyālamṛgaaṭavīhīnaḥ kāntaḥ sītākhanidravyahastivanavān gavyaḥ pauruṣeyo guptagocaraḥ paśumān adevamātṛko vāristhalapathābhyām upetaḥ sāracitrabahupaṇyo daṇḍakarasahaḥ karmaśīlakarṣakoabāliśasvāmyavaravarṇaprāyo bhaktaśucimanuṣya iti janapadasampat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Possessed of capital cities both in the centre and the extremities of the kingdom, productive of subsistence not only to its own people, but also to outsiders on occasions of calamities, repulsive to enemies, powerful enough to put down neighbouring kings, free from miry, rocky, uneven, and desert tracts as well as from conspirators, tigers, wild beasts, and large tracts of wilderness, beautiful to look at, containing fertile lands, mines, timber and elephant forests, and pasture grounds, artistic, containing hidden passages, full of cattle, not depending upon rain for water, possessed of land and waterways, rich in various kinds of commercial articles, capable of bearing the burden of a vast army and heavy taxation, inhabited by agriculturists of good and active character, full of intelligent masters and servants, and with a population noted for its loyalty and good character;these are the qualities of a good country

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgasampad uktā purastāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The excellent qualities of forts have already been described

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dharmaadhigataḥ pūrvaiḥ svayaṃ vā hemarūpyaprāyaś citrasthūlaratnahiraṇyo dīrghām apy āpadam anāyatiṃ sahetaiti kośasampat
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Justly obtained either by inheritance or by selfacquisition, rich in gold and silver, filled with an abundance of big gems of Kautilyas Arthashastra various colours and of gold coins, and capable to withstand calamities of long duration is the best treasury

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / pitṛpaitāmaho nityo vaśyas tuṣṭabhṛtaputradāraḥ pravāseṣv avisaṃvāditaḥ sarvatraapratihato duḥkhasaho bahuyuddhaḥ sarvayuddhapraharaṇavidyāviśāradaḥ sahavṛddhikṣayikatvād advaidhyaḥ kṣatraprāya iti daṇḍasampat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Coming down directly, from father and grandfather of the king, ever strong, obedient, happy in keeping their sons and wives well contented, not averse to making a long sojourn, ever and everywhere invincible, endowed with the power of endurance, trained in fighting various kinds of battles, skillful in handling various forms of weapons, ready to share in the weal or woe of the king, and consequently not falling foul with him, and purely composed of soldiers of Kshatriya caste, is the best army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pitṛpaitāmahaṃ nityaṃ vaśyam advaidhyaṃ mahallaghusamuttham iti mitrasampat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Coming down directly from father and grandfather, longstanding, open to conviction, never falling foul, and capable of making preparations for war quickly and on a large scale, is the best friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / arājabījī lubdhaḥ kṣudrapariṣatko viraktaprakṛtir anyāyavṛttir ayukto vyasanī nirutsāho daivapramāṇo yatkiṃcanakāryagatir ananubandhaḥ klībo nityaapakārī caity amitrasampat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not born of a royal family, greedy, possessed of a mean assembly of ministers, with disloyal subjects, ever doing unrighteous acts, of loose character, addicted to mean pleasures, devoid of enthusiasm, trusting to fate, indiscreet in action, powerless, helpless, impotent, and ever injurious, is the worst enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃbhūto hi śatruḥ sukhaḥ samucchettuṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such an enemy is easily uprooted

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arivarjāḥ prakṛtayaḥ saptaetāḥ svaguṇaudayāḥ / uktāḥ pratyaṅgabhūtās tāḥ prakṛtā rājasampadaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Excepting the enemy, these seven elements, possessed of their excellent characteristics are said to be the limblike elements of sovereignty A wise king can make even the poor and miserable elements of his sovereignty happy and prosperous;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vivṛddhāś caanuraktāś ca prakṛtīr hanty anātmavān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but a wicked king will surely destroy the most prosperous and loyal elements of his kingdom

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sa duṣṭaprakṛtiś cāturantoapy anātmavān / hanyate vā prakṛtibhir yāti vā dviṣatāṃ vaśam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Hence a king of unrighteous character and of vicious habits will, though he is an emperor, fall a prey either to the fury of his own subjects or to that of his enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ātmavāṃs tv alpadeśoapi yuktaḥ prakṛtisampadā / pṛthivīṃ kṛtsnāṃ jayaty eva na hīyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But a wise king, trained in politics, will, though he possesses a small territory, conquer the whole earth with the help of the bestfitted elements of his sovereignty, and will never be defeated

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śamavyāyāmau yogakṣemayor yoniḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the ninetyseventh chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER CONCERNING PEACE AND EXERTION

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karmaārambhāṇāṃ yogaārādhano vyāyāmaḥ // karmaphalaupabhogānāṃ kṣemaārādhanaḥ śamaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: ACQUISITION and security of property are dependent upon peace and industry Efforts to achieve the results of works undertaken is industry vyáyáma Absence of disturbance to the enjoyment of the results achieved from works is peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śamavyāyāmayor yoniḥ ṣāḍguṇyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The application of the sixfold royal policy is the source of peace and industry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣayaḥ sthānaṃ vṛddhir ity udayās tasya //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Deterioration, stagnation, and progress are the three aspects of position

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mānuṣaṃ nayaapanayau,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those causes of human make which affect position are policy and impolicy naya and apanaya;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivam ayaanayau //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: fortune and misfortune aya and anaya are providential causes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivamānuṣaṃ hi karma lokaṃ yāpayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Causes, both human and providential, govern the world and its affairs

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adṛṣṭakāritaṃ daivam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra What is unforeseen is providential;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasminn iṣṭena phalena yogoayaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: here, the attainment of that desired end which seemed almost lost is termed fortune

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dṛṣṭakāritaṃ mānuṣam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: What is anticipated is human;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmin yogakṣemaniṣpattir nayaḥ, vipattir apanayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the attainment of a desired end as anticipated is due to policy What produces unfavourable results is impolicy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tac cintyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This can be foreseen;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: acintyaṃ daivam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but misfortune due to providence cannot be known

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājā ātmadravyaprakṛtisampanno nayasyaadhiṣṭhānaṃ vijigīṣuḥ // tasya samantato maṇḍalībhūtā bhūmyanantarā ariprakṛtiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king who, being possessed of good character and bestfitted elements of sovereignty, is the fountain of policy, is termed the conqueror The king who is situated anywhere immediately on the circumference of the conquerors territory is termed the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathāeva bhūmyekaantarā mitraprakṛtiḥ // arisampadyuktaḥ sāmantaḥ śatruḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king who is likewise situated close to the enemy, but separated from the conqueror only by the enemy, is termed the friend of the conqueror A neighbouring foe of considerable power is styled an enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanī yātavyaḥ, anapāśrayo durbalaāśrayo vāucchedanīyaḥ, viparyaye pīḍanīyaḥ karśanīyo vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when he is involved in calamities or has taken himself to evil ways, he becomes assailable; and when he has little or no help, he becomes destructible; otherwise ie, when he is provided with some help, he deserves to be harassed or reduced

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity ariviśeṣāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such are the aspects of an enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmān mitram arimitraṃ mitramitram arimitramitraṃ caānantaryeṇa bhūmīnāṃ prasajyante purastāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In front of the conqueror and close to his enemy, there happen to be situated kings such as the conquerors friend, next to him, the enemys friend, and next to the last, the conquerors friends friend, and next, the enemys friends friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paścāt pārṣṇigrāha ākrandaḥ pārṣṇigrāhaāsāra ākrandaāsāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the rear of the conqueror, there happen to be situated a rearward enemy párshnigráha, a rearward friend ákranda, an Kautilyas Arthashastra ally of the rearward enemy párshnigráhásárá, and an ally of the rearward friend ákrandására

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmyanantaraḥ prakṛtimitraḥ, tulyaabhijanaḥ sahajaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That foe who is equally of high birth and occupies a territory close to that of the conqueror is a natural enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viruddho virodhayitā vā kṛtrimaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: while he who is merely antagonistic and creates enemies to the conqueror is a factitious enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmyekaantaraṃ prakṛtimitram, mātāpitṛsambaddhaṃ sahajam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He whose friendship is derived from father and grandfather, and who is situated close to the territory of the immediate enemy of the conqueror is a natural friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhanajīvitahetor āśritaṃ kṛtrimam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: while he whose friendship is courted for selfmaintenance is an acquired friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arivijigīṣvor bhūmyanantaraḥ saṃhataasaṃhatayor anugrahasamartho nigrahe caasaṃhatayor madhyamaḥ // arivijigīṣumadhyānāṃ bahiḥ prakṛtibhyo balavattaraḥ saṃhataasaṃhatānām arivijigīṣumadhyamānām anugrahasamartho nigrahe caasaṃhatānām udāsīnaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king who occupies a territory close to both the conqueror and his immediate enemy in front and who is capable of helping both the kings, whether united or disunited, or of resisting either of them individually is termed a Madhyama mediatory king He who is situated beyond the territory of any of the above kings and who is very powerful and capable of helping the enemy, the conqueror, and the Madhyama king together or individually, or of resisting any of them individually, is a neutral king udásína,these are the twelve primary kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijigīṣur mitraṃ mitramitraṃ vāasya prakṛtayas tisraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The conqueror, his friend, and his friends friend are the three primary kings constituting a circle of states

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāḥ pañcabhir amātyajanapadadurgakośadaṇḍaprakṛtibhir ekaekaśaḥ samyuktā maṇḍalam aṣṭādaśakaṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As each of these three kings possesses the five elements of sovereignty, such as the minister, the country, the fort, the treasury, and the army, a circle of states consists of eighteen elements

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anena maṇḍalapṛthaktvaṃ vyākhyātam arimadhyamaudāsīnānām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus, it needs no commentary to understand that the three Circles of States having the enemy of the conqueror, the Madhyama king, or the neutral king at the centre of each of the three circles, are different from that of the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ caturmaṇḍalasaṃkṣepaḥ // dvādaśa rājaprakṛtayaḥ ṣaṣṭir dravyaprakṛtayaḥ, saṃkṣepeṇa dvisaptatiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus there are four primary Circles of States, twelve Kautilyas Arthashastra kings, sixty elements of sovereignty, and seventytwo elements of states Each of the twelve primary kings shall have their elements of sovereignty, power, and end

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukhaṃ siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Strength is power, and happiness is the end

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktis trividhā jñānabalaṃ mantraśaktiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Strength is of three kinds power of deliberation is intellectual strength;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośadaṇḍabalaṃ prabhuśaktiḥ, vikramabalam utsāhaśaktiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the possession of a prosperous treasury and a strong army is the strength of sovereignty; and martial power is physical strength

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ siddhis trividhāeva mantraśaktisādhyā mantrasiddhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The end is also of three kinds that which is attainable by deliberation is the end of deliberation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prabhuśaktisādhyā prabhusiddhiḥ, utsāhaśaktisādhyā utsāhasiddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is attainable by the strength of sovereignty is the end of sovereignty; and that which is to be secured by perseverance is the end of martial power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apacito hīnaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in a less degree, inferior;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyaśaktiḥ samaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and in an equal degree, equal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmātśaktiṃ siddhiṃ ca ghaṭetaātmany āveśayitum,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence a king shall always endeavor to augment his own power and elevate his happiness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sādhāraṇo vā dravyaprakṛtiṣv ānantaryeṇa śaucavaśena vā // dūṣyaamitrābhyāṃ vāapakraṣṭuṃ yateta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A king who is equal to his enemy in the matter of his sovereign elements shall, in virtue of his own righteous conduct or with the help of those who are hostile or conspiring against his enemy, endeavor to throw his enemy‟s power into the shade;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā paśyet amitro me śaktiyukto vāgdaṇḍapāruṣyaarthadūṣaṇaiḥ prakṛtīr upahaniṣyati, siddhiyukto vā mṛgayādyūtamadyastrībhiḥ pramādaṃ gamiṣyati, sa viraktaprakṛtir upakṣīṇaḥ pramatto vā sādhyo me bhaviṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or if he thinks That my enemy, possessed as he is of immense power, will yet in the near future, hurt the elements of his own sovereignty, by using contumelious language, by inflicting severe punishments, and by squandering his wealth; that though attaining success for a time yet he will blindly take himself to hunting, gambling, drinking and women; that as his subjects are disaffected, himself powerless Kautilyas Arthashastra and haughty, can overthrow him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigrahaabhiyukto vā sarvasaṃdohenaekasthoadurgastho vā sthāsyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that when attacked, he will take shelter with all his paraphernalia into a fort or elsewhere;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa saṃhatasainyo mitradurgaviyuktaḥ sādhyo me bhaviṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that possessed as he is of a strong army, he will yet fall into my hands, as he has neither a friend nor a fort to help him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balavān vā rājā parataḥ śatrum ucchettukāmaḥ tam ucchidya mām ucchindyād iti balavatā prārthitasya me vipannakarmaārambhasya vā sāhāyyaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that a distant king is desirous to put down his own enemy, and also inclined to help me to put down my own assailable enemy when my resources are poor;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamalipsāyāṃ ca, ity evaṃādiṣu kāraṇeṣv amitrasyaapi śaktiṃ siddhiṃ caicchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that may be invited as a Madhyama king,for these reasons the conqueror may allow his enemy to grow in strength and to attain success for the time being

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nemim ekaantarān rājñaḥ kṛtvā caanantarān arān / nābhim ātmānam āyacchen netā prakṛtimaṇḍale //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Throwing the circumference of the Circle of States beyond his friends territory, and making the kings of those states as the spokes of that circle, the conqueror shall make himself as the nave of that circle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhye hy upahitaḥ śatrur netur mitrasya caubhayoḥ / ucchedyaḥ pīḍanīyo vā balavān api jāyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A reducible or a conquerable enemy will, when placed between a conqueror and the conquerors friend, appear to be growing in strength [Thus ends Chapter Peace and Exertion in Book , The Source of Sovereign States of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṣāḍguṇyasya prakṛtimaṇḍalaṃ yoniḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE Circle of States is the source of the sixfold policy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhivigrahaāsanayānasaṃśrayadvaidhībhāvāḥ ṣāḍguṇyam ity ācāryāḥ // dvaiguṇyam iti vātavyādhiḥ // saṃdhivigrahābhyāṃ hi ṣāḍguṇyaṃ sampadyate iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that peace sandhi, war vigraha observance of neutrality ásana, marching yána, alliance samsraya, and making peace with one and waging war with another are the six forms of statepolicy But Vátavyádhi holds that there are only two forms of policy, peace and war, inasmuch as the six forms result from these two primary forms of policy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṣāḍguṇyam evaetad avasthābhedād iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: While Kautilya holds that as their respective conditions differ, the forms of policy are six

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra paṇabandhaḥ saṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, agreement with pledges is peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apakāro vigrahaḥ // upekṣaṇam āsanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: offensive operation is war; indifference is neutrality; making preparations is marching;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraarpaṇaṃ saṃśrayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: seeking the protection of another is alliance;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhivigrahaupādānaṃ dvaidhībhāvaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and making peace with one and waging war with another, is termed a double policy dvaidhíbháva

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti ṣaḍguṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: These are the six forms

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasmādd hīyamānaḥ saṃdadhīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever is inferior to another shall make peace with him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhyuccīyamāno vigṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever is superior in power shall wage war;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na māṃ paro naahaṃ param upahantuṃ śaktaḥ ity āsīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever thinks no enemy can hurt me, nor am strong enough to destroy my enemy, shall observe neutrality;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guṇaatiśayayukto yāyāt // śaktihīnaḥ saṃśrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever is possessed of necessary means Kautilyas Arthashastra shall march against his enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sahāyasādhye kārye dvaidhībhāvaṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever thinks that help is necessary to work out an end shall make peace with one and wage war with another

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti guṇaavasthāpanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such is the aspect of the six forms of policy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ yasmin vā guṇe sthitaḥ paśyet ihasthaḥ śakṣyāmi durgasetukarmavaṇikpathaśūnyaniveśakhanidravyahastivanakarmāṇy
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, a wise king shall observe that form of policy which, in his opinion, enables him to build forts, to construct buildings and commercial roads, to open new plantations and villages, to exploit mines and timber and elephant forests, and at the same time to harass similar works of his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya caetāni karmāṇy upahantum iti tam ātiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If any two kings hostile to each other find the time of achieving the results of their respective works to be equal, they shall make peace with each other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yasmin vā guṇe sthitaḥ svakarmaṇām upaghātaṃ paśyen naitarasya tasmin na tiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No king shall keep that form of policy, which causes him the loss of profit from his own works, but which entails no such loss on the enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣa kṣayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it is deterioration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ciratareṇaalpataraṃ vṛddhyudayataraṃ vā kṣeṣye, viparītaṃ paraḥ iti jñātvā kṣayam upekṣeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever thinks that in the course of time his loss will be less than his acquisition as contrasted with that of his enemy, may neglect his temporary deterioration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyakālaphalaudaye vā kṣaye saṃdhim upeyāt // yasmin vā guṇe sthitaḥ svakarmavṛddhiṃ kṣayaṃ vā naabhipaśyed etatsthānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That position in which neither progress nor retrogression is seen is stagnation Kautilyas Arthashastra Whoever thinks his stagnancy to be of a shorter duration and his prosperity in the long run to be greater than his enemys may neglect his temporary stagnation

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyakālaphalaudaye vā sthāne saṃdhim upeyād ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that if any two kings, who are hostile to each other and are in a stationary condition expect to acquire equal amount of wealth and power in equal time, they shall make peace with each other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naetad vibhāṣitam iti kauṭilyaḥ // yadi vā paśyet sandhau sthito mahāphalaiḥ svakarmabhiḥ parakarmāṇy upahaniṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of course, says Kautilya, there is no other alternative Or if a king thinks That keeping the agreement of peace, can undertake productive works of considerable importance and destroy at the same time those of my enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parakarmāṇi vā, saṃdhiviśvāsena vā yogaupaniṣatpraṇidhibhiḥ parakarmāṇy upahaniṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or apart from enjoying the results of my own works, shall also enjoy those of my enemy in virtue of the agreement of peace; or can destroy the works of my enemy by employing spies and other secret means;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukhaṃ vā saanugrahaparihārasaukaryaṃ phalalābhabhūyastvena svakarmaṇāṃ parakarmayogaāvahaṃ janam āsrāvayiṣyāmi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by holding out such inducements as a happy dwelling, rewards, remission of taxes, little work and large profits and wages, can empty my enemys country of its population, with which he has been able to carry his own works;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balināatimātreṇa vā saṃhitaḥ paraḥ svakarmaupaghātaṃ prāpsyati, yena vā vigṛhīto mayāsaṃdhatte tenaasya vigrahaṃ dīrghaṃ kariṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or being allied with a king of considerable power, my enemy will have his own works destroyed; or can prolong my enemys hostility with another king whose threats have driven my enemy to seek my protection;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mayā vā saṃhitasya maddveṣiṇo janapadaṃ pīḍayiṣyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or being allied with me, my enemy can harass the country of another king who hates me;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraupahato vāasya janapado mām āgamiṣyati, tataḥ karmasu vṛddhiṃ prāpsyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or oppressed by another king, the subjects of my enemy will immigrate into my country, and can, therefore, achieve the results of my own works very easily;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vipannakarmaārambho vā viṣamasthaḥ paraḥ karmasu na me vikrameta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or being in a precarious condition due to the destruction of his works, my enemy will not be so powerful as to attack me;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parataḥ pravṛttakarmaārambho vā tābhyāṃ saṃhitaḥ karmasu vṛddhiṃ prāpsyāmi, śatrupratibaddhaṃ vā śatruṇā saṃdhiṃ kṛtvā maṇḍalaṃ bhetsyāmi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by exploiting my own resources in alliance with any two friendly kings, can augment my resources; or if a Circle of States is formed by my enemy as one of its members, can divide Kautilyas Arthashastra them and combine with the others;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍaanugraheṇa vā śatrum upagṛhya maṇḍalalipsāyāṃ vidveṣaṃ grāhayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by threats or favour, can catch hold of my enemy, and when he desires to be a member of my own Circle of States, can make him incur the displeasure of the other members

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vidviṣṭaṃ tenaeva ghātayiṣyāmi iti saṃdhinā vṛddhim ātiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and fall a victim to their own fury,if a king thinks thus, then he may increase his resources by keeping peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā paśyet āyudhīyaprāyaḥ śreṇīprāyo vā me janapadaḥ śailavananadīdurgaekadvāraārakṣo vā śakṣyati paraabhiyogaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or if a king thinks That as my country is full of born soldiers and of corporations of fighting men, and as it possesses such natural defensive positions as mountains, forests, rivers, and forts with only one entrance, it can easily repel the attack of my enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viṣayaante durgam aviṣahyam apāśrito vā śakṣyāmi parakarmāṇy upahantuṃ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having taken my stand in my impregnable fortress at the border of my country, can harass the works of my enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanapīḍaupahatautsāho vā paraḥ samprāptakarmaupaghātakālaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or owing to internal troubles and loss of energy, my enemy will early suffer from the destruction of his works;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigṛhītasyaanyato vā śakṣyāmi janapadam apavāhayitum iti vigrahe sthito vṛddhim ātiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when my enemy is attacked by another king, can induce his subjects to immigrate into my country, then he may augment his own resources by keeping open hostility with such an enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā manyeta na me śaktaḥ paraḥ karmāṇy upahantuṃ naahaṃ tasya karmaupaghātī vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or if a king thinks That neither is my enemy strong enough to destroy my works, nor am his;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvavarāhayor iva kalahe vā, svakarmaanuṣṭhānaparo vā vardhiṣye ity āsanena vṛddhim ātiṣṭhet // yadi vā manyeta yānasādhyaḥ karmaupaghātaḥ śatroḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or if he comes to fight with me, like a dog with a boar, can increase his afflictions without incurring any loss in my own works, then he may observe neutrality and augment his own resources Or if a king thinks That by marching my troops it is possible to destroy the works of my enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā manyeta naasmi śaktaḥ parakarmāṇy upahantum,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and as for myself, have made proper arrangements to safeguard my own works, then he may increase his resources by marching

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svakarmaupaghātaṃ vā trātum iti, balavantam āśritaḥ svakarmaanuṣṭhānena kṣayāt sthānaṃ sthānād vṛddhiṃ caākāṅkṣeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Or if a king thinks That am strong enough neither to harass my enemy‟s works nor to defend my own against my enemys attack, then he shall seek protection from a king of superior power and endeavour to pass from the stage of deterioration to that of stagnancy and from the latter to that of progress

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā manyeta saṃdhināekataḥ svakarmāṇi pravartayiṣyāmi, vigraheṇaekataḥ parakarmāṇy upahaniṣyāmi iti dvaidhībhāvena vṛddhim ātiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or if a king thinks That by making peace with one, can work out my own resources, and by waging war with another, can destroy the works of my enemy, then he may adopt that double policy and improve his resources

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ ṣaḍbhir guṇair etaiḥ sthitaḥ prakṛtimaṇḍale / paryeṣeta kṣayāt sthānaṃ sthānād vṛddhiṃ ca karmasu //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus, a king in the circle of sovereign state shall, by adopting the sixfold policy, endeavour to pass from the state of deterioration to that of stagnation and from the latter to that of progress [Thus ends Chapter , The Sixfold Policy and Determination of Deterioration, Stagnation and Progress in Book , The end of the Sixfold Policy of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (saṃśrayavṛtti)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the ninetyninth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhivigrahayos tulyāyāṃ vṛddhau saṃdhim upeyāt // vigrahe hi kṣayavyayapravāsapratyavāyā bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN the advantages derivable from peace and war are of equal character, one should prefer peace; for disadvantages, such as the loss of power and wealth, sojourning, and sin, are everattending upon war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tenaāsanayānayor āsanaṃ vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same holds good in the case of neutrality and war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvaidhībhāvasaṃśrayayor dvaidhībhāvaṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the two forms of policy, double policy and alliance, double policy Kautilyas Arthashastra ie, making peace with one and waging war with another is preferable;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvaidhībhūto hi svakarmapradhāna ātmana evaupakaroti, saṃśritas tu parasyaupakaroti, naātmanaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for whoever adopts the double policy enriches himself, being ever attentive to his own works, whereas an allied king has to help his ally at his own expense

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadbalaḥ sāmantas tadviśiṣṭabalam āśrayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One shall make an alliance with a king who is stronger than ones neighbouring enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadviśiṣṭabalaabhāve tam evaāśritaḥ kośadaṇḍabhūmīnām anyatamenaasyaupakartum adṛṣṭaḥ prayateta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the absence of such a king, one should ingratiate oneself with ones neighbouring enemy, either by supplying money or army or by ceding a part of ones territory and by keeping oneself aloof;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahādoṣo hi viśiṣṭabalasamāgamo rājñām, anyatraarivigṛhītāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for there can be no greater evil to kings than alliance with a king of considerable power, unless one is actually attacked by ones enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśakye daṇḍaupanatavad varteta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A powerless king should behave as a conquered king towards his immediate enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / yadā caasya prāṇaharaṃ vyādhim antaḥkopaṃ śatruvṛddhiṃ mitravyasanam upasthitaṃ vā tannimittām ātmanaś ca vṛddhiṃ paśyet tadā sambhāvyavyādhidharmakāryaapadeśenaapayāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but when he finds that the time of his own ascendancy is at hand due to a fatal disease, internal troubles, increase of enemies, or a friends calamities that are vexing his enemy, then under the pretence of performing some expiatory rites to avert the danger of his enemy, he may get out of the enemys court;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svaviṣayastho vā naupagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or if he is in his own territory, he should not go to see his suffering enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balīyasor vā madhyagatas trāṇasamartham āśrayeta, yasya vāantardhiḥ syāt, ubhau vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or if he is near to his enemy, he may murder the enemy when opportunity affords itself A king who is situated between two powerful kings shall seek protection from the stronger of the two;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhedam ubhayor vā parasparaapadeśaṃ prayuñjīta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or from one of them on whom he can rely; or he may make peace with both of them on equal terms

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārśvastho vā balasthayor āsannabhayāt pratikurvīta // durgaapāśrayo vā dvaidhībhūtas tiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When they are divided, he may pat down each separately by secret or covert means Or, throwing himself under the protection of any two immediate kings of considerable power, he may defend himself against an immediate enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhivigrahakramahetubhir vā ceṣṭeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or, be may adapt himself to circumstances depending upon the causes of peace and war in order

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaamitraāṭavikān ubhayor upagṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or, he may make friendship with traitors, enemies, and wild chiefs who are conspiring against both the kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etayor anyataraṃ gacchaṃs tair evaanyatarasya vyasane praharet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or, pretending to be a close friend of one of them, he may strike the other at the latters weak point by employing enemies, and wild tribes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvābhyām upahato vā maṇḍalaapāśrayas tiṣṭhet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or, having made friendship with both, he may form a Circle of States

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamam udāsīnaṃ vā saṃśrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or, he may make an alliance with the madhyama or the neutral king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena sahaekam upagṛhyaitaram ucchindyād, ubhau vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and with this help he may put down one of them or both

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvābhyām ucchinno vā madhyamaudāsīnayos tatpakṣīyāṇāṃ vā rājñāṃ nyāyavṛttim āśrayeta // tulyānāṃ vā yasya prakṛtayaḥ sukhyeyur enam, yatrastho vā śaknuyād ātmānam uddhartum, yatra vā pūrvapuruṣaucitā gatir āsannaḥ sambandho vā,
