Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or when hurt by both, he may seek protection from a king of righteous character among the madhyama king, the neutral king, and their friends or equals, or from any other king whose subjects are so disposed as to increase his happiness and peace, with whose help he may be able to recover his lost position, with whom his ancestors were in close intimacy, or blood relationship, and in whose kingdom he can find a number of powerful friends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: priyo yasya bhaved yo vā priyoasya kataras tayoḥ / priyo yasya sa taṃ gacched ity āśrayagatiḥ parā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of two powerful kings who are on amicable terms with each other, a king shall make alliance with one of them who likes him and whom he likes; this is the best way of making alliance

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (samahīnajyāyasāṃ guṇaabhiniveśaḥ hīnasaṃdhayah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundredth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER THE CHARACTER OF EQUAL, INFERIOR AND SUPERIOR KINGS;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijigīṣuḥ śaktyapekṣaḥ ṣāḍguṇyam upayuñjīta // samajyāyobhyāṃ saṃdhīyeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A KING desirous of expanding his own power shall make use of the sixfold policy Kautilyas Arthashastra Agreements of peace shall be made with equal and superior kings;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hīnena vigṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and an inferior king shall be attacked

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigṛhīto hi jyāyasā hastinā pādayuddham ivaabhyupaiti // samena caāmaṃ pātram āmenaahatam ivaubhayataḥ kṣayaṃ karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever goes to wage war with a superior king will be reduced to the same condition as that of a footsoldier opposing an elephant Just as the collision of an unbaked mudvessel with a similar vessel is destructive to both, so war with an equal king brings ruin to both

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kumbhenaivaaśmā hīnenaekaantasiddhim avāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Like a stone striking an earthen pot, a superior king attains decisive victory over an inferior king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jyāyāṃś cen na saṃdhim icched daṇḍaupanatavṛttam ābalīyasaṃ vā yogam ātiṣṭhet // samaś cen na saṃdhim icched yāvanmātram apakuryāt tāvanmātram asya pratyapakuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If a superior king discards the proposal of an inferior king for peace, the latter should take the attitude of a conquered king, or play the part of an inferior king towards a superior When a king of equal power does not like peace, then the same amount of vexation as his opponent has received at his hands should be given to him in return;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tejo hi saṃdhānakāraṇam // naataptaṃ lohaṃ lohena saṃdhatta iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it is power that brings about peace between any two kings no piece of iron that is not made redhot will combine with another piece of iron

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hīnaś cet sarvatraanupraṇatas tiṣṭhet saṃdhim upeyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When an inferior king is all submissive, peace should be made with him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āraṇyoagnir iva hi duḥkhaamarṣajaṃ tejo vikramayati // maṇḍalasya caanugrāhyo bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when provoked by causing him troubles and anger, an inferior king, like a wild fire, will attack his enemy and will also be favoured by his Circle of States

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃhitaś cet paraprakṛtayo lubdhakṣīṇaapacaritāḥ pratyādānabhayād vā naupagacchanti iti paśyedd hīnoapi vigṛhṇīyāt // vigṛhītaś cet paraprakṛtayo lubdhakṣīṇaapacaritā vigrahaudvignā vā māṃ naupagacchanti iti paśyej jyāyān api saṃdhīyeta, vigrahaudvegaṃ vā śamayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king in peace with another finds that greedy, impoverished, and oppressed as are the subjects of his ally, they do not yet immigrate into his own territory lest they might be called back by their master, then he should, though of inferior power, proclaim war against his ally Kautilyas Arthashastra When a king at war with another finds that greedy, impoverished, and oppressed as are the subjects of his enemy, still they do not come to his side in consequence of the troubles of war, then he should, though of superior power, make peace with his enemy or remove the troubles of war as far as possible

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanayaugapadyeapi guruvyasanoasmi, laghuvyasanaḥ paraḥ sukhena pratikṛtya vyasanam ātmanoabhiyuñjyād iti paśyej jyāyān api saṃdhīyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When one of the two kings at war with each other and equally involved in trouble finds his own troubles to be greater than his enemys, and thinks that by getting rid of his enemys trouble his enemy can successful wage war with him, then he should, though possessing greater resources, sue for peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhivigrahayoś cet parakarśanam ātmaupacayaṃ vā naabhipaśyej jyāyān apy āsīta // paravyasanam apratikāryaṃ cet paśyedd hīnoapy abhiyāyāt // apratikāryaāsannavyasano vā jyāyān api saṃśrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, either in peace or war, a king finds neither loss to his enemy nor gain to himself, he should, though superior, observe neutrality When a king finds the troubles of his enemy irremediable, he should, though of inferior power, march against the enemy When a king finds himself threatened by imminent dangers or troubles, he should, though superior, seek the protection of another

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhināekato vigraheṇaekataś cet kāryasiddhiṃ paśyej jyāyān api dvaidhībhūtas tiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king is sure to achieve his desired ends by making peace with one and waging war with another, he should, though superior, adopt the double policy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ samasya ṣāḍguṇyaupayogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus it is that the six forms of policy are applied together

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra tu prativiśeṣaḥ // pravṛttacakreṇaākrānto rājñā balavatāabalaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As to their special application When a powerless king finds himself attacked by a powerful king, leading a Circle of States, he should submissively sue for peace on the condition of offering treasure, army, himself or his territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhināupanamet tūrṇaṃ kośadaṇḍaātmabhūmibhiḥ // svayaṃ saṃkhyātadaṇḍena daṇḍasya vibhavena vā / upasthātavyam ity eṣa saṃdhir ātmaāmiṣo mataḥ // senāpatikumārābhyām upasthātavyam ity ayam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Agreement made on the condition that with a fixed number of troops or with the flower of his army, a king should present himself when called for, is peace termed átmámisha, „offering himself as flesh‟ Agreement made on the condition that the commander of the army together with the heirapparent should present himself when called for, is peace styled purushántarasandhi, „peace with hostages other than the king himself‟;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puruṣaantarasaṃdhiḥ syān naātmanāity ātmarakṣaṇaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and it is conducive to selfpreservation, as it does not require the personal attendance of the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekenaanyatra yātavyaṃ svayaṃ daṇḍena vāity ayam / adṛṣṭapuruṣaḥ saṃdhir daṇḍamukhyaātmarakṣaṇaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Agreement made on the condition that the king himself or some one else should march with the army to some place, as required, is peace termed adrishtapurusha, ‘peace with no specified person to serve‟;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mukhyastrībandhanaṃ kuryāt pūrvayoḥ paścime tv arim /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the first two forms of the peace, a woman of rank should be given as an hostage, and in the last, a secret attempt should be made to capture the enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sādhayed gūḍham ity ete daṇḍaupanatasaṃdhayaḥ // kośadānena śeṣāṇāṃ prakṛtīnāṃ vimokṣaṇam / parikrayo bhavet saṃdhiḥ sa eva ca yathāsukham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: these are the forms of peace concluded on the condition of supplying his army When,by offering wealth, the rest of the elements of sovereignty are set free, that peace is termed parikraya, „price‟ Similarly, when peace is concluded by offering money capable of being taken on a mans shoulders, it is termed upagraha, „subsidy‟;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: skandhaupaneyo bahudhā jñeyaḥ saṃdhir upagrahaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and it is of various forms;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niruddho deśakālābhyām atyayaḥ syād upagrahaḥ // viṣahyadānād āyatyāṃ kṣamaḥ strībandhanād api /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Owing to distance and owing to its having been kept long, the amount of the tribute promised may sometimes fall in arrears Yet as such a burden can tolerably be paid in future, this peace is better than the one with a woman given as an hostage

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suvarṇasaṃdhir viśvāsād ekībhāvagato bhavet // viparītaḥ kapālaḥ syād atyādānaabhibhāṣitaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the parties making an agreement of peace are amicably united, it is termed suvarnasandhi, „golden peace‟ Quite reverse from the former is the peace called kapála, „half of a pot,‟ which is concluded on the condition of paying immense quantity of money

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūrvayoḥ praṇayet kupyaṃ hastyaśvaṃ vā garaanvitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the first two, one should send the supply of raw materials, Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 elephants, horses and troops;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tṛtīye praṇayed arthaṃ kathayan karmaṇāṃ kṣayam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the third, money; and in the fourth, one should evade the payment under the plea of loss of results from works;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tiṣṭhec caturtha ity ete kośaupanatasaṃdhayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: these are the forms of peace concluded on the payment of money

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmyekadeśatyāgena śeṣaprakṛtirakṣaṇam / ādiṣṭasaṃdhis tatraiṣṭo gūḍhastenaupaghātinaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When by ceding a part of the territory, the rest of the kingdom with its subjects are kept safe, it is termed ádishta, „ceded,‟ and is of advantage to one who is desirous of destroying thieves and other wicked persons infesting the ceded part

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmīnām āttasārāṇāṃ mūlavarjaṃ praṇāmanam / ucchinnasaṃdhis tatraiṣṭaḥ paravyasanakāṅkṣiṇaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When with the exception of the capital, the whole of the territory, impoverished by exploitation of its resources is ceded, it is termed uchchhinnasandhi, „peace cut off from profit,‟ and is of advantage to one who desires to involve the enemy in troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: phaladānena bhūmīnāṃ mokṣaṇaṃ syād avakrayaḥ / phalaatimukto bhūmibhyaḥ saṃdhiḥ sa paridūṣaṇaḥ // kuryād avekṣaṇaṃ pūrvau paścimau tv ābalīyasam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When by the stipulation of paying the produce of the land, the kingdom is set free, it is termed avakraya, „rent‟ That which is concluded by the promise of paying more than the land yields is paribhúshana, „ornament‟ One should prefer the first; but the last two based upon the payment of the produce should be made only when one is obliged to submit to power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ādāya phalam ity ete deśaupanatasaṃdhayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: These are the forms of peace made by ceding territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svakāryāṇāṃ vaśenaete deśe kāle ca bhāṣitāḥ / ābalīyasikāḥ kāryās trividhā hīnasaṃdhayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: These three kinds of peace are to be concluded by an inferior king in submission to the power of a superior king owing to the peculiar condition of his own works, circumstances and time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (vigṛhyaāsanaṃ saṃdhāyaāsanaṃ vigṛhyayānaṃ saṃdhāyayānaṃ sambhūyaprayāṇam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: NEUTRALITY AFTER PROCLAIMING WAR OR AFTER CONCLUDING A TREATY OF PEACE; Kautilyas Arthashastra MARCHING AFTER PROCLAIMING WAR OR AFTER MAKING PEACE; AND THE MARCH OF COMBINED POWERS

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhivigrahayor āsanaṃ yānaṃ ca vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: NEUTRALITY or marching after proclaiming war or peace has been explained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthānam āsanam upekṣaṇaṃ caity āsanaparyāyāḥ // viśeṣas tu guṇaekadeśe sthānam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Sthána keeping quiet, ásana withdrawal from hostility, and upekshana negligence are synonymous with the word „ásana,‟ „neutrality‟ As to the difference between three aspects of neutrality Keeping quiet, maintaining a particular kind of policy is sthána;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svavṛddhiprāptyartham āsanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: withdrawal from hostile actions for the sake of one‟s own interests is ásana;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upāyānām aprayoga upekṣaṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and taking no steps against an enemy is upekshana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atisaṃdhānakāmayor arivijigīṣvor upahantum aśaktayor vigṛhyaāsanaṃ saṃdhāya vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When two kings, who, though bent on making conquests, are desirous of peace, are unable to proceed, one against the other, they may keep quiet after proclaiming war or after making peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadā vā paśyet svadaṇḍair mitraaṭavīdaṇḍair vā samaṃ jyāyāṃsaṃ vā karśayitum utsahe iti tadā kṛtabāhyaabhyantarakṛtyo vigṛhyaāsīta yadā vā paśyet utsāhayuktā me prakṛtayaḥ saṃhatā vivṛddhāḥ svakarmāṇy avyāhatāś cariṣyanti parasya vā karmāṇy upahaniṣyanti
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king finds it possible to put down by means of his own army, or with the help of a friend, or of wild tribes, another king of equal or superior power, then having set up proper defences against both internal and external enemies, he may keep quiet after proclaiming war When a king is convinced that his own subjects are brave, united, prosperous, and able not only to carry on their own works without interference, but also to harass his enemys works, then he may keep quiet after proclaiming war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadā vā paśyet parasyaapacaritāḥ kṣīṇā lubdhāḥ svacakrastenaaṭavīvyathitā vā prakṛtayaḥ svayam upajāpena vā mām eṣyanti, sampannā me vārttā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king finds that as his enemys subjects are illtreated, impoverished and greedy and are ever being oppressed by the inroads of the army, thieves, and wild tribes, they can be made through intrigue to join his side; or that his own agriculture and Kautilyas Arthashastra commerce are flourishing while those of his enemy are waning;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vipannā parasya, tasya prakṛtayo durbhikṣaupahatā mām eṣyanti;
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that as the subjects of his enemy are suffering from famine, they will immigrate into his own territory;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vipannā me vārttā, sampannā parasya, // taṃ me prakṛtayo na gamiṣyanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that, though his own returns of agriculture and commerce are falling and those of his enemy increasing, his own subjects will never desert him in favour of his enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigṛhya caasya dhānyapaśuhiraṇyāny āhariṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that by proclaiming war, he can carry off, by force, the grains, cattle and gold of his enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svapaṇyaupaghātīni vā parapaṇyāni nivartayiṣyāmi, // paravaṇikpathād vā saravanti mām eṣyanti vigṛhīte,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that he can prevent the import of his enemys merchandise, which was destructive of his own commerce; or that valuable merchandise would come to his own territory, leaving that of his enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naitaram, dūṣyaamitraaṭavīnigrahaṃ vā vigṛhīto na kariṣyati, tair eva vā vigrahaṃ prāpsyati, //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that war being proclaimed, his enemy would be unable to put down traitors, enemies, and wild tribes and other rebels, and would be involved in war with them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraṃ me mitrabhāvy abhiprayāto bahvalpakālaṃ tanukṣayavyayam arthaṃ prāpsyati, guṇavatīm ādeyāṃ vā bhūmim, // sarvasaṃdohena vā mām anādṛtya prayātukāmaḥ kathaṃ na yāyād iti paravṛddhipratighātaarthaṃ pratāpaarthaṃ ca vigṛhyaāsīta
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that his own friend would in a very short time accumulate wealth without much loss and would not fail to follow him in his march, since no friend would neglect the opportunity of acquiring a fertile land and a prosperous friend like himself,then in view of inflicting injuries on his enemy and of exhibiting his own power, he may keep quiet after proclaiming war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam eva hi pratyāvṛtto grasate ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But my teacher says that turning against such a king, his enemy may swallow him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // karśanamātram asya kuryād avyasaninaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: „Not so,‟ says Kautilya, „impoverishment of the enemy who is free from troubles is all that is aimed at when a king keeps quiet after proclaiming war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paravṛddhyā tu vṛddhaḥ samucchedanam // evaṃ parasya yātavyoasmai sāhāyyam avinaṣṭaḥ prayacchet // tasmāt sarvasaṃdohaprakṛtaṃ vigṛhyaāsīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As soon as such a king acquires sufficient strength, he will undertake to destroy the enemy To such a king, the enemy‟s enemy will send help to secure his own personal safety‟ Hence, whoever is provided with necessary strength may keep quiet after proclaiming war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigṛhyaāsanahetuprātilomye saṃdhāyaāsīta // vigṛhyaāsanahetubhir abhyuccitaḥ sarvasaṃdohavarjaṃ vigṛhya yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the policy of keeping quiet after proclaiming war is found productive of unfavourable results, then one shall keep quiet after making peace Kautilyas Arthashastra Whoever has grown in strength in consequence of keeping quiet after proclaiming war should proceed to attack his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadā vā paśyet vyasanī paraḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king finds that his enemy has fallen into troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prakṛtivyasanaṃ vāasya śeeṣaprakṛtibhir apratikāryam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that the troubles of his enemy‟s subjects can by no means be remedied;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svacakrapīḍitā viraktā vāasya prakṛtayaḥ karśitā nirutsāhāḥ parasparād vā bhinnāḥ śakyā lobhayitum,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that as his enemy‟s subjects are oppressed, illtreated, disaffected, impoverished, become effiminate and disunited among themselves, they can be prevailed upon to desert their master;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agnyudakavyādhimarakadurbhikṣanimittaṃ kṣīṇayugyapuruṣanicayarakṣāvidhānaḥ paraḥ iti tadā vigṛhya yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that his enemy‟s country has fallen a victim to the inroads of such calamities, as fire, floods, pestilence epidemics maraka, and famine and is therefore losing the flower of its youth and its defensive power,then he should march after proclaiming war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadā vā paśyet mitram ākrandaś ca me śūravṛddhaanuraktaprakṛtiḥ, viparītaprakṛtiḥ paraḥ pārṣṇigrāhaś caāsāraś ca, śakṣyāmi mitreṇaāsāram ākrandena pārṣṇigrāhaṃ vā vigṛhya yātum iti tadā vigṛhya yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king is so fortunate as to have a powerful friend in front and a powerful ally ákranda in the rear, both with brave and loyal subjects, while the reverse is the case with he enemies both in front and in the rear, and when he finds it possible for his friend to hold his frontal enemy in check, and for his rearally to keep his rearenemy párshnigráha at bay, then he may march after proclaiming war against his frontal enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadā vā phalam ekahāryam alpakālaṃ paśyet tadā pārṣṇigrāhaāsārābhyāṃ vigṛhya yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king finds it possible to achieve the results of victory singlehanded in a very short time, then he may march against his frontal enemy after proclaiming war against his rearenemies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye saṃdhāya yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise he should march after making peace with his rearenemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadā vā paśyet na śakyam ekena yātum avaśyaṃ ca yātavyam iti tadā samahīnajyāyobhiḥ sāmavāyikaiḥ sambhūya yāyād,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king finds himself unable to confront his enemy singlehanded and when it is necessary that he should march, then he should make the expedition in combination with kings of inferior, equal, or superior powers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekatra nirdiṣṭenaaṃśena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the object aimed at is of a definite nature, then the share of spoils should be fixed;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anekatraanirdiṣṭenaaṃśena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but when it is of a manifold or complex Kautilyas Arthashastra nature, then with no fixity in the share of the spoils

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām asamavāye daṇḍam anyatamasmān niviṣṭaaṃśena yāceta // sambhūyaabhigamanena vā nirviśyeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When no such combination is possible, he may request a king either to supply him with the army for a fixed share, or to accompany him for an equal share of the spoils

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhruve lābhe nirdiṣṭenaaṃśena, adhruve lābhaaṃśena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When profit is certain, then they should march with fixed shares of profit; but when it is uncertain, with no fixity of shares

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṃśo daṇḍasamaḥ pūrvaḥ prayāsasama uttamaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Share of profit proportional to the strength of the army is of the first kind; that which is equal to the effort made is the best;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vilopo vā yathālābhaṃ prakṣepasama eva vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shares may be allotted in proportion to the profit earned or to the capital invested

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (yātavyaamitrayor abhigrahacintāḥ kṣayalobhavirāgahetavaḥ prakṛtīnāṃ sāmavāyikaviparimarśah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: CONSIDERATIONS ABOUT MARCHING AGAINST AN ASSAILABLE ENEMY AND A STRONG ENEMY; CAUSES LEADING TO THE DWINDLING, GREED, AND DISLOYALTY OF THE ARMY; AND CONSIDERATIONS ABOUT THE COMBINATION OF POWERS

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyasāmantavyasane yātavyam amitraṃ vāity amitram abhiyāyāt, tatsiddhau yātavyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN two enemies, one an assailable enemy and another a strong enemy, are equally involved in troubles, which of them is to be marched against first? The strong enemy is to be marched against first;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amitrasiddhau hi yātavyaḥ sāhāyyaṃ dadyān naamitro yātavyasiddhau //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: after vanquishing him, the assailable enemy is to be attacked, for, when Kautilyas Arthashastra a strong enemy has been vanquished, an assailable enemy will volunteer of his own accord to help the conqueror;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guruvyasanaṃ yātavyaṃ laghuvyasanam amitraṃ vāiti guruvyasanaṃ saukaryato yāyād ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is to be marched againstan assailable enemy involved in troubles to a greater degree or a strong enemy troubled to a lesser degree? My teacher says that as a matter of easy conquest, the assailable enemy under worse troubles should be marched against first

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // laghuvyasanam amitraṃ yāyāt // laghv api hi vyasanam abhiyuktasya kṛcchraṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya The conqueror should march against the strong enemy under less troubles, for the troubles of the strong enemy, though less, will be augmented when attacked

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: satyaṃ gurv api gurutaraṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: True, that the worse troubles of the assailable enemy will be still worse when attacked

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anabhiyuktas tu laghuvyasanaḥ sukhena vyasanaṃ pratikṛtyaamitro yātavyam abhisaret, pārṣṇiṃ vā gṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But when left to himself, the strong enemy under less troubles will endeavour to get rid of his troubles and unite with the assailable enemy or with another enemy in the rear of the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yātavyayaugapadye guruvyasanaṃ nyāyavṛttiṃ laghuvyasanam anyāyavṛttiṃ viraktaprakṛtiṃ vāiti viraktaprakṛtiṃ yāyāt // guruvyasanaṃ nyāyavṛttim abhiyuktaṃ prakṛtayoanugṛhṇanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there are two assailable enemies, one of virtuous character and under worse troubles, and another of vicious character, under less troubles, and with disloyal subjects, which of them is to be marched against first? When the enemy of virtuous character and under worse troubles is attacked, his subjects will help him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: laghuvyasanam anyāyavṛttim upekṣante,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whereas, the subjects of the other of vicious character and under less troubles will be indifferent

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viraktā balavantam apy ucchindanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Disloyal or indifferent subjects will endeavour to destroy even a strong king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād viraktaprakṛtim eva yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the conqueror should march against that enemy whose subjects are disloyal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣīṇalubdhaprakṛtim apacaritaprakṛtiṃ vāiti kṣīṇalubdhaprakṛtiṃ yāyāt, kṣīṇalubdhā hi prakṛtayaḥ sukhenaupajāpaṃ pīḍāṃ vāupagacchanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is to be marched againstan enemy whose subjects are Kautilyas Arthashastra impoverished and greedy or an enemy whose subjects are being oppressed? My teacher says that the conqueror should march against that enemy whose subjects are impoverished and greedy, for impoverished and greedy subjects suffer themselves to be won over to the other side by intrigue, and are easily excited

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naapacaritāḥ pradhānaavagrahasādhyāḥ ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But not so the oppressed subjects whose wrath can be pacified by punishing the chief men of the State

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // kṣīṇalubdhā hi prakṛtayo bhartari snigdhā bhartṛhite tiṣṭhanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya for though impoverished and greedy, they are loyal to their master and are ready to stand for his cause and to defeat any intrigue against him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anurāge sārvaguṇyam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it is in loyalty that all other good qualities have their strength

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād apacaritaprakṛtim eva yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the conqueror should march against the enemy whose subjects are oppressed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balavantam anyāyavṛttiṃ durbalaṃ vā nyāyavṛttim iti balavantam anyāyavṛttiṃ yāyāt // balavantam anyāyavṛttim abhiyuktaṃ prakṛtayo naanugṛhṇanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which enemy is to be marched againsta powerful enemy of wicked character or a powerless enemy of righteous character? The strong enemy of wicked character should be marched against, for when he is attacked, his subjects will not help him, but rather put him down or go to the side of the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durbalaṃ tu nyāyavṛttim abhiyuktaṃ prakṛtayaḥ parigṛhṇanti, anuniṣpatanti vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But when the enemy of virtuous character is attacked, his subjects will help him or die with him By insulting the good and commending the wicked;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avakṣepeṇa hi satām asatāṃ pragraheṇa ca / abhūtānāṃ ca hiṃsānām adharmyāṇāṃ pravartanaiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by causing unnatural and unrighteous slaughter of life; by neglecting the observance of proper and righteous customs; by doing unrighteous acts and neglecting righteous ones;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: akāryāṇāṃ ca karaṇaiḥ kāryāṇāṃ ca praṇāśanaiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by doing what ought not to be done and not doing what ought to be done;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apradānaiś ca deyānām adeyānāṃ ca sādhanaiḥ // adaṇḍanaiś ca daṇḍyānām adaṇḍyānāṃ ca daṇḍanaiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by not paying what ought to be paid and exacting what ought not to be taken; by not punishing the guilty and severely punishing the less guilty;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agrāhyāṇām upagrāhair grāhyāṇāṃ caanabhigrahaiḥ // anarthyānāṃ ca karaṇair arthyānāṃ ca vighātanaiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by arresting those who are not to be caught hold of and leaving Kautilyas Arthashastra those who are to be arrested; by undertaking risky works and destroying profitable ones;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arakṣaṇaiś ca corebhyaḥ svayaṃ ca parimoṣaṇaiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by not protecting the people against thieves and by robbing them of their wealth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pātaiḥ puruṣakārāṇāṃ karmaṇāṃ guṇadūṣaṇaiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by giving up manly enterprise and condemning good works; by hurting the leaders of the people and despising the worthy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: virodhanaiś ca vṛddhānāṃ vaiṣamyeṇaanṛtena ca / kṛtasyaapratikāreṇa sthitasyaakaraṇena ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by provoking the aged, by crooked conduct, and by untruthfulness; by not applying remedies against evils and neglecting works in hand;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājñaḥ pramādaālasyābhyāṃ yogakṣemavadhena vā / prakṛtīnāṃ kṣayo lobho vairāgyaṃ caupajāyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and by carelessness and negligence of himself in maintaining the security of person and property of his subjects, the king causes impoverishment, greed, and disaffection to appear among his subjects;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣīṇāḥ prakṛtayo lobhaṃ lubdhā yānti virāgatām /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when a people are impoverished, they become greedy; when they are greedy, they become disaffected;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viraktā yānty amitraṃ vā bhartāraṃ ghnanti vā svayam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when disaffected, they voluntarily go to the side of the enemy or destroy their own master

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmāt prakṛtīnāṃ kṣayalobhavirāgakāraṇāni nautpādayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, no king should give room to such causes as would bring about impoverishment, greed or disaffection among his people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utpannāni vā sadyaḥ pratikurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If, however, they appear, he should at once take remedial measures against them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣīṇā lubdhā viraktā vā prakṛtaya iti // kṣīṇāḥ pīḍanaucchedanabhayāt sadyaḥ saṃdhiṃ yuddhaṃ niṣpatanaṃ vā rocayante // lubdhā lobhenaasaṃtuṣṭāḥ paraupajāpaṃ lipsante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which of the three is the worstan impoverished people? greedy people? or disaffected people? An impoverished people are ever apprehensive of oppression and destruction by overtaxation, etc, and are therefore desirous of getting rid of their impoverishment, or of waging war or of migrating elsewhere A greedy people are ever discontented and they yield themselves to the intrigues of an enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viraktāḥ paraabhiyogam abhyuttiṣṭhante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A disaffected people rise against their master along with his Kautilyas Arthashastra enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāsāṃ hiraṇyadhānyakṣayaḥ sarvaupaghātī kṛcchrapratīkāraś ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the dwindling of the people is due to want of gold and grain, it is a calamity fraught with danger to the whole of the kingdom and can be remedied with difficulty

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yugyapuruṣakṣayo hiraṇyadhānyasādhyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The dearth of efficient men can be made up by means of gold and grain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lobha aikadeśiko mukhyaāyattaḥ paraartheṣu śakyaḥ pratihantum ādātuṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Greed is partial and is found among a few chief officers, and it can be got rid of or satisfied by allowing them to plunder an enemys wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: virāgaḥ pradhānaavagrahasādhyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Disaffection or disloyalty virága can be got rid of by putting down the leaders;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niṣpradhānā hi prakṛtayo bhogyā bhavanty anupajāpyāś caanyeṣām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for in the absence of a leader or leaders, the people are easily governed bhogya and they will not take part in the intrigues of enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anāpatsahās tu // prakṛtimukhyapragrahais tu bahudhā bhinnā guptā bhavanty āpatsahāś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a people are too nervous to endure the calamities, they first become dispersed, when their leaders are put down; and when they are kept under restraint, they endure calamities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmavāyikānām api saṃdhivigrahakāraṇāny avekṣya śaktiśaucayuktaiḥ sambhūya yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having well considered the causes which bring about peace or war, one should combine with kings of considerable power and righteous character and march against ones enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktimān hi pārṣṇigrahaṇe yātrāsāhāyyadāne vā śaktaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: „A king of considerable power,‟ means one who is strong enough to put down or capture an enemy in the rear of his friend or to give sufficient help to his friend in his march

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śuciḥ siddhau caasiddhau ca yathāsthitakārīiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: „A king of righteous character,‟ means one who does what one has promised to do, irrespective of good or bad results

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ jyāyasāekena dvābhyāṃ samābhyāṃ vā sambhūya yātavyam iti dvābhyāṃ samābhyāṃ śreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having combined with one of superior power, or with two of equal power among such kings, should the conqueror march against his enemy? It is better to march combined with two kings of equal power;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jyāyasā hy avagṛhītaś carati, samābhyām atisaṃdhānaādhikye vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for, if combined with a king of superior power, the ally appears to move, caught hold of, by his superior, whereas in marching with two kings of equal power, the same will be the result, only, when Kautilyas Arthashastra those two kings are experts in the art of intrigue;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tau hi sukhau bhedayitum,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: besides it is easy to separate them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: duṣṭaś caeko dvābhyāṃ niyantuṃ bhedaupagrahaṃ caupagantum iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when one of them is wicked, he can be put down by the other two and made to suffer the consequence of dissension

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samenaekena dvābhyāṃ hīnābhyāṃ vāiti dvābhyāṃ hīnābhyāṃ śreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Combined with one of equal power or with two of lesser power, should a king march against his enemy? Better to march with two kings of lesser power;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tau hi dvikāryasādhakau vaśyau ca bhavataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the conqueror can depute them to carry out any two different works and keep them under his control

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāryasiddhau tu kṛtaarthāj jyāyaso gūḍhaḥ saapadeśam apasravet / aśuceḥ śucivṛttāt tu pratīkṣetaā visarjanāt // sattrād apasared yattaḥ kalatram apanīya vā /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the desired end is achieved, the inferior king will quietly retire after the satisfaction of his superior Till his discharge, the good conduct of an ally of usually bad character should be closely scrutinised either by suddenly coming out at a critical time from a covert position sattra to examine his conduct, or by having his wife as a pledge for his good conduct

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samād api hi labdhaarthād viśvas tasya bhayaṃ bhavet // jyāyastve caapi labdhaarthaḥ samoapi parikalpate /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Though actuated with feelings of true friendship, the conqueror has reason to fear his ally, though of equal power, when the latter attains success in his mission; having succeeded in his mission, an ally of equal power is likely to change his attitude even towards the conqueror of superior power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhyuccitaś caaviśvāsyo vṛddhiś cittavikāriṇī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An ally of superior power should not be relied upon, for prosperity changes the mind

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśiṣṭād alpam apy aṃśaṃ labdhvā tuṣṭamukho vrajet / anaṃśo vā tatoasyaaṅke prahṛtya dviguṇaṃ haret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Even with little or no share in the spoils, an ally of superior power may go back, appearing contented; but some time afterwards, he may not fail to sit on the lap of the conqueror and carry off twice the amount of share due to him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtaarthas tu svayaṃ netā visṛjet sāmavāyikān / api jīyeta na jayen maṇḍalaiṣṭas tathā bhavet //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having been satisfied with mere victory, the leading conqueror should discharge his allies, having satisfied them with their shares he may allow himself to be conquered by them instead of attempting to conquer them in the matter of spoils;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (saṃhitaprayāṇikaṃ paripaṇitaaparipaṇitaapasṛtāḥ saṃdhayah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE MARCH OF COMBINED POWERS; AGREEMENT OF PEACE WITH OR WITHOUT DEFINITE TERMS; AND PEACE WITH RENEGADES

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijigīṣur dvitīyāṃ prakṛtim evam atisaṃdadhyāt // sāmantaṃ saṃhitaprayāṇe yojayet tvam ito yāhi, aham ito yāsyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE Conqueror should thus overreach the second element, the enemy close to his territoryHe should engage his neighbouring enemy to undertake a simultaneous march with him and tell the enemy Thou, march in that direction, and shall march in this direction;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samāno lābhaḥ iti // lābhasāmye saṃdhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the share in the spoils is equal If the booty is to be equally divided, it is an agreement of peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaiṣamye vikramaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if otherwise, it is overpowering the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhiḥ paripaṇitaś caaparipaṇitaś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An agreement of peace may be made with promise to carry out a definite work paripanita or with no such promise aparipanita

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvam etaṃ deśaṃ yāhi, aham imaṃ deśaṃ yāsyāmi iti paripaṇitadeśaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the agreement is to the effect that Thou, march to that place, and shall march to this place, it is termed an agreement of peace to carry out a work in definite locality

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvam etāvantaṃ kālaṃ ceṣṭasva, aham etāvantaṃ kālaṃ ceṣṭiṣye iti paripaṇitakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When it is agreed upon that Thou, be engaged so long, shall be engaged thus long, it is an agreement to attain an object in a fixed time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvam etāvatkāryaṃ sādhaya, aham idaṃ kāryaṃ sādhayiṣyāmi iti paripaṇitaarthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When it is agreed upon that Thou, try to accomplish that Kautilyas Arthashastra work, and shall try to finish this work, it is an agreement to achieve a definite end

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / yadi vā manyeta śailavananadīdurgam aṭavīvyavahitaṃ chinnadhānyapuruṣavīvadhaāsāram ayavasaindhanaudakam avijñātaṃ prakṛṣṭam anyabhāvadeśīyaṃ vā sainyavyāyāmānām
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the conqueror thinks that my enemy now an ally has to march through an unknown country, which is intersected with mountains, forests, rivers, forts and deserts which is devoid of foodstuffs, people, pastoral grounds, fodder, firewood and water, and which is far away, different from other countries, and not affording suitable grounds for the exercise of his army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alabdhabhaumaṃ vā deśaṃ paro yāsyati, viparītam aham ity etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇitadeśaṃ saṃdhim upeyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and have to traverse a country of quite the reverse description, then he should make an agreement to carry out a work in a definite locality

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / yadi vā manyeta pravarṣauṣṇaśītam ativyādhiprāyam upakṣīṇaāhāraupabhogaṃ sainyavyāyāmānāṃ caauparodhikaṃ kāryasādhanānām ūnam atiriktaṃ vā kālaṃ paraś ceṣṭiṣyate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the conqueror thinks that my enemy has to work with food stuffs falling short and with no comfort during the rainy, hot or cold season, giving rise to various kinds of diseases and obstructing the free exercise of his army during a shorter or longer period of time than necessary for the accomplishment of the work in hand;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītam aham ity etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇitakālaṃ saṃdhim upeyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and have to work during a time of quite the reverse nature, then he should make time a factor of the agreement

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / yadi vā manyeta pratyādeyaṃ prakṛtikopakaṃ dīrghakālaṃ mahākṣayavyayam alpam anarthaanubandham akalyam adharmyaṃ madhyamaudāsīnaviruddhaṃ mitraupaghātakaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the conqueror thinks that my enemy has to accomplish a work which, not lasting but trifling in its nature, enrages his subjects, which requires much expenditure of time and money, and which is productive of evil consequences, unrighteous, repugnant to the Madhyama and neutral kings, and destructive of all friendship;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vā kāryaṃ paraḥ sādhayiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whereas, have to do the reverse, then he should make an agreement to carry out a definite work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ deśakālayoḥ kālakāryayor deśakāryayor deśakālakāryāṇāṃ caavasthāpanāt saptavidhaḥ paripaṇitaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Likewise with space and time, with time and work, with space and work, and with space, time, and work, made as terms of an agreement, it resolves itself into seven forms

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmin prāg evaārabhya pratiṣṭhāpya ca svakarmāṇi parakarmasu vikrameta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Long before making such an agreement, the conqueror has to fix his own work and then attempt to overreach his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / vyasanatvaraavamānaālasyayuktam ajñaṃ vā śatrum atisaṃdhātukāmo deśakālakāryāṇām anavasthāpanāt saṃhitau svaḥ iti saṃdhiviśvāsena paracchidram āsādya prahared ity aparipaṇitaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra When, in order to destroy an enemy who has fallen into troubles and who is hasty, indolent, and not foresighted, an agreement of peace with no terms of time, space, or work is made with an enemy merely for mutual peace, and when under cover of such an agreement, the enemy is caught hold of at his weak points and is struck, it is termed peace with no definite terms aparipanita

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraetad bhavati // sāmantenaeva sāmantaṃ vidvān āyojya vigrahe / tatoanyasya hared bhūmiṃ chittvā pakṣaṃ samantataḥ // saṃdher akṛtacikīrṣā kṛtaśleṣaṇaṃ kṛtavidūṣaṇam avaśīrṇakriyā ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With regard to this there is a saying as follows Having kept a neighbouring enemy engaged with another neighbouring enemy, a wise king should proceed against a third king, and having conquered that enemy of equal power, take possession of his territory Peace with no specific end akritachikírshá, peace with binding terms kritasleshana, the breaking of peace kritavidúshana, and restoration of peace broken apasírnakriyá are other forms of peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikramasya prakāśayuddhaṃ kūṭayuddhaṃ tūṣṇīṃyuddham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Open battle, treacherous battle, and silent battle ie killing an enemy by employing spies when there is no talk of battle at all, are the three forms of battle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti saṃdhivikramau // apūrvasya saṃdheḥ saanubandhaiḥ sāmaādibhiḥ paryeṣaṇaṃ samahīnajyāyasāṃ ca yathābalam avasthāpanam akṛtacikīrṣā // kṛtasya priyahitābhyām ubhayataḥ paripālanaṃ yathāsambhāṣitasya ca nibandhanasyaanuvartanaṃ rakṣaṇaṃ ca kathaṃ parasmān na
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, by making use of conciliation and other forms of stratagem and the like, a new agreement of peace is made and the rights of equal, inferior, and superior powers concerned in the agreement are defined according to their respective positions, it is termed an agreement of peace with no specific end other than selfpreservation When, by the employment of friends at the Courts of each other, the agreement of peace made is kept secure and the terms are invariably observed and strictly maintained so that no dissension may creep among the parties, it is termed peace with binding terms

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhidyeta iti kṛtaśleṣaṇam // parasyaapasaṃdheyatāṃ dūṣyaatisaṃdhānena sthāpayitvā vyatikramaḥ kṛtavidūṣaṇam // bhṛtyena mitreṇa vā doṣaapasṛtena pratisaṃdhānam avaśīrṇakriyā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra When, having proved through the agency of traitors and spies the treachery of a king, who has made an agreement of peace, the agreement is broken, it is termed the breaking of peace When reconciliation is made with a servant, or a friend, or any other renegade, it is termed the restoration of broken peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyāṃ gataāgataś caturvidhaḥ kāraṇād gataāgato,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There are four persons who run away from, and return to, their master one who had reason to run away and to return;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: one who had no reason either to run away or to return;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāraṇād gatoakāraṇād āgato,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and one who had no reason to run away, but had reason to come back

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītaś caiti // svāmino doṣeṇa gato guṇenaāgataḥ parasya guṇena gato doṣeṇaāgata iti kāraṇād gataāgataḥ saṃdheyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He who runs away owing to his masters fault and returns in consideration of his masters good nature, or he who runs away attracted by the good nature of his masters enemy and returns finding fault with the enemy is to be reconciled as he had reason to run away and to return

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svadoṣeṇa gataāgato guṇam ubhayoḥ parityajya akāraṇād gataāgataḥ calabuddhir asaṃdheyaḥ // svāmino doṣeṇa gataḥ parasmāt svadoṣeṇaāgata iti kāraṇād gatoakāraṇād āgataḥ tarkayitavyaḥ paraprayuktaḥ svena vā doṣeṇaapakartukāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever runs away owing to his own fault and returns without minding the good nature either of his old or new master is a fickleminded person having no explanation to account for his conduct, and he should have no terms of reconciliation Whoever runs away owing to his masters fault and returns owing to his own defects, is a renegade who had reason to run away, but none to return and his case is to be well considered before he is taken back Whoever returns deputed by the enemy; or of his own accord, with the intention of hurting his old master, as is natural to persons of such bad character;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasyaucchettāram amitraṃ me jñātvā pratighātabhayād āgataḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or coming to know that his old master is attempting to put down the enemy, his new master, and apprehensive of danger to himself;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraṃ vā mām ucchettukāmaṃ parityajyaānṛśaṃsyād āgataḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or looking on the attempt of his new master to destroy his old master as cruelty, these should be Kautilyas Arthashastra examined;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jñātvā kalyāṇabuddhiṃ pūjayed,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and if he is found to be actuated with good motives, he is to be taken back respectfully;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathābuddhim apakṛṣṭaṃ vāsayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise, he should be kept at a distance

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svadoṣeṇa gataḥ paradoṣeṇaāgata ity akāraṇād gataḥ kāraṇād āgataḥ tarkayitavyaḥ chidraṃ me pūrayiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever runs away owing to his own fault and returns owing to his new masters wickedness is a renegade who had no reason to run away, but had reason to come back;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ucitoayam asya vāsaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: such a person is to be examined

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrair me saṃhitaḥ, śatrubhir vigṛhītaḥ, lubdhakrūrād āvignaḥ śatrusaṃhitād vā parasmāt iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: his own people with me are in friendship with my friends and at enmity with my enemies and are easily excited at the sight of greedy and cruel persons or of a band of enemies, he may treat such a renegade as deserved

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtapraṇāśaḥ śaktihānir vidyāpaṇyatvam āśānirvedo deśalaulyam aviśvāso balavadvigraho vā parityāgasthānam ity ācāryāḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that whoever has failed to achieve profit from his works, lost his strength, or made his learning a commercial article, or is very greedy, inquisitive to see different countries, dead to the feelings of friendship, or has strong enemies, deserves to be abandoned

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhayam avṛttir amarṣa iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But Kautilya says that it is timidity, unprofessional business, and lack of forbearance to do so

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ihaapakārī tyājyaḥ, paraapakārī saṃdheyaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever is injurious to the kings interests should be abandoned, while he who is injurious to the interests of the enemy should be reconciled;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ubhayaapakārī tarkayitavya iti samānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and whoever is injurious to the interests of both the king and his enemy should be carefully examined

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: asaṃdheyena tv avaśyaṃ saṃdhātavye yataḥ prabhāvas tataḥ pratividadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When it is necessary to make peace with a king with whom no peace ought to be made, defensive measures should be taken against that point where he can show his power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saupakāraṃ vyavahitaṃ guptam āyuḥkṣayād iti / vāsayed aripakṣīyam avaśīrṇakriyāvidhau //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In restoring broken peace, a renegade or a person inclined towards the enemy should be kept at such a distance that till the Kautilyas Arthashastra close of his life, he may be useful to the State

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikramayed bhartari vā siddhaṃ vā daṇḍacāriṇam // kuryād amitraaṭavīṣu pratyante vāanyataḥ kṣipet // paṇyaṃ kuryād asiddhaṃ vā siddhaṃ vā tena saṃvṛtam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or, he may be set against the enemy or may be employed as a captain of an army to guard wild tracts against enemies, or thrown somewhere on the boundary Or, he may be employed to carry on a secret trade in new or old commodities in foreign countries and may accordingly be accused of conspiracy with the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atha vā śamayed enam āyatyartham upāṃśunā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or, in the interests of future peace, a renegade who must be put to death may at once be destroyed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aritoabhyāgato doṣaḥ śatrusaṃvāsakāritaḥ // sarpasaṃvāsadharmitvān nityaudvegena dūṣitaḥ // jāyate plakṣabījaāśāt kapotād iva śālmaleḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That kind of wicked character which has from the beginning grown upon a man owing to his association with enemies is as ever fraught with danger as constant living in company with a snake; and is ever threatening with destruction just as a pigeon living on the seeds of plaksha holy figtree is to the salmali silkcotton tree

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udvegajanano nityaṃ paścād api bhayaāvahaḥ // prakāśayuddhaṃ nirdiṣṭe deśe kāle ca vikramaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whenbattle is fought in daylight and in some locality, it is termed an open battle; threatening in one direction, assault in another, destruction of an enemy captured while he was careless or in troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vibhīṣaṇam avaskandaḥ pramādavyasanaardanam // ekatra tyāgaghātau ca kūṭayuddhasya mātṛkā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and bribing a portion of the army and destroying another portion, are forms of treacherous fight; and attempt to win over the chief officers of the enemy by intrigue, is the characteristic of silent battle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (dvaidhībhāvikāḥ saṃdhivikramāh)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Agreement of Peace with or without Definite Terms;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijigīṣur dvitīyāṃ prakṛtim evam upagṛhṇīyāt // sāmantaṃ sāmantena sambhūya yāyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE conqueror may overpower the second member ie, the immediate enemy thus Having combined with a neighbouring king, the conqueror may march against another neighbouring king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā manyeta pārṣṇiṃ me na grahīṣyati, pārṣṇigrāhaṃ vārayiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or if he thinks that my enemy will neither capture my rear nor make an alliance with my assailable enemy against whom am going to march;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya vārayiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for otherwise shall have to fight against great odds;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahvābādhe me pathi kaṇṭakān mardayiṣyati, durgaaṭavyapasāreṣu daṇḍena cariṣyati, yātavyam aviṣahye doṣe saṃdhau vā sthāpayiṣyati, labdhalābhaaṃśo vā śatrūn anyān me viśvāsayiṣyati iti // dvaidhībhūto vā kośena daṇḍaṃ daṇḍena kośaṃ sāmantānām anyatamāl lipseta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: my ally will not only facilitate the collection of my revenue and supplies and put down the internal enemies who are causing me immense trouble, but also punish wild tribes and their followers entrenched in their strongholds, reduce my assailable enemy to a precarious condition or compel him to accept the proffered peace, and having received as much profit as he desires, he will endeavour to endear my other enemies to me, then the conqueror may proclaim war against one and make peace with another and endeavour to get an army for money or money for the supply of an army from among his neighbouring kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ jyāyasoadhikenaaṃśena samāt samena hīnādd hīnenaiti samasaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the kings of superior, equal or inferior power make peace with the conqueror and agree to pay a greater, or equal, or less amount of profit in proportion to the army supplied, it is termed even peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye viṣamasaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is of the reverse character is styled uneven peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor viśeṣalābhād atisaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when the profit is proportionally very high, it is termed deception atisandhi

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasaninam apāyasthāne saktam anarthinaṃ vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīno balasamena lābhena paṇeta // paṇitas tasyaapakārasamartho vikrameta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king of superior power is involved in troubles, or is come to grief or is afflicted with misfortune, his enemy, though of inferior power, may request of him the help of his army in return for a share in the profit proportional to the strength of the army supplied

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā saṃdadhyāt // evaṃbhūto vā hīnaśaktipratāpapūraṇaarthaṃ sambhāvyaarthaabhisārī mūlapārṣṇitrāṇaarthaṃ vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīno balasamād viśiṣṭena
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and otherwise he Kautilyas Arthashastra may accept the terms In view of marching for the purpose of exacting some expected revenue to be utilised in recouping his own strength and resources, an inferior king may request of a superior the help of the latters army for the purpose of guarding the base and the rear of his territory in return for the payment of a greater share in the profit than the strength of the arm supplied deserves

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lābhena paṇeta // paṇitaḥ kalyāṇabuddhim anugṛhṇīyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king to whom such a proposal is made may accept the proposal, if the proposer is of good intentions;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā vikrameta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but otherwise he may declare war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / jātavyasanaprakṛtirandhram upasthitaanarthaṃ vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīno durgamitrapratiṣṭabdho vā hrasvam adhvānaṃ yātukāmaḥ śatrum ayuddham ekaantasiddhiṃ vā lābham ādātukāmo balasamādd hīnena lābhena paṇeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king of inferior power or one who is provided with the aid of forts and friends has to make a short march in order to capture an enemy without waging war or to receive some expected profit, he may request a third king of superior power involved under various troubles and misfortunes the help of the latters army in return for the payment of a share in the profit less than the strength of the army supplied deserves

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paṇitas tasyaapakārasamartho vikrameta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the king to whom this proposal is made is powerful enough to retaliate, he may declare war;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā saṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but otherwise he may accept the proposal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / arandhravyasano vā jyāyān durārabdhakarmāṇaṃ bhūyaḥ kṣayavyayābhyāṃ yoktukāmo dūṣyadaṇḍaṃ pravāsayitukāmo dūṣyadaṇḍam āvāhayitukāmo vā pīḍanīyam ucchedanīyaṃ vā hīnena vyathayitukāmaḥ saṃdhipradhāno vā kalyāṇabuddhir hīnaṃ lābhaṃ pratigṛhṇīyāt // kalyāṇabuddhinā sambhūyaarthaṃ lipseta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king of superior power and free from all troubles is desirous of causing to his enemy loss of men an money in the latters illconsidered undertakings, or of sending his own treacherous army abroad, or bringing his enemy under the clutches of an inimical army, or of causing trouble to a reducible and tottering enemy by setting a inferior king against that enemy, or is desirous of having peace for the sake of peace itself and is possessed of good intentions, he may accept a less share in the profit promise for the army supplied to another and endeavour to make wealth by combining with an ally if the latter is equally of good intentions;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā vikrameta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but otherwise he may declare war against that ally

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ samaḥ samam atisaṃdadhyād anugṛhṇīyād vā // paraanīkasya pratyanīkaṃ mitraaṭavīnāṃ vā, śatror vibhūmīnāṃ deśikaṃ mūlapārṣṇitrāṇaarthaṃ vā samo balasamena lābhena paṇeta // paṇitaḥ kalyāṇabuddhim anugṛhṇīyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra A king may deceive or help his equal as follows When a king proposes peace to another king of equal power on the condition of receiving the help of the latter army strong enough to oppose an enemys army, or to guard the front, centre, and rear of his territory, or to help his friend, or to protect any other wild tracts of his territory in return for the payment of a share in the profit proportionally equal to the strength of the army supplied, the latter may accept the terms if the proposer is of good intentions;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā vikrameta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but otherwise he may declare war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jātavyasanaprakṛtirandhram anekaviruddham anyato labhamāno vā samo balasamādd hīnena lābhena paṇeta // paṇitas tasyaapakārasamartho vikrameta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king of equal power, capable of receiving the help of an army from another quarter requests of another king in troubles due to the diminished strength of the elements of sovereignty, and with many enemies, the help of the latters army in return for the payment of a share in the profit less than the strength of the army supplied deserves, the latter, if powerful, may declare war or accept the terms otherwise

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā saṃdadhyāt // evaṃbhūto vā samaḥ sāmantaāyattakāryaḥ kartavyabalo vā balasamād viśiṣṭena lābhena paṇeta // paṇitaḥ kalyāṇabuddhim anugṛhṇīyāt anyathā vikrameta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king who is under troubles, who has his works at the mercy of his neighbouring kings, and who has yet to make an army, requests of another king of equal power the help of the latters army in return for the payment of a share in the profit greater than the strength of the army supplied deserves, the latter may accept the terms if the proposer is of good intentions but otherwise war may be declared

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / jātavyasanaprakṛtirandhram abhihantukāmaḥ svārabdham ekaantasiddhiṃ vāasya karmaupahantukāmo mūle yātrāyāṃ vā prahartukāmo yātavyādbhūyo labhamāno vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīnaṃ samaṃ vā bhūyo yāceta // / bhūyo vā yācitaḥ svabalarakṣāarthaṃ durdharṣam anyadurgam āsāram aṭavīṃ vā paradaṇḍena marditukāmaḥ prakṛṣṭeadhvani kāle vā paradaṇḍaṃ kṣayavyayābhyāṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, with the desire of putting down a king in troubles due to the diminished strength of the elements of sovereignty, or with the desire of destroying his wellbegun work of immense and unfailing profit, or with the intention of striking him in his own place or on the occasion of marching, one, though frequently getting immense subsidy from an assailable enemy of equal, inferior, or superior power, sends demands to him again and again, Kautilyas Arthashastra then he may comply with the demands of the former if he is desirous of maintaining his own power by destroying with the army of the former an impregnable fortress of an enemy or a friend of that enemy or laying waste the wild tracts of that enemy, or if he is desirous of exposing the army of the ally to wear and tear even in good roads and good seasons, or if he is desirous of strengthening his own army with that of his ally and thereby putting down the ally or winning over the army of the ally

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jyāyān vā hīnaṃ yātavyaapadeśena haste kartukāmaḥ param ucchidya vā tam evaucchettukāmaḥ, tyāgaṃ vā kṛtvā pratyādātukāmo balasamād viśiṣṭena lābhena paṇeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king is desirous of keeping under his power another king of superior or inferior power as an assailable enemy and of destroying the latter after routing out another enemy with the help of the latter, or when he is desirous of getting back whatever he has paid as subsidy, he may send a proposal of peace to another on the condition of paying more than the cost of the army supplied

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paṇitas tasyaapakārasamartho vikrameta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the king to whom this proposal is made is powerful enough to retaliate he may declare war;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā saṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or if otherwise, he may accept the terms;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yātavyasaṃhito vā tiṣṭhet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may keep quiet allied with the assailable enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaamitraaṭavīdaṇḍaṃ vāasmai dadyāt // jātavyasanaprakṛtirandhro vā jyāyān hīnaṃ balasamena lābhena paṇeta // paṇitas tasyaapakārasamartho vikrameta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king of superior power falls into troubles owing to the weakness of the elements of his sovereignty, and requests of an inferior king the help of the latters army in return for the payment of a share in the profit proportionally equal to the strength of the army supplied, the latter, if powerful enough to retaliate, may declare war and if otherwise, accept the terms

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā saṃdadhyāt // evaṃbhūtaṃ hīnaṃ jyāyān balasamādd hīnena lābhena paṇeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A king of superior power may request of an inferior the help of the latters army in return for the payment of a share in the profit less than the cost of the army supplied;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paṇitas tasyaapakārasamartho vikrameta, anyathā saṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the latter, if powerful enough to retaliate, may declare war, or accept the terms otherwise

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ādau budhyeta paṇitaḥ paṇamānaś ca kāraṇam // tato vitarkyaubhayato yataḥ śreyaś tato vrajet //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king who is sued for peace and also the king who offers peace should both consider the motive with which the proposal of Kautilyas Arthashastra 00 peace is made, and adopt that course of action which on consideration seems to be productive of good results

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (yātavyavṛttiḥ anugrāhyamitraviśeṣāh)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and fifth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER THE ATTITUDE OF AN ASSAILABLE ENEMY;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yātavyoabhiyāsyamānaḥ saṃdhikāraṇam ādātukāmo vihantukāmo vā sāmavāyikānām anyatamaṃ lābhadvaiguṇyena paṇeta // paṇamānaḥ kṣayavyayapravāsapratyavāyaparaupakāraśarīraābādhāṃś caasya varṇayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN an assailable enemy who is in danger of being attacked is desirous of taking upon himself the condition which led one king to combine with another against himself, or of splitting them from each other, he may propose peace to one of the kings on the condition of himself paying twice the amount of profit accruing from the combination The agreement having been made, he may describe to that king the loss of men and money, the hardships of sojourning abroad, the commission of sinful deeds, and the misery and other personal troubles to which that king would have been subjected

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannam arthena yojayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the king is convinced of the truth, the amount promised may be paid;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vairaṃ vā parair grāhayitvā visaṃvādayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having made that king to incur enmity with other kings, the agreement itself may be broken off

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / durārabdhakarmāṇaṃ bhūyaḥ kṣayavyayābhyāṃ yoktukāmaḥ svārabdhāṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king is inclined to cause to another, loss of men and money in the illconsidered undertakings of the latter or to frustrate the latter in the attempt of achieving large profits from wellbegun undertakings;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vā yātrāsiddhiṃ vighātayitukāmo mūle yātrāyāṃ vā prahartukāmo yātavyasaṃhitaḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he means to strike another at his anothers own place or while marching; or when he intends to exact subsidy again in combination with the latters assailable enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: punar yācitukāmaḥ pratyutpannaarthakṛcchras tasminn aviśvasto vā tadātve lābham alpam icchet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he is in need of money and does not like to trust to his ally, he may, for Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 the time being, be satisfied with a small amount of profit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraupakāram amitraupaghātam arthaanubandham avekṣamāṇaḥ pūrvaupakārakaṃ kārayitukāmo bhūyas tadātve mahāntaṃ lābham utsṛjyaāyatyām
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king has in view the necessity of helping a friend or of destroying an enemy, or the possibility of acquiring much wealth in return for the present help or when he intends to utilize in future the services of the one now obliged by him, he may reject the offer of large profit at the present in preference of a small gain in future

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaamitrābhyāṃ mūlahareṇa vā jyāyasā vigṛhītaṃ trātukāmas tathāvidham upakāraṃ kārayitukāmaḥ sambandhaavekṣī vā tadātve caāyatyāṃ ca lābhaṃ na pratigṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king means to help another from the clutches of traitors or enemies or of a superior king threatening the very existence of the latter, and intends thereby to set an example of rendering similar help to himself in future, he should receive no profit either at the present or in the future

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtasaṃdhir atikramitukāmaḥ parasya prakṛtikarśanaṃ mitraamitrasaṃdhiviśleṣaṇaṃ vā kartukāmaḥ paraabhiyogātśaṅkamāno lābham aprāptam adhikaṃ vā yāceta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king means to harass the people of an enemy or to break the agreement of peace between a friend and a foe, or when he suspects of anothers attack upon himself, and when owing to any of these causes, he wants to break peace with his ally, he may demand from the latter an enhanced amount of profit long before it is due

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam itaras tadātve caāyatyāṃ ca kramam avekṣeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The latter under these circumstances may demand for a procedure krama either at the present or in the future

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena pūrve vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same procedure explains the cases treated of before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arivijigīṣvos tu svaṃ svaṃ mitram anugṛhṇatoḥ śakyakalyabhavyaārambhisthirakarmaanuraktaprakṛtibhyo viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The conqueror and his enemy helping their respective friends differ according as their friends are such or are not such as undertake possible, praiseworthy or productive works and as are resolute in their undertakings and are provided with loyal and devoted subjects

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śakyaārambhī viṣahyaṃ karmaārabhate, kalyaārambhī nirdoṣam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever undertakes tolerable work is a beginner possible work whoever undertakes an unblemished work is a beginner of praiseworthy work;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhavyaārambhī kalyāṇaudayam // sthirakarmā naasamāpya karmauparamate // anuraktaprakṛtiḥ susahāyatvād alpenaapy anugraheṇa kāryaṃ sādhayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever takes no rest before the Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 completion of the work undertaken is a resolute worker; and whoever has loyal and devoted subjects is in a position to command help and to bring to a successful termination any work without losing anything in the form of favour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ta ete kṛtaarthāḥ sukhena prabhūtaṃ caupakurvanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When such friends are gratified by the enemy or the conqueror, they can be of immense help to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ataḥ pratilomā naanugrāhyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: friends of reverse character should never be helped

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor ekapuruṣaanugrahe yo mitraṃ mitrataraṃ vāanugṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the two, the conqueror and his enemy, both of whom may happen to have a friend in the same person, he who helps a true or a truer friend overreaches the other;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrād ātmavṛddhiṃ hi prāpnoti, kṣayavyayapravāsaparaupakārān itaraḥ // kṛtaarthaś ca śatrur vaiguṇyam eti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for, by helping a true friend, he enriches himself, while the other not only incurs loss of men and money and the hardships of sojourning abroad, but also showers benefits on an enemy who hates the benefactor all the more for his gratification

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamaṃ tv anugṛhṇator yo madhyamaṃ mitraṃ mitrataraṃ vāanugṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever of the two, the conqueror and his enemy, who may happen to have a friend in the same Madhyama king, helps a Madhyama king of true or truer friendship overreaches the other;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrād ātmavṛddhiṃ hi prāpnoti, kṣayavyayapravāsaparaupakārān itaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for, by helping a true friend, he enriches himself, while the other incurs loss of men and money and the difficulties of sojourning abroad

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamaś ced anugṛhīto viguṇaḥ syād amitroatisaṃdhatte // kṛtaprayāsaṃ hi madhyamaamitram apasṛtam ekaarthaupagataṃ prāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a Madhyama king thus helped is devoid of good qualities, then the enemy overreaches the conqueror for, such a Madhyama king, spending his energies on useless undertakings and receiving help with no idea of returning it, withdraws himself away

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tenaudāsīnaanugraho vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same thing holds good with a neutral king under similar circumstances

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamaudāsīnayor balaaṃśadāne yaḥ śūraṃ kṛtaastraṃ duḥkhasaham anuraktaṃ vā daṇḍaṃ dadāti soatisaṃdhīyate // viparītoatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In case of helping with a portion of the army one of the two, a Madhyama or a neutral king, whoever happens to help one who is brave, skillful in handling weapons, and possessed of endurance and friendly feelings will himself be deceived while his enemy, Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 helping one of reverse character, will overreach him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatra tu daṇḍaḥ prahitas taṃ vā caartham anyāṃś ca sādhayati tatra maulabhṛtaśreṇīmitraaṭavībalānām anyatamam upalabdhadeśakālaṃ daṇḍaṃ dadyāt, amitraaṭavībalaṃ vā vyavahitadeśakālam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king achieves this or that object with the assistance of a friend who is to receive the help of his army in return later on, then he may send out of his various kinds of armysuch as hereditary army, hired army, army formed of corporations of people, his friends army and the army composed of wild tribeseither that kind of army which has the experience of all sorts of grounds and of seasons or the army of enemies or of wild tribes, which is far removed in space and time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yaṃ tu manyeta kṛtaartho me daṇḍaṃ gṛhṇīyād, amitraaṭavyabhūmyanṛtuṣu vā vāsayed, aphalaṃ vā kuryād iti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king thinks that, Though successful, my ally may cause my army to move in an enemys territory or in wild tracts, and during unfavourable seasons and thereby he may render it useless to me, then under the excuse of having to employ his army otherwise, he may help his ally in any other way;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍavyāsaṅgaapadeśena naenam anugṛhṇīyāt // evam avaśyaṃ tv anugrahītavye tatkālasaham asmai daṇḍaṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but when he is obliged to lend his army, he may send that kind of his army, which is used to the weather of the time of operation, under the condition of employing it till the completion of the work, and of protecting it from dangers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsamāpteś caenaṃ vāsayed yodhayec ca balavyasanebhyaś ca rakṣet // kṛtaarthāc ca saapadeśam apasrāvayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the ally has finished his work, he should, under some excuse, try to get back his army or he may send to his ally that army which is composed of traitors, enemies, and wild tribes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yātavyena vā saṃdhāyaenam atisaṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having made peace with the allys assailable enemy, he may deceive the ally

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: same hi lābhe saṃdhiḥ syād viṣame vikramo mataḥ // samahīnaviśiṣṭānām ity uktāḥ saṃdhivikramāḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the profit accruing to kings under an agreement, whether they be of equal, inferior, or superior power, is equal to all, that agreement is termed peace sandhi; when unequal, it is termed defeat vikrama Such is the nature of peace and war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (mitrahiraṇyabhūmikarmasaṃdhayaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and Friends that Deserve Help, in Book , The end of the Sixfold Policy of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra mitrasaṃdhiḥ hiraṇyasaṃdhiś ca) saṃhitaprayāṇe mitrahiraṇyabhūmilābhānām uttarauttaro lābhaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: AGREEMENT FOR THE ACQUISITION OF A FRIEND OR GOLD OF the three gains, the acquisition of a friend, of gold, and of territory, accruing from the march of combined powers, that which is mentioned later is better than the one previously mentioned;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrahiraṇye hi bhūmilābhād bhavataḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for friends and gold can be acquired by means of territory;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraṃ hiraṇyalābhāt // yo vā lābhaḥ siddhaḥ śeṣayor anyataraṃ sādhayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: of the two gains, that of a friend and of gold, each can be a means to acquire the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvaṃ caahaṃ ca mitraṃ labhāvahe ity evaṃādidh samasaṃdhiḥ // tvaṃ mitram ity evaṃādir viṣamasaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Agreement under the condition, let us acquire a friend, etc, is termed even peace; when one acquires a friend and the other makes an enemy, etc, it is termed uneven peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor viśeṣalābhād atisaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when one gains more than the other, it is deception

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samasaṃdhau tu yaḥ sampannaṃ mitraṃ mitrakṛcchre vā mitram avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In an even peace ie, agreement on equal terms whoever acquires a friend of good character or relieves an old friend from troubles, overreaches the other;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āpadd hi sauhṛdasthairyam utpādayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for help given in misfortune renders friendship very firm
