oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrakṛcchreapi nityam avaśyam anityaṃ vaśyaṃ vāiti nityam avaśyaṃ śreyaḥ, tadd hi anupakurvad api naapakaroti ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better of the two a friend of longstanding, but unsubmissive nature, or a temporary friend of submissive nature, both being acquired by affording relief from their respective troubles? My teacher says that a longstanding friend of unsubmissive nature is better inasmuch as such a friend, though not helpful, will not create harm

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya a temporary friend of submissive nature is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yāvad upakaroti tāvan mitraṃ bhavati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for such a friend will be a true friend so long as he is helpful;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upakāralakṣaṇaṃ mitram iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the real characteristic of friendship lies in giving help

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaśyayor api mahābhogam anityam alpabhogaṃ vā nityam iti // mahābhogam anityaṃ śreyaḥ, mahābhogam anityam alpakālena mahadupakurvan mahānti vyayasthānāni pratikaroti ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 Which is the better of two submissive friends a temporary friend of large prospects, or a longstanding friend of limited prospects? My teacher says that a temporary friend of large prospects is better inasmuch as such a friend can, in virtue of his large prospects, render immense service in a very short time, and can stand undertakings of large outlay

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // nityam alpabhogaṃ śreyaḥ // mahābhogam anityam upakārabhayād apakrāmati, upakṛtya vā pratyādātum īhate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya a longstanding friend of limited prospects is better, inasmuch as a temporary friend of large prospects is likely to withdraw his friendship on account of material loss in the shape of help given, or is likely to expect similar kind of help in return;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityam alpabhogaṃ sātatyād alpam upakurvan mahatā kālena mahad upakaroti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but a longstanding friend of limited prospects can, in virtue of his longstanding nature, render immense service in the long run

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gurusamutthaṃ mahan mitraṃ laghusamuttham alpaṃ vāiti gurusamutthaṃ mahan mitraṃ pratāpakaraṃ bhavati, yadā cauttiṣṭhate tadā kāryaṃ sādhayati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, a big friend, difficult to be roused, or a small friend, easy to be roused? My teacher says that a big friend, though difficult to be roused, is of imposing nature, and when he rises up, he can accomplish the work undertaken

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // laghusamuttham alpaṃ śreyaḥ // lagusamuttham alpaṃ mitraṃ kāryakālaṃ naatipātayati daurbalyāc ca yathāiṣṭabhogyaṃ bhavati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya a small friend easy to be roused is better, for such a friend will not, in virtue of his ready preparations, be behind the opportune moment of work, and can, in virtue of his weakness in power, be used in any way the conqueror may like;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naitarat prakṛṣṭabhaumam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but not so the other of vast territorial power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikṣiptasainyam avaśyasainyaṃ vāiti vikṣiptaṃ sainyaṃ śakyaṃ pratisaṃhartuṃ vaśyatvād ity ācāryāḥ // naiti kauṭilyaḥ // avaśyasainyaṃ śreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, scattered troops, or an unsubmissive standing army? My teacher says that scattered troops can be collected in time Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 as they are of submissive nature Not so, says Kautilya an unsubmissive standing army is better as it can be made submissive by conciliation and other strategic means;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avaśyaṃ hi śakyaṃ sāmaādibhir vaśyaṃ kartum,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but it is not so easy to collect in time scattered troops as they are engaged in their individual avocations

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puruṣabhogaṃ hiraṇyabhogaṃ vā mitram iti puruṣabhogaṃ mitraṃ śreyaḥ, pruṣabhogaṃ mitraṃ pratāpakaraṃ bhavati, yadā cauttiṣṭhate tadā kāryaṃ sādhayati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, a friend of vast population, or a friend of immense gold? My teacher says that a friend of vast population is better inasmuch as such a friend will be of imposing power and can, when he rises up, accomplish any work undertaken

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya a friend possessing immense gold is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityo hi hiraṇyena yogaḥ kadācid daṇḍena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for possession of gold is ever desirable; but an army is not always required

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍaś ca hiraṇyenaanye ca kāmāḥ prāpyanta iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Moreover armies and other desired objects can be purchased for gold

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hiraṇyabhogaṃ bhūmibhogaṃ vā mitram iti hiraṇyabhogaṃ gatimattvāt sarvavyayapratīkārakaram ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, a friend possessing gold, or a friend possessing vast territory? My teacher says that a friend possessing gold can stand any heavy expenditure made with discretion

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // mitrahiraṇye hi bhūmilābhād bhavata ity uktaṃ purastād //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya for it has already been stated that both friends and gold can be acquired by means of territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād bhūmibhogaṃ mitraṃ śreya iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence a friend of vast territory is far better

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulye puruṣabhoge vikramaḥ kleśasahatvam anurāgaḥ sarvabalalābho vā mitrakulād viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the friend of the conqueror and his enemy happen to possess equal population, their people may yet differ in possession of qualities such as bravery, power of endurance, amicableness, and qualification for the formation of any kind of army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulye hiraṇyabhoge prārthitaarthatā prābhūtyam alpaprayasatā sātatyaṃ ca viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the friends are equally rich in gold, they may yet differ Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 in qualities such as readiness to comply with requests, magnanimous and munificent help, and accessibility at any time and always

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraetad bhavati // nityaṃ vaśyaṃ laghuutthānaṃ pitṛpaitāmahaṃ mahat /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: About this topic, the following sayings are current Long standing, submissive, easy to be roused, coming from fathers and grandfathers, powerful, and never of a contradictory nature, is a good friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: advaidhyaṃ caiti sampannaṃ mitraṃ ṣaḍguṇam ucyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and these are said to be the six qualities of a good friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṛte yad arthaṃ praṇayād rakṣyate yac ca rakṣati / pūrvaupacitasambandhaṃ tan mitraṃ nityam ucyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that friend who maintains friendship with disinterested motives and merely for the sake of friendship and by whom the relationship acquired of old is kept intact, is a longstanding friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvacitramahābhogaṃ trividhaṃ vaśyam ucyate / ekatobhogy ubhayataḥ sarvatobhogi caaparam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that friend whose munificence is enjoyable in various ways is a submissive friend, and is said to be of three formsOne who is enjoyable only by one, one who is enjoyable by two the enemy and the conqueror, and one who is enjoyable by all, is the third;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ādātṛ vā dātrapi vā jīvaty ariṣu hiṃsayā / mitraṃ nityam avaśyaṃ taddurgaaṭavyapasāri ca // anyato vigṛhītaṃ yal laghuvyasanam eva vā / saṃdhatte caupakārāya tan mitraṃ vaśyam adhruvam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that friend who, whether as receiving help or as giving help, lives with an oppressive hand over his enemies, and who possesses a number of forts and a vast army of wild tribes is said to be a longstanding friend of unsubmissive nature; that friend who, either when attacked or when in trouble, makes friendship for the security of his own existence is temporary and submissive friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaarthenaatha sambaddham upakāryavikāri ca / mitrabhāvi bhavaty etan mitram advaidhyam āpadi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that friend who contracts friendship with a single aim in view and who is helpful, immutable, and amicable is a friend never falling foul even in adversity;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrabhāvād dhruvaṃ mitraṃ śatrusādhāraṇāc calam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever is of an amicable nature is a true friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na kasyacid udāsīnaṃ dvayor ubhayabhāvi tat // vijigīṣor amitraṃ yan mitram antardhitāṃ gatam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever sides also with the enemy is a mutable friend and whoever is indifferent to neither the conqueror and his enemy is a friend to both;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: priyaṃ parasya vā rakṣyaṃ pūjyaṃ sambaddham eva vā / anugṛhṇāti yan mitraṃ śatrusādhāraṇaṃ hi tat // prakṛṣṭabhaumaṃ saṃtuṣṭaṃ balavac caālasaṃ ca yat /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that friend who is inimical to the conqueror or who is equally friendly to the conquerors enemy is a harmful friend, whether he is giving help or is capable of helping; whoever helps the enemys friend, protege, or any vulnerable Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 person or a relation of the enemy is a friend common to both the enemy and the conqueror;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udāsīnaṃ bhavaty etad vyasanād avamānitam // arer netuś ca yad vṛddhiṃ daurbalyād anuvartate /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever possesses extensive and fertile territory and is contented, strong, but indolent, will be indifferent towards his ally when the latter becomes despicable under troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ubhayasyaapy avidviṣṭaṃ vidyād ubhayabhāvi tat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever, owing to his own weakness, follows the ascendancy of both the conqueror and his enemy, not incurring enmity with either, is known as a common friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yo mitraṃ samupekṣeta sa mṛtyum upagūhati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever neglects a friend who is being hurt with or without reason and who seeks help with or without reason despises his own danger

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣipram alpo lābhaś cirān mahān iti vā kṣipram alpo lābhaḥ kāryadeśakālasaṃvādakaḥ śreyān ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, an immediate small gain, or a distant large gain? My teacher says that an immediate small gain is better, as it is useful to carry out immediate undertakings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // cirād avinipātī bījasadharmā mahāml lābhaḥ śreyān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya a large gain, as continuous as a productive seed, is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye pūrvaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise an immediate small gain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ dṛṣṭvā dhruve lābhe lābhaaṃśe ca guṇaudayam / svaarthasiddhiparo yāyāt saṃhitaḥ sāmavāyikaiḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus, having taken into consideration the good aspects of a permanent gain or of a share in a permanent gain, should a king, desirous of strengthening himself, march combined with others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (mitrahiraṇyabhūmikarmasaṃdhayaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , Agreement for the Acquisition of a Friend or Gold in the section of Agreement for the Acquisition of a Friend, Gold, or Land and Agreement for Undertaking a Work, in Book , The end of the Sixfold Policy of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra bhūmisaṃdhih)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: AGREEMENT OF PEACE FOR THE ACQUISITION OF LAND

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvaṃ caahaṃ ca bhūmiṃ labhāvahe iti bhūmisaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE agreement made under the condition, Let us acquire land, is an agreement of peace for the acquisition of land

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor yaḥ pratyupasthitaarthaḥ sampannāṃ bhūmim avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the two kings thus entering into an agreement whoever acquires a rich and fertile land withstanding crops overreaches the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulye sampannaalābhe yo balavantam ākramya bhūmim avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte // bhūmilābhaṃ śatrukarśanaṃ pratāpaṃ ca hi prāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The acquisition of rich land being equal, whoever acquires such land by putting down a powerful enemy overreaches the other; for not only does he acquire territory, but also destroys an enemy and thereby augments his own power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durbalādbhūmilābhe satyaṃ saukaryaṃ bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: True, there is beauty in acquiring land by putting down a weak enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durbala eva ca bhūmilābhaḥ, tatsāmantaś ca mitram amitrabhāvaṃ gacchati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but the land acquired will also be poor, and the king in the neighbourhood who has hitherto been a friend, will now become an enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulye balīyastve yaḥ sthitaśatrum utpāṭya bhūmim avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte // durgaavāptir hi svabhūmirakṣaṇam amitraaṭavīpratiṣedhaṃ ca karoti // calaamitrādbhūmilābhe śakyasāmantato viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The enemies being equally strong, he who acquires territory after beating a fortified enemy overreaches the other; for the capture of a fort is conducive to the protection of territory and to the destruction of wild tribes As to the acquisition of land from a wandering enemy, there is the difference of having a powerful or powerless enemy close to the acquired territory;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durbalasāmantā hi kṣipraāpyāyanayogakṣemā bhavati // viparītā balavat sāmantā kośadaṇḍaavacchedanī ca bhūmir bhavati // sampannā nityaamitrā mandaguṇā vā bhūmir anityaamitrāiti sampannā nityaamitrā śreyasī bhūmiḥ sampannā hi kośadaṇḍau sampādayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the land which is close to a powerless enemy is easily maintained while that bordering upon the territory of a powerful enemy has to be kept at the expense of men and money Which is better, the acquisition of a rich land close to a constant enemy, or that of sterile land near to a temporary enemy? My teacher say that a rich land with a constant enemy is Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 better, inasmuch as it yields much wealth to maintain a strong army, by which the enemy can be put down

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // nityaamitraalābhe bhūyān śatrulābho bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya for a rich land creates many enemies, and the constant enemy will ever be an enemy, whether or not he is helped with men and money to conciliate him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anityas tu śatrur upakārād anapakārād vā śāmyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but a temporary enemy will be quiet either from fear or favour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yasyā hi bhūmer bahudurgāś coragaṇair mlecchaaṭavībhir vā nityaavirahitāḥ pratyantāḥ sā nityaamitrā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That land, on the border of which there are a number of forts giving shelter to bands of thieves, Mlechchhas, and wild tribes is a land with a constant enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye tv anityaamitrā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that which is of reverse character is one with a temporary enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alpā pratyāsannā mahatī vyavahitā vā bhūmir iti alpā pratyāsannā śreyasī // sukhā hi prāptuṃ pālayitum abhisārayituṃ ca bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, a small piece of land, not far, or an extensive piece of land, very far? A small piece of land, not far, is better, inasmuch as it can be easily acquired, protected, and defended, whereas the other is of a reverse nature

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyavahitayor api daṇḍadhāraṇāātmadhāraṇā vā bhūmir iti ātmadhāraṇā śreyasī // sā hi svasamutthābhyāṃ kośadaṇḍābhyāṃ dhāryate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the above two kinds of land, which is better, that which can be maintained by itself, or that which requires external armed force to maintain? The former is better, as it can be maintained with the army and money produced by itself, whereas the latter is of a reverse character as a military station

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bāliśāt prājñād vā bhūmilābha iti bāliśādbhūmilābhaḥ śreyān // suprāpyāanupālyā hi bhavati, apratyādeyā ca // viparītā prājñād anuraktā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, acquisition of land from a stupid or a wise king? That acquired from a stupid king is better, as it can be easily acquired and secured, and cannot be taken back, whereas that obtained from a wise king, beloved of his subjects, is of a reverse nature

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pīḍanīyaucchedanīyayor ucchedanīyād bhūmilābhaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Of two enemies, of whom one can only be harassed and another is reducible, acquisition of land from the latter is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ucchedanīyo hy anapāśrayo durbalaapāśrayo vāabhiyuktaḥ kośadaṇḍāv ādāyaapasartukāmaḥ prakṛtibhis tyajyate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when the latter is attacked, he, having little or no help, begins to run away, taking his army and treasure with him, and he is deserted by his subjects;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na pīḍanīyo durgamitrapratiṣṭabdhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whereas the former does not do so, as he has the help of his forts and friends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgapratiṣṭabdhayor api sthalanadīdurgīyābhyāṃ sthaladurgīyād bhūmilābhaḥ śreyān // sthāleyaṃ hi surodhaavamardaavaskandam anihśrāviśatru ca // nadīdurgaṃ tu dviguṇakleśakaram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of two fortified kings, one who has his forts on a plain is more easily reduced than the other owning a fort in the centre of a river; for a fort in a plain can be easily assailed, destroyed or captured along with the enemy in it, whereas a fort, surrounded by a river requires twice as much effort to capture and supplies the enemy with water and other necessaries of life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nadīparvatadurgīyābhyāṃ nadīdurgīyād bbhūmilābhaḥ śreyān // nadīdurgaṃ hi hastistambhasaṃkramasetubandhanaubhiḥ sādhyam anityagāmbhīryam avasrāvy udakaṃ ca // pārvataṃ tu svārakṣaṃ duruparodhi kṛcchraārohaṇam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of two kings, one owning a fort surrounded by a river, and another having mountainous fortifications, seizing the formers land is better, for a fort in the centre of a river can be assailed by a bridge formed of elephants made to stand in a row in the river or by wooden bridges, or by means of boats; and the river will not always be deep and can be emptied of its water, whereas a fort on a mountain is of a selfdefensive nature, and not easy to besiege or to ascend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śilāvṛkṣapramokṣaś ca mahāapakāriṇām // nimnasthalayodhibhyo nimnayodhibhyo bhūmilābhaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when one portion of the army defending it is routed out, the other portions can escape unhurt and such a fort is of immense service, as it affords facilities to throw down heaps of stone and trees over the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthalayodhinas tu sarvadeśakālayodhinaḥ // khanakaākāśayodhibhyaḥ khanakebhyo bhūmilābhaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is easier, seizing land from those who fight on plains, or from those who fight from low grounds? Seizing the land from the latter is easier, inasmuch as they have to fight in time and space of adverse nature whereas the former can fight anywhere and at any time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khanakā hi khātena śastreṇa caubhayathā yudhyante, śastreṇaevaākāśayodhinaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for they can be serviceable inasmuch as they fight from ditches and with weapons in hand, whereas the latter can only fight with weapons in hand

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃvidhyebhyaḥ pṛthivīṃ labhamānoarthaśāstravit / saṃhitebhyaḥ parebhyaś ca viśeṣam adhigacchati //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever, wellversed in the science of polity, wrests land from such and other enemies will outshine both his allies in combination with him and enemies out of combination

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (mitrahiraṇyabhūmikarmasamdhayah tatra anavasitasamdhih)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and eighth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER INTERMINABLE AGREEMENT

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvaṃ caahaṃ ca śūnyaṃ niveśayāvahe ity anavasitasaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE agreement made under the condition, Let us colonize waste land, is termed an interminable agreement

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor yaḥ pratyupasthitaartho yathāuktaguṇāṃ bhūmiṃ niveśayati soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever of the two parties of the agreement colonizes a fertile land, reaping the harvest earlier, overreaches the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraapi sthalam audakaṃ vāiti mahataḥ sthalād alpam audakaṃ śreyaḥ, sātatyād avasthitatvāc ca phalānām // sthalayor api prabhūtapūrvaaparasasyam alpavarṣapākam asaktaārambhaṃ śreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better for colonization a plain or watery land? A limited tract of land with water is far better than a vast plain, inasmuch as the former is conducive to the growth of crops and fruits throughout the year Of plains, that which is conducive to the growth of both early and late crops and which requires less labour and less rain for cultivation is better than the other of reverse character

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: audakayor api dhānyavāpam adhānyavāpātśreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Of watery lands, that which is conducive to the growth of grains is better than another productive of crops other than grains

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor alpabahutve dhānyakāntād alpān mahad adhānyakāntaṃ śreyaḥ // mahaty avakāśe hi sthālyāś caanūpyāś caoṣadhayo bhavanti // durgaādīni ca karmāṇi prabhūtyena kriyante // kṛtrimā hi bhūmiguṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of two watery tracts, one of limited area and conducive to the growth of grains, and another, vast and productive of crops other than grains, the latter is better, inasmuch as it affords vast area not only to grow spices and other medicinal crops, but also to construct forts and other defensive works in plenty for fertility and other qualities of lands are artificial kritrimah

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khanidhānyabhogayoḥ khanibhogaḥ kośakaraḥ, dhānyabhogaḥ kośakoṣṭhaagārakaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the two tracts of land, one rich in grains and another in mines, the latter helps the treasury, while the former can fill both the treasury and the storehouse;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhānyamūlā hi durgaādīnāṃ karmaṇām ārambhāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and besides this, the construction of forts and other buildings requires grains

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahāviṣayavikrayo vā khanibhogaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Still, that kind of land containing mines and which yields precious metals to purchase large tracts of land is far better

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyahastivanabhogayor dravyavanabhogaḥ sarvakarmaṇāṃ yoniḥ prabhūtanidhānakṣamaś ca, viparīto hastivanabhogaḥ ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the two forests, one productive of timber, and another of elephants, the former is the source of all kinds of works and is of immense help in forming a storehouse, while the latter is of reverse character

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // śakyaṃ dravyavanam anekam anekasyāṃ bhūmau vāpayitum, na hastivanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya, for it is possible to plant any of timberforests in many places, but not an elephantforest;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastipradhāno hi paraanīkavadha iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: yet it is on elephants that the destruction of an enemys army depends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinnamanuṣyā bhogyā bhavati, anupajāpyā caanyeṣām, anāpatsahā tu //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the two, communication by water and by land, the former is not longstanding, while the latter can ever be enjoyed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītā śreṇīmanuṣyā, kope mahādoṣā // tasyāṃ cāturvarṇyaniveśe sarvabhogasahatvād avaravarṇaprāyā śreyasī, bāhulyād dhruvatvāc ca kṛṣyāḥ karṣakavatī,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, the land with scattered people or that with a corporation of people? The former is better inasmuch as it can be kept under control and is not susceptible to the intrigues of enemys while the latter is Kautilyas Arthashastra intolerant of calamities and susceptible, of anger and other passions In colonizing a land with four castes, colonization with the lowest caste is better, inasmuch as it is serviceable in various ways, plentiful, and permanent

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛṣyāś caanyeṣāṃ caārambhāṇāṃ prayojakatvāt gorakṣakavatī,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of cultivated and uncultivated tracts, the uncultivated tract may be suitable for various kinds of agricultural operations;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paṇyanicayaṛṇaanugrahād āḍhyavaṇigvatī // bhūmiguṇānām apāśrayaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when it is fertile, adapted for pasture grounds, manufacture of merchandise, mercantile transactions of borrowing and lending, and attractive to rich merchants, it is still far better than a cultivated tract

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgaapāśrayā puruṣaapāśrayā vā bhūmir iti puruṣaapāśrayā śreyasī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better of the two, the tract of land with forts or that which is thickly populated? The latter is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puruṣavad dhi rājyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for that which is thickly populated is a kingdom in all its senses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apuruṣā gaur vandhy eva kiṃ duhīta // / mahākṣayavyayaniveśāṃ tu bhūmim avāptukāmaḥ pūrvam eva kretāraṃ paṇeta durbalam arājabījinaṃ nirutsāham apakṣam anyāyavṛttiṃ vyasaninaṃ daivapramāṇaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: What can a depopulated country like a barren cow be productive of? The king who is desirous of getting back the land sold for colonization to another when the latter has lost his men and money in colonizing it, should first make an agreement with such a purchaser as is weak, baseborn, devoid of energy, helpless, of unrighteous character, addicted to evil ways, trusting to fate, and indiscreet in his actions

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahākṣayavyayaniveśāyāṃ hi bhūmau durbalo rājabījī niviṣṭaḥ sagandhābhiḥ prakṛtibhiḥ saha kṣayavyayenaavasīdati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the colonization of a land entails much expenditure of men and money, and when a weak and baseborn man attempts to colonize it, he will perish along with his people in consequence of his loss of men and money Though strong, a baseborn man will be deserted by his people who do not like him lest they may come to grief under him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balavān arājabījī kṣayavyayabhayād asagandhābhiḥ prakṛtibhis tyajyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: though possessing an army, he cannot employ it if he is devoid of energy; and such an army will perish in consequence of the loss incurred by its master;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośavān apy apakṣaḥ kṣayavyayaanugrahahīnatvān na kutaścit prāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: though possessing wealth, a man who hesitates to part with his Kautilyas Arthashastra money and shows favour to none, cannot find help in any quarter;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyāyavṛttir niviṣṭam apy utthāpayet // sa katham aniviṣṭaṃ niveśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when it is easy to drive out a man of unrighteous character from the colony in which he has firmly established himself, none can expect that a man of unrighteous character would be capable of colonizing a tract of waste land and keeping it secure;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena vyasanī vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the same fact explains the fate of such a colonizer as is addicted to evil ways;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivapramāṇo mānuṣahīno nirārambho vipannakarmaārambho vāavasīdati // yatkiṃcanakārī na kiṃcid āsādayati // sa caeṣāṃ pāpiṣṭhatamo bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever, trusting to fate and putting no reliance on manliness, withdraws himself from energetic work, will perish without undertaking anything or without achieving anything from his undertakings; and whoever is indiscreet in his actions will achieve nothing, and is the worst of the set of the colonizers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatkiṃcidārabhamāṇo hi vijigīṣoḥ kadācic chidram āsādayed ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that an indiscreet colonizer may sometimes betray the weak points of his employer, the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā chidraṃ tathā vināśam apy āsādayed iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But Kautilya says that, just as he betrays the weak points, so also does he facilitate his destruction by the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām alābhe yathā pārṣṇigrāhaupagrahe vakṣyāmas tathā bhūmim avasthāpayet // ity abhihitasaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of such persons to colonize waste lands, the conqueror may arrange for the colonization of waste land in the same way as we shall treat of later on in connection with the Capture of an enemy in the rear The above is what is termed verbal agreement abhihitasandhih

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guṇavatīm ādeyāṃ vā bhūmiṃ balavatā krayeṇa yācitaḥ saṃdhim avasthāpya dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king of immense power compels another to sell a portion of the latters fertile territory of which the former is very fond, then the latter may make an agreement with the former and sell the land

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity anibhṛtasaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This is what is termed unconcealed peace anibhritasandhih

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samena vā yācitaḥ kāraṇam avekṣya dadyāt pratyādeyā me bhūmir vaśyā vā, anayā pratibaddhaḥ paro me vaśyo bhaviṣyati bhūmivikrayād vā mitrahiraṇyalābhaḥ kāryasāmarthyakaro me bhaviṣyati iti // tena hīnaḥ kretā vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king of equal power demands land from another as above, then the latter may sell it after considering whether the Kautilyas Arthashastra land can be recovered by me, or can be kept under my control; whether my enemy can be brought under my power in consequence of his taking possession of the land; and whether can acquire by the sale of the land friends and wealth, enough to help me in my undertakings This explains the case of a king of inferior power, who purchases lands

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ mitraṃ hiraṇyaṃ ca sajanām ajanāṃ ca gām / labhamānoatisaṃdhatte śāstravit sāmavāyikān //E (mitrahiraṇyabhūmikarmasamdhayah,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever, well versed in the science of polity, thus acquires friends, wealth, and territory with or without population will overreach other kings in combination with him [Thus ends Chapter , Interminable Agreement in the section of Agreement for the Acquisition of a Friend, Gold, or Land and Agreement for Undertaking a Work, Book , The End of the Sixfold Policy of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatra karmasamdhih)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: AGREEMENT FOR UNDERTAKING A WORK

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tvaṃ caahaṃ ca durgaṃ kārayāvahe iti karmasaṃdhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN an agreement is made on the condition Let us have a fort built, it is termed agreement for undertaking a work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor yo daivakṛtam aviṣahyam alpavyayaārambhaṃ durgaṃ kārayati soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever of the two kings builds an impregnable fortress on a spot naturally best fitted for the purpose with less labour and expenditure overreaches the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraapi sthalanadīparvatadurgāṇām uttarauttaraṃ śreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of forts such as a fort on a plain, in the centre of a river, and on a mountain, that which is mentioned later is of more advantage Kautilyas Arthashastra than the one previously mentioned;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: setubandhayor apy āhāryaudakāt sahaudakaḥ śreyān // sahaudakayor api prabhūtavāpasthānaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: of irrigational works setubandha, that which is of perennial water is better than that which is fed wit water drawn from other sources; and of works containing perennial water, that which can irrigate an extensive area is better

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyavanayor api yo mahatsāravaddravyaaṭavīkaṃ viṣayaante nadīmātṛkaṃ dravyavanaṃ chedayati soatisaṃdhatte // nadīmātṛkaṃ hi svājīvam apāśrayaś caāpadi bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of timber forests, whoever plants a forest which produces valuable articles, which expands into wild tracts, and which possesses a river on its border overreaches the other, for a forest containing a river is selfdependent and can afford shelter in calamities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastivanayor api yo bahuśūramṛgaṃ durbalaprativeśaṃanantaavakleśi viṣayaante hastivanaṃ badhnāti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of gameforests, whoever plants a forest full of cruel beasts, close to an enemys forest containing wild animals, causing therefore much harm to the enemy, and extending into an elephantforest at the countrys border, overreaches the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraapi bahukuṇṭhaalpaśūrayoḥ alpaśūraṃ śreyaḥ, śūreṣu hi yuddham, alpāḥ śūrā bahūn aśūrān bhañjanti, te bhagnāḥ svasainyaavaghātino bhavanti ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the two countries, one with a large number of effete persons, and another with a small number of brave persons, the latter is better inasmuch as, a few brave persons can destroy a large mass of effete persons whose slaughter brings about the destruction of the entire army of their master

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // kuṇṭhā bahavaḥ śreyāṃsaḥ, skandhaviniyogād anekaṃ karma kurvāṇāḥ sveṣām apāśrayo yuddhe,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya, a large number of effete persons is better, inasmuch as they can be employed to do other kinds of works in the camp to serve the soldiers fighting in battlefields, and to terrify the enemy by its number

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pareṣāṃ durdharṣā vibhīṣaṇāś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is also possible to infuse spirit and enthusiasm in the timid by means of discipline and training

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khanyor api yaḥ prabhūtasārām adurgamārgām alpavyayaārambhāṃ khaniṃ khānayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of mines, whoever exploits with less labour and expenditure a mine of valuable output and of easy communication overreaches the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraapi mahāsāram alpam alpasāraṃ vā prabhūtam iti mahāsāram alpaṃ śreyaḥ, vajramaṇimuktāpravālahemarūpyadhātur hi prabhūtam alpasāram atyargheṇa grasate ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better of the two, a small mine of valuable yield, or a big mine productive of commodities of inferior value? Kautilyas Arthashastra My teacher says that the former is better inasmuch as valuable products, such as diamonds, precious stones, pearls, corals, gold and silver, can swallow vast quantities of inferior commodities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // cirād alpo mahāsārasya kretā vidyate, prabhūtaḥ sātatyād alpasārasya //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya, for there is the possibility of purchasing valuable commodities by a mass of accumulated articles of inferior value, collected from a vast and longstanding mine of inferior commodities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena vaṇikpatho vyākhyātaḥ // tatraapi vāristhalapathayor vāripathaḥ śreyān, alpavyayavyāyāmaḥ prabhūtapaṇyaudayaś ca ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the selection of traderoutes My teacher says that of the two traderoutes, one by water and another by land, the former is better, inasmuch as it is less expensive, but productive of large profit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // samruddhagatir asārvakālikaḥ prakṛṣṭabhayayonir niṣpratīkāraś ca vāripathaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya, for water route is liable to obstruction, not permanent, a source of imminent dangers, and incapable of defence, whereas a landroute is of reverse nature

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāripathe tu kūlasamyānapathayoḥ kūlapathaḥ paṇyapattanabāhulyātśreyān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of waterroutes, one along the shore and another in midocean, the route along, and close to the shore is better, as it touches at many trading porttowns;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nadīpatho vā, sātatyād viṣahyaābādhatvāc ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise river navigation is better, as it is uninterrupted and is of avoidable or endurable dangers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthalapatheapi haimavato dakṣiṇāpathātśreyān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of landroutes, that which leads to the Himalayas is better than that which leads to the south

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // kambalaajinaaśvapaṇyavarjāḥ śaṅkhavajramaṇimuktāsuvarṇapaṇyāś ca prabhūtatarā dakṣiṇāpathe //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Not so, says Kautilya, for with the exception of blankets, skins, and horses, other articles of merchandise such as, conchshells, diamonds, precious stones, pearls and gold are available in plenty in the south

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dakṣiṇāpatheapi bahukhaniḥ sārapaṇyaḥ prasiddhagatir alpavyayavyāyāmo vā vaṇikpathaḥ śreyān, prabhūtaviṣayo vā phalgupuṇyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of routes leading to the south, either that traderoute which Kautilyas Arthashastra traverses a large number of mines which is frequented by people, and which is less expensive or troublesome, or that route by taking which plenty of merchandise of various kinds can be obtained is better

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena pūrvaḥ paścimaś ca vaṇikpatho vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the selection of traderoutes leading either to the east or to the west

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraapi cakrapādapathayoś cakrapatho vipulaārambhatvātśreyān, deśakālasambhāvano vā kharauṣṭrapathaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of a carttrack and a footpath, a carttrack is better as it affords facilities for preparations on a large scale Routes that can be traversed by asses or camels, irrespective of countries and seasons are also good

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ābhyām aṃsapatho vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the selection of traderoutes traversed by men alone amsapatha, shoulderpath, ie, a path traversed by men carrying merchandise on their shoulders

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parakarmaudayo netuḥ kṣayo vṛddhir viparyaye //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is a loss for the conqueror to undertake that kind of work which is productive of benefits to the enemy, while a work of reverse nature is a gain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulye karmapathe sthānaṃ jñeyaṃ svaṃ vijigīṣuṇā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the benefits are equal, the conqueror has to consider that his condition is stagnant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alpaāgamaativyayatā kṣayo vṛddhir viparyaye //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Likewise it is a loss to undertake a work of less output and of a greater outlay, while a work of reverse nature is a gain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samāyavyayatā sthānaṃ karmasu jñeyam ātmanaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the output and outlay of a work are at par, the conqueror has to consider that his condition is stagnant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād alpavyayaārambhaṃ durgaādiṣu mahāudayam // karma labdhvā viśiṣṭaḥ syād ity uktāḥ karmasaṃdhayaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence the conqueror should find out such fortbuilding and other works as, instead of being expensive, are productive of greater profit and power Such is the nature of agreements for undertaking works

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (pārṣṇigrāhcintā)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: CONSIDERATIONS ABOUT AN ENEMY IN THE REAR

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃhatyaarivijigīṣvor amitrayoḥ paraabhiyoginoḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇator yaḥ śaktisampannasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN the conqueror and his enemy simultaneously proceeded to capture the rear of their respective enemies who are engaged in an attack against others, he who captures the rear of one who is possessed of vast resources gains more advantages atisandhatte;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktisampanno hy amitram ucchidya pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt, na hīnaśaktir alabdhalābhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for one who is possessed of vast resources has to put down the rearenemy only after doing away with ones frontal enemy already attacked, but not one who is poor in resources and who has not realised the desired profits

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktisāmye yo vipulaārambhasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte // vipulaārambho hy amitram ucchidya pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt, naalpaārambhaḥ saktacakraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Resources being equal, he who captures the rear of one who has made vast preparations gains more advantages for one who has made vast preparations has to put down the enemy in the rear only after destroying the frontal enemy, but not one whose preparations are made on a small scale and whose movements are, therefore, obstructed by the Circle of States

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ārambhasāmye yaḥ sarvasaṃdohena prayātasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Preparations being equal, he who captures the rear of one who has marched out with all the resources gains more advantages;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūnyamūlo hy asya sukaro bhavati, naikadeśabalaprayātaḥ kṛtapārṣṇipratividhānaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for one whose base is undefended is easy to be subdued, but not one who has marched out with a part of the army after having made arrangements to defend the rear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balaupādānasāmye yaś calaamitraṃ prayātasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Troops taken being of equal strength, he who captures the rear of one who has gone against a wandering enemy gains more advantages;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: calaamitraṃ prayāto hi sukhenaavāptasiddhiḥ pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for one who has marched out against a wandering enemy has to put down the rearenemy only after obtaining an easy Kautilyas Arthashastra victory over the wandering enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na sthitaamitraṃ prayātaḥ // asau hi durgapratihataḥ pārṣṇigrāhe ca pratinivṛttaḥ sthitenaamitreṇaavagṛhyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but not one who has marched out against an entrenched enemy, for one who has marched out against an entrenched enemy will be repelled in his attack against the enemys forts and will, after his return, find himself between the rearenemy, and the frontal enemy who is possessed of strong forts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena pūrve vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the cases of other enemies described before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatrusāmye yo dhārmikaabhiyoginaḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte // dhārmikaabhiyogī hi sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca dveṣyo bhavati, adhārmikaabhiyogī sampriyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Enemies being of equal description, he who attacks the rear of one who has gone against a virtuous king gains more advantages, for one who has gone against a virtuous king will incur the displeasure of even his own people, whereas one who has attacked a wicked king will endear himself to all

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena mūlaharatādātvikakadaryaabhiyogināṃ pārṣṇigrahaṇaṃ vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the consequences of capturing the rear of those who have marched against an extravagant king or a king living from hand to mouth, or a niggardly king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraabhiyoginoḥ pārṣṇigrahaṇe ta eva hetavaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same reasons hold good in the case of those who have marched against their own friends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitram amitraṃ caabhiyuñjānayor yo mitraabhiyoginaḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte // mitraabhiyogī hi sukhenaavāptasiddhiḥ pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there are two enemies, one engaged in attacking a friend and another an enemy, he who attacks the rear of the latter gains more advantages for one who has attacked a friend will, after easily making peace with the friend, proceed against the rearenemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukaro hi mitreṇa saṃdhir naamitreṇa //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it is easier to make peace with a friend than with an enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitram amitraṃ cauddharator yoamitrauddhāriṇaḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte // vṛddhamitro hy amitrauddhārī pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt, naitaraḥ svapakṣaupaghātī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there are two kings, one engaged in destroying a friend, and another an enemy, he who attacks the rear of the former gains more advantages; for one who is engaged in destroying an enemy will have the support of his friends and will thereby put down the rearenemy, but not the former who is engaged in destroying his own side

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor alabdhalābhaapagamane yasyaamitro mahato lābhād viyuktaḥ kṣayavyayaadhiko vā sa pārṣṇigrāhoatisaṃdhatte // labdhalābhaapagamane yasyaamitro lābhena śaktyā hīnaḥ sa pārṣṇigrāhoatisaṃdhatte,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra When the conqueror and his enemy in their attack against the rear of an enemy mean to enforce the payment of what is not due to them, he whose enemy has lost considerable profits and has sustained a great loss of men and money gains more advantages; when they mean to enforce the payment of what is due to them, then he whose enemy has lost profits and army, gains more advantages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yasya vā yātavyaḥ śatror vigrahaapakārasamarthaḥ syāt // pārṣṇigrāhayor api yaḥ śakyaārambhabalaupādānaadhikaḥ sthitaśatruḥ pārśvasthāyī vā soatisaṃdhatte // pārśvasthāyī hi yātavyaabhisāro mūlaābādhakaś ca bhavati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the assailable enemy is capable of retaliation and when the assailants rearenemy, capable of augmenting his army and other resources, has entrenched himself on one of the assailants flanks, then the rearenemy gains more advantages; for a rear enemy on one of the assailants flanks will not only become a friend of the assailable enemy, but also attack the base of the assailant, whereas a rearenemy behind the assailant can only harass the rear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārṣṇigrāhās trayo jñeyāḥ śatroś ceṣṭānirodhakāḥ / sāmantaḥ pṛṣṭhato vargaḥ prativeśau ca pārśvayoḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kings, capable of harassing the rear of an enemy and of obstructing his movements are three the group of kings situated behind the enemy, and the group of kings on his flanks

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arer netuś ca madhyastho durbaloantardhir ucyate /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He who is situated between a conqueror and his enemy is called an antardhi one between two kings;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratighāto balavato durgaaṭavyapasāravān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when such a king is possessed of forts, wild tribes, and other kinds of help, he proves an impediment in the way of the strong

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamaṃ tvarivijigīṣvor lipsamānayor madhyamasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇator labdhalābhaapagamane yo madhyamaṃ mitrād viyojayaty amitraṃ ca mitram āpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the conqueror and his enemy are desirous of catching hold of a madhyama king and attack the latters rear, then he who in his attempt to enforce the promised payment separates the madhyama king from the latters friend and obtains, thereby, an enemy as a friend, gains more advantages;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdheyaś ca śatrur upakurvāṇo, na mitraṃ mitrabhāvād utkrāntam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for an enemy compelled to sue for peace will be of greater help than a friend compelled to maintain the abandoned friendship

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tenaudāsīnalipsā vyākhyātā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the attempt to catch hold of a neutral king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārṣṇigrahaṇaabhiyānayos tu mantrayuddhād abhyuccayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Of attacks from the rear and front, that which affords opportunities of carrying on a treacherous fight mantrayuddha is preferable

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: Kaś/ vyāyāmayuddhe hi kṣayavyayābhyām ubhayor avṛddhiḥ // jitvāapi hi kṣiṇadaṇḍakośaḥ parājito bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that in an open war, both sides suffer by sustaining a heavy loss of men and money; and that even the king who wins a victory will appear as defeated in consequence of the loss of men and money

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // sumahatāapi kṣayavyayena śatruvināśoabhyupagantavyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, even at considerable loss of men and money, the destruction of an enemy is desirable

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulye kṣayavyaye yaḥ purastād dūṣyabalaṃ ghātayitvā nihśalyaḥ paścād vaśyabalo yudhyeta soatisaṃdhatte // dvayor api purastād dūṣyabalaghātinor yo bahulataraṃ śaktimattaram atyantadūṣyaṃ ca ghātayet soatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Loss of men and money being equal, he who entirely destroys first his frontal enemy, and next attacks his rearenemy gains more advantages; when both the conqueror and his enemy are severally engaged in destroying their respective frontal enemies, he who destroys a frontal enemy of deep rooted enmity and of vast resources, gains more advantages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tenaamitraaṭavībalaghāto vyākhyātaḥ // pārṣṇigrāhoabhiyoktā vā yātavyo vā yadā bhavet / vijigīṣus tadā tatra netram etat samācaret // pārṣṇigrāho bhaven netā śatror mitraabhiyoginaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the destruction of other enemies and wild tribes When an enemy in the rear and in the front, and an assailable enemy to be marched against happen together then the conqueror should adopt the following policy The rearenemy will usually lead the conquerors frontal enemy to attack the conquerors friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigrāhya pūrvam ākrandaṃ pārṣṇigrāhaabhisāriṇā // ākrandenaabhiyuñjānaḥ pārṣṇigrāhaṃ nivārayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: then having set the ákranda the enemy of the rearenemy against the rearenemys ally, and, having caused war between them, the conqueror should frustrate the rearenemys designs;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathāākrandaabhisāreṇa pārṣṇigrāhaabhisāriṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise he should provoke hostilities between, the allies of the ákranda and of the rearenemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arimitreṇa mitraṃ ca purastād avaghaṭṭayet / mitramitram areś caapi mitramitreṇa vārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he should also keep his frontal enemys friend engaged in war with his own friend; and with the help of his friends friend, he should avert the attack, threatened by the friend of his enemys friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitramitreṇa caākrandaṃ pārṣṇigrāhān nivārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and with the help of his friends friend, he should prevent his rearenemy attacking the ákranda his rearally;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ maṇḍalam ātmaarthaṃ vijigīṣur niveśayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: thus the conqueror should, through the aid of his friends, bring the Circle of States under his own sway both in his rear and front;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pṛṣṭhataś ca purastāc ca mitraprakṛtisampadā // kṛtsne ca maṇḍale nityaṃ dūtān gūḍhāṃś ca vāsayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he should send messengers and spies to reside in each of the states composing the Circle and having again and again destroyed the strength of his enemies he should keep his counsels concealed, being friendly with his friends;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: asaṃvṛtasya kāryāṇi prāptāny api viśeṣataḥ / nihsaṃśayaṃ vipadyante bhinnaplava ivaudadhau //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the works of him whose counsels are not kept concealed, will, though they may prosper for a time, perish as undoubtedly as a broken raft on the sea

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (hīnaśaktipūraṇam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and eleventh chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmavāyikair evam abhiyukto vijigīṣur yas teṣāṃ pradhānas taṃ brūyāt tvayā me saṃdhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: RECRUITMENT OF LOST POWER WHEN the conqueror is thus attacked by the combined army of his enemies, he may tell their leader shall make peace with you;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: idaṃ hiraṇyam, ahaṃ ca mitram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this is the gold, and am the friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviguṇā te vṛddhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: your gain is doubled;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naarhasy ātmakṣayeṇa mitramukhān amitrān vardhayitum,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: it is not worthy of you to augment at your own expense the power of your enemies who keep a friendly appearance now;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ete hi vṛddhās tvām eva paribhaviṣyanti iti // bhedaṃ vā brūyāt anapakāro yathāaham etaiḥ sambhūyaabhiyuktas tathā tvām apy ete saṃhitabalāḥ svasthā vyasane vāabhiyokṣyante,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for gaining in power, they will put you down in the long run Or he may tell the leader so as to break the combination Just as an innocent person like myself is now attacked by the combined army of these kings, so the very same kings in combination will attack you in weal or woe;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balaṃ hi cittaṃ vikaroti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for power intoxicates the mind;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad eṣāṃ vighātaya iti // bhinneṣu pradhānam upagṛhya hīneṣu vikramayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: hence Kautilyas Arthashastra break their combination The combination being broken, he may set the leader against the weak among his enemies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hīnān anugrāhya vā pradhāne,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or offering inducements, he may set the combined power of the weak against the leader;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā vā śreyoabhimanyeta tathā // vairaṃ vā parair grāhayitvā visaṃvādayet // phalabhūyastvena vā pradhānam upajāpya saṃdhiṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or in whatever way be may find it to be conducive to his own prosperity, in that way he may make the leader incur the displeasure of others, and thus frustrate their attempts; or showing the prospect of a larger profit, he may through intrigue, make peace with their leader

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaubhayavetanāḥ phalabhūyastvaṃ darśayantaḥ sāmavāyikān atisaṃhitāḥ stha ity udddūṣayeyuḥ // duṣṭeṣu saṃdhiṃ dūṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then the recipients of salaries from two states, exhibiting the acquisition of large profits to the leader, may satirise the kings, saying, You are all very well combined If some of the kings of the combination are wicked, they may be made to break the treaty;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaubhayavetanā bhūyo bhedam eṣāṃ kuryuḥ evaṃ tad yad asmābhir darśitam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: then the recipients of salaries from two states may again tell them so as to break the combination entirely This is just what we have already pointed out When the enemies are separated, the conqueror may move forward by catching hold of any of the kings as an ally

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinneṣv anyatamaupagraheṇa ceṣṭeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of a leader, the conqueror may win him over who is the inciter of the combination;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lobhād bhayād vā saṃghātam upāgataṃ vijigīṣor bhītaṃ rājyapratisambaddhaṃ mitraṃ calaamitraṃ vā pūrvān uttaraabhāve sādhayet utsāhayitāram ātmanisargeṇa,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or who is of a resolute mind, or who has endeared himself to his people, or who, from greed or fear, joined the combination, or who is afraid of the conqueror, or whose friendship with the conqueror is based upon some consanguinity of royalty, or who is a friend, or who is a wandering enemy,in the order of enumeration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthirakarmāṇaṃ sāntvapraṇipātena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by conciliation and salutation; him who is of a resolute mind;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anuraktaprakṛtiṃ kanyādānayāpanābhyām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by giving a daughter in marriage or by availing oneself of his youth to beget a son on ones wife?;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lubdham aṃśadvaiguṇyena, bhītam ebhyaḥ kośadaṇḍaanugraheṇa, svato bhītaṃ viśvāsya pratibhūpradānena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: him who is the beloved of his people, by giving twice the amount of profits; him who is greedy, by helping with men and money; him who is afraid of the Kautilyas Arthashastra combination, by giving a hostage to him who is naturally timid;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājyapratisambaddham ekībhāvaupagamanena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by entering into a closer union with him whose friendship is based upon some consanguinity of royalty;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitram ubhayataḥ priyahitābhyām, upakāratyāgena vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by doing what is pleasing and beneficial to both or by abandoning hostilities against him who is a friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: calaamitram avadhṛtam anapakāraupakārābhyām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and by offering help and abandoning hostilities against him who is a wandering enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yo vā yathāayogaṃ bhajeta taṃ tathā sādhayet, sāmadānabhedadaṇḍair vā yathāāpatsu vyākhyāsyāmaḥ // vyasanaupaghātatvarito vā kośadaṇḍābhyāṃ deśe kāle kārye vāavadhṛtaṃ saṃdhim upeyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: one has to win over the confidence of any of the above kings by adopting suitable means or by means of conciliation, gifts, dissension, or threats, as will be explained under Troubles He who is in troubles and is apprehensive of an attack from his enemy, should, on the condition of supplying the enemy with army and money, make peace with the enemy on definite terms with reference to place, time, and work;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣe hīno bandhumitrapakṣaṃ kurvīta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he should also set right any offence he might have given by the violation of a treaty;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgam aviṣahyaṃ vā // durgamitrapratiṣṭabdho hi sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca pūjyo bhavati // mantraśaktihīnaḥ prājñapuruṣaupacayaṃ vidyāvṛddhasamyogaṃ vā kurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if he has no supporters, he should find them among his relatives and friends; or he may build an impregnable fortress, for he who is defended by forts and friends will be respected both by his own and his enemys people Whoever is wanting in the power of deliberation should collect wise men around himself, and associate with old men of considerable learning;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathā hi sadyaḥ śreyaḥ prāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: thus he would attain his desired ends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prabhāvahīnaḥ prakṛtiyogakṣemasiddhau yateta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He who is devoid of a good treasury and army should direct his attention towards the strengthening of the safety and security of the elements of his sovereignty;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: janapadaḥ sarvakarmaṇāṃ yoniḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the country is the source of all those works which are conducive to treasury and army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya sthānam ātmanaś caāpadi durgam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the haven of the king and of his army is a strong fort

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: setubandhaḥ sasyānāṃ yoniḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Irrigational works setubandha are the source of crops;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityaanuṣakto hi varṣaguṇalābhaḥ setuvāpeṣu //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the results of a good shower of rain are ever attained in the case of crops below irrigational works

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaṇikpathaḥ paraatisaṃdhānasya yoniḥ // vaṇikpathena hi daṇḍagūḍhapuruṣaatinayanaṃ śastraāvaraṇayānavāhanakrayaś ca kriyate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The roads of traffic are a means to overreach an enemy; for it is through the roads of traffic that armies and spies are led from one country to another; and that weapons, armour, chariots, and draughtanimals are purchased;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: praveśo nirṇayanaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that entrance and exit in travelling are facilitated

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khaniḥ saṃgrāmaupakaraṇānāṃ yoniḥ, dravyavanaṃ durgakarmaṇāṃ yānarathayoś ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Mines are the source of whatever is useful in battle Timberforests are the source of such materials as are necessary for building forts, conveyances and chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastivanaṃ hastinām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Elephantforests are the source of elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gavaaśvakharauṣṭrāṇāṃ ca vrajaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pasturelands are the source of cows, horses, and camels to draw chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām alābhe bandhumitrakulebhyaḥ samārjanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of such sources of his own, he should acquire them from some one among his relatives and friends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utsāhahīnaḥ śreṇīpravīrapuruṣāṇāṃ coragaṇaāṭavikamlecchajātīnāṃ paraapakāriṇāṃ gūḍhapuruṣāṇāṃ ca yathālābbham upacayaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is destitute of an army, he should, as far as possible, attract to himself the brave men of corporations, of thieves, of wild tribes, of Mlechchhas, and of spies who are capable of inflicting injuries upon enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paramiśraapratīkāram ābalīyasaṃ vā pareṣu prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should also adopt the policy of a weak king towards powerful king in view of averting danger from enemies or friends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ pakṣeṇa mantreṇa dravyeṇa ca balena ca / sampannaḥ pratinirgacchet paraavagraham ātmanaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus with the aid of ones own party, the power of deliberation, the treasury, and the army, one should get rid of the clutches of ones enemies [Thus ends Chapter , Recruitment of Lost Power, in Book , The End of the Sixfold Policy of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (vigṛhyauparodhahetavah daṇḍaupanatavṛttam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: MEASURES CONDUCIVE TO PEACE WITH A STRONG AND PROVOKED ENEMY; AND THE ATTITUDE OF A CONQUERED ENEMY

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durbalo rājā balavatāabhiyuktas tadviśiṣṭabalam āśrayeta yam itaro mantraśaktyā naatisaṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN a weak king is attacked by a powerful enemy, the former should seek the protection of one who is superior to his enemy and whom his enemys power of deliberation for intrigue cannot affect

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyamantraśaktīnām āyattasampado vṛddhasamyogād vā viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of kings who are equal in the power of deliberation, difference should be sought in unchangeable prosperity and in association with the aged

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśiṣṭabalaabhāve samabalais tulyabalasaṃghair vā balavataḥ sambhūya tiṣṭhed yān na mantraprabhāvaśaktibhyām atisaṃdadhyāt
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of a superior king, he should combine with a number of his equals who are equal in power to his enemy and whom his enemys power of purse, army, and intrigue cannot reach

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyamantraprabhāvaśaktīnāṃ vipulaārambhato viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of kings who are equally possessed of the power of purse, army, and intrigue, difference should be sought in their capacity for making vast preparations

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samabalaabhāve hīnabalaiḥ śucibhir utsāhibhiḥ pratyanīkabhūtair balavataḥ sambhūya tiṣṭhed yān na mantraprabhāvautsāhaśaktibhir
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of equals, he should combine with a number of inferior kings who are pure and enthusiastic, who can oppose the enemy, and whom his enemys power of purse, army, and intrigue cannot react Of kings who are equally possessed of enthusiasm and capacity for action, a difference should be sought in the opportunity of securing favourable battle fields

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyautsāhaśaktīnāṃ svayuddhabhūmilābhād viśeṣaḥ // tulyabhūmīnāṃ svayuddhakālalābhād viśeṣaḥ // tulyadeśakālānāṃ yugyaśastraāvaraṇato viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of kings who are equally possessed of favourable battle fields, difference should be sought in their ever being ready for war Of kings who are equal possessed of favourable battlefields and who are equally ready for war, difference should be sought in their possession of weapons and armour necessary for war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sahāyaabhāve durgam āśrayeta yatraamitraḥ prabhūtasainyoapi bhaktayavasaindhanaudakauparodhaṃ na kuryāt svayaṃ ca kṣayavyayābhyāṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of any such help, he should seek shelter inside a fort in which his enemy with a large army can offer no obstruction to the supply of foodstuff, grass, firewood and water, Kautilyas Arthashastra but would sustain a heavy loss of men and money

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tulyadurgāṇāṃ nicayaapasārato viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there are many forts, difference should be sought in their affording facility for the collection of stores and supplies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nicayaapasārasampannaṃ hi manuṣyadurgam icched iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilya is of opinion that one should entrench oneself in a fort inhabited by men and provided with stores and supplies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ebhiḥ kārṇair āśrayeta pārṣṇigrāham āsāraṃ madhyamam udāsīnaṃ vā pratipādayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also for the following reasons, one should shelter oneself in such a fort shall oppose him the enemy with his rearenemys ally or with a madhyama king, or with a neutral king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmantaāṭavikatatkulīnaaparuddhānām anyatamenaasya rājyaṃ hārayiṣyāmi ghātayiṣyāmi vā // kṛtyapakṣaupagraheṇa vāasya durge rāṣṭre skandhaāvāre vā kopaṃ samutthāpayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall either capture or devastate his kingdom with the aid of a neighbouring king, a wild tribe, a scion of his family, or an imprisoned prince; by the help of my partisans with him, shall create troubles in his fort, country or camp; when he is near, shall murder him with weapons, fire, or poison, or any other secret means at my pleasure;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svayaṃadhiṣṭhitena vā yogapraṇidhānena kṣayavyayam enam upaneṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall, cause him to sustain a heavy loss of men and money in works undertaken by himself or made to be undertaken at the instance of my spies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣayavyayapravāsaupatapte vāasya mitravarge sainye vā krameṇaupajāpaṃ prāpsyāmi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall easily sow the seeds of dissension among his friends or his army when they have suffered from loss of men and money;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vīvadhaāsāraprasāravadhena vāasya skandhaāvāraavagrahaṃ kariṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall catch hold of his camp by cutting off supplies and stores going to it;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍaupanayena vāasya randhram utthāpya sarvasaṃdohena prahariṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by surrendering myself to him, shall create some weak points in him and put him down with all my resources;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratihatautsāhena vā yathāiṣṭaṃ saṃdhim avāpsyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having curbed his spirit, shall compel him to make peace with me on my own terms;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mayi pratibaddhasya vā sarvataḥ kopāḥ samutthāsyanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when obstruct his movements troubles arise to him from all sides;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nirāsāraṃ vāasya mūlaṃ mitraaṭavīdaṇḍair uddhātayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when he is helpless, shall slay him with the help of my hereditary army or with his enemys army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahato vā deśasya yogakṣemam ihasthaḥ pālayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall maintain the safety and security of my vast country by entrenching myself within my fort;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svavikṣiptaṃ mitravikṣiptaṃ vā me sainyam ihasthasyaekastham aviṣahyaṃ bhaviṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the army of myself and of my friends will be invincible when collected together in this fort;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nimnakhātarātriyuddhaviśāradaṃ vā me sainyaṃ pathyaābādhamuktam āsanne karma kariṣyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: my army which is trained to fight from valleys, pits, or at night, will bring him into difficulties on his way, when he is engaged in an immediate work;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viruddhadeśakālam ihaāgato vā svayam eva kṣayavyayābhyāṃ na bhaviṣyati, mahākṣayavyayaabhigamyoayaṃ deśo durgaaṭavyapasārabāhulyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: owing to loss of men and money, he will make himself powerless when he arrives here at a bad place and in a bad time; owing to the existence of forts and of wild tribes on the way, he will find this country accessible only at Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 considerable cost of men and money;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pareṣāṃ vyādhiprāyaḥ sainyavyāyāmānām alabdhabhaumaś ca, tam āpadgataḥ pravekṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: being unable to find positions favourable for the exercise of the armies of himself and of his friends, suffering from disease, he will arrive here in distress;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: praviṣṭo vā na nirgamiṣyati iti // kāraṇaabhāve balasamucchraye vā parasya durgam unmucyaapagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having arrived here, he will not return In the absence of such circumstances, or when the enemys army is very strong, one may run away abandoning ones fort

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agnipataṅgavad amitre vā praviśet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that one may rush against the enemy like a moth against a flame;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyatarasiddhir hi tyaktaātmano bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: success in one way or other ie, death or victory is certain for one who is reckless of life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // saṃdheyatām ātmanaḥ parasya caupalabhya saṃdadhīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, having observed the conditions conducive to peace between himself and his enemy, he may make peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye vikrameṇa saṃdhim apasāraṃ vā lipseta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the absence of such conditions, he may, by taking recourse to threats secure peace or a friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdheyasya vā dūtaṃ preṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may send a messenger to one who is likely to accept peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena vā preṣitam arthamānābhyāṃ satkṛtya brūyāt idaṃ rājñaḥ paṇyaagāram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having pleased with wealth and honour the messenger sent by his enemy, he may tell the latter This is the kings manufactory;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: idaṃ devīkumārāṇām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this is the residence of the queen and the princes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: devīkumāravacanāt, idaṃ rājyam ahaṃ ca tvadarpaṇaḥ iti // labdhasaṃśrayaḥ samayaācārikavad bhartari varteta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: myself and this kingdom are at your disposal, as approved of by the queen and the princes Having secured his enemys protection, he should behave himself like a servant to his master by serving the protectors occasional needs

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgaādīni ca karmāṇi āvāhavivāhaputraabhiṣekaaśvapaṇyahastigrahaṇasattrayātrāvihāragamanāni caanujñātaḥ kurvīta
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Forts and other defensive works, acquisition of things, celebration of marriages, installation of the heirapparent, commercial undertakings, capture of elephants, construction of covert places for battle sattra, marching against an enemy, and holding sports,all these he should undertake only at the permission of his protector

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svabhūmyavasthitaprakṛtisaṃdhim upaghātam apasṛteṣu vā sarvam anujñātaḥ kurvīta // duṣṭapaurajānapado vā nyāyavṛttir anyāṃ bhūmiṃ yāceta // duṣyavad upāṃśudaṇḍena vā pratikurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should also obtain his protectors permission before making any agreement with people settled in his country or before punishing those who may run away from his country If the citizens and country people living in his kingdom prove disloyal or inimical to him, he may request of his protector Kautilyas Arthashastra another good country; or he may get rid of wicked people by making use of such secret means as are employed against traitors

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ucitāṃ vā mitrād bhūmiṃ dīyamānāṃ na pratigṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should not accept the offer of a good country even from a friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantripurohitasenāpatiyuvarājānām anyatamam adṛśyamāne bhartari paśyet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Unknown his protector, he may see the protectors minister, high priest, commander of the army or heirapparent

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathāśakti caupakuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should also help his protector as much as he can

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivatasvastivācaneṣu tatparā āśiṣo vācayet // sarvatraātmanisargaṃ guṇaṃ brūyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On all occasions of worshipping gods and of making prayers, be should cause his people to pray for the long life of his protector; and he should always proclaim his readiness to place himself at the disposal of his protector

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samyuktabalavatsevī viruddhaḥ śaṅkitaādibhiḥ / varteta daṇḍaupanato bhartary evam avasthitaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Serving him who is strong and combined with others and being far away from the society of suspected persons, a conquered king should thus always behave himself towards his protector

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (daṇḍaupanāyivṛttam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and thirteenth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anujñātasaṃdhipaṇaudvegakaraṃ balavān vijigīṣamāṇo yataḥ svabhūmiḥ svaṛtuvṛttiś ca svasainyānām, adurgaapasāraḥ śatrurapārṣṇir anāsāraś ca, tato yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: IN view of causing financial trouble to his protector, a powerful vassal king, desirous of making conquests, may, under the permission of his protector, march on countries where the formation of the ground and the climate are favourable for the manœuvre of his army, his enemy having neither forts, nor any other defensive works, and the conqueror himself having no enemies in the rear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye kṛtapratīkāro yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Otherwise in case of enemies in the rear, he Kautilyas Arthashastra should march after making provisions for the defence of his rear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmadānābhyāṃ durbalān upanamayet, bhedadaṇḍābhyāṃ balavataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By means of conciliation and gifts, he should subdue weak kings; and by means of sowing the seeds of dissension and by threats, strong kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niyogavikalpasamuccayaiś caupāyānām anantaraekaantarāḥ prakṛtīḥ sādhayet // grāmaaraṇyaupajīvivrajavaṇikpathaanupālanam ujjhitaapasṛtaapakāriṇāṃ caarpaṇam iti sāntvam ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By adopting a particular, or an alternative, or all of the strategic means, he should subdue his immediate and distant enemies He should observe the policy of conciliation by promising the protection of villages, of those who live in forests, of flocks of cattle, and of the roads of traffic as well as the restoration of those who have been banished or who have run away or who have done some harm

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmidravyakanyādānam abhayasya caiti dānam ācaret //
