Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Gifts of land, of things, and of girls in marriage and absence of fear,by declaring these, he should observe the policy of gifts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmantaāṭavikatatkulīnaaparuddhānām anyatamaupagraheṇa kośadaṇḍabhūmidāyayācanam iti bhedam ācaret // prakāśakūṭatūṣṇīṃyuddhadurgalambhaupāyair amitrapragrahaṇam iti daṇḍam ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By instigating any one of a neighbouring king, a wild chief, a scion of the enemys family, or an imprisoned prince, he should sow the seeds of dissension By capturing the enemy in an open battle, or in a treacherous fight, or through a conspiracy, or in the tumult of seizing the enemys fort by strategic means, he should punish the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam utsāhavato daṇḍaupakāriṇaḥ sthāpayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise he may reinstate those who are possessed of a good treasury and army and who can therefore help him with money;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prajñāvato bhūmyupakāriṇaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as well as those who are wise and who can therefore provide him with lands

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ paṇyapattanagrāmakhanisaṃjātena ratnasāraphalgukupyena dravyahastivanavrajasamutthena yānavāhanena vā yad bahuśa upakaroti tac citrabhogam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever among his friends helps him with gems, precious things, raw materials acquired from commercial towns, villages, and mines, or with conveyances and draughtanimals acquired from timber and elephantforests, and herds of cattle, is a friend Kautilyas Arthashastra affording a variety of enjoyment chitrabhoga;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad daṇḍena kośena vā mahad upakaroti tan mahābhogam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever supplies him with wealth and army is a friend affording vast enjoyment mahábhoga;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad daṇḍakośabhūmībhir upakaroti tat sarvabhogam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever supplies him with army, wealth, and lands is a friend affording all enjoyments sarvabhoga;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad amitram ekataḥ pratikaroti tad ekatobhogi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever safeguards him against a sideenemy is a friend affording enjoyments on one side ekatobhogi;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad amitram āsāraṃ caubhayataḥ pratikaroti tad ubhayatobhogi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever helps also his enemy and his enemys allies is a friend affording enjoyment to both sides ubhayatobhogi;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad amitraāsāraprativeśaāṭavikān sarvataḥ pratikaroti tat sarvatobhogi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and whoever helps him against his enemy, his enemys ally, his neighbour, and wild tribes is a friend affording enjoyment on all sides sarvatobogi

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārṣṇigrāhaś caāṭavikaḥ śatrumukhyaḥ śatrur vā bhūmidānasādhyaḥ kaścid āsādyeta, nirguṇayā bhūmyāenam upagrāhayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he happens to have an enemy in the rear, or a wild chief, or an enemy, or a chief enemy capable of being propitiated with the gift of lands, he should provide such an enemy with a useless piece of land,; an enemy possessed of forts with a piece of land not connected with his conquerors own territory;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apratisambaddhayā durgastham,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a wild chief with a piece of land yielding no livelihood;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratyādeyayā tatkulīnaṃ śatroḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a scion of the enemys family with a piece of land that can be taken back;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apacchinnayā śatror aparuddhaṃ nityaamitrayā śreṇībalam, balavatsāmantayā saṃhatabalam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: an enemys prisoner with a piece of land which is not? snatched from the enemy; a corporation of armed men with a piece of land, constantly under troubles from an enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ubhābhyāṃ yuddhe pratilomam, //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a corporation invincible in war with a piece of land under both the above troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alabdhavyāyāmayāutsāhinam, śūyayāaripakṣīyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: an enemys partisan with waste lands; a banished prince with a piece of land exhausted of its resources;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karśitayāapavāhitam, mahākṣayavyayaniveśayā gatapratyāgatam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a king who has renewed the observance of a treaty of peace after breaking it, with a piece of land which can be colonized at considerable cost of men and money;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anapāśrayayā pratyapasṛtam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a deserted prince with a piece of land which affords no protection, and his own protector with an uninhabitable piece of land

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pareṇaanadhivāsyayā svayam eva bhartāram upagrāhayet // teṣāṃ mahāupakāraṃ nirvikāraṃ caanuvartayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king who is desirous of making conquests should Kautilyas Arthashastra continue in following the same policy towards him, who, among the above kings, is most helpful and keeps the same attitude;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratilomam upāṃśunā sādhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: should by secret means bring him round who is opposed;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upakāriṇam upakāraśaktyā toṣayet // prayāsataś caarthamānau kuryād,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: should favour the helpful with facilities for giving further help, besides bestowing rewards and honour at all costs upon him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasaneṣu caanugraham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: should give relief to him who is under troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svayaṃāgatānāṃ yathāiṣṭadarśanaṃ pratividhānaṃ ca kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: should receive visitors at their own choice and afford satisfaction to them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paribhavaupaghātakutsaativādāṃś caeṣu na prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: should avoid using contemptuous, threatening, defamatory, or harsh words towards them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dattvā caabhayaṃ pitāivaanugṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: should like a father protect those who are promised security from fear;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yaś caasyaapakuryāt tad doṣam abhivikhyāpya prakāśam enaṃ ghātayet // paraudvegakāraṇād vā dāṇḍakarmikavac ceṣṭeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: should punish the guilty after publishing their guilt; and in order to avoid causing suspicion to the protector, the vassalking should adopt the procedure of inflicting secret punishments upon offenders

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na ca hatasya bhūmidravyaputradārān abhimanyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should never covet the land, things, and sons and wives of the king slain by him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kulyān apy asya sveṣu pātreṣu sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he should reinstate in their own estates the relatives of the kings slain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karmaṇi mṛtasya putraṃ rājye sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should install in the kingdom the heirapparent of the king who has died while working with the conqueror;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam asya daṇḍaupanatāḥ putrapautrān anuvartante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: all conquered kings will, if thus treated, loyally follow the sons and grandsons of the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yas tuupanatān hatvā baddhvā vā bhūmidravyaputradārān abhimanyeta tasyaudvignaṃ maṇḍalam abhāvāyauttiṣṭhate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever covets the lands, things, sons, and wives of the kings whom he has either slain or bound in chains will cause provocation to the Circle of States and make it rise against himself;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ye caasyaamātyāḥ svabhūmiṣv āyattās te caasyaudvignā maṇḍalam āśrayante // svayaṃ vā rājyaṃ prāṇān vāasyaabhimanyante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: also his own ministers employed in his own territory will be provoked and will seek shelter under the circle of states, having an eye upon his life and kingdom

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svabhūmiṣu ca rājānas tasmāt sāmnāanupālitāḥ / bhavanty anuguṇā rājñaḥ putrapautraanuvartinaḥ //E (samdhikarma samādhimokṣah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence conquered kings preserved in their own lands in accordance with the policy of conciliation will be loyal to the conqueror and follow his sons and grandsons [Thus ends Chapter , The Attitude of a Conquered King, in Book , The End of the Sixfold Policy, of the Arthasástra of Kautilyas Arthashastra Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śamaḥ saṃdhiḥ samādhir ity ekoarthaḥ // rājñāṃ viśvāsaupagamaḥ śamaḥ saṃdhiḥ samādhir iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: MAKING PEACE AND BREAKING IT THE words sama quiet, sandhi agreement of peace, and samádhi reconcilement, are synonymous That which is conducive to mutual faith among kings is termed sama, sandhi, or samádhi

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratibhūḥ pratigraho vā sthāvaraḥ ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that peace, depended upon honesty or oath, is mutable, while peace with a security or an hostage is immutable

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // satyaṃ śapatho vā paratraiha ca sthāvaraḥ saṃdhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, peace, dependent upon honesty or oath is immutable both in this and the next world

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ihaartha eva pratibhūḥ pratigraho vā balaapekṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is for this world only that a security or an hostage is required for strengthening the agreement

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃhitāḥ smaḥ iti satyasaṃdhāḥ pūrve rājānaḥ satyena saṃdadhire // / tasyaatikrame śapathena agnyudakasītāprākāraloṣṭahastiskandhaaśvapṛṣṭarathaupasthaśastraratnabījagandharasasuvarṇahiraṇyāny ālebhire hanyur etāni tyajeyuś caenaṃ yaḥ śapatham atikrāmet iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Honest kings of old made their agreement of peace with this declaration We have joined in peace In case of any apprehension of breach of honesty, they made their agreement by swearing by fire, water, plough, the brick of a fortwall, the shoulder of an elephant, the hips of a horse, the front of a chariot, a weapon, seeds, scents, juice rasa, wrought gold suvarna, or bullion gold hiranya, and by declaring that these things will destroy and desert him who violates the oath

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śapathaatikrame mahatāṃ tapasvināṃ mukhyānāṃ vā prātibhāvyabandhaḥ pratibhūḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In order to avoid the contingency of violation of oath, peace made with the security of such persons as ascetics engaged in penance, or nobles is peace with a security

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmin yaḥ paraavagrahasamarthān pratibhuvo gṛhṇāti, soatisaṃdhatte // viparītoatisaṃdhīyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In such a peace, whoever takes as security a person capable of controlling the Kautilyas Arthashastra enemy gains more advantages, while he who acts to the contrary is deceived

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bandhumukhyapragrahaḥ pratigrahaḥ // tasmin yo dūṣyaamātyaṃ dūṣyaapatyaṃ vā dadāti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In peace made with children as hostages, and in the case of giving a princess or a prince as an hostage, whoever gives a princess gains advantages;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kanyā hy adāyādā pareṣām evaarthāyaākleśyā(?) ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for a princess, when taken as an hostage, causes troubles to the receiver, while a prince is of reverse nature

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītaḥ putraḥ // putrayor api yo jātyaṃ prājñaṃ śūraṃ kṛtaastram ekaputraṃ vā dadāti soatisaṃdhīyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With regard to two sons, whoever hands over a highborn, brave and wise son, trained in military art, or an only son is deceived, while he who acts otherwise gains advantages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jātyād ajātyo hi luptadāyādasaṃtānatvād ādhātuṃ śreyān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is better to give a baseborn son as an hostage than a highborn one, inasmuch as the former has neither heirship nor the right to beget heirs;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prājñād aprājño mantraśaktilopāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: it is better to give a stupid son than a wise one, inasmuch as the former is destitute of the power of deliberation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūrād aśūra utsāhaśaktilopāt, kṛtaastrād akṛtaastraḥ prahartavyasampallopāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: better to give a timid son than a brave one, inasmuch as the former is destitute of martial spirit; better, a son who is not trained in military art than one who is trained, inasmuch as the former is devoid of the capacity for striking an enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaputrād anekaputro nirapekṣatvāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and better one of many sons than an only son, since many sons are not wanted

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jātyaprājñayor jātyam aprājñam aiśvaryaprakṛtir anuvartate, prājñam ajātyaṃ mantraadhikāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With regard to a highborn and a wise son, people will continue to be loyal to a highborn son though he is not wise; a wise son, though baseborn, is characterized with capacity to consider state matters;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantraadhikāreapi vṛddhasamyogāj jātyaḥ prājñam atisaṃdhatte // prājñaśūrayoḥ prājñam aśūraṃ matikarmaṇāṃ yogoanuvartate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but so far as capacity to consider state matters is concerned, a highborn prince associating himself with the aged, has more advantages than a wise but baseborn prince With regard to a wise and a brave prince, a wise prince, though timid, is characterized with capacity for intellectual works;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūram aprājñaṃ vikramaadhikāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and a brave prince though not wise, possesses warlike spirit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikramaadhikāreapi hastinam iva lubdhakaḥ prājñaḥ śūram atisaṃdhatteś //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: So far as warlike spirit is concerned, a wise prince overreaches a brave one just as a hunter does an elephant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūrakṛtaastrayoḥ śūram akṛtaastraṃ vikramavyavasāyoanuvartate, kṛtaastram aśūraṃ lakṣyalambhaadhikāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra With regard to a brave and a trained prince, a brave prince, though untrained, is characterized with capacity for war; and a trained prince, though timid, is capable of hitting objects aright

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lakṣyalambhaadhikāreapi sthairyapratipattyasammoṣaiḥ śūraḥ kṛtaastram atisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Notwithstanding the capacity for hitting objects aright, a brave prince excels a trained prince in determination and firm adherence to his policy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahvekaputrayor bahuputra ekaṃ dattvā śeṣapratiṣṭabdhaḥ saṃdhim atikrāmati, naitaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With regard to a king having many sons and another an only son, the former, giving one of his sons as a hostage and being contented with the rest, is able to break the peace but not the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: putrasarvasvadāne saṃdhiś cet putraphalato viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When peace is made by handing over the whole lot of sons, advantage is to be sought in capacity to beget additional sons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samaphalayoḥ śaktaprajananato viśeṣaḥ // śaktaprajananayor apy upasthitaprajananato viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: capacity to beget additional sons being common, he who can beget able sons will have more advantages than another king who is not so fortunate; capacity to beget able sons being common, he by whom the birth of a son is early expected will have more advantages than another who is not so fortunate

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktimaty ekaputre tu luptaputrautpattir ātmānam ādadhyāt, na caekaputram iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the case of an only son who is also brave, he who has lost capacity to beget any more sons should surrender himself as an hostage, but not the only son

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhyuccīyamānaḥ samādhimokṣaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever is rising in power may break the agreement of peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kumāraāsannāḥ sattriṇaḥ kāruśilpivyañjanāḥ karmāṇi kurvāṇāḥ suruṅgayā rātrāv upakhānayitvā kumāram apahareyuḥ // naṭanartakagāyanavādakavāgjīvanakuśīlavaplavakasaubhikā vā pūrvapraṇihitāḥ param upatiṣṭheran //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Carpenters, artisans, and other spies, attending upon the prince kept as an hostage and doing work under the enemy, may take away the prince at night through an underground tunnel dug for the purpose Dancers, actors, singers, players on musical instruments, buffoons, courtbards, swimmers, and saubhikas ?, previously set about the enemy, may continue under his service and may indirectly serve the prince

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām aniyatakālapraveśasthānanirgamanāni sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They should have the privilege of entering into, staying in and going out of, the palace at any time without rule

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatas tadvyañjano vā rātrau pratiṣṭheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The prince may therefore get out at night disguised as any one of the above spies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena rūpaājīvā bhāryāvyañjanāś ca vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra This explains the work of prostitutes and other women spies under the garb of wives;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ vā tūryabhāṇḍaphelāṃ gṛhītvā nirgacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the prince may get out, carrying their pipes, utensils, or vessels

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sūdaārālikasnāpakasaṃvāhakaāstarakakalpakaprasādhakaudakaparicārakair vā dravyavastrabhāṇḍaphelāśayanaāsanasambhogair nirhriyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or the prince may be removed concealed under things, clothes, commodities, vessels, beds, seats and other articles by cooks, confectioners, servants employed to serve the king while bathing, servants employed for carrying conveyances, for spreading the bed, toiletmaking, dressing, and procuring water;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paricārakacchadmanā vā kiṃcid arūpavelāyām ādāya nirgacchet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or taking something in pitch dark, he may get out, disguised as a servant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suruṅgāmukhena vā niśāupahāreṇa // toyaāśaye vā vāruṇaṃ yogam ātiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may pretend to be in communion with god Varuna in a reservoir which is seen through a tunnel or to which he is taken at night;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaidehakavyañjanā vā pakvaannaphalavyavahāreṇaārakṣiṣu rasam upacārayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: spies under the guise of traders dealing in cooked rice and fruits may poison those things and distribute among the sentinels

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivataupahāraśrāddhaprahavaṇanimittam ārakṣiṣu madanayogayuktam annapānaṃ rasaṃ vā prayujyaapagacchet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having served the sentinels with cooked rice and beverage mixed with the juice of madana plant on occasions of making offerings to gods or of performing an ancestral ceremony or some sacrificial rite, the prince may get out;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ārakṣakaprotsāhanena vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by bribing the sentinels;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nāgarakakuśīlavacikitsakaāpūpikavyañjanā vā rātrau samṛddhagṛhāṇy ādīpayeyuḥ ārakṣiṇāṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or spies disguised as a nágaraka officer in charge of the city, a courtbard, or a physician may set fire to a building filled with valuable articles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaidehakavyañjanā vā paṇyasaṃsthām ādīpayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or sentinels or spies disguised as merchants may set fire to the store of commercial articles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyad vā śarīraṃ nikṣipya svagṛham ādīpayed anupātabhayāt // tataḥ saṃdhicchedakhātasuruṅgābhir apagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or in view of avoiding the fear of pursuit, the prince may, after putting some human body in the house occupied by him, set fire to it and escape by breaking open some housejoints, or a window, or through a tunnel;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kācakumbhabhāṇḍabhāravyañjano vā rātrau pratiṣṭheta // muṇḍajaṭilānāṃ pravāsanāny anupraviṣṭo vā rātrau tadvyañjanaḥ pratiṣṭheta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having disguised himself as a carrier of glassbeads, pots, and other commodities, he may set out at night; or having entered the residence of ascetics with shaven heads or with twisted hair, he may set out at night, disguised as any one of them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: virūpavyādhikaraṇaaraṇyacaracchadmanām anyatamena vā // pretavyañjano vā gūḍhair nirhriyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having disguised himself as one suffering from a peculiar disease or as a forestman, he may get out; or spies may carry him away as a Kautilyas Arthashastra corpse;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pretaṃ vā strīveṣeṇaanugacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or disguised as a widowed wife, be may follow a corpse that is being carried away

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vanacaravyañjanāś caenam anyato yāntam anyatoapadiśeyuḥ // tatoanyato gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies disguised as forestpeople, should mislead the pursuers of the prince by pointing out another direction, and the prince himself may take a different direction

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cakracarāṇāṃ vā śakaṭavāṭair apagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may escape, hiding himself in the midst of carts of cartdrivers;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsanne caanupāte sattraṃ vā gṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if he is closely followed, he may lead the pursuers to an ambuscade sattra;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sattraabhāve hiraṇyaṃ rasaviddhaṃ vā bhakṣyajātam ubhayataḥpanthānam utsṛjet // tatoanyatoapagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the absence of an ambuscade he may leave here and there gold or morsels of poisoned food on both sides of a road and take a different road

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gṛhīto vā sāmaādibhir anupātam atisaṃdadhyāt, rasaviddhena vā pathyadanena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is captured, he should try to win over the pursuers by conciliation and other means, or serve them with poisoned food;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāruṇayogaagnidāheṣu vā śarīram anyad ādhāya śatrum abhiyuñjīta putro me tvayā hataḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and having caused another body to be put in a sacrifice performed to please god Varuna or in a fire that has broken out the princes father, may accuse the enemy of the murder of his son and attack the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upāttacchannaśastro vā rātrau vikramya rakṣiṣu // śīghrapātair apasared gūḍhapraṇihitaiḥ saha //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or taking out a concealed sword, and falling upon the sentinels, he may quickly run away together with the spies concealed before [Thus ends Chapter , Making Peace and Breaking It, in Book , The End of the Sixfold Policy of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (madhyamacaritam udāsīnacaritam maṇḍalacaritam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE CONDUCT OF A MADHYAMA KING, A NEUTRAL KING, AND OF A CIRCLE OF STATES

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamasyaātmā tṛtīyā pañcamī ca prakṛtī prakṛtayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 THE third and the fifth states from a madhyama king are states friendly to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvitīyā caturthī ṣaṣṭhī ca vikṛtayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: while the second, the fourth, and the sixth are unfriendly

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tac ced ubhayaṃ madhyamoanugṛhṇīyāt, vijigīṣur madhyamaanulomaḥ syāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the madhyama king shows favour to both of these states, the conqueror should be friendly with him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na ced anugṛhṇīyāt, prakṛtyanulomaḥ syāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if he does not favour them, the conqueror should be friendly with those states

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madyamaś ced vijigīṣor mitraṃ mitrabhāvi lipseta, mitrasyaātmanaś ca mitrāṇy utthāpya madhyamāc ca mitrāṇi bhedayitvā mitraṃ trāyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the madhyama king is desirous of securing the friendship of the conqueors wouldbe friend, then having set his own and his friends friends against the madhyama, and having separated the madhyama from the latters friends, the conqueror should preserve his own friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇḍalaṃ vā protsāhayet atipravṛddhoayaṃ madhyamaḥ sarveṣāṃ no vināśāyaabhyutthitaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or the conqueror may incite the Circle of States against the madhyama by telling them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sambhūyaasya yātrāṃ vihanāma iti // tac cen maṇḍalam anugṛhṇīyāt, madhyamaavagraheṇaātmānam upabṛṃhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this madhyama king has grown haughty, and is aiming at our destruction let us therefore combine and interrupt his march If the Circle of States is favourable to his cause, then he may aggrandise himself by putting down the madhyama;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na ced anugṛhṇīyāt, kośadaṇḍābhyāṃ mitram anugṛhya ye madhyamadveṣiṇo rājānaḥ parasparaanugṛhītā vā bahavas tiṣṭheyuḥ, ekasiddhau vā bahavaḥ sidhyeyuḥ, parasparād vā śaṅkitā nauttiṣṭheran, teṣāṃ pradhānam ekam āsannaṃ vā sāmadānābhyāṃ labheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if not favourable, then having helped his friend with men and money, he should, by means of conciliation and gifts, win over either the leader or a neigbbouring king among the kings who hate the madhyama, or who have been living with mutual support, or who will follow the one that is won over by the conqueror, or who do not rise owing to mutual suspicion;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviguṇo dvitīyaṃ trigunas tṛtīyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: thus by winning over a second king, he should double his own power; by securing a third, he should treble his own power;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam abhyuccito madhyamam avagṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: thus gaining in strength, he should put down the madhyama king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśakālaatipattau vā saṃdhāya madhyamena mitrasya sācivyaṃ kuryāt, dūṣyeṣu vā karmasaṃdhim //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When place and time are found unsuitable for success in the above attempt, he should, by peace, seek the friendship of one of the enemies of the madhyama king, or cause some traitors to combine against the madhyama;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karśanīyaṃ vāasya mitraṃ madhyamo lipseta, pratistambhayed enaṃ ahaṃ tvā trāyeya iti ā karśanāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if the madhyama king is desirous of reducing the conquerors friend, the conqueror should prevent it, and tell the friend shall protect you as long as you are weak, and should accordingly protect him when he is poor in resources;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karśitam enaṃ trāyeta // ucchedanīyaṃ vāasya mitraṃ madhyamo lipseta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if Kautilyas Arthashastra the madhyama king desires to rout out a friend of the conqueror, the latter should protect him in his difficulties;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karśitam enaṃ trāyeta madhyamavṛddhibhayāt // ucchinnaṃ vā bhūmyanugraheṇa haste kuryād anyatraapasārabhayāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having removed him from the fear of the madhyama king, the conqueror should provide him with new lands and keep him under his the conquerors protection, lest he might go elsewhere

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karśanīyaucchedanīyayoś cen mitrāṇi madhyamasya sācivyakarāṇi syuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If, among the conquerors friends who are either reducible or assailable enemies of the madhyama king, some undertake to help the madhyama, then the conqueror should make peace with a third king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijigīṣor vā tayor mitrāṇy avagrahasamarthāni syuḥ, saṃdhim upeyāt // amitraṃ vāasya madhyamo lipseta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and if among the madhyama kings friends who are either reducible or assailable enemies of the conqueror, some are capable of offence and defence and become friendly to the conqueror, then he should make peace with them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ svaarthaś ca kṛto bhavati madhyamasya priyaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: thus the conqueror cannot only attain his own ends, but also please the madhyama king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamaś cet svamitraṃ mitrabhāvi lipseta, puruṣaantareṇa saṃdadhyāt // saapekṣaṃ vā naarhasi mitram ucchettum iti vārayet // upekṣeta vā maṇḍalam asya kupyatu svapakṣavadhāt iti // amitram ātmano vā madhyamo lipseta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the madhyama king is desirous of securing a wouldbe friend of the conqueror as a friend, then the conqueror may make peace with another king, or prevent the friend from going to the madhyama, telling him It is unworthy of you to forsake a friend who is desirous of your friendship, or the conqueror may keep quiet, if the conqueror thinks that the Circle of States would be enraged against the friend for deserting his own party

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośadaṇḍābhyām enam adṛśyamānoanugṛhṇīyāt // udāsīnaṃ vā madhyamo lipseta, asmai sāhāyyaṃ dadyād udāsīnād bhidyatām iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the madhyama king is desirous of securing the conquerors enemy as his friend, then the conqueror should indirectly ie, without being known to the madhyama help the enemy with wealth and army If the madhyama king desires to win the neutral king, the conqueror should sow the seeds of dissension between them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamaudāsīnayor yo maṇḍalasyaabhipretas tam āśrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever of the madhyama and the neutral kings is esteemed by the Circle of States, his protection should the conqueror seek

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamacaritenaudāsīnacaritaṃ vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The conduct of the madhyama king explains that of the neutral king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udāsīnaś cen madhyamaṃ lipseta, yataḥ śatrum atisaṃdadhyān mitrasyaupakāraṃ kuryād udāsīnaṃ vā daṇḍaupakāriṇaṃ labheta tataḥ pariṇameta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the neutral king is desirous of combining with the madhyama king, then the conqueror should so attempt as to Kautilyas Arthashastra frustrate the desire of the neutral king to overreach an enemy or to help a friend or to secure the services of the army of another neutral king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam upabṛhyaātmānam ariprakṛtiṃ karśayen mitraprakṛtiṃ caupagṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having thus strengthened himself, the conqueror should reduce his enemies and help his friends, though their position is inimical towards him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saty apy amitrabhāve tasyaanātmavān nityaapakārī śatruḥ śatrusaṃhitaḥ pārṣṇigrāho vā vyasanī yātavyo vyasane vā netur abhiyoktā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those who may be inimical to the conqueror are a king who is of wicked character and who is therefore always harmful, a rearenemy in combination with a frontal enemy, a reducible enemy under troubles, and one who is watching the troubles of the conqueror to invade him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaarthaabhiprayātaḥ pṛthagarthaabhiprayātaḥ sambhūyayātrikaḥ saṃhitaprayāṇikaḥ svaarthaabhiprayātaḥ sāmutthāyikaḥ kośadaṇḍayor anyatarasya kretā vikretā vā dvaidhībhāvika iti mitrabhāvinaḥ, //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those who may be friendly with the conqueror are one who marches with him with the same end in view, one who marches with him with a different end in view, one who wants to combine with the conqueror to march against a common enemy, one who marches under an agreement for peace, one who marches with a set purpose of, his own, one who rises along with others, one who is ready to purchase or to sell either the army or the treasury, and one who adopts the double policy ie, making peace with one and waging war with another

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmanto balavataḥ pratighātoantardhiḥ prativeśo vā balavataḥ pārṣṇigrāho vā svayam upanataḥ pratāpaupanato vā daṇḍaupanata iti bhṛtyabhāvinaḥ sāmantāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those neighbouring kings who can be servants to the conqueror are a neighbouring king under the apprehension of an attack from a powerful king, one who is situated between the conqueror and his enemy, the rearenemy of a powerful king, one who has voluntarily surrendered oneself to the conqueror, one who has surrendered oneself under fear, and one who has been subdued

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tair bhūmyekaantarā vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same is the case with those kings who are next to the territory of the immediate enemies of the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ śatruvirodhe yan mitram ekaarthatāṃ vrajet / śaktyā tadanugṛhṇīyād viṣaheta yayā param //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these kings, the conqueror should, as far as possible, help that friend who has the same end in view as the conqueror in his conflict with the enemy, and thus hold the enemy at bay

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prasādhya śatruṃ yan mitraṃ vṛddhaṃ gacched avaśyatām / sāmantaekaantarābhyāṃ tatprakṛtibhyāṃ virodhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, after having put down the enemy, and after having grown Kautilyas Arthashastra in power, a friend becomes unsubmissive, the conqueror should cause the friend to incur the displeasure of a neighbour and of the king who is next to the neighbour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatkulīnaaparuddhābhyāṃ bhūmiṃ vā tasya hārayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or the conqueror may employ a scion of the friends family or an imprisoned prince to seize his lands;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā vāanugrahaapekṣaṃ vaśyaṃ tiṣṭhet tathā caret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or the conqueror may so act that his friend, desirous of further help, may continue to be obedient

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naupakuryād amitraṃ vā gacched yad atikarśitam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The conqueror should never help his friend when the latter is more and more deteriorating;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ahīnam avṛddhaṃ ca sthāpayen mitram arthavit //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a politician should so keep his friend that the latter neither deteriorates nor grows in power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthayuktyā calaṃ mitraṃ saṃdhiṃ yad upagacchati / tasyaapagamane hetuṃ vihanyān na caled yathā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When,with the desire of getting wealth, a wandering friend ie, a nomadic king makes an agreement with the conqueror, the latter should so remove the cause of the friends flight that he never flies again

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arisādhāraṇaṃ yad vā tiṣṭhet tad aritaḥ śaṭham / bhedayed bhinnam ucchindyāt tataḥ śatrum anantaram // udāsīnaṃ ca yat tiṣṭhet sāmantais tad virodhayet /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a friend is as accessible to the conqueror as to the latters enemy, the conqueror should first separate that obstinate friend from the enemy, and then destroy him, and afterwards the enemy also When a friend remains neutral, the conqueror should cause him to incur the displeasure of his immediate enemies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato vigrahasaṃtaptam upakāre niveśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when he is worried in his wars with them, the conqueror should oblige him with help

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amitraṃ vijigīṣuṃ ca yat saṃcarati durbalam / tad balenaanugṛhṇīyād yathā syān na parānmukham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, owing to his own weakness, a friend seeks protection both from the conqueror and the latters enemy, the conqueror should help him with the army, so that he never turns his attention elsewhere

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apanīya tatoanyasyāṃ bhūmau vā samniveśayet / niveśya pūrvaṃ tatraanyad daṇḍaanugrahahetunā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having, removed him from his own lands, the conqueror may keep him in another tract of land, having made some previous arrangements to punish or favour the friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apakuryāt samarthaṃ vā naupakuryād yad āpadi / ucchindyād eva tanmitraṃ viśvasyaaṅkam upasthitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or the conqueror may harm him when he has grown powerful, or destroy him when he does nut help the conqueror in danger and when he lies on the conquerors lap in good faith

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitravyasanato vāarir uttiṣṭhed yoanavagrahaḥ / mitreṇaeva bhavet sādhyaś chāditavyasanena saḥ // amitravyasanān mitram utthitaṃ yad virajyati / arivyasanasiddhyā tatśatruṇāeva prasidhyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When an enemy furiously rises against his own enemy ie, the conquerors friend under troubles, the former should be put down Kautilyas Arthashastra by the latter himself with troubles concealed When a friend keeps quiet after rising against an enemy under troubles, that friend will be subdued by the enemy himself after getting rid of his troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vṛddhiṃ kṣayaṃ ca sthānaṃ ca karśanaucchedanaṃ tathā // sarvaupāyān samādadhyād etān yaś caarthaśāstravit /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever is acquainted with the science of polity should clearly observe the conditions of progress, deterioration, stagnation, reduction, and destruction, as well as the use of all kinds of strategic means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam anyonyasaṃcāraṃ ṣāḍguṇyaṃ yoanupaśyati // sa buddhinigalair baddhair iṣṭaṃ krīḍati pārthivaiḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever thus knows the interdependence of the six kinds of policy plays at his pleasure with kings, bound round, as it were, in chains skillfully devised by himself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (prakṛtivyasanavargah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and sixteenth chapter from the beginning

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanayaugapadye saukaryato yātavyaṃ rakṣitavyaṃ vāiti vyasanacintā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN calamities happen together, the form of consideration Kautilyas Arthashastra should be whether it is easier to take an offensive or defensive attitude

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivaṃ mānuṣaṃ vā prakṛtivyasanam anayaapanayābhyāṃ sambhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: National calamities, coming from Providence or from man happen from ones misfortune or bad policy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: guṇaprātilomyam abhāvaḥ pradoṣaḥ prasaṅgaḥ pīḍā vā vyasanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The word vyasana vices or calamities, means the reverse or absence of virtue, the preponderance of vices, and occasional troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasyaty enaṃ śreyasa iti vyasanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which deprives vyasyati a person of his happiness is termed vyasana vices or calamities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svāmyamātyajanapadadurgakośadaṇḍamitravyasanānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ garīyaḥ ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the calamities, viz, the king in distress, the minister in distress, the people in distress, distress due to bad fortifications, financial distress, the army in distress, and an ally in distress,that which is first mentioned is more serious than the one, coming later in the order of enumeration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti bharadvājaḥ // svāmyamātyavyasanayor amātyavyasanaṃ garīyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Bháradvája, of the distress of the king and of his minister, ministerial distress is more serious;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / mantro mantraphalaavāptiḥ karmaanuṣṭhānam āyavyayakarma daṇḍapraṇayanam amitraaṭavīpratiṣedho rājyarakṣaṇaṃ vyasanapratīkāraḥ kumārarakṣaṇam abhiṣekaś ca kumārāṇām āyattam amātyeṣu //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: deliberations in council, the attainment of results as anticipated while deliberating in council, the accomplishment of works, the business of revenuecollection and its expenditure, recruiting the army, the driving out of the enemy and of wild tribes, the protection of the kingdom, taking remedial measures against calamities, the protection of the heirapparent, and the installation of princes constitute the duties of ministers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām abhāve tadabhāvaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of ministers; the above works are illdone;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: chinnapakṣasyaiva rājñaś ceṣṭānāśaś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and like a bird, deprived of its feathers, the king loses his active capacity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasaneṣu caāsannaḥ paraupajāpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In such calamities, the intrigues of the enemy find a ready scope

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaiguṇye ca prāṇaābādhaḥ prāṇaantikacaratvād rājñaḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In ministerial distress, the kings life itself comes into danger, for a minister is the mainstay of the security of the kings life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // mantripurohitaādibhṛtyavargam adhyakṣapracāraṃ puruṣadravyaprakṛtivyasanapratīkāram edhanaṃ ca rājāeva karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, it is verily the king who attends to the business of appointing ministers, priests, and other servants, including the superintendents of several departments, the application of remedies against the troubles of his people, and of his kingdom, and the adoption of progressive measures;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasaniṣu vāamātyeṣv anyān avyasaninaḥ karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when his Kautilyas Arthashastra ministers fall into troubles, he employs others;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūjyapūjane dūṣyaavagrahe ca nityayuktas tiṣṭhati // svāmī ca sampannaḥ svasampadbhiḥ prakṛtīḥ sampādayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he is ever ready to bestow rewards on the worthy and inflict punishments on the wicked; when the king is well off, by his welfare and prosperity, he pleases the people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa yatśīlas tatśīlāḥ prakṛtayo bhavanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: of what kind the kings character is, of the same kind will be the character of his people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utthāne pramāde ca tadāyattatvāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for their progress or downfall, the people depend upon the king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatkūṭasthānīyo hi svāmīiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the king is, as it were, the aggregate of the people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amātyajanapadavyasanayor janapadavyasanaṃ garīyaḥ iti viśālaakṣaḥ // kośo daṇḍaḥ kupyaṃ viṣṭir vāhanaṃ nicayāś ca janapadād uttiṣṭhante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Visáláksha says that of the troubles of the minister and of the people; the troubles of the people are more serious; finance, army, raw products, free labour, carriage of things, and collection of necessaries are all secured from the people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām abhāvo janapadaabhāve,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There will be no such things in the absence of people, next to the king and his minister

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // amātyamūlāḥ sarvaārambhāḥ janapadasya karmasiddhayaḥ svataḥ parataś ca yogakṣemasādhanaṃ vyasanapratīkāraḥ śūnyaniveśaupacayau daṇḍakaraanugrahaś caiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, all activities proceed from the minister, activities such as the successful accomplishment of the works of the people, security of person and property from internal and external enemies, remedial measures against calamities, colonization and improvement of wild tracts of land, recruiting the army, collection of revenue, and bestowal of favour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: janapadadurgavyasanayor durgavyasanam iti pārāśarāḥ // durge hi kośadaṇḍautpattir āpadi sthānaṃ ca janapadasya //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The school of Parásara say that of the distress of the people and distress due to bad fortifications, the latter is a more serious evil; for it is in fortified towns that the treasury and the army are secured; they fortified towns are a secure place for the people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktimattarāś ca paurā jānapadebhyo nityāś caāpadi sahāyā rājñaḥ // jānapadās tv amitrasādhāraṇāḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: they are a stronger power than the citizens or country people; and they are a powerful defensive instrument in times of danger for the king As to the people, they are common both to the king and his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, for forts, finance, and the army depend upon the people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śauryaṃ sthairyaṃ dākṣyaṃ bāhulyaṃ ca jānapadeṣu //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: likewise buildings, trade, agricuture, cattlerearing, bravery, stability, power, and abundance of things

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parvataantardvīpāś ca durgā naadhyuṣyante janapadaabhāvāt // karṣakaprāye tu durgavyasanam, āyudhīyaprāye tu janapade janapadavyasanam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In countries inhabited by people, there are mountains and islands Kautilyas Arthashastra as natural forts; in the absence of an expansive country, forts are resorted to When a country consists purely of cultivators, troubles due to the absence of fortifications are apparent;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgakośavyasanayoḥ kośavyasanam iti piśunaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pisuna says that of the troubles due to the absence of forts and to want of finance, troubles due to want of finance are more serious;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośamūlo hi durgasaṃskāro durgarakṣaṇaṃ janapadamitraamitranigraho deśaantaritānām utsāhanaṃ daṇḍabalavyavahāraś ca durgaḥ kośād upajāpyaḥ pareṣām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: by means of wealth, intrigue to capture an enemys fort may be carried on; by means of wealth, the people, friends, and enemies can be kept under control; by means of it, outsiders can be encouraged and the establishment of the army and its operations conducted

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośam ādāya ca vyasane śakyam apayātum, na durgam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is possible to remove the treasure in times of danger, but not the fort

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // durgaarpaṇaḥ kośo daṇḍas tūṣṇīṃyuddhaṃ svapakṣanigraho daṇḍabalavyavahāra āsārapratigrahaḥ paracakraaṭavīpratiṣedhaś
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, for it is in the fort that the treasury and the army are safely kept, and it is from the fort that secret war intrigue, control over ones partisans, the upkeep of the army, the reception of allies and the driving out of enemies and of wild tribes are successfully practised

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgaabhāve ca kośaḥ pareṣām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of forts, the treasury is to the enemy, for it seems that for those who own forts, there is no destruction

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośadaṇḍavyasanayor daṇḍavyasanam iti kauṇapadantaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kaunapadanta says that of distress due to want of finance or to an inefficient army, that which is due to the want of an efficient army is more serious;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍamūlo hi mitraamitranigrahaḥ paradaṇḍautsāhanaṃ svadaṇḍapratigrahaś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for control over ones own friends and enemies, the winning over the army of an enemy, and the business of administration are all dependent upon the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośaabhāve ca śakyaḥ kupyena bhūmyā parabhūmisvayaṃgrāheṇa vā daṇḍaḥ piṇḍayitum,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of the army, it is certain that the treasury will be lost, whereas lack of finance can be made up by procuring raw products and lands or by seizing an enemys territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośaabhāve daṇḍaḥ paraṃ gacchati, svāminaṃ vā hanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The army may go to the enemy, or murder the king himself, Kautilyas Arthashastra and bring about all kinds of troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvaabhiyogakaraś ca kośo dharmakāmahetuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But finance is the chief means of observing virtuous acts and of enjoying desires

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśakālakāryavaśena tu kośadaṇḍayor anyataraḥ pramāṇībhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Owing to a change in place, time, and policy, either finance or the army may be a superior power;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lambhapālano hi daṇḍaḥ kośasya,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the army is sometimes the means of securing the wealth acquired;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośaḥ kośasya daṇḍasya ca bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but wealth is always the means of securing both the treasury and the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvadravyaprayojakatvāt kośavyasanaṃ garīya iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Since all activities are dependent upon finance, financial troubles are more serious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍamitravyasanayor mitravyasanam iti vātavyādhiḥ // mitram abhṛtaṃ vyavahitaṃ ca karma karoti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Vátavyádhi says that of the distress of the army and of an ally, the distress of an ally is more seriousan ally, though he is not fed and is far off, is still serviceable;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārṣṇigrāham āsāram amitram āṭavikaṃ ca pratikaroti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he drives off not only the rearenemy and the friends of the rearenemy, but also the frontal enemy and wild tribes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośadaṇḍabhūmibhiś caupakaroti vyasanaavasthāyogam iti // naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he also helps his friend with money, army, and lands on occasions of troubles No, says Kautilya, the ally of him who has a powerful army keeps the alliance;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍavato mitraṃ mitrabhāve tiṣṭhati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and even the enemy assumes a friendly attitude;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amitro vā mitrabhāve // daṇḍamitrayos tu sādhāraṇe kārye sārataḥ svayuddhadeśakālalābhād viśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when there is a work that can be equally accomplished either by the army or by an ally, then preference to the army or to the ally should depend on the advantages of securing the appropriate place and time for war and the expected profit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śīghraabhiyāne tv amitraāṭavikaanabhyantarakope ca na mitraṃ vidyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In times of sudden expedition and on occasions of troubles from an enemy, a wild tribe, or local rebels, no friend can be trusted

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanayaugapadye paravṛddhau ca mitram arthayuktau tiṣṭhati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When calamities happen together, or when an enemy has grown strong, a friend keeps up his friendship as long as money is forthcoming

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti prakṛtivyasanasampradhāraṇam uktam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the determination of the comparative seriousness of the calamities of the various elements of sovereignty

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prakṛtyavayavānāṃ tu vyasanasya viśeṣataḥ / bahubhāvoanurāgo vā sāro vā kāryasādhakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a part of one of the elements of sovereignty is under troubles, the extent, affection, and strength of the serviceable part can be the means of accomplishing a work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvayos tu vyasane tulye viśeṣo guṇataḥ kṣayāt / śeṣaprakṛtisādguṇyaṃ yadi syān naavidheyakam // śeṣaprakṛtināśas tu yatraekavyasanād bhavet / vyasanaṃ tad garīyaḥ syāt pradhānasyaitarasya vā //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When any two elements of sovereignty are equally under troubles, they should be distinguished in respect of their progressive or declining tendency, provided that the good Kautilyas Arthashastra condition of the rest of the elements needs no description When the calamities of a single element tend to destroy the rest of the elements, those calamities, whether they be of the fundamental or any other element, are verily serious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (rājarājyayor vyasanacintā)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: CONSIDERATIONS ABOUT THE TROUBLES OF THE KING AND OF HIS KINGDOM

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājā rājyam iti prakṛtisaṃkṣepaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE king and his kingdom are the primary elements of the state

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājñoabhyantaro bāhyo vā kopa iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The troubles of the king may be either internal or external

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ahibhayād abhyantaraḥ kopo bāhyakopāt pāpīyān, antaramātyakopaś caantaḥkopāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Internal troubles are more serious than external troubles which are like the danger arising from a lurking snake Troubles due to a minister are more serious than other kinds of internal troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmāt kośadaṇḍaśaktim ātmasaṃsthāṃ kurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, the king should keep under his own control the powers of finance and the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvairājyavairājyayor dvairājyam anyonyapakṣadveṣaanurāgābhyāṃ parasparasaṃgharṣeṇa vā vinaśyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of divided rule and foreign rule, divided rule or rule of a country by two kings, perishes owing to mutual hatred, partiality and rivalry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vairājyaṃ tu jīvataḥ parasyaācchidya naetan mama iti manyamānaḥ karśayati, apavāhayati, paṇyaṃ vā karoti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Foreign rule which comes into existence by seizing the country from its king still alive, thinks that the country is not its own, impoverishes it, and carries off its wealth, or treats it as a commercial article;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viraktaṃ vā parityajyaapagacchatiiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when the country ceases to love it, it retires abandoning the country

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: andhaś calitaśāstro vā rājāiti aśāstracakṣur andho yatkiṃcanakārī dṛḍhaabhiniveśī parapraṇeyo vā rājyam anyāyenaupahanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, a blind king, or a king erring against the science? Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 My teacher says that a blind king, ie, a king who is not possessed of an eye in sciences, is indiscriminate in doing works, very obstinate, and is led by others; such a king destroys the kingdom by his own maladministration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: calitaśāstras tu yatra śāstrāc calitamatir bhavati śakyaanunayo bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But an erring king can be easily brought round when and where his mind goes astray from the procedure laid down in sciences

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // andho rājā śakyate sahāyasampadā yatra tatra vā paryavasthāpayitum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, a blind king can be made by his supporters to adhere to whatever line of policy he ought to

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: calitaśāstras tu śāstrād anyathāabhiniviṣṭabuddhir anyāyena rājyam ātmānaṃ caupahantiiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But an erring king who is bent upon doing what is against the science, brings about destruction to himself and his kingdom by maladministration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyādhito navo vā rājāiti vyādhito rājā rājyaupaghātam amātyamūlaṃ prāṇaābādhaṃ vā rājyamūlam avāpnoti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, a diseased or a new king ? My teacher says that a diseased king loses his kingdom owing to the intrigue of his ministers, or loses his life on account of the kingdom;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: navas tu rājā svadharmaanugrahaparihāradānamānakarmabhiḥ prakṛtirañjanaupakāraiś carati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but a new king pleases the people by such popular deeds as the observance of his own duties and the act of bestowing favours, remissions of taxes, gifts, and presents upon others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, a diseased king continues to observe his duties as usual

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyādhito rājā yathāpravṛttaṃ rājapraṇidhim anuvartayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But a new king begins to act as he pleases under the impression that the country, acquired by his own might, belongs to himself;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmutthāyikair avagṛhīto vā rājyaupaghātaṃ marṣayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when pressed by combined kings for plunder, he tolerates their oppression of the country Or having no firm control over the elements of the state, he is easily removed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyādhite viśeṣaḥ pāparogyapāparogī ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There is this difference among diseased kings a king who is morally diseased, and a king who is suffering from physical disease;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naveapy abhijātoanabhijāta iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: there is also this difference among new kings a highborn king and a baseborn king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durbaloabhijāto balavān anabhijāto rājāiti durbalasyaabhijātasyaupajāpaṃ daurbalyaapekṣāḥ prakṛtayaḥ kṛcchreṇaupagacchanti, balavataś caanabhijātasya balaapekṣāḥ sukhena ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is better, a weak but highborn king, or a strong but lowborn king? Kautilyas Arthashastra My teacher says that a people, even if interested in having a weak king, hardly allow room for the intrigues of a weak but highborn person to be their king; but that if they desire power, they will easily yield themselves to the intrigues of a strong but baseborn person to be their king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // durbalam abhijātaṃ prakṛtayaḥ svayam upanamanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, a people will naturally obey a highborn king though he is weak, for the tendency of a prosperous people is to follow a highborn king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balavataś caanabhijātasyaupajāpaṃ visaṃvādayanti, anurāge sārvaguṇyam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also they render the intrigues of a strong but baseborn person, unavailing, as the saying is, that possession of virtues makes for friendship

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prayāsavadhāt sasyavadho muṣṭivadhāt pāpīyān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The destruction of crops is worse than the destruction of handfuls of grains, since it is the labour that is destroyed thereby;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nirājīvatvād avṛṣṭir ativṛṣṭitaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: absence of rain is worse than too much rain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvayor dvayor vyasanayoḥ prakṛtīnāṃ balaabalam / pāramparyakrameṇauktaṃ yāne sthāne ca kāraṇam //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The comparative seriousness or insignificance of any two kinds of troubles affecting the elements of sovereignty, in the order of enumeration of the several kinds of distress, is the cause of adopting offensive or defensive operations

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (puruṣavyasanavargah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE AGGREGATE OF THE TROUBLE OF MEN

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avidyāvinayaḥ puruṣavyasanahetuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: IGNORANCE and absence of discipline are the causes of a mans troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avinīto hi vyasanadoṣān na paśyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An untrained man does not perceive the injuries arising from vices

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tān upadekṣyāmaḥ // kopajas trivargaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: We are going to treat of them vices Kautilyas Arthashastra Vices due to anger form a triad;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāmajaś caturvargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and those due to desire are fourfold

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvatra hi kopaś carati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these two, anger is worse, for anger proceeds against all

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prāyaśaś ca kopavaśā rājānaḥ prakṛtikopair hatāḥ śrūyante, kāmavaśāḥ kṣayanimittam arivyādhibhir iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In a majority of cases, kings given to anger are said to have fallen a prey to popular fury But kings addicted to pleasures have perished in consequence of serious diseases brought about by deterioration and improverishment

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti bhāradvājaḥ // satpuruṣaācāraḥ kopo vairayātanam avajñāvadho bhītamanuṣyatā ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Bháradvája, anger is the characteristic of a righteous man It is the foundation of bravery; it puts an end to despicable persons; and it keeps the people under fear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityaś ca kopena sambandhaḥ pāpapratiṣedhaarthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Anger is always a necessary quality for the prevention of sin

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāmaḥ siddhilābhaḥ sāntvaṃ tyāgaśīlatā sampriyabhāvaś ca // nityaś ca kāmena sambandhaḥ kṛtakarmaṇaḥ phalaupabhogaarthaḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But desire accompanies the enjoyment of results, reconciliation, generosity, and the act of endearing oneself to all Possession of desire is always necessary for him who is inclined to enjoy the fruits of what he has accomplished

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // dveṣyatā śatruvedanaṃ duḥkhaāsaṅgaś ca kopaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, anger brings about enmity with, and troubles from, an enemy, and is always associated with pain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paribhavo dravyanāśaḥ pāṭaccaradyūtakāralubdhakagāyanavādakaiś caanarthyaiḥ samyogaḥ kāmaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Addiction to pleasure káma occasions contempt and loss of wealth, and throws the addicted person into the company of thieves, gamblers, hunters, singers, players on musical instruments, and other undesirable persons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayoḥ paribhavād dveṣyatā garīyasī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when harshly spoken to, a brave man retaliates;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paribhūtaḥ svaiḥ paraiś caavagṛhyate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of gambling and drinking, gambling causes gain or loss of the stakes to one party or other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dveṣyaḥ samucchidyata iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The reception of what is condemned is due to desire;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyanāśātśatruvedanaṃ garīyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: all kinds of troubles, except those due to fire, can be alleviated, and troubles due to floods can be passed over

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyanāśaḥ kośaābādhakaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the repair of fortifications and their maintenance depend upon finance;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatruvedanaṃ prāṇaābādhakam iti // anarthyasamyogād duḥkhasamyogo garīyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE AGGREGATE OF THE TROUBLE OF MEN IGNORANCE and absence of discipline are the causes of a mans troubles An untrained man does not perceive the injuries arising from vices

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anarthyasamyogo muhūrtapratīkāro,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is the foundation of bravery; it puts an end to despicable persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dīrghakleśakaro duḥkhānām āsaṅga iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Suffering on account of vices is more serious than keeping company with undesirable persons, for the company of undesirable persons can be got rid of in a moment, whereas suffering from vices causes injury for a long time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmāt kopo garīyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, anger is a more serious evil

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vākpāruṣyam arthadūṣaṇaṃ daṇḍapāruṣyam iti // vākpāruṣyaarthadūṣaṇayor vākpāruṣyaṃ garīyaḥ iti viśālaakṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is worse abuse of language, or of money, or oppressive punishment? Visáláksha says that of abuse of language and of money, abuse of language is worse;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paruṣamukto hi tejasvī tejasā pratyārohati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when harshly spoken to, a brave man retaliates;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: duruktaśalyaṃ hṛdi nikhātaṃ tejaḥsaṃdīpanam indriyaupatāpi ca iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and bad language, like a nail piercing the heart, excites anger and gives pain to the senses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // arthapūjā vākśalyam apahanti, vṛttivilopas tv arthadūṣaṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, gift of money palliates the fury occasioned by abusive language, whereas abuse of money causes the loss of livelihood itself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adānam ādānaṃ vināśaḥ parityāgo vāarthasyaity arthadūṣaṇam // arthadūṣaṇadaṇḍapāruṣyayor arthadūṣaṇaṃ garīyaḥ iti pārāśarāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Abuse of money means gifts, exaction, loss or abandonment of money The School of Parásara say that of abuse of money and oppressive punishment, abuse of money is worse;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthamūlau dharmakāmau // arthapratibaddhaś ca loko vartate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for good deeds and enjoyments depend upon wealth; the world itself is bound by wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyaupaghāto garīyān iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, its abuse is a more serious evil

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // sumahatāapy arthena na kaścana śarīravināśam icchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, in preference to a large amount of wealth, no man desires the loss of his own life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍapāruṣyāc ca tam eva doṣam anyebhyaḥ prāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Owing to oppressive punishment, one is liable to the same punishment at the hands of ones enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti kopajas trivargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such is the nature of the triad of evils due to anger

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāmajas tu mṛgayā dyūtaṃ striyaḥ pānam iti caturvargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The fourfold vices due to desire are hunting, gambling, women and drinking

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya mṛgayādyūtayor mṛgayā garīyasī iti piśunaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Pisuna says that of hunting and gambling, hunting is a worse vice;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: stenaamitravyāladāvapraskhalanabhayadinmohāḥ kṣutpipāse ca prāṇaābādhas tasyām // dyūte tu jitam evaakṣaviduṣā yathā jayatsenaduryodhanābhyām iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for falling into the hand of robbers, enemies and elephants, getting into wild fire, fear, inability to distinguish between the cardinal points, hunger, thirst and loss of life are evils consequent upon hunting, whereas in gambling, the expert gambler wins a victory like Jayatsena and Duryodhana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naity kauṭilyaḥ // tayor apy anyataraparājayoastiiti nalayudhiṣṭhirābhyāṃ vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, of the two parties, one has to suffer from defeat, as is well known from the history of Nala and Yudhishthira;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad eva vijitadravyam āmiṣaṃ vairaanubandhaś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the same wealth that is won like a piece of flesh in gambling, causes enmity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: satoarthasya vipratipattir asataś caarjanam apratibhuktanāśo mūtrapurīṣadhāraṇabubhukṣāādibhiś ca vyādhilābha iti dyūtadoṣāḥ mṛgayāyāṃ tu vyāyāmaḥ śleṣmapittamedaḥsvedanāśaś cale sthite ca kāye lakṣaparicayaḥ kopabhayasthāneṣu ca mṛgāṇāṃ cittajñānam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Lack of recognition of wealth properly acquired, acquisition of illgotten wealth, loss of wealth without enjoyment, staying away from answering the calls of nature, and contracting diseases from not taking timely meals, are the evils of gambling, whereas in hunting, exercise, the disappearance of phlegm, bile, fat, and sweat, the acquisition of skill in aiming at stationary and moving bodies, the ascertainment of the appearance of beasts when provoked, and occasional march are its good characteristics

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dyūtastrīvyasanayoḥ kaitavavyasanam iti kauṇapadantaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kaunapadanta says that of addiction to gambling and to women, gambling is a more serious evil;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sātatyena hi niśi pradīpe mātari ca mṛtāyāṃ dīvyaty eva kitavaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for gamblers always play, even at night by lamp light, and even when the mother of one of the players is dead;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛcchre ca pratipṛṣṭaḥ kupyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the gambler exhibits anger when spoken to in times of trouble;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: strīvyasane tu snānapratikarmabhojanabhūmiṣu bhavaty eva dharmaarthaparipraśnaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whereas in the case of addiction to women, it is possible to hold conversation about virtue and wealth, at the time of bathing, dressing and eating

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śakyā ca strī rājahiteniyoktum, upāṃśudaṇḍena vyādhinā vā vyāvartayitum avasrāvayituṃ vā iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also it is possible to make, by means of secret punishment, a woman to be so good as to secure the welfare of the king, or to get rid of her, or drive her out, under the plea of disease

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // sapratyādeyaṃ dyūtaṃ niṣpratyādeyaṃ strīvyasanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra No, says Kautilya, it is possible to divert the attention from gambling, but not so from women

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adarśanaṃ kāryanirvedaḥ kālaatipātanād anartho dharmalopaś ca tantradaurbalyaṃ pānaanubandhaś caiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The evils of the latter are failure to see what ought to be seen, violation of duty, the evil of postponing works that are to be immediately done, incapacity to deal with politics, and contracting the evil of drinking

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: strīpānavyasanayoḥ strīvyasanam iti vātavyādhiḥ // strīṣu hi bāliśyam anekavidhaṃ niśāntapraṇidhau vyākhyātam // pāne tu śabdaādīnām indriyaarthānām upabhogaḥ prītidānaṃ parijanapūjanaṃ karmaśramavadhaś ca iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Vátavyádhi says that of addiction to women and to drinking, addiction to women is a more serious evil there are various kinds of childishness among women, as explained in the chapter on „The Harem,‟ whereas in drinking, the enjoyment of sound and other objects of the senses, pleasing other people, honouring the followers, and relaxation from the fatigue of work are the advantages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // strīvyasane bhavaty apatyautpattir ātmarakṣaṇaṃ caantardāreṣu, viparyayo vā bāhyeṣu,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, in the case of addiction to women, the consequences are the birth of children, selfprotection, change of wives in the harem, and absence of such consequences in the case of unworthy outside women

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ubhayaṃ pānavyasane //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Both the above consequences follow from drinking

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kaupīnadarśanaṃ śrutaprajñāprāṇavittamitrahāniḥ sadbhir viyogoanarthyasamyogas tantrīgītanaipuṇyeṣu caarthaghneṣu prasaṅga iti // dyūtamadyayor dyūtam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The auspicious effects of drinking are loss of money, lunacy in a sensate man, corpselike appearance while living, nakedness, the loss of the knowledge of the Vedas, loss of life, wealth, and friends, disassociation with the good, suffering from pain, and indulgence in playing on musical instruments and in singing at the expense of wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekeṣāṃ paṇanimitto jayaḥ parājayo vā prāṇiṣu niścetaneṣu vā pakṣadvaidhena prakṛtikopaṃ karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of gambling and drinking, gambling causes gain or loss of the stakes to one party or other Even among dumb animals, it splits them into factions and causes provocation

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśeṣataś ca saṃghānāṃ saṃghadharmiṇāṃ ca rājakulānāṃ dyūtanimitto bhedas tannimitto vināśa ity asatpragrahaḥ pāpiṣṭhatamo
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is specially due to gambling that assemblies and royal confederacies possessing the characteristics of assemblies are split into factions, and are consequently destroyed The reception of what is condemned is the worst of all evils since it causes incapacity to deal with politics

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: asatāṃ pragrahaḥ kāmaḥ kopaś caavagrahaḥ satām /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The reception of what is condemned is due to desire; and anger consists in oppressing the good;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanaṃ doṣabāhulyād atyantam ubhayaṃ matam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: since both these are productive of many evils, both of them are held to be the worst evils

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmāt kopaṃ ca kāmaṃ ca vyasanaārambham ātmavān / parityajen mūlaharaṃ vṛddhasevī jitaindriyaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence be who is possessed of discretion should associate with the aged, and, after controlling his passions, abandon both anger and desire which are productive of other evils and destructive of the very basis of life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (pīḍanavargah stambhavargah kośasangavargah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE GROUP OF MOLESTATIONS, THE GROUP OF OBSTRUCTIONS, AND THE GROUP OF FINANCIAL TROUBLES

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivapīḍanaṃ agnir udakaṃ vyādhir durbhikṣaṃ maraka iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: PROVIDENTIAL calamities are fire, floods, pestilence, famine, and the epidemic disease called maraka My teacher says that of fire and floods, destruction due to fire is irremediable;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agnyudakayor agnipīḍanam apratikāryaṃ sarvadāhi ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: all kinds of troubles, except those due to fire, can be alleviated, and troubles due to floods can be passed over

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nait kauṭilyaḥ // agnir grāmam ardhagrāmaṃ vā dahati, udakavegas tu grāmaśatapravāhīiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, fire destroys a village, or part of a village whereas floods carry off hundreds of villages

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyādhidurbhikṣayor vyādhiḥ pretavyādhitaupasṛṣṭaparicārakavyāyāmauparodhena karmāṇy upahanti, durbhikṣaṃ punar akarmaupaghāti hiraṇyapaśukaradāyi ca ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of pestilence and famine, pestilence brings all kinds of business to a stop by causing obstruction to work on account of disease and death among men and owing to the flight of servants, whereas famine stops no work, but is productive of gold, cattle and taxes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // ekadeśapīḍano vyādhiḥ śakyapratīkāraś ca, sarvadeśapīḍanaṃ durbhikṣaṃ prāṇinām ajīvanāyaiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra No, says Kautilya, pestilence devastates only a part of the country and can be remedied, whereas famine causes troubles to the whole of the country and occasions dearth of livelihood to all creatures

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena marako vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the consequences of maraka

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣudrakamukhyakṣayayoḥ kṣudrakakṣayaḥ karmaṇām ayogakṣemaṃ karoti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the loss of chief and vulgar men, the loss of vulgar men causes obstruction to work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, it is possible to recruit vulgar men, since they form the majority of people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na mukhyakṣayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the sake of vulgar men, nobles should not be allowed to perish;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sahasreṣu hi mukhyo bhavaty eko na vā sattvaprajñāādhikyāt tadāśrayatvāt kṣudrakāṇām iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: one in a thousand may or may not be a noble man; he it is who is possessed of excessive courage and wisdom and is the refuge of vulgar people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svacakraparacakrayoḥ svacakram atimātrābhyāṃ daṇḍakarābhyāṃ pīḍayaty aśakyaṃ ca vārayitum, paracakraṃ tu śakyaṃ praiyoddhum upasāreṇa saṃdhinā vā mokṣayitum ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the troubles arising from ones own or one‟s enemys Circle of States, those due to ones own Circle are doubly injurious and are irremediable, whereas an inimical Circle of States can be fought out or kept away by the intervention of an ally or by making peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // svacakrapīḍanaṃ prakṛtipuruṣamukhyaupagrahavighātābhyāṃ śakyate vārayitum ekadeśaṃ vā pīḍayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, troubles due to ones own Circle can be got rid of by arresting or destroying the leaders among the subjective people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvadeśapīḍanaṃ tu paracakraṃ vilopaghātadāhavidhvaṃsanaapavāhanaiḥ pīḍayatiiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may be injurious to a part of the country, whereas troubles due to an enemys Circle of States cause oppression by inflicting loss and destruction and by burning, devastation, and plunder
