oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prakṛtirājavivādayoḥ prakṛitivivādaḥ prakṛtīnāṃ bhedakaḥ paraabhiyogān āvahati, rājavivādas tu prakṛtīnāṃ dviguṇabhaktavetanaparihārakaro bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the quarrels among the people and among kings, quarrel among the people brings about disunion and thereby enables an enemy to invade the country, whereas quarrel among kings is productive of double pay and wages and of remission of taxes to the people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // śakyaḥ prakṛtivivādaḥ prakṛtimukhyaupagraheṇa kalahasthānaapanayanena vā vārayitum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 No, says Kautilya, it is possible to end the quarrel among the people by arresting the leaders, or by removing the cause of quarrel;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vivadamānās tu prakṛtayaḥ parasparasaṃgharṣeṇaupakurvanti // rājavivādas tu pīḍanaucchedanāya prakṛtīnāṃ dviguṇavyāyāmasādhya iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and people quarrelling among themselves vie with each other and thereby help the country, whereas quarrel among kings causes trouble and destruction to the people and requires double the energy for its settlement

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśarājavihārayor deśavihāras traikālyena karmaphalaupaghātaṃ karoti, rājavihāras tu kāruśilpikuśīlavavāgjīvanarūpaājīvāvaidehakaupakāraṃ karoti ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of a sportive king and a sportive country, a sportive country is always ruinous to the results of work, whereas a sportive king is beneficial to artisans, carpenters, musicians, buffoons and traders

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, a sportive country, taking to sports for relaxation from labour, causes only a trifling loss;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśavihāraḥ karmaśramam avadhāartham alpaṃ bhakṣayati bhakṣayitvā ca bhūyaḥ karmasu yogaṃ gacchati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and after enjoyment, it resumes work, whereas a sportive king causes oppression by showing indulgence to his courtiers, by seizing and begging, and by obstructing work in the manufactories

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: subhagākumārayoḥ kumāraḥ svayaṃ vallabhaiś ca svayaṃgrāhapraṇayapaṇyaagārakāryaupagrahaiḥ pīḍayati, subhagā vilāsaupabhogena ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of a favourite wife and a prince, the prince causes oppression by showing indulgence to his followers, by seizing and begging, and by obstructing the work in manufactories whereas the favourite wife is addicted to her amorous sports

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // śakyaḥ kumāro mantripurohitābhyāṃ vārayitum, na subhagā bāliśyād anarthyajanasamyogāc caiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, it is possible to prevent through the minister and the priest, the oppression caused by the prince, but not the oppression caused by the favourite wife, since she is usually stubborn and keeps company with wicked persons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śreṇīmukhyayoḥ śreṇī bāhulyād anavagrahā steyasāhasābhyāṃ pīḍayati, mukhyaḥ kāryaanugrahavighātābhyām ity ācāryāḥ // naiti kauṭilyaḥ // suvyāvartyā śreṇī samānaśīlavyasanatvāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the troubles due to a corporation of people and to a leader a chief, the corporation of people people cannot be put down since it consists of a number of men and causes oppression by theft and violence, whereas a leader causes troubles by obstruction to, and destruction of, work Kautilyas Arthashastra No, says Kautilya, it is very easy to get rid of the troubles from a corporation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śreṇīmukhyaekadeśaupagraheṇa vā // stambhayukto mukhyaḥ paraprāṇadravyaupaghātābhyāṃ pīḍayatiiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: since it has to rise or fall with the king; or it can be put down by arresting its leader or a part of the corporation itself, whereas a leader backed up with support causes oppression by injuring the life and property of others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samnidhātṛsamāhartroḥ samnidhātā kṛtavidūṣaṇaatyayābhyāṃ pīḍayati, samāhartā karaṇaadhiṣṭhitaḥ pradiṣṭaphalaupabhogī bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the chamberlain and the collector of revenue, the chamberlain causes oppression by spoiling works and by inflicting fines, whereas the collector of revenue makes use of the ascertained revenue in the department over which he presides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // samnidhātā kṛtaavastham anyaiḥ kośapraveśyaṃ pratigṛhṇāti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, the chamberlain takes to himself what is presented by others to be entered into the treasury whereas the collector makes his own revenue first and then the kings;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasvaādāne ca svapratyayaś caratiiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he destroys the kings revenue and proceeds as he pleases to seize the property of others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: antapālavaidehakayor antapālaś coraprasargadeyaatyādānābhyāṃ vaṇikpathaṃ pīḍayati, vaidehakās tu paṇyapratipaṇyaanugrahaiḥ prasādhayanti ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the superintendent of the boundary and a trader, the superintendent of the boundary destroys traffic by allowing thieves and taking taxes more than he ought to, whereas a trader renders the country prosperous by a favourable barter of commercial articles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // antapālaḥ paṇyasampātaanugraheṇa vartayati, vaidehakās tu sambhūya paṇyānām utkarṣaapakarṣaṃ kurvāṇāḥ paṇe paṇaśataṃ kumbhe kumbhaśatam ity ājīvanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, the superintendent of the boundary increases commercial traffic by welcoming the arrival of merchandise, whereas traders unite in causing rise and fall in the value of articles, and live by making profits cent per cent in panas or kumbhas measures of grain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhijātauparuddhā bhūmiḥ paśuvrajauparuddhā vāiti abhijātauparuddhā bhūmiḥ mahāphalāapy āyudhīyaupakāriṇī na kṣamā mokṣayituṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Which is more desirable, land occupied by a highborn person or land reserved for grazing a flock of cattle? My teacher says that the land occupied by a highborn person is very productive;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and it supplies men to the army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhijātauparuddhā bhūmir atyantamahāupakārāapi kṣamā mokṣayituṃ vyasanaābādhabhayāt, paśuvrajauparuddhā tu kośavāhanaupakāriṇī na kṣamā mokṣayitum, anyatra sasyavāpauparodhād iti // / pratirodhakaāṭavikayoḥ pratirodhakā rātrisattracarāḥ śarīraākramiṇo
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: hence it does Kautilyas Arthashastra not deserve to be confiscated lest the owner might cause troubles, whereas the land occupied for grazing a flock of cattle is cultivable and deserves therefore to be freed, for cultivable land is preferred to pasture land No, says Kautilya, though immensely useful, the land occupied by a highborn person deserves to be freed, lest he might cause troubles otherwise, whereas the land held for grazing a flock of cattle is productive of money and beasts, and does not therefore deserve to be confiscated unless cultivation of crops is impeded thereby

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityāḥ śatasahasraahapāriṇaḥ pradhānakopakāś ca vyavahitāḥ pratyantaraaraṇyacarāś caāṭavikāḥ prakāśā dṛsyāś caranti, ekadeśaghātakāś ca ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of robbers and wild tribes, robbers are ever bent on carrying off women at night, make assaults on persons, and take away hundreds and thousands of panas, whereas wild tribes, living under a leader and moving in the neighbouring forests can be seen here and there causing destruction only to a part

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // pratirodhakāḥ pramattasyaaparahanti, alpāḥ kuṇṭhāḥ sukhā jñātuṃ grahītuṃ ca, svadeśasthāḥ prabhūtā vikrāntāś caāṭavikāḥ prakāśayodinoapahartāro hantāraś ca deśānāṃ rājasadharmāṇa iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, robbers carry off the property of the careless and can be put down as they are easily recognized and caught hold of, whereas wild tribes have their own strongholds, being numerous and brave, ready to fight in broad daylight, and seizing and destroying countries like kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mṛgahastivanayoḥ mṛgāḥ prabhūtāḥ prabhūtamāṃsacarmaupakāriṇo mandagrāsaavakleśinaḥ suniyamyāś ca // viparītā hastino gṛhyamāṇā duṣṭāś ca deśavināśāyaiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the forests of beasts and of elephants, beasts are numerous and productive of plenty of flesh and skins; they arrest the growth of the grass and are easily controlled, whereas elephants are of the reverse nature and are seen to be destructive of countries even when they are captured and tamed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svaparasthānīyaupakārayoḥ svasthānīyaupakāro dhānyapaśuhiraṇyakupyaupakāro jānapadānām āpady ātmadhāraṇaḥ // viparītaḥ parasthānīyaupakāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of benefits derived from ones own or a foreign country, benefits derived from ones own country consists of grains, cattle, gold, and raw products and are useful for the maintenance of the Kautilyas Arthashastra people in calamities, whereas benefits derived from a foreign country are of the reverse nature

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti pīḍanāni ābhyantaro mukhyastambho bāhyoamitraaṭavīstambhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such is the group of molestations Obstruction to movements caused by a chief is internal obstruction;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: [iti stambhavargah]
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the group of financial troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tābhyāṃ pīḍanair yathāuktaiś ca pīḍitaḥ, sakto mukhyeṣu, parihāraupahataḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the interests of the prosperity of the country, one should attempt to avoid the cause of troubles, remedy them when they happen, and avert obstructions and financial troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mithyāsaṃhṛtaḥ, sāmantaaṭavīhṛta iti kośasaṅgavargaḥ // pīḍanānām anutpattāv utpannānāṃ ca vāraṇe /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , The Group of Molestations, the Group of Obstructions, and the Group of Financial Troubles in BookVIII, Concerning Vices and Calamities, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yateta deśavṛddhyarthaṃ nāśe ca stambhasaṅgayoḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and twentieth chapter from the beginning] Kautilyas Arthashastra CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (balavyasanavargah mitravyasanavargah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE GROUP OF TROUBLES OF THE ARMY, AND THE GROUP OF TROUBLES OF A FRIEND

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balavyasanāni amānitam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The troubles of the army areThat which is disrespected;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vimānitam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is mortified;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhṛtam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is not paid for;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyādhitam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is diseased;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: navaāgatam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has freshly arrived;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūraāyātam, pariśrāntam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has made a long journey; that which is tired;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parikṣīṇam, pratihatam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has sustained loss; that which has been repelled;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hataagravegam, anṛtuprāptam, abhūmiprāptam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has found itself in an unsuitable ground; that which is displeased from disappointment;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parisṛptam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has run away;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalatragarbhi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which contains traitors;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: antaḥśalyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has dissensions;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kupitamūlam, bhinnagarbham, apasṛtam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has come from a foreign state; that which has served in many states;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atikṣiptam, upaniviṣṭam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is obstructed; that which is surrounded;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parikṣiptam, chinnadhānyapuruṣavīvadham,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has its supply of grains cut off; that which has its men and stores cut off;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svavikṣiptam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is kept in ones own country;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitravikṣiptam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is under the protection of an ally;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyayuktam, duṣṭapārṣṇigrāham,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which contains inimical persons; that which is afraid of an enemy in the rear;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: asvāmisaṃhatam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has lost its communication;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinnakūṭam, andham iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has lost its leader; and that which is blind ie, untrained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām amānitavimānitaaniyatayor amānitaṃ kṛtaarthamānaṃ yudhyeta, na vimānitam antaḥkopam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the disrespected and the mortified among these, that which is disrespected may be taken to fight after being honoured, but not that which is suffering from its own mortification

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhṛtavyādhitayor abhṛtaṃ tadātvakṛtavetanaṃ yudhyeta, na vyādhitam akarmaṇyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of unpaid and diseased armies, the unpaid may be taken to fight after making full payment but not the diseased, which is unfit for work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: navaāgatadūraāyātayor navaāgatam anyata upalabdhadeśam anavamiśraṃ yudhyeta, na dūraāyatam āyatagataparikleśam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Of freshly arrived and longtravelled armies, that which has freshly arrived may be taken to fight after it has taken its position without mingling with any other new army, but not that which is tired from its long journey

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pariśrāntaparikṣīṇayoḥ pariśrāntaṃ snānabhojanasvapnalabdhaviśrāmaṃ yudhyeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of tired and reduced armies, the army that is tired may be taken to fight after it has refreshed itself from bathing, eating, and sleeping, but not the reduced army, ie, the army, the leaders of which have been killed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na parikṣīṇam anyatraāhave kṣīṇayugyapuruṣam // pratihatahataagravegayoḥ pratihatam agrapātabhagnaṃ pravīrapuruṣasaṃhataṃ yudhyeta, na hataagravegam agrapātahatavīram // anṛtvabhūmiprāptayor anṛtuprāptaṃ yathaṛtuyugyaśastraāvaraṇaṃ yudhyeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of armies which have either been repelled or have their front destroyed, that which has been repelled may be taken to fight together with fresh men attached to it, but not the army which has lost many of its brave men in its frontal attack Of armies, either suffering from inclemency of weather or driven to an unsuitable ground, that which is suffering from inclemency of weather may be taken to fight after providing it with weapons and dress appropriate for the season, but not the army on an unfavourable ground obstructing its movements

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āśānirvediparisṛptayor āśānirvedi labdhaabhiprāyaṃ yudhyeta, na parisṛptam apasṛtamukhyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of disappointed and renegade armies, that which is disappointed may be taken to fight after satisfying it but not the army which has once run away

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalatragarbhyantaḥśalyayoḥ kalatragarbhi unmucya kalatraṃ yudhyeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of soldiers who are either fond of their wives or are under an enemy, those who are fond of their wives may be taken to fight after separating them from their wives;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naantaḥśalyam antaramitram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but not those who are under an enemy, and are, therefore, like internal enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kupitamūlabhinnagarbhayoḥ kupitamūlaṃ praśamitakopaṃ sāmaādibhir yudhyeta, na bhinnagarbham anyonyasmād bhinnam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of provoked and disunited armies, that, of which a part is provoked, may be taken to fight after pacifying it by conciliation and other strategic means but not the disunited army, the members of which are estranged from each other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apasṛtaatikṣiptayor apasṛtam ekarājyaatikrāntaṃ mantravyāyāmābhyāṃ sattramitraapāśrayaṃ yudhyeta, naatikṣiptam anekarājyaatikrāntaṃ bahvābādhatvāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Of armies which have left service either in one state or in many states, that whose resignation of service in a foreign state is not due to instigation or conspiracy may be taken to fight under the leadership of spies and friends, but not the army which has resigned its service in many states and is, therefore, dangerous

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upaniviṣṭasamāptayor upaniviṣṭaṃ pṛthagyānasthānam atisaṃdhāyaariṃ yudhyeta, na samāptam ariṇāekasthānayānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of armies which are trained either to a particular kind of manœuvre and encampment or to a particular movement in a particular place, that which is taught a special kind of manœuvre and encampment may be taken to fight, but not the army whose way of making encampments and marches is only suited for a particular place

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: uparuddhaparikṣiptayor uparuddham anyato niṣkramyauparoddhāraṃ pratiyudhyeta, na parikṣiptaṃ sarvataḥ pratiruddham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of obstructed and surrounded armies, that which is prevented from its movements in one direction may be taken to fight against the obstructor in another direction, but not the army whose movements are obstructed on all sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: chinnadhānyapuruṣavīvadhayoḥ chinnadhānyam anyato dhānyam ānīya jaṅgamasthāvaraāhāraṃ vā yudhyeta, na chinnapuruṣavīvadham anabhisāram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of troops whose supply of grain is cut off or whose supply of men and stores is cut off, that which has lost its supply of grain may be taken to fight after providing it with grain brought from another quarter or after supplying to it moveable and immoveable foodstuffs animal and vegetable foodstuffs but not the army to which men and provisions cannot be supplied

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svavikṣiptamitravikṣiptayoḥ svavikṣiptaṃ svabhūmau vikṣiptaṃ sainyam āpadi śakyam āvāhayitum, na mitravikṣiptaṃ viprakṛṣṭadeśakālatvāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of armies kept in ones own country or under the protection of an ally, that which is kept in ones own country can possibly be disbanded in time of danger, but not the army under the protection of an ally, as it is far removed in place and time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyayuktaduṣṭapārṣṇigrāhayor dūṣyayuktam āptapuruṣaadhiṣṭhitam asaṃhataṃ yudhyeta, na duṣṭapārṣṇigrāhaṃ pṛṣṭhaabhighātatrastam // śūnyamūlaasvāmisaṃhatayoḥ śūnyamūlaṃ kṛtapaurajānapadaārakṣaṃ sarvasaṃdohena yudhyeta, naasvāmisaṃhataṃ rājasenāpatihīnam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of armies either filled with traitors, or frightened by an enemy in the rear, that which is full of traitors may be taken to fight apart under the leadership of a trusted commander, but not the army which is afraid of an attack from the rear Kautilyas Arthashastra Of armies without communication or without leaders, that which has lost its communication with the base of operations may be taken to fight after restoring the communication and placing it under the protection of citizens and country people, but not the army which is without a leader such as the king or any other persons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinnakūṭaandhayor bhinnakūṭam anyaadhiṣṭhitaṃ yudhyeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of troops which have lost their leader or which are not trained, those that have lost their leader may be taken to fight under the leadership of a different person but not the troops which are not trained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: doṣaśuddhir balaāvāpaḥ sattrasthānaatisaṃhitam / saṃdhiś cauttarapakṣasya balavyasanasādhanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Removal of vices and troubles, recruitment of new men, keeping away from places of an enemys ambush, and harmony among the officers of the army, are the means of protecting the army from troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rakṣet svadaṇḍaṃ vyasane śatrubhyo nityam utthitaḥ / prahared daṇḍarandhreṣu śatrūṇāṃ nityam utthitaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He the king should ever carefully guard his army from the troubles caused by an enemy, and should ever be ready to strike his enemys army when the latter is under troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yato nimittaṃ vyasanaṃ prakṛtīnām avāpnuyāt / prāg eva pratikurvīta tan nimittam atandritaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whatever he may come to know as the source of trouble to his people, he should quickly and carefully apply antidotes against that cause

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhiyātaṃ svayaṃ mitraṃ sambhūyaanyavaśena vā // parityaktam aśaktyā vā lobhena praṇayena vā / vikrītam abhiyuñjāne saṃgrāme vāapavartinā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A friend who, by himself, or in combination with others or under the influence of another king, has marched against his own ally, a friend who is abandoned owing to inability to retain his friendship, or owing to greediness or indifference; A friend who is bought by another and who has withdrawn himself from fighting;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvaidhībhāvena vāamitraṃ yāsyatā vāanyam anyataḥ / pṛthag vā sahayāne vā viśvāsenaatisaṃhitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra A friend who, following the policy of making peace with one and marching against another, has contracted friendship with one, who is going to march either singly or in combination with others against an ally;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhayaavamānaālasyair vā vyasanān na pramokṣitam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A friend who is not relieved from his troubles owing to fear, contempt, or indifference;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avaruddhaṃ svabhūmibhyaḥ samīpād vā bhayād gatam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a friend who is surrounded in his own place or who has run away owing to fear;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ācchedanād adānād vā dattvā vāapy avamānitam / atyāhāritam arthaṃ vā svayaṃ paramukhena vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A friend who is displeased owing to his having to pay much, or owing to his not having received his due or owing to his dissatisfaction even after the receipt of his due; A friend who has voluntarily paid much or who is made by another to pay much to his ally;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atibhāre niyuktaṃ vā bhaṅktvā param upasthitam / upekṣitam aśaktyā vā prārthayitvā virodhitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a friend who is kept under pressure, or who, having broken the bond of friendship, sought friendship with another; A friend who is neglected owing to inability to retain his friendship;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛcchreṇa sādhyate mitraṃ siddhaṃ caāśu virajyati /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and a friend who has become an enemy in spite of his allys entreaties to the contrary;such friends are hardly acquired;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtaprayāsaṃ mānyaṃ vā mohān mitram amānitam / mānitaṃ vā na sadṛśaṃ śaktito vā nivāritam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A friend who has realised the responsibilities of friendship, or who is honourable; or whose disappointment is due to want of information, or who, though excited, is unequal to the task, or who is made to turn back owing to fear from another;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraupaghātatrastaṃ vā śaṅkitaṃ vāarisaṃhitāt / dūṣyair vā bhedituṃ mitraṃ sādhyaṃ siddhaṃ ca tiṣṭhati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or who is frightened at the destruction of another friend, or who is apprehensive of danger from the combination of enemies, or who is made by traitors to give up his friendship,it is possible to acquire such a friend; and if acquired, he keeps up his friendship

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmān nautpādayed enān doṣān mitraupaghātakān /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Hence one should not give rise to those causes which are destructive of friendship;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utpannān vā praśamayed guṇair doṣaupaghātibhiḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when they arise, one should get rid of them by adopting such friendly attitude as can remove those causes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (śaktideśakālabalaabalajnānam yātrākālāh)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE KNOWLEDGE OF POWER, PLACE, TIME, STRENGTH, AND WEAKNESS; THE TIME OF INVASION

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijigīṣur ātmanaḥ parasya ca balaabalaṃ śaktideśakālayātrākālabalasamuddānakālapaścātkopakṣayavyayalābhaāpadāṃ jñātvā viśiṣṭabalo yāyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE conqueror should know the comparative strength and weakness of himself and of his enemy; and having ascertained the power, place, time, the time of marching and of recruiting the army, the consequences, the loss of men and money, and profits and danger, he should march with his full force;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathāāsīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise, he should keep quiet

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utsāhaprabhāvayor utsāhaḥ śreyān // svayaṃ hi rājā śūro balavān arogaḥ kṛtaastro daṇḍadvitīyoapi śaktaḥ prabhāvavantaṃ rājānaṃ jetum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of enthusiasm and power, enthusiasm is better a king, himself energetic, brave, strong, free from disease, skilful in wielding weapons, is able with his army as a secondary power to subdue a powerful king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alpoapi caasya daṇḍas tejasā kṛtyakaro bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: his army, though small, will, when led by him, be, capable of turning out any work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nirutsāhas tu prabhāvavān rājā vikramaabhipanno naśyati ity ācāryāḥ // naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But a king who has no enthusiasm in himself, will perish though possessed of a strong army No, says Kautilya, he who is possessed of power overreaches, by the sheer force of his power, another who is merely enthusiastic

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prabhūtaprabhāvahayahastirathaupakaraṇasampannaś caasya daṇḍaḥ sarvatraapratihataś carati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having acquired, captured, or bought another enthusiastic king as well as brave soldiers, he can make his enthusiastic army of horses, elephants, chariots, and others to move anywhere without obstruction

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utsāhavataś ca prabhāvavanto jitvā krītvā ca striyo bālāḥ paṅgavoandhāś ca pṛthivīṃ jigyur iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Powerful kings, whether women, young men, lame or blind, conquered the earth by winning over or purchasing the aid of enthusiastic persons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prabhāvamantrayoḥ prabhāvaḥ śreyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of power money and army and skill in intrigue, power is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantraśaktisampanno hi vandhyabuddhir aprabhāvo bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for a king, though possessed of skill for Kautilyas Arthashastra intrigue mantrasakti becomes a man of barren mind if he has no power;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantrakarma caasya niścitam aprabhāvo garbhadhānyam avṛṣṭir ivaupahanti ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the work of intrigue is well defined He who has no power loses his kingdom as sprouts of seeds in drought vomit their sap

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, skill for intrigue is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prajñāśāstracakṣur hi rājāalpenaapi prayatnena mantram ādhātuṃ śaktaḥ parān utsāhaprabhāvavataś ca sāmaādibhir yogaupaniṣadbhyāṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he who has the eye of knowledge and is acquainted with the science of polity can with little effort make use of his skill for intrigue and can succeed by means of conciliation and other strategic means and by spies and chemical appliances in overreaching even those kings who are possessed of enthusiasm and power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam utsāhaprabhāvamantraśaktīnām uttarauttaraadhikoatisaṃdhatte //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus of the three acquirements, viz, enthusiasm, power and skill for intrigue, he who posesses more of the quality mentioned later than the one mentioned first in the order of enumeration will be successful in over reaching others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśaḥ pṛthivī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Country space means the earth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyāṃ himavatsamudraantaram udīcīnaṃ yojanasahasraparimāṇaṃ tiryak cakravartikṣetram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in it the thousand yojanas of the northern portion of the country that stretches between the Himalayas and the ocean form the dominion of no insignificant emperor;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraaraṇyo grāmyaḥ parvata audako bhaumaḥ samo viṣama iti viśeṣāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in it there are such varieties of land, as forests, villages, waterfalls, level plains, and uneven grounds

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣu yathāsvabalavṛddhikaraṃ karma prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In such lands, he should undertake such works as he considers to be conducive to his power and prosperity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatraātmanaḥ sainyavyāyāmānāṃ bhūmiḥ, abhūmiḥ parasya,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That part of the country, in which his army finds a convenient place for its manœuvre and which proves unfavourable to his enemy, is the best;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa uttamo deśaḥ, viparītoadhamaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that part of the country which is of the reverse nature, is the worst;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sādhāraṇo madhyamaḥ // kālaḥ śītauṣṇavarṣaātmā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that which partakes of both the characteristics, is a country of middling quality Time consists of cold, hot, and rainy periods

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya rātrir ahaḥ pakṣo māsa ṛtur ayanaṃ saṃvatsaro yugam iti viśeṣāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The divisions of time are the night, the day, the fortnight, the month, the season, solstices, the year, and the Yuga cycle of five years

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣu yathāsvabalavṛddhikaraṃ karmaprayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In these divisions of time he should undertake such works as are conducive to the growth of his power and prosperity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatraātmanaḥ sainyavyāyāmānām ṛtuḥ anṛtuḥ parasya, sa uttamaḥ kālaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That time which is congenial for the manœuvre of his Army, but which is of the Kautilyas Arthashastra reverse nature for his enemy is the best;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītoadhamaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is of the reverse nature is the worst;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sādhāraṇo madhyamaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that which possesses both the characteristics is of middling quality

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktideśakālānāṃ tu śaktiḥ śreyasī ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of strength, place, and time, strength is the best;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktimān hi nimnasthalavato deśasya śītauṣṇavarṣavataś ca kālasya śaktaḥ pratīkāre bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for a man who is possessed of strength can overcome the difficulties due either to the unevenness of the ground or to the cold, hot, or rainy periods of time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśaḥ śreyān ity eke // sthalagato hi śvā nakraṃ vikarṣati, nimnagato nakraḥ śvānam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Some say that place is the best for the reason that a dog, seated in a convenient place, can drag a crocodile and that a crocodile in low ground can drag a dog

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kālaḥ śreyān ity eke // divā kākaḥ kauśikaṃ hanti, rātrau kauśikaḥ kākam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Others say that time is the best for the reason that during the daytime the crow kills the owl, and that at night the owl the crow

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // parasparasādhakā hi śaktideśakālāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, of strength, place, and time, each is helpful to the other;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / tair abhyuccitas tṛtīyaṃ caturthaṃ vā daṇḍasyaaṃśaṃ mūle pārṣṇyāṃ pratyantaaṭavīṣu ca rakṣā vidhāya kāryasādhanasahaṃ kośadaṇḍaṃ caādāya kṣīṇapurāṇabhaktam agṛhītanavabhaktam asaṃskṛtadurgamamitraṃ vārṣikaṃ caasya sasyaṃ haimanaṃ ca muṣṭim upahantuṃ mārgaśīrṣīṃ yātrāṃ yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever is possessed of these three things should, after having placed onethird or one fourth of his army to protect his base of operations against his rearenemy and wild tribes in his vicinity and after having taken with him as much army and treasure as is sufficient to accomplish his work, march during the month of Márgásírsha December against his enemy whose collection of foodstuffs is old and insipid and who has not only not gathered fresh foodstuffs, but also not repaired his fortifications, in order to destroy the enemys rainy crops and autumnal handfuls mushti

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: haimānaṃ caasya sasyaṃ vāsantikaṃ ca muṣṭim upahantuṃ caitrīṃ yātrāṃ yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should march during the month of Chaitra March, if he means to destroy the enemys autumnal crops and vernal handfuls

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣīṇakṛṇakāṣṭhaudakam asaṃskṛtadurgamamitraṃ vāsantikaṃ caasya sasyaṃ vārṣikīṃ ca muṣṭim upahantuṃ jyeṣṭhāmūlīyāṃ yātrāṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should march during the month of Jyestha MayJune against one whose storage of fodder, firewood and water has diminished and who has not repaired his fortifications, if he means to destroy the enemys vernal crops and handfuls of the rainy season

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atyuṣṇam alpayavasaindhanaudakaṃ vā deśaṃ hemante yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may march during the dewy season against a country which is of hot climate and in which fodder and water are obtained in little quantities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tuṣāradurdinam agādhanimnaprāyaṃ gahanatṛṇavṛkṣaṃ vā deśaṃ grīṣme yāyāt // svasainyavyāyāmayogyaṃ parasyaayogyaṃ varṣati yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may march during the summer against a country in which the sun is enshrouded by mist and which is full of deep Kautilyas Arthashastra valleys and thickets of trees and grass, or he may march during the rains against a country which is suitable for the manœuvre of his own army and which is of the reverse nature for his enemys army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mārgaśīrṣīṃ taiṣīṃ caantareṇa dīrghakālāṃ yātrāṃ yāyāt, caitrīṃ vaiśākhīṃ caantareṇa madhyamakālām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He has to undertake a long march between the months of Márgasírsha December and Taisha January, a march of mean length between March and April, and a short march between May and June;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upoṣiṣyan vyasane caturthīm //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and one, afflicted with troubles, should keep quiet

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanaabhiyānaṃ vigṛhyayāne vyākhyātam // prāyaśaś caācāryāḥ paravyasane yātavyam ity upadiśanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Marching against an enemy under troubles has been explained in connection with March after declaring war My teacher says that one should almost invariably march against an enemy in troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktyudaye yātavyam anaikānntikatvād vyasanānām iti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But Kautilya says that when ones resources are sufficient one should march, since the troubles of an enemy cannot be properly recognised;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadā vā prayātaḥ karśayitum ucchetuṃ vā śaknuyād amitraṃ tadā yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or whenever one finds it possible to reduce or destroy an enemy by marching against him, then one may undertake a march

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atyuṣṇaupakṣīṇe kāle hastibalaprāyo yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the weather is free from heat, one should march with an army mostly composed of elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastino hy antaḥsvedāḥ kuṣṭhino bhavanti // anavagāhamānās toyam apibantaś caantaravakṣārāc caandhībhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Elephants with profuse sweat in hot weather are attacked by leprosy; and when they have no water for bathing and drinking, they lose their quickness and become obstinate

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmāt prabhūtaudake deśe varṣati ca hastibalaprāyo yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, against a country containing plenty of water and during the rainy season, one should march with an army mostly composed of elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye kharauṣṭraaśvabalaprāyo deśam alpavarṣapaṅkam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Against a country of the reverse description, ie, which as little rain and muddy water, one should march with an army mostly composed of asses, camels, and horses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: varṣati maruprāyaṃ caturaṅgabalo yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Against a desert, one should march during the rainy season with all the four constituents of the army elephants, horses, chariots, and men

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samaviṣamanimnasthalahrasvadīrghavaśena vāadhvano yātrāṃ vibhajet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One should prepare a programme of short and long distances to be marched in accordance with the nature of the ground to be traversed, viz, even ground, uneven ground, valleys Kautilyas Arthashastra and plains

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvā vā hrasvakālāḥ syur yātavyāḥ kāryalāghavāt /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the work to be accomplished is small, march against all kinds of enemies should be of short duration;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dīrghāḥ kāryagurutvād vā varṣāvāsaḥ paratra ca //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when it is great, it should also be of long duration; during the rains, encampment should be made abroad

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (balaupādānakālāh samnāhaguṇāh pratibalakarma)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and twentysecond chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER THE TIME OF RECRUITING THE ARMY;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maulabhṛtakaśreṇīmitraamitraaṭavībalānāṃ samuddānakālāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE time of recruiting troops, such as hereditary troops maula, hired troops, corporation of soldiers srení, troops belonging to a friend or to an enemy, and wild tribes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mūlarakṣaṇād atiriktaṃ maulabalam, atyāvāpayuktā vā maulā mūle vikurvīran,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he a king thinks that his hereditary army is more than he requires for the defence of his own possessions or when he thinks that as his hereditary army consists of more men than he requires, some of them may be disaffected;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahulaanuraktamaulabalaḥ sārabalo vā pratiyoddhā, vyāyāmena yoddhavyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he thinks that his enemy has a strong hereditary army famous for its attachment, and is, therefore, to be fought out with much skill on his part;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prakṛṣṭeadhvani kāle vā kṣayavyayasahatvān maulānām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he thinks that though the roads are good and the weather favourable, it is still the hereditary army that can endure wear and tear;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahulaanuraktasampāte ca yātavyasyaupajāpabhayād anyasainyānāṃ bhṛtaādīnām aviśvāse,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he thinks that though they are famous for their attachment, hired soldiers and other kinds of troops cannot be relied upon lest they might lend their ears to the intrigues of the Kautilyas Arthashastra enemy to be invaded;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balakṣaye vā sarvasainyānāṃ iti maulabalakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he thinks that other kinds of force are wanting in strength, then is the time for taking the hereditary army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prabhūtaṃ me bhṛtabalam alpaṃ ca maulabalamṇ parasyaalpaṃ viraktaṃ vā maulabalam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he thinks that the army he has hired is greater than his hereditary army; that his enemys hereditary army is small and disaffected, while the army his enemy has hired is insignificant and weak;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśaḥ kālo vā tanukṣayavyayahṇ alpaāvāpaṃ śāntaupajāpaṃ viśvastaṃ vā me sainyamṇ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that the place to be traversed and the time required do not entail much loss; that his own army is little given to stupor, is beyond the fear of intrigue, and is reliable;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasyaalpaḥ prasāro hantavyahṇ iti bhṛtabalakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that little is the enemys power which he has to put down, then is the time for leading the hired army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prabhūtaṃ me śreṇībalam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that he has to be absent only for a short time;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śreṇībalaprāyaḥ pratiyoddhā mantravyāyāmābhyāṃ pratiyoddhukāmaḥ, daṇḍabalavyavahāraḥ iti śreṇībalakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that his enemys army consists mostly of soldiers of corporations, and consequently the enemy is desirous of carrying on treacherous fight rather than an actual war, then is the time for the enlistment of corporations of soldiers srení

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / prabhūtaṃ me mitrabalaṃ śakyaṃ mūle yātrāyāṃ caādhātumṇ alpaḥ pravāso
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he thinks that the strong help he has in his friend can be made use of both in his own country and in his marches; that he has to be absent only for a short time, and actual fight is more than treacherous fight;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsāraṃ vā yodhayitvā paścāt svabalena yoddhayiṣyāmiṇ mitrasādhāraṇaṃ vā me kāryamṇ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that having made his friends army to occupy wild tracts, cities, or plains and to fight with the enemys ally, he, himself, would lead his own army to fight with the enemys army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraāyattā vā me kāryasiddhihṇ āsannam anugrāhyaṃ vā me mitramṇ atyāvāpaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that his work can be accomplished by his friend as well; that his success depends on his friend; that he has a friend near and deserving of obligation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāasya sādayiṣyāmi iti mitrabalakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or that he has to utilize the excessive force of his friend, then is the time for the enlistment of a friends army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatrubalena yodhayiṣyāmi nagarasthānam aṭavīṃ vā, tatra me śvavarāhayoḥ kalahe caṇḍālasyaivaanyatarasiddhir bhaviṣyatiṇ āsārāṇām aṭavīnāṃ vā kaṇṭakamardanam etat kariṣyāmiṇ atyupacitaṃ vā kopabhayān nityam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he thinks that he will have to make his strong enemy to fight against another enemy on account of a city, a plain, or a wild Kautilyas Arthashastra tract of land, and that in that fight he will achieve one or the other of his objects, just like an outcast person in the fight between a dog and a pig; that through the battle, he will have the mischievous power of his enemys allies or of wild tribes destroyed;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsannam aribalaṃ vāsayed, anyatraabhyantarakopaśaṅkāyāḥ śatruyuddhaavarayuddhakālaś ca ity amitrabalakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that he will have to make his immediate and powerful enemy to march elsewhere and thus get rid of internal rebellion which his enemy might have occasioned; and that the time of battle between enemies or between inferior kings has arrived, then is the time for the exercise of an enemys forces

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tenaaṭavībalakālo vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the time for the engagement of wild tribes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mārgaādeśikam, parabhūmiyogyam, ariyuddhapratilomam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that the road is unfavourable for the march of his enemys army; that his enemys army consists mostly of wild tribes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṭavībalaprāyaḥ śatrur vā, bilvaṃ bilvena hanyatāmṇ alpaḥ prasāro hantavyaḥ ity aṭavībalakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that just as a woodapple bilva is broken by means of another woodapple, the small army of his enemy is to be destroyed, then is the time for engaging the army of wild tribes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sainyam anekam anekastham uktam anuktaṃ vā vilopaarthaṃ yad uttiṣṭhati tad autsāhikaṃ abhaktavetanaṃ vilopaviṣṭipratāpakaraṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That army which is vast and is composed of various kinds of men and is so enthusiastic as to rise even without provision and wages for plunder when told or untold; that which is capable of applying its own remedies against unfavourable rains;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhedyaṃ pareṣām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which can be disbanded and which is invincible for enemies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhedyaṃ tulyadeśajātiśilpaprāyaṃ saṃhataṃ mahat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and that, of which all the men are of the same country, same caste, and same training, is to be considered as a compact body of vast power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: [iti balaupādānakālāh]
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such are the periods of time for recruiting the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ kupyabhṛtam amitraaṭavībalaṃ vilopabhṛtaṃ vā kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these armies, one has to pay the army of wild tribes either with raw produce or with allowance for plunder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amitrasya vā balakāle pratyutpanne śatrubalam avagṛhṇīyāt, anyatra vā preṣayet, aphalaṃ vā kuryāt, vikṣiptaṃ vā vāsayet, kāle vāatikrānte visṛjet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the time for the march of ones enemys army has approached, one has to obstruct the enemy or send him far away, or Kautilyas Arthashastra make his movements fruitless, or, by false promise, cause him to delay the march, and then deceive him after the time for his march has passed away

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya caetad balasamuddānaṃ vighātayet, ātmanaḥ sampādayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One should ever be vigilant to increase ones own resources and frustrate the attempts of ones enemy to gain in strength

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ caeṣāṃ śreyaḥ samnāhayitum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these armies, that which is mentioned first is better than the one subsequently mentioned in the order of enumeration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadbhāvabhāvitvān nityasatkāraanugamāc ca maulabalaṃ bhṛtabalātśreyaḥ // nityaanantaraṃ kṣiprautthāyi vaśyaṃ va bhṛtabalaṃ śreṇībalātśreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hereditary army is better than hired army inasmuch as the former has its existence dependent on that of its master, and is constantly drilled That kind of hired army which is ever near, ready to rise quickly, and obedient, is better than a corporation of soldiers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jānapadam ekaarthaupagataṃ tulyasaṃgharṣaamarṣasiddhilābhaṃ ca śreṇībalaṃ mitrabalātśreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That corporation of soldiers which is native, which has the same end in view as the king, and which is actuated with similar feelings of rivalry, anger, and expectation of success and gain, is better than the army of a friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aparimitadeśakālam ekaarthaupagamāc ca mitrabalam amitrabalātśreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Even that corporation of soldiers which is further removed in place and time is, in virtue of its having the same end in view, better than the army of a friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āryaadhiṣṭhitam amitrabalam aṭavībalātśreyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The army of an enemy under the leadership of an Arya is better than the army of wild tribes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ubhayaṃ vilopaartham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Both of them the army of an enemy and of wild tribes are anxious for plunder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avilope vyasane ca tābhyām ahibhayaṃ syāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of plunder and under troubles, they prove as dangerous as a lurking snake

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: brāhmaṇakṣatriyavaiśyaśūdrasainyānāṃ tejaḥprādhānyāt pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ śreyaḥ samnāhayitum ity ācāryāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: My teacher says that of the armies composed of Bráhmans, Kshatriyas, Vaisyas, or Súdras, that which is mentioned first is, on account of bravery, better to be enlisted than the one subsequently mentioned in the order of enumeration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // praṇipātena brāhmaṇabalaṃ paroabhihārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra No, says Kautilya, the enemy may win over to himself the army of Bráhmans by means of prostration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: praharaṇavidyāvinītaṃ tu kṣatriyabalaṃ śreyaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, the army of Kshatriyas trained in the art of wielding weapons is better;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahulasāraṃ vā vaiśyaśūdrabalam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or the army of Vaisyas or Súdras having great numerical strength is better

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyaetat pratibalam iti balasamuddānaṃ kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence one should recruit one‟s army, reflecting that such is the army of my enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastiyantraśakaṭagarbhakuntaprāsahāṭakaveṇuśalyavad hastibalasya pratibalam // tad eva pāṣāṇalaguḍaāvaraṇaaṅkuśakacagrahaṇīprāyaṃ rathabalasya pratibalam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and this is my army to oppose it The army which possesses elephants, machines, sakatagarbha ?, Kunta a wooden rod, prása a weapon, inches long, with two handles, Kharvataka ?, bamboo sticks, and iron sticks is the army to oppose an army of elephants The same possessed of stones, clubs, armour, hooks, and spears in plenty is the army to oppose an army of chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad evaaśvānāṃ pratibalam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same is the army to oppose cavalry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: varmiṇo vā hastinoaśvā vā varmiṇaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Men, clad in armour, can oppose elephants Horses can oppose men, clad in armour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kavacino rathā āvaraṇinaḥ pattayaś ca caturaṅgabalasya pratibalam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Men , clad in armour, chariots, men possessing defensive weapons, and infantry can oppose an army consisting of all the four constituents elephants, chariots, cavalry and infantry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ balasamuddānaṃ parasainyanivāraṇam / vibhavena svasainyānāṃ kuryād aṅgavikalpaśaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thusconsidering the strength of the constituents of one‟s own quadripartite army, one should recruit men to it so as to oppose an enemy‟s army successfully

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (paścātkopacintā bāhyaabhyantaraprakṛtikopapratīkārah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: CONSIDERATION OF ANNOYANCE IN THE REAR; AND REMEDIES AGAINST INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL TROUBLES

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alpaḥ paścātkopo mahān purastāllābha iti alpaḥ paścātkopo garīyān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: OF the two things, slight annoyance in the rear, and considerable profit in the front, slight annoyance in the rear is more serious;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alpaṃ paścātkopaṃ prayātassya dūṣyaamitraāṭavikā hi sarvataḥ samedhayanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for traitors, enemies, and wild tribes augment on all sides the slight annoyance which one may have in the rear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: labdham api ca mahāntaṃ purastāllāham evaṃbhūte bhṛtyamitrakṣayavyayā grasante // tasmāt sahasraekīyaḥ purastāllābhasyaayogaḥ śataekīyo vā paścātkopa iti na yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The members of ones own state may be provoked about the acquisition of considerable profit in the front When one under the protection of another has come to such a condition ie, slight annoyance in the rear and considerable profit in the front, then one should endeavour so as to cause to the rear enemy the loss and impoverishment of his servants and friends;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purastāllābhe senāpatiṃ kumāraṃ vā daṇḍacāriṇaṃ kurvīta // balavān vā rājā paścātkopaavagrahasamarthaḥ purastāllābham ādātuṃ yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and in order to fetch the profit in the front, one should also employ the commander of the army or the heirapparent to lead the army Or the king himself may go in person to receive the profit in the front, if he is able to ward off the annoyance in the rear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhyantarakopaśaṅkāyāṃ śaṅkitān ādāya yāyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is apprehensive of internal troubles, he may take with him the suspected leaders

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bāhyakopaśaṅkāyāṃ vā putradāram eṣām // abhyantaraavagrahaṃ kṛtvā śūnyapālam anekabalavargam anekamukhyaṃ ca sthāpayitvā yāyāt, na vā yāyāt // abhyantarakopo bāhyakopāt pāpīyān ity uktaṃ purastāt // mantrapurohitasenāpatiyuvarājānām anyatamakopoabhyantarakopaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he is apprehensive of external troubles, he should march after keeping inside his capital as hostages the sons and wives of suspected enemies and after having split into a number of divisions the troops of the officer in charge of waste lands súnyapála and having placed those divisions under the command of several chiefs, or he may abandon his march, for it has been already stated that internal troubles are more serious than external troubles Kautilyas Arthashastra 00 The provocation of any one of the minister, the priest, the commanderinchief, and the heirapparent is what is termed internal trouble

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam ātmadoṣatyāgena paraśaktyaparādhavaśena vā sādhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The king should get rid of such an internal enemy either by giving up his own fault or by pointing out the danger arising from an external enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahāaparādheapi purohite samrodhanam avasrāvaṇaṃ vā siddhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the priest is guilty of the gravest treason, relief should be found either by confining him or by banishing him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yuvarāje samrodhanaṃ nigraho vā guṇavaty anyasmin sati putre //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when the heirapparent is so, confinement or death nigraha, provided that there is another son of good character

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: putraṃ bhrātaram anyaṃ vā kulyaṃ rājagrāhiṇam utsāhena sādhayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a son, or a brother, or any other person of the royal family attempts to seize the kingdom, he should be won over by holding out hopes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utsāhaabbhāve gṛhītaanuvartanasaṃdhikarmabhyām arisaṃdhānabhayāt // anyebhyas tadvidhebhyo vā bhūmidānair viśvāsayed enam // tadviśiṣṭaṃ svayaṃgrāhaṃ daṇḍaṃ vā preṣayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when this is not possible, he should be conciliated by allowing him to enjoy what he has already seized, or by making an agreement with him, or by means of intrigue through an enemy, or by securing to him land from an enemy, or any other person of inimical character Or he may be sent out on a mission with an inimical force to receive the only punishment he deserves;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmantaāṭavikān vā, tair vigṛhītam atisaṃdadhyāt // aparuddhaādānaṃ pāragrāmikaṃ vā yogam ātiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or a conspiracy may be made with a frontier king or wild tribes whose displeasure he has incurred; or the same policy that is employed in securing an imprisoned prince or in seizing an enemys villages may be resorted to

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantryādivarjānām antaramātyānām anyatamakopoantaramātyakopaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The provocation of ministers other than the prime minister is what is called the internal ministerial troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatraapi yathāarham upāyān prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Even in this case, necessary strategic means should be employed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rāṣṭramukhyaantapālaāṭavikadaṇḍaupanatānām anyatamakopo bāhyakopaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The provocation of the chief of a district ráshramukhya, the officer in charge of the boundary, the chief of wild tribes, and a conquered king is what is termed external trouble

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam anyonyenaavagrāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This should be overcome by setting one against the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atidurgapratiṣṭabdhaṃ vā sāmantaāṭavikatatkulīnaaparuddhānām anyatamenaavagrāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever among these has strongly fortified himself should be caught hold of through the agency of a frontier king, or the chief of wild tribes, or a scion of Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 his family, or an imprisoned prince;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitreṇaupagrāhayed vā yathā naamitraṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may be captured through the agency of a friend, so that he may not combine with an enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amitrād vā sattrī bhedayed enaṃ ayaṃ tvā yogapuruṣaṃ manyamāno bhartary eva vikramayiṣyati, avāptaartho daṇḍacāriṇam amitraāṭavikeṣu kṛcchre vā prayāse yokṣyati, viputradāram ante vā vāsayiṣyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or a spy may prevent him from combining with an enemy by saying This enemy makes a catspaw of you and causes you to fall upon your own lord; When his aim is realised, he makes you to lead an army against enemies or wild tribes, or to sojourn in a troublesome place; or he causes you to reside at a frontier station far from the company of your sons and wife

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratihatavikramaṃ tvāṃ bhartary paṇyaṃ kariṣyati, tvayā vā saṃdhiṃ kṛtvā bhartāram eva prasādayiṣyati // mitram upakṛṣṭaṃ vāasya gaccha iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When you have lost all your strength, he sells you to your own lord; or having made peace with you, he will please your own lord Hence it is advisable for you to go to the best friend of your lord When he agrees to the proposal, he is to be honoured;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apratipannasya saṃśrayaṃ bhedayed asau te yogapuruṣaḥ praṇihitaḥ iti // sattrī caenam abhityaktaśāsanair ghātayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but when he refuses to listen, he is to be told am specially sent to separate you from the enemy The spy should however appoint some persons to murder him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūḍhapuruṣair vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may be killed by some concealed persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sahaprasthāyino vāasya pravīrapuruṣān yathāabhiprāyakaraṇenaāvāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or some persons pretending to be brave soldiers may be made to accompany him and may be told by a spy to murder him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the end of troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya caenān kopān utthāpayet, ātmanaś ca śamayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One should cause such troubles to ones enemy and ward off those of ones own

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yaḥ kopaṃ kartuṃ śamayituṃ vā śaktas tatraupajāpaḥ kāryaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the case of a person who is capable of causing or alleviating troubles, intrigue should be made use of;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yaḥ satyasaṃdhaḥ śaktaḥ karmaṇi phalaavāptau caanugrahītuṃ vinipāte ca trātuṃ tatra pratijāpaḥ kāryaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and in the case of a person who is of reliable character, able to undertake works, and to favour his ally in his success, and to afford protection against calamities, counterintrigue pratijápa should be made use of to keep his friendship secure

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tarkayitavyaś ca kalyāṇabuddhir utaaho śaṭha iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It should also be considered whether the person is of good disposition or of obstinate temper satha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaṭho hi bāhyoabhyantaram evam upajapati bhartāraṃ cedd hatvā māṃ pratipādayiṣyati śatruvadho bhūmilābhaś ca me dvividho
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The intrigue carried on by a foreigner of obstinate temper with local persons is of the following formIf after killing his own master, he comes to me, then will secure these two objects, the destruction of my enemy and the acquisition of the enemys lands;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atha vā śatrur enam āhaniṣyatiiti hatabandhupakṣas tulyadoṣadaṇḍenaudvignaś ca me bhūyān akṛtyapakṣo bhaviṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or else my enemy kills him, with the consequence that the Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 partisans of the relations killed, and other persons who are equally guilty and are therefore apprehensive of similar punishment to themselves will perturb my enemys peace when my enemy has no friends to count;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyam anyaṃ caasya mukhyam abhityaktaśāsanena ghātayiṣyāmi iti // abhyantaro vā śaṭho bāhyam evam upajapati kośam asya hariṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when my enemy falls to suspect any other person who is equally guilty, shall be able to cause the death of this or that officer under my enemys own command The intrigue carried on by a local person of obstinate temper with a foreigner is of the following formI shall either plunder the treasury of this king or destroy his army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: duṣṭaṃ vā bhartāram anena ghātayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall murder my master by employing this man;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannaṃ bāhyam amitraāṭavikeṣu vikramayiṣyāmi cakram asya sajyatām, vairam asya prasajyatām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if my master consents, shall cause him to march against an external enemy or a wild tribe; let his Circle of States be brought to confusion, let him incur enmity with them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ svaadhīno me bhaviṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: then it is easy to keep him under my power, and conciliate him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svayaṃ vā rājyaṃ grahīṣyāmiṇ baddhvā vā bāhyabhūmiṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or myself shall seize the kingdom; or, having bound him in chains, shall obtain both my masters land and outside land;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viruddhaṃ vāāvāhayitvā bāhyaṃ viśvastaṃ ghātayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having caused the enemy of my master to march out, shall cause the enemy to be murdered in good faith;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūnyaṃ vāasya mūlaṃ hariṣyāmi iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or shall seize the enemys capital when it is empty of soldiers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalyāṇabuddhis tu sahajīvy artham upajapati // kalyāṇabuddhinā saṃdadhīta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a person of good disposition makes a conspiracy for the purpose of acquiring what is to be enjoyed by both then an agreement should be made with him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaṭhaṃ tathā iti pratigṛhyaatisaṃdadhyāt iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the form of policy to be adopted should be considered

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam upalabhya pare parebhyaḥ sve svebhyaḥ sve parebhyaḥ svataḥ pare / rakṣyāḥ svebhyaḥ parebhyaś ca nityam ātmā vipaścitā //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Enemies from enemies, subjects from subjects, subjects from enemies, and enemies from subjects should ever be guarded; and both from his subjects and enemies, a learned man should ever guard his own person

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (kṣayavyayalābhaviparimarśah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and twentyfourth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yugyapuruṣaapacayaḥ kṣayaḥ // hiraṇyadhānyaapacayo vyayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: CONSIDERATION ABOUT LOSS OF MEN, WEALTH, AND PROFIT Loss of trained men is what is called kshaya, loss of men Diminution of gold and grains is loss of wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tābhyāṃ bahuguṇaviśiṣṭe lābhe yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the expected profit overweighs both these; then one should march against an enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ādeyaḥ pratyādeyaḥ prasādakaḥ prakopako hrasvakālas tanukṣayoalpavyayo mahān vṛddhyudayaḥ kalyo dharmyaḥ purogaś caiti lābhasampat
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The characteristics of an expected profit are that which is receivable, that which is to be returned, that which pleases all, that which excites hatred, that which is realised in a short time, that which entails little loss of men to earn, that which entails little loss of wealth to earn, that which is vast, that which is productive, that which is harmless, that which is just, and that which comes first

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suprāpyaanupālyaḥ pareṣām apratyādeya ity ādeyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a profit is easily acquired and secured without the necessity of returning it to others, it is termed „receivable‟;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye pratyādeyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is of the reverse nature is „repayable‟;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam ādadānas tatrastho vā vināśaṃ prāpnoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever goes to receive a repayable profit or is enjoying it gets destruction

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yadi vā paśyet pratyādeyam ādāya kośadaṇḍanicayarakṣāvidhānāny avasrāvayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he, however, thinks that by taking a repayable profit shall cause my enemy‟s treasury, army, and other defensive resources to dwindle;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khanidravyahastivanasetubandhavaṇikpathān uddhṛtasārān kariṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall exploit to impoverishment the mines, timber and elephant forests, irrigational works and roads of traffic of my enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apavāhayiṣyāmi, āyogenaārādhayiṣyāmi vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall impoverish his subjects, or cause them to migrate, or conspire against him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāḥ paraṃ pratiyogena kopayiṣyati, pratipakṣe vāasya paṇyam enaṃ kariṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when they are reduced to this condition, my enemy inflames their hatred by punishing them; or shall set my enemy against another enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitram āśrayaṃ vāasya vaiguṇyaṃ grāhayiṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: my enemy will give up his hopes and run away to one who has some bloodrelationship Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 with him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃhitasamutthitaṃ mitraṃ me cirāya bhaviṣyati iti pratyādeyam api lābham ādadīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having improved his lands, shall return them to him, and when he is thus brought to ascendancy, he will be a lasting friend of mine,then he may take even a repayable profit

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity ādeyapratyādeyau vyākhyātau //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus receivable and repayable profits are explained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adhārmikād dhārmikasya lābho labhyamānaḥ sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca prasādako bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That profit which a virtuous king receives from a wicked king pleases both his own and other people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītaḥ prakopaka iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is of the reverse nature excites hatred;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantriṇām upadeśāl lābhoalabhyamānaḥ kopako bhavati ayam asmābhiḥ kṣayavyayau grāhitaḥ iti // dūṣyamantriṇām anādarāl lābho labhyamānaḥ kopako bhavati siddhaarthoayam asmān vināśayiṣyati iti // viparītaḥ prasādakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that profit which is received at the advice of ministers excites hatred, for they think „This king has reduced our party and impoverished us That profit which is received without caring for the opinion of treacherous ministers excites hatred, for they think Having made the profit, this king destroys us But that which is of the reverse nature pleases

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti prasādakakopakau vyākhyātau
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus pleasing and provoking profits are explained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gamanamātrasādhyatvād hrasvakālah mantrasādhyatvāt tanukṣayaḥ // bhaktamātravyayatvād alpavyayah
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is to be realised by negotiation mantrasáddhya entails little loss of men That which requires merely the expenditure of provisions for servants employed to earn it entails little loss of wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadātvavaipulyān mahān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is immediately of considerable value is vast

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthaanubandhakatvād vṛddhyudayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is the source of wealth is productive

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nirābādhakatvāt kalyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is attained with no troubles is harmless

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: praśastaupādānād dharmyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is acquired best is just

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmavāyikānām anirbandhagāmitvāt purogaḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is acquired without any hindrance from allies is profit coming first

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / tulye lābhe deśakālau śaktyupāyau priyaapriyau javaajavau sāmīpyaviprakarṣau
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 When profits from two sources are equal, he should consider the place and time, the strength and means required to acquire it, affection and disaffection caused by it, intrigue and absence of intrigue involving it, its nearness and distance, its present and future effects, its constant worth or worthlessness, and its plentifulness and usefulness;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadātvaanubandhau sāratvasātatye bāhulyabāhuguṇye ca vimṛśya bahuguṇayuktaṃ lābham ādadīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and he should accept only that profit which is possessed of most of the above good characteristics

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / lābhavighnāḥ kāmaḥ kopaḥ sādhvasaṃ kāruṇyaṃ hrīr anāryabhāvo mānaḥ sānukrośatā paralokaapekṣā dhārmikatvam atyāgitvaṃ dainyam asūyā hastagataavamāno
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Obstructions to profit are passion, anger, timidity, mercy, bashfulness, living like one who is not an Arya, haughtiness, pity, desire for the other world, strict adherence to virtuous life, deception, neediness, envy, negligence of what is at hand, generosity, want of faith, fear, inability to endure cold, heat, and rain, and faith in the auspiciousness of lunar days and stars

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nakṣatram ati pṛcchantaṃ bālam arthoativartate /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wealth will pass away from that childish man who inquires most after the stars; for wealth is the star for wealth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: artho hy arthasya nakṣatraṃ kiṃ kariṣyanti tārakāḥ // naadhanāḥ prāpnuvanty arthān narā yatnaśatair api / arthair arthā prabadhyante gajāḥ prajigajair iva //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: what will the stars do? Capable men will certainly secure wealth at least after a hundred trials; and wealth is bound by wealth just as elephants are bound by counterelephants [Thus ends Chapter , Consideration about Loss of Men, Wealth and Profit,‟ in Book , The Work of an Invader, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (bāhyaabhyantarāś caāpadah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and twentyfifth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhyādīnām ayathāuddeśaavasthāpanam apanayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE formation of a treaty and other settlements otherwise Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 than they ought to have been made is impolicy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād āpadaḥ sambhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: From it arise dangers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bāhyautpattir abhyantarapratijāpā, abhyantarautpattir bāhyapratijāpā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The various kinds of dangers are that which is of external origin and of internal abetment; that which is of internal origin and of external abetment;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bāhyautpattir bāhyapratijāpā, abhyantarautpattir abhyantarapratijāpā ity āpadaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is of external origin and of external abetment; and that which is of internal origin and of internal abetment

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatra bāhyā abhyantaraanupajapanti, abhyantarā vā bāhyān, tatraubhayayoge pratijapataḥ siddhir viśeṣavatī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Where foreigners carry on an intrigue with local men or local men with foreigners, there the consequence of the intrigue carried on by the combination of local and foreign persons will be very serious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suvyājā hi pratijapitāro bhavanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Abettors of an intrigue have a better chance of success than its originators;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naupajapitāraḥ // teṣu praśānteṣu naanyānśaknuyur upajapitum upajapitāraḥ // kṛcchraupajāpā hi bāhyānām abhyantarās teṣām itare vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when the originators of an intrigue are put down, others will hardly succeed in undertaking any other intrigue Foreigners can hardly win over local persons by intrigue; nor can local men seduce foreigners

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahataś ca prayatnasya vadhaḥ pareṣām, arthaanubandhaś caātmana iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Foreigners will find their vast efforts after all unavailing, and only conducive, to the prosperity of the king against whom they want to conspire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhyantareṣu pratijapatsu sāmadāne prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When local persons are abetting with foreigners, the means to be employed to suppress them are conciliation sáma and gifts dána

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthānamānakarma sāntvam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The act of pleasing a man with a high rank and honour is conciliation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anugrahaparihārau karmasv āyogo vā dānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: favour and remission of taxes or employment to conduct stateworks is what is termed gifts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bāhyeṣu pratijapatsu bhedadaṇḍau prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When foreigners are abetting, the king should employ the policy of dissension and coercion

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sattriṇo mitravyañjanā vā bāhyānāṃ cāram eṣāṃ brūyuḥ ayaṃ vo rājā dūṣyavyañjanair atisaṃdhātukāmaḥ, budhyadhvam iti // dūṣyeṣu vā dūṣyavyañjanāḥ praṇihitā dūṣyān bāhyair bhedayeyuḥ, bāhyān vā dūṣyaiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies under the guise of friends may inform foreigners Mind, this man is desirous of deceiving you with the help of his own spies who are disguised as traitors Spies under the garb of traitors may mix with traitors and separate them from foreigners, or foreigners from local traitors

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyān anupraviṣṭā vā tīkṣṇāḥ śastrarasābhyāṃ hanyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Fiery spies may make friendship with traitors and kill them with weapons or Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 poison;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āhūya vā bāhyān ghātayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having invited the plotting foreigners, they may murder the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatra bāhyā bāhyān upajapanti, abhyantarān abhyantarā vā, tatraekāntayoga upajapituḥ siddhir viśeṣavatī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Where foreigners carry on an intrigue with foreigners, or local men with local men, there the consequences of the intrigue, unanimously carried on with a set purpose, will be very serious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: doṣaśuddhau hi dūṣyā na vidyante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When guilt is got rid of, there will be no guilty persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaśuddhau hi doṣaḥ punar anyān dūṣayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but when a guilty person is got rid of, the guilt will contaminate others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād bāhyeṣuupajapatsu bhedadaṇḍau prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, when foreigners carry on an intrigue, the king should employ the policy of dissension and coercion

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sattriṇo mitravyañjanā vā brūyuḥ ayaṃ vo rājā svayam ādātukāmaḥ, vigṛhītāḥ sthānena rājñā, budhyadhvam iti // pratijapitur vā dūtadaṇḍān anupraviṣṭās tīkṣṇāḥ śastrarasaādibhir eṣāṃ chidreṣu prahareyuḥ //
