Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies under the guise of friends may inform foreign conspirators Mind, this your king, with the desire of enriching himself, is naturally provoked against you all Then fiery spies may mix with the servants and soldiers of the abettor of foreign conspirators and kill them with weapons, poison, and other means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sattriṇaḥ pratijapitāram abhiśaṃseyuḥ // abhyantarān abhyantareṣuupajapatsu yathāarham upāyaṃ prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Other spies may then expose or betray the abettor When local men carry on an intrigue with local men, the king should employ necessary strategic means to put it down

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tuṣṭaliṅgam atuṣṭaṃ viparītaṃ vā sāma prayuñjīta // śaucasāmarthyaapadeśena vyasanaabhyudayaavekṣaṇena vā pratipūjanam iti dānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may employ the policy of conciliation with regard to those who keep the appearance of contentment, or who are naturally discontented or otherwise Gifts may be given under the pretext of having been satisfied with a favoured mans steadfastness in maintaining the purity of his character, or under the plea of anxious care about his weal or woe

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitravyañjano vā brūyād etān cittajñānaartham upadhāsyati vo rājā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A spy under the garb of a friend may tell the local persons „Your king is attempting to find your heart;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad asyaākhyātavyam iti // parasparād vā bhedayed enān asau caasau ca vo rājany evam upajapati iti bhedaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: you should tell him the truth Or local men may be separated from each other, by telling them This man carries such a tale to the king against you And coercive measures may be employed as described in the Chapter on Awards of Punishments Of these four kinds of danger, internal danger should first be got rid of;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etāsāṃ catasṛṇām āpadām abhyantarām eva pūrvaṃ sādhayet // ahibhayād abhyantarakopo bāhyakopāt pāpīyān ity uktaṃ purastād // pūrvāṃ pūrvāṃ vijānīyāl laghvīm āpadam āpadām /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it has been already stated that internal troubles like the fear from a lurking snake are more serious than external troubles Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 One must consider that of these four kinds of danger, that which is mentioned first is less grave than the one subsequently mentioned, whether or not it is caused by powerful persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utthitāṃ balavadbhyo vā gurvīṃ laghvīṃ viparyaye //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise ie, when the danger is caused by insignificant persons, simple means may be used to get rid of it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (dūṣyaśatrusamyuktāh āpadah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and twentysixth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyebhyaḥ śatrubhyaś ca dvividhā śuddhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: PERSONS ASSOCIATED WITH TRAITORS AND ENEMIES THERE are two kinds of innocent persons, those who have disassociated themselves from traitors and those who have kept themselves away from enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaśuddhāyāṃ paureṣu jānapadeṣu vā daṇḍavarjān upāyān prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In order to separate citizens and countrypeople from traitors, the king should employ all the strategic means, except coercion

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍo hi mahājane kṣeptum aśakyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is very difficult to inflict punishment on an assembly of influential men;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣipto vā taṃ caarthaṃ na kuryāt, anyaṃ caanartham utpādayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and if inflicted at all, it may not produce the desired effect, but may give rise to undesirable consequences

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mukhyeṣu tv eṣāṃ dāṇḍakarmikavac ceṣṭeta // śatruśuddhāyāṃ yataḥ śatruḥ pradhānaḥ kāryo vā tataḥ sāmaādibhiḥ siddhiṃ lipseta // svāminy āyattā pradhānasiddhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may, however, take steps against the leaders of the seditious as shown in the chapter on Awards of Punishments In order to separate his people from an enemy, he should employ conciliation and other strategic means to frustrate the attempt of those who are the enemys principal agents or by whom the enemys work is to be carried out

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantriṣv āyattāāyattasiddhiḥ, ubhayaāyattā pradhānaāyattasiddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: success of efforts depends upon ministers; and success to be achieved through capable agents is, therefore, dependent both upon the king and his ministers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaadūṣyāṇām āmiśritatvād āmiśrā // āmiśrāyām adūṣyataḥ siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, in spite of the combination of traitors and loyal persons, success is achieved, it is mixed success; when people are thus mixed, success is to be achieved through the agency of loyal persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ālambanaabhāve hy ālambitā na vidyante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for in the absence of a support, nothing that requires a support for its existence can exist

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraamitrāṇām ekībhāvāt paramiśrā // paramiśrāyāṃ mitrataḥ siddhiḥ // sukaro hi mitreṇa saṃdhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When success is involved in the union of friends and enemies it is termed a success contaminated by an enemy; when success is contaminated by an enemy, it is to be achieved through the agency of a friend; for it is easy to attain success through a friend, but not through an enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraṃ cen na saṃdhim icched abhīkṣṇam upajapet // tataḥ sattribhir amitrād bhedayitvā mitraṃ labheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a friend does not come to terms, intrigue should be frequently resorted to Through the agency of spies, the friend should be won over after separating him from the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrasaṃghasya vā yoantasthāyī taṃ labheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or attempts may be made to win him over who is the last among combined friends;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: antasthāyini labdhe madhyasthāyino bhidyante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when he who is the last among combined friends is secured, those who occupy the middle rank will be separated from each other;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyasthāyinaṃ vā labheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or attempts may be made to win over a friend who occupies middle rank;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyasthāyini labdhe naantasthāyinaḥ saṃhanyante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when a friend occupying middle rank among combined kings is secured, friends, occupying the extreme ranks cannot keep the union

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā caeṣām āśrayabhedas tān upāyān prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In brief all those measures which tend to break their combination should be employed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhārmikaṃ jātikulaśrutavṛttastavena sambandhena pūrveṣāṃ traikālyaupakārān apakārābhyāṃ vā sāntvayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A virtuous king may be conciliated by praising his birth, family, learning and character, and by pointing out the relationship which his ancestors had with the proposer of peace, or by describing the benefits and absence of enmity shown to him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / nivṛttautsāhaṃ vigrahaśrāntaṃ pratihataupāyaṃ kṣayavyayābhyāṃ pravāsena caupataptaṃ śaucenaanyaṃ lipsamānam anyasmād vā śaṅkamānaṃ maitrīpradhānaṃ vā kalyāṇabuddhiṃ sāmnā sādhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or a king who is of good intentions, or who has lost his enthusiastic spirits, or whose strategic means are all exhausted and Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 thwarted in a number of wars, or who has lost his men and wealth, or who has suffered from sojourning abroad, or who is desirous of gaining a friend in good faith, or who is apprehensive of danger from another, or who cares more for friendship than anything else, may be won over by conciliation

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lubdhaṃ kṣīṇaṃ vā tapasvimukhyaavasthāpanāpūrvaṃ dānena sādhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or a king who is greedy or who has lost his men may be won over by giving gifts through the medium of ascetics and chiefs who have been previously kept with him for the purpose

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tat pañcavidhaṃ deyavisargo gṛhītaanuvartanam āttapratidānaṃ svadravyadānam apūrvaṃ parasveṣu svayaṃgrāhadānaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Gifts are of five kinds abandonment of what is to be paid; continuance of what is being given; repayment of what is received; payment of ones own wealth; and help for a voluntary raid on the property of others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasparadveṣavairabhūmiharaṇaśaṅkitam atoanyatamena bhedayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When any two kings are apprehensive of enmity and seizure of land from each other, seeds of dissension may be sown between them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhīruṃ vā pratighātena kṛtasaṃdhir eṣa tvayi karmakariṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The timid of the two may be threatened with destruction and may be told Having made peace with you, this king works against you;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitram asya nisṛṣṭam, saṃdhau vā naabhyantaraḥ iti // yasya vā svadeśād anyadeśād vā paṇyāni paṇyaagāratayāāgaccheyuḥ tāni asya yātavyāl labdhāni iti sattriṇaś cārayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the friend of this other king is permitted to make an open peace When from ones own country or from anothers country merchandise or commodities for manufacture in a manufactory are going to an enemys country, spies may spread the information that those commodities are obtained from one whom the enemy wanted to march against

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahulībhūte śāsanam abhityaktena preṣayet etat te paṇyaṃ paṇyaagāraṃ vā mayā te preṣitam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When commodities are thus gathered in abundance the owner of the articles may send a message to the enemy These commodities and merchandise are sent by me to you;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmavāyikeṣu vikramasva, apagaccha vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: please declare war against the combined kings or desert them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ paṇaśeṣam avāpsyasi iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: you will then get the rest of the tribute Then spies may inform the other kings of the combination;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sattriṇaḥ pareṣu grāhayeyuḥ etad aripradattam iti // śatruprakhyātaṃ vā paṇyam avijñātaṃ vijigīṣuṃ gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: These articles are given to him by your enemy Kautilyas Arthashastra The conqueror may gather some merchandise peculiar to his enemys country and unknown elsewhere

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad asya vaidehakavyañjanāḥ śatrumukhyeṣu vikrīṇīran // tataḥ sattriṇaḥ pareṣu grāhayeyuḥ etat paṇyam aripradattam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, under the garb of merchants, may sell that merchandise to other important enemies and tell them that that merchandise was given to the conqueror by the enemy whose countrys product it is

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahāaparādhān arthamānābhyām upagṛhya vā śastrarasaagnibhir amitre praṇidadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having pleased with wealth and honour those who are highly treacherous among an enemys people, the conqueror may cause them to live with the enemy, armed with weapons, poison and fire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaekam amātyaṃ niṣpātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One of the ministers of the enemy may be killed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya putradāram upagṛhya rātrau hatam iti khyāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: His sons and wife may be induced to say that the minister was killed at night by such and such a person

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaamātyaḥ śatros tān ekaekaśaḥ prarūpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then the enemys minister may ask every one of the family of the murdered minister as to the cause of the death

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: te ced yathāuktaṃ kuryur na caenān grāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If they say in reply as they are told, they may be caused to be set free;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśaktimato vā grāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if they do not do so, they may be caused to be caught hold of

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āptabhāvaupagato mukhyād asyaātmānaṃ rakṣaṇīyaṃ kathayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever has gained the confidence of the king may tell the king the enemy that he the enemy has to guard his own person from such and such a minister

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaamitraśāsanaṃ mukhyaupaghātāya preṣitam ubhayavetano grāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then the recipient of salaries from the two states the conquerors and the enemys state may inform the suspected minister to destroy the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utsāhaśaktimato vā preṣayet amuṣya rājyaṃ gṛhāṇa, yathāasthito naḥ saṃdhiḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or such kings as are possessed of enthusiasm and power may be told Seize the country of this king, our treaty of peace standing as before Then spies should inform the particular king of the attempt of these kings and cause the destruction of the commissariat and of the followers of one of these kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sattriṇaḥ pareṣu grāhayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Other spies, pretending to be friends, should inform these kings of the necessity of destroying the particular king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yasya vā pravīrapuruṣo hastī hayo vā mriyeta gūḍhapuruṣair hanyeta hriyeta vā sattriṇaḥ parasparaupahataṃ brūyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When an enemys brave soldier, elephant, or horse dies, or is killed, or carried off by spies, other spies may tell the enemy that the death is due to mutual conflict among his followers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ śāsanam abhiśastasya preṣayet bhūyaḥ kuru tataḥ paṇaśeeṣam avāpsyasi iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The man who is employed to commit such murders may be asked to repeat his work again on the condition of his receiving the balance due to Kautilyas Arthashastra him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ubhayavetanā grāhayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should receive the amount from the recipient of salaries from two states;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinneṣv anyatamaṃ labheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when the kings party is thus divided, some may be won over to the side of the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena senāpatikumāradaṇḍacāriṇo vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the case of the commanderinchief, the prince, and the officers of the army of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāṃdhikaṃ ca bhedaṃ prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Likewise seeds of dissension may be sown among combined states

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti bhedakarma //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the work of sowing the seeds of dissension

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tīkṣṇam utsāhinaṃ vyasaninaṃ sthitaśatruṃ vā gūḍhapuruṣāḥ śastraagnirasaādibhiḥ sādhayeyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies under concealment may, without the help of a fiery spy, murder by means of weapons, poison or other things a fortified enemy who is of mean character or who is under troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tīkṣṇo hy ekaḥ śastrarasaagnibhiḥ sādhayet // ayaṃ sarvasaṃdohakarma viśiṣṭaṃ vā karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: any one of hidden spies may do the work when it is found easy; or a fiery spy alone may do the work by means of weapons, poison or fire; for a fiery spy can do what others require all the necessary aids to do

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity upāyacaturvargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the four forms of strategic means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūrvaḥ pūrvaś caasya laghiṣṭhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these means, that which comes first in the order of enumeration is, as stated in connection with invaders, easier than the rest

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāntvam ekaguṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Conciliation is of single quality;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dānaṃ dviguṇaṃ sāntvapūrvam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: gift is twofold, since conciliation precedes it;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhedas triguṇaḥ sāntvadānapūrvaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: dissension is threefold, since conciliation and gift precede it;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍaś caturguṇaḥ sāntvadānabhedapūrvaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and conciliatory coercion is fourfold, since conciliation, gift, and dissension precede it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svabhūmiṣṭheṣu tu ta evaupāyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same means are employed in the case of local enemies, too;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśeṣas tu // svabhūmiṣṭhānām anyatamasya paṇyaagārair abhijñātān dūtamukhyān abhīkṣṇaṃ preṣayet // ta enaṃ saṃdhau parahiṃsāyāṃ vā yojayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the difference is this the chief messengers known to the manufactories may be sent to any one of the local enemies in order to employ him for the purpose of making a treaty or for the purpose of destroying another person

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apratipadyamānaṃ kṛto naḥ saṃdhiḥ ity āvedayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he agrees to the proposal, the messengers should inform their master of their success

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam itareṣām ubhayavetanāḥ saṃkrāmayeyuḥ ayaṃ vo rājā duṣṭaḥ iti // yasya vā yasmād bhayaṃ vairaṃ dveṣo vā taṃ tasmād bhedayeyuḥ ayaṃ te śatruṇā saṃdhatte,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then recipients of salaries from two states should inform the people or Kautilyas Arthashastra enemies concerned in the local enemys work This person the local enemy is your wicked king When a person has reason to fear or hate another, spies may augment dissension between them by telling one of them This man is making an agreement with your enemy, and will soon deceive you;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣiprataraṃ saṃdhīyasva, nigrahe caasya prayatasva iti // āvāhavivāhābhyāṃ vā kṛtvā samyogam asamyuktān bhedayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: hence make peace with the king soon and attempt to put down this man Or by bringing about friendship or marriage connection between persons who have not been hitherto connected, spies may separate them from others;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmantaāṭavikatatkulīnaaparuddhaiś caeṣāṃ rājyāni ghātayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or through the aid of a neighbouring king, a wild chief, a scion of an enemy‟s family, or an imprisoned prince, local enemies may be destroyed outside the kingdom;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sārthavrajaaṭavīr vā, daṇḍaṃ vāabhisṛtam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or through the agency of a caravan or wild tribes, a local enemy may be killed along with his army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasparaapāśrayāś caeṣāṃ jātisaṃghāś chidreṣu prahareyuḥ, gūḍhāś caagnirasaśastreṇa //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or persons, pretending to be the supporters of a local enemy and who are of the same caste, may under favourable opportunities kill him; or spies under concealment may kill local enemies with fire, poison, and weapons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vītaṃsagilavac caarīn yogair ācaritaiḥ śaṭhaḥ / ghātayet paramiśrāyāṃ viśvāsenaāmiṣeṇa ca //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: an obstinate clever enemy may be destroyed by spies or by means of poisoned flesh given to him in good faith [Thus ends Chapter , Persons Associated with Traitors and Enemies, in Book , The Work of an Invader, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (arthaanarthasamśayayuktāh āpadah tāsām upāyavikalpajāh siddhayah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: AND SUCCESS TO BE OBTAINED BY THE EMPLOYMENT OF ALTERNATIVE STRATEGIC MEANS

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāmaādir utsekaḥ svāḥ prakṛtīḥ kopayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra INTENSITY of desire and other passions provoke ones own people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apanayo bāhyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: impolicy provokes external enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad ubhayam āsurī vṛttiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Both these are the characteristics of demoniac life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svajanavikāraḥ kopaḥ // paravṛddhihetuṣu āpadarthoanarthaḥ saṃśaya iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Anger disturbs the feelings of ones own men Those causes which are conducive to the prosperity of ones enemy are dangerous wealth, provocative wealth, and wealth of doubtful consequences

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prāptaḥ pratyādeyaḥ pareṣāṃ bhavati, prāpyamāṇo vā kṣayavyayaudayo bhavati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wealth which, when obtained, increases the enemys prosperity, or which, though obtained, is repayable to the enemy, or which causes loss of men and money, is dangerous wealth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā sāmantānām āmiṣabhūtaḥ sāmantavyasanajo lābhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example, wealth which is enjoyed in common by neighbouring kings and which is acquired at their expense;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatruprārthito vā svabhāvaadhigamyo lābhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or wealth which is asked for by an enemy; or wealth which is seized like ones own property;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paścāt kopena pārṣṇigrāheṇa vā vigṛhītaḥ purastāllābhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or wealth which is acquired in the front and which causes future troubles or provokes an enemy in the rear;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraucchedena saṃdhivyatikrameṇa vā maṇḍalaviruddho lābhaḥ ity āpadarthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or wealth which is obtained by destroying a friend or by breaking a treaty and which is therefore detested by the Circle of Statesall these are the varieties of dangerous wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svataḥ parato vā bhayautpattir ity anarthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wealth which causes fear from ones own people or from an enemy is provocative wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthoanartha iti, anarthoartha iti saṃśayaḥ // śatrumitram utsāhayitum artho na vāiti saṃśayaḥ // śatrubalam arthamānābhyām āvāhayitum anartho na vāiti saṃśayaḥ // balavatsāmantāṃ bhūmim ādātum arthoanartha iti saṃśayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, in connection with these two kinds of wealth, there arise doubts, such as Is it provocative wealth or not? Harmless wealth or provocative wealth? First provocative and then harmless? Is it profitable to encourage an enemy or a friend? Would the bestowal of wealth and honour on an enemys army excite hatred or not?of these doubts, doubt regarding the acquirement of wealth is preferable to doubts regarding harm or provocation

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthoarthaanubandhaḥ, artho niranubandhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wealth productive of wealth; wealth productive of nothing; wealth productive of harm;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthoanarthaanubandhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: loss or harm productive of wealth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anarthoarthaanubandhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: sustenance of harm for no profit;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udāsīnasya daṇḍaanugrahaḥ phalena artho niranubandhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: harm productive of harmthese are the six varieties of harmful wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasyaantarucchedanam arthoanarthaanubandhaḥ // śatruprativeśasyaanugrahaḥ kośadaṇḍābhyām anarthoanarthaanubandhaḥ // hīnaśaktim utsāhya nivṛttir anartho niranubandhaḥ // jyāyāṃsam utthāpya nivṛttir anarthoanarthaanubandhaḥ // teṣāṃ pūrvaḥ pūrvaḥ śreyān upasamprāptum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Destruction of an enemy in the front resulting in the destruction of an enemy in the rear is what is termed wealth productive of wealth Wealth acquired by helping a neutral king with the army is what is called wealth productive of nothing The reduction of the internal strength of an enemy is wealth productive of harm Helping the neighbouring king of an enemy with men and money is harm productive of wealth Withdrawal after encouraging or setting a king of poor resources against another is harm productive of nothing Inactivity after causing excitement to a superior king is harm productive of harm Of these, it is better to pursue that which is mentioned first in the order of enumeration than that which is subsequently mentioned

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti kāryaavasthāpanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the procedure of setting to work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samantato yugapadarthautpattiḥ samantatoarthaāpad bhavati // sāeva pārṣṇigrāhavigṛhītā samantatoarthasaṃśayaāpad bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the surrounding circumstances are conducive to wealth, it is known as wealth from all sides When the acquirement of wealth from all sides is obstructed by an enemy in the rear, it takes the form of dangerous wealth involved in doubts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayor mitraākrandaupagrahāt siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In these two cases, success can be achieved by securing the help of a friend and the enemy of the rearenemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāeva mitravigṛhītā samantatoanarthasaṃśayaāpad bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when a friend comes forward to avert this fear, that trouble becomes involved in doubt

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ito lābha itarato lābha ity ubhayatoarthaāpad bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In these two cases, success can be achieved by securing the support of a nomadic enemy and the enemy of the rearenemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyāṃ samantatoarthāyāṃ ca lābhaguṇayuktam artham ādātuṃ yāyāt // tulye lābhaguṇe pradhānam āsannam anatipātinam ūno vā yena bhavet tam ādātuṃ yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the prospect of acquiring profit from one or the other side is irremediably obstructed by enemies, it is called dangerous wealth In this case as well as in the case of profit from all sides, one should undertake to march for acquiring profitable wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: itoanartha itaratoanartha ity ubhayatoanarthaāpat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there is the apprehension of harm from one quarter as well as from another, it is wealth beset with danger from two sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyāṃ samantatoanarthāyāṃ ca mitrebhyaḥ siddhiṃ lipseta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In this case as well as in the case of wealth involved in danger from all sides, success is to be desired with the help of friends

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraabhāve prakṛtīnāṃ laghīyasyaekatoanarthāṃ sādhayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of friends, he should attempt to ward off harm from one side with the help of an ally who can be easily won over;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ubhayatoanarthāṃ jyāyasyā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he should ward off harm from two sides with help of an ally of superior power;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samantatoanarthāṃ mūlena pratikuryāt // aśakye sarvam utsṛjyaapagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and he should ward off harm from all sides with all the resources he can command When it is impossible to do this, he should run away, leaving all that belongs to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dṛṣṭā hi jīvataḥ punarāvṛttir yathā suyātrāudayanābhyām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for if he lives, his return to power is certain as in the case of Suyátra and Udayana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ito lābha itarato rājyaabhimarśa ity ubhayatoarthaanarthaāpad bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there is the prospect of wealth from one side and the apprehension of an attack from another, it is termed a situation beset with wealth and harm

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyām anarthasādhako yoarthas tam ādātuṃ yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In this case, he should march to acquire that wealth which will enable him to ward off the attack;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anyathā hi rājyaabhimarśaṃ vārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise he should attempt to avert the attack

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etayā samantatoarthaanarthaāpad vyākhyātā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the situation which is beset with wealth and harm on all sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: itoanartha itaratoarthasaṃśaya ity ubhayatoanarthaarthasaṃśayā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there is the apprehension of harm from one side and when the prospect of acquiring wealth from another side is involved in doubt, it is termed doubt of harm and wealth from two Kautilyas Arthashastra sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyāṃ pūrvam anarthaṃ sādhayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In this, he should ward off the harm first;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatsiddhāv arthasaṃśayam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when this is done, he should attempt to acquire the doubtful wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etayā samantatoanarthaarthasaṃśayā vyākhyātā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the doubtful situation of harm and wealth from all sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: itoartha itaratoanarthasaṃśaya ity ubhayatoarthaanarthasaṃśayaāpad //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When there is the prospect of wealth from one side and the apprehension of doubtful harm from another, it is a doubtful situation of harm and wealth from two sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etayā samantatoarthaanarthasaṃśayā vyākhyātā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the situation of doubtful harm and wealth from all sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyāṃ pūrvāṃ pūrvāṃ prakṛtīnām anarthasaṃśayān mokṣayituṃ yateta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In this, he should attempt to ward off the doubts of harm against each of the elements of his sovereignty in order;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śreyo hi mitram anarthasaṃśaye tiṣṭhan na daṇḍaḥ, daṇḍo vā na kośa iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for it is better to leave a friend under circumstances of doubtful harm, than the army; also the army may be left under circumstances of doubtful harm, but not the treasury

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samagramokṣaṇaabhāve prakṛtīnām avayavān mokṣayituṃ yateta // tatra puruṣaprakṛtīnāṃ bahulam anuraktaṃ vā tīkṣṇalubdhavarjam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When all the elements of his sovereignty cannot be relieved from harm, he should attempt to relieve some of them at least Among the elements, he should attempt to relieve first those animate elements which are most loyal, and free from firebrands and greedy men;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyaprakṛtīnāṃ sāraṃ mahāupakāraṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: of inanimate elements he should relieve that which is most precious and useful

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhināāsanena dvaidhībhāvena vā laghūni,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such elements as are capable of easy relief may be relieved by such means as an agreement of peace, observance of neutrality, and making peace with one and waging war with another

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyayair gurūṇi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those which require greater efforts may be relieved by other means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣayasthānavṛddhīnāṃ cauttarauttaraṃ lipseta // prātilomyena vā kṣayaādīnām āyatyāṃ viśeṣaṃ paśyet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of deterioration, stagnation and progress, he should attempt to secure that which is mentioned later in the order of enumeration; or in the reverse order, if he finds that deterioration and other stages are conducive to future prosperity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti deśaavasthāpanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the determination of situations

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena yātrāādimadhyaanteṣv arthaanarthasaṃśayānām upasamprāptir vyākhyātā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the situation of doubtful harm and wealth in the middle or at the close of a march

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / nirantarayogitvāc caarthaanarthasaṃśayānāṃ yātrāādāv arthaḥ śreyān upasamprāptuṃ pārṣṇigrāhaāsārapratighāte kṣayavyayapravāsapratyādeye mūlarakṣaṇeṣu ca bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Since doubts of wealth and harm are constantly associated with all expeditions, it is better to secure wealth by which it is easy to destroy an enemy in the rear and his allies, to recoup the loss of men and money, to make provisions during the time of sojourning Kautilyas Arthashastra abroad, to make good what is repayable, and to defend the state

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathāanarthaḥ saṃśayo vā svabhūmiṣṭhasya viṣahyo bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also harm or doubtful prospects of wealth in ones own state are always intolerable

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena yātrāmadhyearthaanarthasaṃśayānām upasamprāptir vyākhyātā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the situation of doubtful harm in the middle of an expedition

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yātrāante tu karśanīyam ucchedanīyaṃ vā karśayitvāucchidya vāarthaḥ śreyān upasamprāptuṃ naanarthaḥ saṃśayo vā paraābādhabhayāt
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But at the close of an expedition, it is better to acquire wealth either by reducing or destroying a reducible or assailable enemy than to get into a situation of doubtful harm, lest enemies might cause troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāmavāyikānām apurogasya tu yātrāmadhyaantagoanarthaḥ saṃśayo vā śreyān upasamprāptum anirbandhagāmitvāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But, for one who is not the leader of combination of states, it is better to risk the situation of doubtful wealth or harm in the middle or at the close of an expedition, since one is not obliged to continue the expedition

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: artho dharmaḥ kāma ity arthatrivargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wealth, virtue, and enjoyment form the aggregate of the three kinds of wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya pūrvaḥ pūrvaḥ śreyān upasamprāptum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, it is better to secure that which is mentioned first than that which is subsequently mentioned in the order of enumeration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anarthoadharmaḥ śoka ity anarthatrivargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Harm, sin and grief form the aggregate, of the three kinds of harm

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya pūrvaḥ pūrvaḥ śreyān pratikartum // arthoanartha iti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, it is better to provide against that which is mentioned first, than that which is subsequently mentioned

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dharmoadharma iti, kāmaḥ śoka iti saṃśayatrivargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wealth or harm, virtue or sin, and enjoyment or grief, are the aggregate of the three kinds of doubts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyauttarapakṣasiddhau pūrvapakṣaḥ śreyān upasamprāptum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, it is better to try that which is mentioned first than that which is mentioned later in the order of enumeration, and which it is certain to shake off

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti kālaavasthāpanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the determination of opportunities

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity āpadaḥ tāsāṃ siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus ends the discourse on danger

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: putrabhrātṛbandhuṣu sāmadānābhyāṃ siddhir anurūpā, paurajānapadadaṇḍamukhyeṣu dānabhedābhyām, sāmantaāṭavikeṣu bhedadaṇḍābhyām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Regarding success in these dangerous situations and times in the case of troubles from sons, brothers or relatives, it is better to secure relief by means of conciliation and gifts; in the case of troubles from citizens, country people, or chiefs of the army, it is by means of gifts and sowing the seeds of dissension;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣāanulomā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This is following the order of the means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye pratilomā // mitraamitreṣu vyāmiśrā siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Success against friends and enemies is always achieved by complicated means; for strategic means help each other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasparasādhakā hy upāyāḥ // śatroḥ śaṅkitaamātyeṣu sāntvaṃ prayuktaṃ śeṣaprayogaṃ nivartayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the case of suspected ministers of an enemy, the employment of conciliation does not need the use of the other means;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaamātyeṣu dānam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the case of treacherous ministers it is by means of gifts;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃghāteṣu bhedaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the case of combination of states, it is by means of sowing the seeds of dissension;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śaktimatsu daṇḍa iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and in the case of the powerful, it is by means of coercion

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gurulāghavayogāc caāpadāṃ niyogavikalpasamuccayā bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When grave and light dangers are together apprehended, a particular means, or alternative means or all the means may be employed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anenaevaupāyena naanyena iti niyogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By this alone, but not by any other means, is what is meant by a particular means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anena vāanyena vā iti vikalpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By this or that, is what is meant by alternative means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anenaanyena ca iti samuccayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By this as well as by that, is what is meant by all the means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām ekayogāś catvāras triyogāś ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, the single means as well as the combination of any three means are four;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviyogāḥ ṣaṭ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the combinations of any two means are six;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaś caturyogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the combination of all the four is one

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti pañcadaśaupāyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus there are fifteen kinds of strategic means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāvantaḥ pratilomāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of the same number are the means in the reverse order

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām ekenaupāyena siddhir ekasiddhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a king attains success by only one means among these various means, he is called one of single success;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvābhyāṃ dvisiddhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when by two, one of double success;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tribhis trisiddhiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when by three, one of treble success;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturbhiś catuḥsiddhir iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when by four, one of fourfold success

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dharmamūlatvāt kāmaphalatvāc caarthasya dharmaarthakāmaanubandhā yāarthasya siddhiḥ sā sarvaarthasiddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 As virtue is the basis of wealth and as enjoyment is the end of wealth, success in achieving that kind of wealth which promotes virtue, wealth and enjoyment is termed success in all sarvárthasiddhi Thus varieties of success

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivād agnir udakaṃ vyādhiḥ pramāro vidravo durbhikṣam āsurī sṛṣṭir ity āpadaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such providential visitations as fire, floods, disease, pestilence pramara, fever vidrava, famine, and demoniac troubles are dangerous

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tāsāṃ daivatabrāhmaṇarpaṇipātataḥ siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Success in averting these is to be sought by worshipping gods and Bráhmans

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ativṛṣṭir avṛṣṭir vā sṛṣṭir vā yāāsurī bhavet / tasyām ātharvaṇaṃ karma siddhaārambhāś ca siddhayaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whether demoniacal troubles are absent, or are too many, or normal, the rites prescribed in the Atharvaveda as well as the rites undertaken by accomplished ascetics are to be performed for success

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (skandhaāvāraniveśah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , Doubts about Wealth and Harm;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāstukapraśaste vāstuni nāyakavardhaki mauhūrtikāḥ skandhaāvāram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and Success to be Obtained by the Employment of Alternative Strategic Means in Book , The Work of an Invader, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vṛttaṃ dīrghaṃ caturaśraṃ vā bhūmivaśena vā, caturdvāraṃ ṣaṭpathaṃ navasaṃsthānaṃ māpayeyuḥ khātavaprasāladvāraaṭṭālakasampannaṃ bhaye sthāne ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: ON a site declared to be the best according to the science of buildings, the leader náyaka, the carpenter vardhaki, and the astrologer mauhúrtika should measure a circular, rectangular, or square spot for the camp which should, in accordance with the available space, consist of four gates, six roads, and nine divisions

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamasyauttare navabhāge rājavāstukaṃ dhanuḥśataāyāmam ardhavistāram, paścimaardhe tasyaantaḥpuram // antarvaṃśikasainyaṃ caante niviśeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Provided with ditches, parapets, walls, doors, and watch towers for defence against fear, the quarters of the king, ,000 bows long and half as broad, should be situated in one of the nine divisions to the north from the centre, while to the west of it his harem, and at its extremity the army of the harem are to be situated

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purastād upasthānam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In his front, the place for worshipping gods;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dakṣiṇataḥ kośaśāsanakāryakaraṇāni,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: to his right the departments of finance and accounts;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāmato rājaaupavāhyānāṃ hastyaśvarathānāṃ sthānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and to his left the quarters of elephants and horses mounted by the king himself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ato dhanuḥśataantarāś catvāraḥ śakaṭamethīpratatistambhasālaparikṣepāḥ // prathame purastān mantripurohitau,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Outside this and at a distance of 00 bows from each other, there should be fixed four cartpoles sakatamedhi pillars and walls In the first of these four divisions, the prime minister and the priest should have their quarters;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇṣiṇataḥ koṣṭhaagāraṃ mahānasaṃ ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: to its right the storehouse and the kitchen to its left the store of raw products and weapons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vāmataḥ kupyaāyudhaagāram // dvitīye maulabhṛtānāṃ sthānam aśvarathānāṃ senāpateś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the second division the quarters of the hereditary army and of horses and chariots outside this, hunters and keepers of dogs with their trumpets and with fire;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūḍhāś caārakṣāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: also spies and sentinels;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatrūṇām āpāte kūpakūṭaavapātakaṇṭakinīś ca sthāpayet // aṣṭādaśavargāṇām ārakṣaviparyāsaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: also, to prevent the attack of enemies, wells, mounds and thorns should be arranged The eighteen divisions of sentinels employed for the purpose of securing the safety of the king should be changing their watches in turn

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: divaāyāmaṃ ca kārayed apasarpajñānaartham // vivādasaurikasamājadyūtavāraṇaṃ ca kārayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In order to ascertain the movements of spies, a timetable of business should also be prepared during the day Disputes, drinking, social gatherings, and gambling should also be prohibited

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mudrārakṣaṇaṃ ca // senānivṛttam āyudhīyam aśāsanaṃ śūnyapālo badhnīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The system of Kautilyas Arthashastra passports should also be observed The officer in charge of the boundary of the camp should supervise the conduct of the commanderinchief and the observance of the instructions given to the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purastād adhvanaḥ samyakpraśāstā rakṣaṇāni ca / yāyād vardhakiviṣṭibhyām udakāni ca kārayet //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The instructor prasástá with his retinue and with carpenters and free labourers should carefully march in front on the road, and should dig wells of water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (skandhaāvāraprayāṇam balavyasanaavaskandakālarakṣaṇam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , Encampment, in Book , Relating to War, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya End of the hundred and twentyninth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: grāmaaraṇyānām adhvani niveśān yavasaindhanaudakavaśena parisaṃkhyāya sthānaāsanagamanakālaṃ ca yātrāṃ yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: HAVING prepared a list of the villages and forests situated on the road with reference to their capacity to supply grass, firewood and water, march of the army should be regulated according to the programme of short and long halts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatpratīkāradviguṇaṃ bhaktaupakaraṇaṃ vāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Foodstuffs and provisions should be carried in double the quantity that may be required in any emergency

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśakto vā sainyeṣv āyojayet, antareṣu vā nicinuyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of separate means to carry foodstuffs, the army itself should be entrusted with the business of carrying them; or they may be stored in a central place

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purastān nāyakaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In front the leader náyaka;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhye kalatraṃ svāmī ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the centre the harem and the master the king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārśvayor aśvā bāhuutsāraḥ, cakraanteṣu hastinaḥ prasāravṛddhir vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: on the sides horses and bodyguards báhútsára; at the extremity of the marching circulararray, elephants and the surplus army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvato vanaājīvaḥ prasāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: on all sides the army habituated to forestlife;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svadeśād anvāyatir vīvadhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The army of the lowest quality can march a yojana / miles a day;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrabalam āsāraḥ // kalatrasthānam apasāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that of the middle quality a yojana and a half and the best army two yojanas

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purastād adhyāghāte makareṇa yāyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The commander should march behind and put up his camp in the front

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paścātśakaṭena, pārśvayor vajreṇa, samantataḥ sarvatobhadreṇa,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In case of any obstruction, the army should march in crocodile array in the front, in cartlike array behind, and on the sides in diamondlike array ie, in four or five rows, each having its front, rear and sides and in a compact array on all sides

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaayane sūcyā // pathidvaidhībhāve svabhūmito yāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the army is marching on a path passable by a single man, it should march in pinlike array

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adhyardhaṃ madhyamā, dviyojanam uttamā, sambhāvyā vā gatiḥ // āśrayakārī sampannaghātī pārṣṇir āsāro madhyama udāsīno vā pratikartavyaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When peace is made with one and war is to be waged with another, steps should be taken to protect the friends who are bringing help against enemies, such as an enemy in the rear, his ally, a madhyama king, or a neutral king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃkaṭo mārgaḥ śodhayitavyaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Roads with obstructions should be examined and cleared

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośo daṇḍo mitraamitraaṭavībalaṃ viṣṭiṛtur vā pratīkṣyāḥ, kṛtadurgakarmanicayarakṣākṣayaḥ krītabalanirvedo mitrabalanirvedaś caāgamiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Finance, the army, the the strength of the armies of friends, enemies, and wild tribes, the prospect of rains, and the seasons should be thoroughly examined When the protective power of fortifications and stores of the enemies is on its decay, when it is thought that distress of the hired army or of a friends army of the enemy is impending;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upajapitāro vā naatitvarayanti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when intriguers are not for a quick march;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatrur abhiprāyaṃ vā pūrayiṣyati, iti śanair yāyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when the enemy is likely to come to terms with the invader, slow march should be made;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye śīghram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise quick march should be made

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastistambhasaṃkramasetubandhanaukāṣṭhaveṇusaṃghātair alābucarmakaraṇḍadṛtiplavagaṇḍikāveṇikābhiś caudakāni tārayet
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Waters may be crossed by means of elephants, planks spread over pillars erected, bridges, boats, timber and mass of bamboos, as well as by means of dry sour gourds, big baskets covered with skins, rafts, gandiká i, and veniká i

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tīrthaabhigrahe hastyaśvair anyato rātrāv uttārya sattraṃ gṛhṇīyāt // anudake cakricatuṣpadaṃ caadhvapramāṇena śaktyāudakaṃ vāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra When the crossing of a river is obstructed by the enemy, the invader may cross it elsewhere together with his elephants and horses, and entangle the enemy in an ambuscade sattra

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / dīrghakāntāram anudakaṃ yavasaindhanaudakahīnaṃ vā kṛcchraadhvānam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should protect his army when it has to pass a long desert without water; when it is without grass, firewood and water; when it has to traverse a difficult road;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhiyogapraskannaṃ kṣutpipāsāadhvaklāntaṃ paṅkatoyagambhīrāṇāṃ vā nadīdarīśailānām
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when it is harassed by an enemys attacks; when it is suffering from hunger and thirst after a journey; when it is ascending or descending a mountainous country full of mire, waterpools, rivers and cataracts;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prasthite visamnāhaṃ bhojanavyāsaktam āyatagatapariśrāntam avasuptaṃ vyādhimarakadurbhikṣapīḍitaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when it finds itself crowded in a narrow and difficult path; when it is halting, starting or eating; when it is tired from a long march; when it is sleepy; when it is suffering from a disease, pestilence or famine;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyādhitapattyaśvadvipam abhūmiṣṭhaṃ vā balavyasaneṣu vā svasainyaṃ rakṣet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when a great portion of its infantry, cavalry and elephants is diseased; when it is not sufficiently strong; or when it is under troubles

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasainyaṃ caabhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should destroy the enemys army under such circumstances

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaayanamārgaprayātasya senāniścāragrāsaāhāraśayyāprastāraagninidhānadhvajaāyudhasaṃkhyānena parabalajñānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the enemys army is marching through a path traversable by a single man, the commander of the invaders army should ascertain its strength by estimating the quantity of foodstuffs, grass, bedding, and other requisites, fire pots agninidhána, flags and weapons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadāātmāno gūhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should also conceal those of his own army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pārvataṃ vanadurgaṃ vā sāpasārapratigraham / svabhumau pṛṣṭhataḥ kṛtvā yudhyeta niviśeta ca //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Keeping a mountainous or river fortress with all its resources at his back in his own country he should fight or put up his camp [Thus ends Chapter , March of the Camp;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (kūṭayuddhavikalpāh svasainyautsāhanam svabalāny abalavyāyogah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and Protection of the Army in Times of Distress and Attack in Book , Relating to War of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balaviśiṣṭaḥ kṛtaupajāpaḥ prativihitaṛtuḥ svabhūmyāṃ prakāśayuddham upeyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: HE who is possessed of a strong army, who has succeeded in his intrigues, and who has applied remedies against dangers may undertake an open fight, if he has secured a position favourable to himself;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye kūṭayuddham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: otherwise a treacherous fight

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balavyasanaavaskandakāleṣu param abhihanyāt, abhūmiṣṭhaṃ vā svabhūmiṣṭhaḥ, prakṛtipragraho vā svabhūmiṣṭham // dūṣyaamitraaṭavībalair vā bhaṅgaṃ dattvā vibhūmiprāptaṃ hanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he who has secured a favourable position may strike the enemy entangled in an unfavourable position Or he who possesses control over the elements of his own state may, through the aid of the enemys traitors, enemies and inimical wild tribes, make a false impression of his own defeat on the mind of the enemy who is entrenched in a favourable position, and having thus dragged the enemy into an unfavourable position, he may strike the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃhataanīkaṃ hastibhir bhedayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the enemys army is in a compact body, he should break it by means of his elephants;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūrvaṃ bhaṅgapradānenaanupralīnaṃ bhinnam abhinnaḥ pratinivṛtya hanyāt // purastād abhihatya pracalaṃ vimukhaṃ vā pṛṣṭhato hastyaśvenaabhihanyāt // pṛṣṭhatoabhihatyā pracalaṃ vimukhaṃ vā purastāt sārabalenaabhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when the enemy has come down from its favourable position, following the false impression of the invaders defeat, the invader may turn back and strike the enemys army, broken or unbroken Having struck the front of the enemys army, he may strike it again by means of his elephants and horses when it has shown its back and is running away When frontal attack is unfavourable, he should strike it from behind;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purastād viṣamāyāṃ pṛṣṭhatoabhihanyāt // pṛṣṭhato viṣamāyāṃ purastād abhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when attack on the rear is unfavourable, he should strike it in front; when attack on one side is unfavourable, he should strike it on the other

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaamitraaṭavībalair vā pūrvaṃ yodhayitvā śrāntam aśrāntaḥ param abhihanyāt // dūṣyabalena vā svayaṃ bhaṅgaṃ dattvā jitam iti viśvastam aviśvastaḥ sattraapāśrayoabhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having caused the enemy to fight with his own army of traitors, enemies and wild tribes, the invader should with his fresh army strike the enemy when tired Or having through the aid of the army of traitors given to the enemy the impression of defeat, the Kautilyas Arthashastra invader with full confidence in his own strength may allure and strike the overconfident enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sārthavrajaskandhaāvārasaṃvāhavilopapramattam apramattoabhihanyāt // phalgubalaavacchannasārabalo vā paravīrān anupraviśya hanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or the invader, if he is vigilant, may strike the careless enemy when the latter is deluded with the thought that the invaders merchants, camp and carriers have been destroyed Or having made his strong force look like a weak force, he may strike the enemys brave men when falling against him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gograhaṇena śvāpadavadhena vā paravīrān ākṛṣya sattracchannoabhihanyāt // rātrāv avaskandena jāgarayitvā nidrāklāntān avasuptān vā divā hanyāt // sapādacarmakośair vā hastibhiḥ sauptikaṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having captured the enemys cattle or having destroyed the enemys dogs svapadavadha?, he may induce the enemys brave men to come out and may slay them Or having made the enemys men sleepless by harassing them at night, he may strike them during the day, when they are weary from want of sleep and are parched by heat, himself being under the shade

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śuṣkacarmavṛttaśarkaraākośakair gomahiṣauṣṭrayūthair vā trasnubhir akṛtahastyaśvaṃ bhinnam abhinnaḥ pratinivṛttaṃ hanyāt
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or with his army of elephants enshrouded with cotton and leather dress, he may offer a nightbattle to his enemy Or he may strike the enemys men during the afternoon when they are tired by making preparations during the forenoon;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratisūryavātaṃ vā sarvam abhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may strike the whole of the enemys army when it is facing the sun

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhānvanavanasaṃkaṭapaṅkaśailanimnaviṣamanāvo gāvaḥ śakaṭavyūho nīhāro rātrir iti sattrāṇi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A desert, a dangerous spot, marshy places, mountains, valleys, uneven boats, cows, cartlike array of the army, mist, and night are sattras temptations alluring the enemy against the invader

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūrve ca praharaṇakālāḥ kūṭayuddhahetavaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The beginning of an attack is the time for treacherous fights

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃgrāmas tu nirdiṣṭadeśakālo dharmiṣṭhaḥ // saṃhatya daṇḍaṃ brūyāt tulyavetanoasmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As to an open or fair fight, a virtuous king should call his army together, and, specifying the place and time of battle, address them thus am a paid servant like yourselves;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhavadbhiḥ saha bhogyam idaṃ rājyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this country is to be enjoyed by me together with you;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mayāabhihitaiḥ paroabhihantavyaḥ iti // vedeṣv apy anuśrūyate samāptadakṣiṇānāṃ yajñānām avabhṛtheṣu sā te gatir yā śūrāṇām iti // apiiha ślokau bhavataḥ // yān yajñasaṃghais tapasā ca viprāḥ svargaeṣiṇaḥ pātracayaiś ca yānti / kṣaṇena tān apy atiyānti śūrāḥ prāṇān suyuddheṣu parityajantaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: you have to strike the enemy specified by me His minister and priest should encourage the army by saying thus Kautilyas Arthashastra It is declared in the Vedas that the goal which is reached by sacrificers after performing the final ablutions in sacrifices in which the priests have been duly paid for is the very goal which brave men are destined to attain About this there are the two verses Beyond those places which Bráhmans, desirous of getting into heaven, attain together with their sacrificial instruments by performing a number of sacrifices, or by practising penance are the places which brave men, losing life in good battles, are destined to attain immediately

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tat tasya mā bhūn narakaṃ ca gacched yo bhartṛpiṇḍasya kṛte na yudhyet iti // mantripurohitābhyām utsāhayed yodhān vyūhasampadā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Let not a new vessel filled with water, consecrated and covered over with darbha grass be the acquisition of that man who does not fight in return for the subsistence received by him from his master, and who is therefore destined to go to hell

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kārtāntikaādiś caasya vargaḥ sarvajñadaivatasamyogakhyāpanābhyāṃ svapakṣam uddharṣayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Astrologers and other followers of the king should infuse spirit into his army by pointing out the impregnable nature of the array of his army, his power to associate with gods, and his omnisciency;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parapakṣaṃ caudvejayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and they should at the same time frighten the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvo yuddham iti kṛtaupavāsaḥ śastravāhanaṃ caanuśayīta // atharvabhiś ca juhuyāt // vijayayuktāḥ svargīyāś caāśiṣo vācayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The day before the battle, the king should fast and lie down on his chariot with weapons He should also make oblations into the fire pronouncing the mantras of the Atharvaveda, and cause prayers to be offered for the good of the victors as well as of those who attain to heaven by dying in the battlefield

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: brāhmaṇebhyaś caātmānam atisṛjet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should also submit his person to Bráhmans;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śauryaśilpaabhijanaanurāgayuktam arthamānābhyām avisaṃvāditam anīkagarbhaṃ kurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he should make the central portion of his army consist of such men as are noted for their bravery, skill, high birth, and loyalty and as are not displeased with the rewards and honours bestowed on them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pitṛputrabhrātṛkāṇām āyudhīyānām adhvajaṃ muṇḍaanīkaṃ rājasthānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The place that is to be occupied by the king is that portion of the army which is composed of his father, sons, brothers, and other men, skilled in using weapons, and having no flags and headdress

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastī ratho vā rājavāhanam aśvaanubandhaḥ // yat prāyasainyo yatra vā vinītaḥ syāt t(ad) adhirohayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should mount an elephant or a chariot, if the army consists mostly of horses; or he may mount that kind of animal, of which the army is mostly composed or which is the most Kautilyas Arthashastra skillfully trained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājavyañjano vyūhaadhiṣṭhānam āyojyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One who is disguised like the king should attend to the work of arraying the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sūtamāgadhāḥ śūrāṇāṃ svargam asvargaṃ bhīrūṇāṃ jātisaṃghakulakarmavṛttastavaṃ ca yodhānāṃ varṇayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Soothsayers and court bards should describe heaven as the goal for the brave and hell for the timid; and also extol the caste, corporation, family, deeds, and character of his men

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: purohitapuruṣāḥ kṛtyaabhicāraṃ brūyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The followers of the priest should proclaim the auspicious aspects of the witchcraft performed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yantrikavardhakimauhūrtikāḥ svakarmasiddhim asiddhiṃ pareṣām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, carpenters and astrologers should also declare the success of their own operations and the failure of those of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: senāpatir arthamānābhyām abhisaṃskṛtam anīkam ābhāṣeta śatasāhasro rājavadhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: After having pleased the army with rewards and honours, the commanderinchief should address it and say A hundred thousand panas for slaying the king the enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcāśatsāhasraḥ senāpatikumāravadhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: fifty thousand for slaying the commanderinchief, and the heirapparent;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daśasāhasraḥ pravīramukhyavadhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: ten thousand for slaying the chief of the brave;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcasāhasro hastirathavadhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: five thousand for destroying an elephant, or a chariot;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sāhasroaśvavadhaḥ, śatyaḥ pattimukhyavadhaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a thousand for killing a horse, a hundred panas for slaying the chief of the infantry;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śiro viṃśatikaṃ bhogadvaiguṇyaṃ svayaṃgrāhaś ca iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: twenty for bringing a head; and twice the pay in addition to whatever is seized

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad eṣāṃ daśavargaadhipatayo vidyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This information should be made known to the leaders of every group of ten men

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cikitsakāḥ śastrayantraagadasnehavastrahastāḥ striyaś caannapānarakṣiṇyaḥ puruṣāṇām uddharṣaṇīyāḥ pṛṣṭhatas tiṣṭheyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Physicians with surgical instruments sastra, machines, remedial oils, and cloth in their hands; and women with prepared food and beverage should stand behind, uttering encouraging words to fighting men

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adakṣiṇāmukhaṃ pṛṣṭhataḥsūryam anulomavātam anīkaṃ svabhūmau vyūheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The army should be arrayed on a favourable position, facing other than the south quarter, with its back turned to the sun, and capable to rush as it stands

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parabhūmivyūhe caaśvāṃś cārayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the array is made on an unfavourable spot, horses should be run

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yatra sthānaṃ prajavaś caabhūmir vyūhasya tatra sthitaḥ prajavitaś caubhayathā jīyeta // viparyaye jayati, ubhayathā sthāne prajave ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the army arrayed on an unfavourable position is confined or is made to run away from it by the enemy, it will be subjugated either as standing or running away; otherwise Kautilyas Arthashastra it will conquer the enemy when standing or running away

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samā viṣamā vyāmiśrā vā bhūmir iti purastāt pārśvābhyāṃ paścāc ca jñeyā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The even, uneven, and complex nature of the ground in the front or on the sides or in the rear should be examined

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samāyāṃ daṇḍamaṇḍalavyūhāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On an even site, stafflike or circular array should be made;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyāmiśrāyāṃ viṣamavyūhāḥ // viśiṣṭabalaṃ bhaṅktvā saṃdhiṃ yāceta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and on an uneven ground, arrays of compact movement or of detached bodies should be made Having broken the whole army of the enemy, the invader should seek for peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samabalena yācitaḥ saṃdadhīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if the armies are of equal strength, he should make peace when requested for it;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hīnam anuhanyāt, na tv eva svabhūmiprāptaṃ tyaktaātmānaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and if the enemys army is inferior, he should attempt to destroy it, but not that which has secured a favourable position and is reckless of life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: punarāvartamānasya nirāśasya ca jīvite /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a broken army, reckless of life, resumes its attack, its fury becomes irresistible;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adhāryo jāyate vegas tasmād bhagnaṃ na pīḍayet //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: hence he should not harass a broken army of the enemy [Thus ends Chapter , Forms of Treacherous Fights;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (yuddhabhūmayah pattyaśvarathahastikarmāṇi) svabhūmiḥ pattyaśvarathadvipānām iṣṭā yuddhe niveśe ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Encouragement to Ones Own Army, and Fight Between Ones Own and Enemys Armies, in Book , Relating to War, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya End of the hundred and thirtyfirst chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / dhānvanavananimnasthalayodhināṃ khanakaākāśadivārātriyodhināṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE WORK OF INFANTRY, CAVALRY, CHARIOTS, AND ELEPHANTS FAVOURABLE positions for infantry, cavalry, chariots, and elephants are desirable both for war and camp

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ca puruṣāṇāṃ nādeyapārvataānūpasārasānāṃ ca hastinām aśvānāṃ ca yathāsvam iṣṭā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For men who are trained to fight in desert tracts, forests, valleys, or plains, and for those who are trained to fight from ditches or heights, during the day or night, and for elephants which Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 are bred in countries with rivers, mountains, marshy lands, or lakes, as well as for horses, such battlefields as they would find suitable are to be secured

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samā sthirāabhikāśā nirutkhātinyacakrakhurāanakṣagrāhiṇyavṛkṣagulmavratatīstambhakedāraśvabhravalmīkasikatāpaṅkabhaṅgurā daraṇahīnā ca rathabhūmiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is even, splendidly firm, free from mounds and pits made by wheels and footprints of beasts, not offering obstructions to the axle, free from trees, plants, creepers and trunks of trees, not wet, and free from pits, anthills, sand, and thorns is the ground for chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastyaśvayor manuṣyāṇāṃ ca same viṣame hitā yuddhe niveśe ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For elephants, horses and men, even or uneven grounds are good, either for war or for camp

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṇvaśmavṛkṣā hrasvalaṅghanīyaśvabhrā mandadaraṇadoṣā caaśvabhūmiḥ // sthūlasthāṇv aśmavṛkṣavratatīvalmīkagulmā padātibhūmiḥ // gamyaśailanimnaviṣamā mardanīyavṛkṣā chedanīyavratatī paṅkabhaṅgurā daraṇahīnā ca hastibhūmiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which contains small stones, trees and pits that can be jumped over and which is almost free from thorns is the ground for horses That which contains big stones, dry or green trees, and anthills is the ground for the infantry That which is uneven with assailable hills and valleys, which has trees that can be pulled down and plants that can be torn, and which is full of muddy soil free from thorns is the ground for elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: akaṇṭakiny abahuviṣamā pratyāsāravatīiti padātīnām atiśayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is free from thorns, not very uneven, but very expansive, is an excellent ground for the infantry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviguṇapratyāsārā kardamaudakakhañjanahīnā nihśarkarāiti vājinām atiśayaḥ // pāṃsukardamaudakanalaśaraādhānavatī śvadaṇṣṭrahīnā mahāvṛkṣaśākhāghātaviyuktāiti hastinām atiśayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is doubly expansive, free from mud, water and roots of trees, and which is devoid of piercing gravel is an excellent ground for horses That which possesses dust, muddy soil, water, grass and weeds, and which is free from thorns known as dogs teeth and obstructions from the branches of big trees is an excellent ground Kautilyas Arthashastra for elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: toyaāśayaapāśrayavatī nirutkhātinī kedārahīnā vyāvartanasamarthāiti rathānām atiśayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which contains lakes, which is free from mounds and wet lands, and which affords space for turning is an excellent ground for chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: uktā sarveṣāṃ bhūmiḥ // etayā sarvabalaniveśā yuddhāni ca vyākhyātāni bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Positions suitable for all the constituents of the army have been treated of This explains the nature of the ground which is fit for the camp or battle of all kinds of the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / bhūmivāsavanavicayoaviṣamatoyatīrthavātaraśmigrahaṇaṃ vīvadhaāsārayor
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Concentration on occupied positions, in camps and forests; holding the ropes of beasts and other things while crossing the rivers or when the wind is blowing hard;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ghāto rakṣā vā viśuddhiḥ sthāpanā ca balasya prasāravṛddhir bāhuutsāraḥ pūrvaprahāro
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: destruction or protection of the commissariat and of troops arriving afresh; supervision of the discipline of the army; lengthening the line of the army; protecting the sides of the army; first attack;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyāveśanaṃ vyāvedhanam āśvāso grahaṇaṃ mokṣaṇaṃ mārgaanusāravinimayaḥ kośakumāraabhiharaṇaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: dispersion of the enemys army; trampling it down; defence; seizing; letting it out;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinnasaṃdhānam abhinnabhedanaṃ vyasane trāṇam abhighāto vibhīṣikā trāsanaṃaudāryaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: causing the army to take a different direction; carrying the treasury and the princes; falling against the rear of the enemy; chasing the timid; pursuit;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: grahaṇaṃ mokṣaṇaṃ sāladvāraaṭṭālakabhañjanaṃ kośavāhanaapavāhanam iti hastikarmāṇi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: magnificence; seizing; abandoning; destruction of walls, gates and towers; and carrying the treasurythese constitute the work of elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svabalarakṣā caturaṅgabalapratiṣedhaḥ saṃgrāme grahaṇaṃ mokṣaṇaṃ bhinnasaṃdhānam abhinnabhedanaṃ trāsanam audāryaṃ bhīmaghoṣaś
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Protection of the army; repelling the attack made by all the Kautilyas Arthashastra four constituents of the enemys army; seizing and abandoning positions during the time of battle; gathering a dispersed army; breaking the compact array of the enemys army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caiti rathakarmāṇi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and fearful noisethese constitute the work of chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvadeśakālaśastravahanaṃ vyāyāmaś caiti padātikarmāṇi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Always carrying the weapons to all places; and fightingthese constitute the work of the infantry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śibiramārgasetukūpatīrthaśodhanakarma yantraāyudhaāvaraṇaupakaraṇagrāsavahanam āyodhanāc ca praharaṇaāvaraṇapratividdhaapanayanam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The examination of camps, roads, bridges, wells and rivers; carrying the machines, weapons, armours, instruments and provisions; carrying away the men that are knocked down, along with their weapons and armoursthese constitute the work of free labourers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti viṣṭikarmāṇi //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , Battlefields;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kuryād gavaaśvavyāyogaṃ ratheṣv alpahayo nṛpaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the Work of Infantry, Cavalry, Chariots and Elephants, in Book , Relating to War, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (pakṣakakṣaurasyānām balaagrato vyūhavibhāgah sāraphalgubalavibhāgah pattyaśvarathahastiyuddhāni)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE DISTINCTIVE ARRAY OF TROOPS IN RFSPECT OF WINGS, FLANKS, AND FRONT; DISTINCTION BETWEEN STRONG AND WEAK TROOPS; AND BATTLE WITH INFANTRY, CAVALRY, CHARIOTS AND ELEPHANTS

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcadhanuḥśataapakṛṣṭaṃ durgam avasthāpya yuddham upeyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: HAVING fortified a camp at the distance of five hundred bows he should begin to fight

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmivaśena vā // vibhaktamukhyām acakṣurviṣaye mokṣayitvā senāṃ senāpatināyakau vyūheyātām // śamaantaraṃ pattiṃ sthāpayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having detached the flower of the army and kept it on a favourable position not visible to the enemy, the commanderinchief and the leader should array the rest of the army The infantry should be arrayed such that the space Kautilyas Arthashastra between any two men is a sama angulas;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: triśamaantaram aśvam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: cavalry with three samas;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcaśamaantaraṃ rathaṃ hastinaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: chariots with four samas;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviguṇaantaraṃ triguṇaantaraṃ vā vyūheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and elephants with twice or thrice as much space as between any two chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ yathāsukham asambādhaṃ yudhyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With such an array free to move and having no confusion, one should fight

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcaaratni dhanuḥ // tasmin dhanvinaṃ sthāpayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A bow means five aratnis x 0 angulas Archers should be stationed at the distance of five bows from one line to another;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tridhanuṣy aśvam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the cavalry at the distance of three bows;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcadhanuṣi rathaṃ hastinaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and chariots or elephants at the distance of five bows

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcadhanur anīkasaṃdhiḥ pakṣakakṣaurasyānām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The intervening space aníkasandhi between wings, flanks and front of the army should be five bows

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśvasya trayaḥ puruṣāḥ pratiyoddhāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There must be three men to oppose a horse pratiyoddha;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcadaśa rathasya hastino vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: fifteen men or five horses to oppose a chariot or an elephant;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañca caaśvāḥ // tāvantaḥ pādagopā vājirathadvipānāṃ vidheyāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and as many fifteen servants pádagopa for a horse, a chariot and an elephant should be maintained

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trīṇi trikāṇy anīkaṃ rathānām urasyaṃ sthāpayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Three groups aníka of three chariots each should be stationed in front;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pañcacatvāriṃśad evaṃ rathā rathavyūhe bhavanti, dve śate pañcaviṃśatiś caaśvāḥ, ṣaṭśatāni pañcasaptatiś ca puruṣāḥ pratiyodhāraḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the same number on the two flanks and the two wings Thus, in an array of chariots, the number of chariots amounts to fortyfive, two hundred and twentyfive horses, six hundred and seventyfive men, and as many servants to attend upon the horses, chariots and elephantsthis is called an even array of troops

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣa samavyūhaḥ // tasya dvirathauttarā vṛddhir āekaviṃśatirathād iti //
