Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The number of chariots in this array of three groups of three chariots each may be increased by two and two till the increased number amounts to twentyone

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam ojā daśa samavyūhaprakṛtayo bhavanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus, this array of odd numbers of chariots gives rise to ten odd varieties

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ataḥ sainyānāṃ vyūhaśeṣam āvāpaḥ kāryaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the surplus of the army may therefore be distributed in the above manner

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rathānāṃ dvau tribhāgāv aṅgeṣv āvāpayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Twothirds of the surplus chariots may be added to the flanks and the wings, the rest being put in front

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ tribhāgaūno rathānām āvāpaḥ kāryaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus the added surplus of chariots should be onethird less than the number added to the flanks and wings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena hastinām aśvānām āvāpo vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the distribution of surplus elephants and horses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yāvadaśvarathadvipānāṃ yuddhasambādhanm na kuryāt tāvad āvāpaḥ kāryaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As many horses, chariots, and elephants may be added as occasion no confusion in fighting

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍabāhulyam āvāpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Excess of the army is called surplus ávápa;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattibāhulyaṃ pratyāpāvaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: deficiency in infantry is called absence of surplus pratyávápa;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaaṅgabāhulyam anvāvāpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: excess of any one of the four constituents of the army is akin to surplus anvávápa;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyabāhulyam atyāvāpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: excess of traitors is far from surplus atyávápa;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraāvāpāt pratyāvāpāc ca caturguṇād āaṣṭaguṇād iti vā vibhavataḥ sainyānām āvāpaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in accordance with ones own resources, one should increase ones army from four to eight times the excess of the enemys army or the deficiency in the enemys infantry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rathavyūhena hastivyūho vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The array of elephants is explained by the array of chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyāmiśro vā hastirathaaśvānāṃ cakraanteṣu hastinaḥ pārśvayor aśvā rathā urasye // hastinām urasyaṃ rathānāṃ kakṣāv aśvānāṃ pakṣāv iti madhyabhedī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An array of elephants, chariots, and horses mixed together may also be made at the extremities of the circle array, elephants; and on the flanks, horses and principal chariots The array in which the front is occupied by elephants, the flanks by chariots, and the wings by horses is an array which can break the centre of the enemys army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītoantabhedī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the reverse of this can harass the extremities of the enemys army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastinām eva tu śuddhaḥ sāmnāhyānām urasyam aupavāhyānāṃ jaghanaṃ vyālānāṃ koṭyāv iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An array of elephants may also be made the front by such elephants as are trained for war; the flanks by such as are trained for riding; and the wings by rogue elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattivyūhaḥ purastād āvaraṇinaḥ pṛṣṭhato dhanvinaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In an array of horses, the front by horses with mail armour;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattayaḥ pakṣayor aśvāḥ pārśvayoḥ hastinaḥ pṛṣṭhato rathāḥ purastāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In an array of infantry, men dressed in mail armour in front, archers in the rear, and men without armour on the wings; or horses on the wings, elephants on the flanks, and chariots in front;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paravyūhavaśena vā viparyāsaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: other changes may also be made so as to oppose the enemys army successfully

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastyaśvayor viśeṣaḥ kulaṃ jātiḥ sattvaṃ vayaḥsthatā prāṇo varṣma javas tejaḥ śilpaṃ stairyam udagratā vidheyatvaṃ suvyañjanaācāratāiti
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The best army is that which consists of strong infantry and of such elephants and horses as are noted for their breed, birth, strength, youth, vitality, capacity to run even in old age, fury, skill, firmness, magnanimity, obedience, and good habits

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattyaśvarathadvipānāṃ sāratribhāgam urasyaṃ sthāpayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Onethird of the best of infantry, cavalry and elephants should be kept in front;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvau tribhāgau kakṣaṃ pakṣaṃ caubhayataḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: twothirds on both the flanks and wings;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anulomam anusāram, pratilomaṃ tṛtīyasāram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which is arrayed mixing onethird of strong and weak troops is in the reverse order

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ sarvam upayogaṃ gamayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus, one should know all the Kautilyas Arthashastra varieties of arraying the array

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: phalgubalam anteṣv avadhāya vegaabhihūliko bhavati // sārabalam agrataḥ kṛtvā koṭīṣv anusāraṃ kuryāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having stationed the weak troops at the extremities, one would be liable to the force of the enemys onslaught Having stationed the flower of the army in front, one should make the wings equally strong

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jaghane tṛtiyiyasāram, madhye phalgubalam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Onethird of the best in the rear, and weak troops in the centrethis array is able to resist the enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyūhaṃ tu sthāpayitvā pakṣakakṣaurasyānām ekena dvābhyāṃ vā praharet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: having made an array, he should strike the enemy with one or two of the divisions on the wings, flanks, and front, and capture the enemy by means of the rest of the troops

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yat parasya durbalaṃ vītahastyaśvaṃ dūṣyaamātyaṃ kṛtaupajāpaṃ vā tatprabhūtasāreṇaabhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the enemys force is weak, with few horses and elephants, and is contaminated with the intrigue of treacherous ministers, the conqueror should strike it with most of his best troops

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad aṅgam alpasāram ātmanas tad bahunāupacinuyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should increase the numerical strength of that constituent of the army which is physically weak

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yataḥ parasyaapacayas tatoabhyāśe vyūheta, yatot vā bhayaṃ syāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should array his troops on that side on which the enemy is weak or from which danger is apprehended Running against;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / abhisṛtaṃ parisṛtam atisṛtam apasṛtam unmathyaavadhānaṃ valayo gomūtrikā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: running round; running beyond; running back; disturbing the enemys halt;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇḍalaṃ prakīrṇikā vyāvṛttapṛṣṭham anuvaṃśam agrataḥ pārśvābhyāṃ pṛṣṭhato bhagnarakṣā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: curving, circling, miscellaneous operations; removal of the rear; pursuit of the line from the front, flanks and rear; protection of the broken army; and falling upon the broken armythese are the forms of waging war with horses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhagnaanupāta ity aśvayuddhāni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same varieties with the exception of what is called miscellaneous operations;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prakīrṇikaāvarjāny etāny eva caturṇām aṅgānāṃ vyastasamastānāṃ vā ghātaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the destruction of the four constituents of the army, either single or combined; the dispersion of the flanks, wings and front trampling down;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: unmathyaavadhānavarjāny etāny eva svabhūmāv abhiyānaapayānasthitayuddhāniiti rathayuddhāni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same varieties with the exception of disturbing the enemys halt; running against; running back; and fighting from where it stands on its own groundthese are the varieties of waging Kautilyas Arthashastra war with chariots

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvadeśakālapraharaṇam upāṃśudaṇḍaś caiti pattiyuddhāni //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Striking in all places and at all times, and striking by surprise are varieties of waging war with infantry

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena vidhinā vyūhān ojān yugmāṃś ca kārayet / vibhavo yāvad aṅgānāṃ caturṇāṃ sadṛśo bhavet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In this way, he should make odd or even arrays, keeping the strength of the four constituents of the army equal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dve śate dhanuṣāṃ gatvā rājā tiṣṭhet pratigrahe /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having gone to a distance of 00 bows, the king should take his position together with the reserve of his army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinnasaṃghātanaṃ tasmān na yudhyetaapratigrahaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and without a reserve, he should never attempt to fight, for it is by the reserved force that dispersed troops are collected together

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (daṇḍabhogamaṇḍalaasamhatavyūhavyūhanam tasya prativyūhasthānam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and thirtythird chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER THE ARRAY OF THE ARMY LIKE A STAFF, A SNAKE, A CIRCLE, OR IN DETACHED ORDER;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣāv urasyaṃ pratigraha ity auśanaso vyūhavibhāgaḥ // pakṣau kakṣāv urasym pratigraha iti bārhasptyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE ARRAY OF THE ARMY AGAINST THAT OF AN ENEMY WINGS and front, capable to turn against an enemy is what is called a snakelike array bhoga; the two wings, the two flanks, the front and the reserve form an array according to the school of Brihaspati

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prapakṣakakṣaurasyā ubhayoḥ daṇḍabhogamaṇḍalaasaṃhatāḥ prakṛtivyūhāḥ // tatra tiryagvṛttir daṇḍaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The principal forms of the array of the army, such as that like a staff, like a snake, like a circle, and in detached order, are varieties of the above two forms of the array consisting of wings, flanks and front

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samastānām anvāvṛttir bhogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Stationing the army in a line so that one may follow the other, is called a snakelike array bhoga

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saratāṃ sarvatovṛttir maṇḍalaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Stationing the army so as to face all the directions, is called a circlelike array mandala

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthitānāṃ pṛthaganīkavṛttir asaṃhataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Detached arrangement of the army into small bodies so as to enable each to act for itself, is termed an array in detached order asamhata

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣakakṣaurasyaiḥ samaṃ vartamāno daṇḍaḥ // sa kakṣaatikrāntaḥ pradaraḥ // sa eva pakṣakakṣābhyāṃ pratikrānto dṛḍhakaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That which is of equal strength on its wings, flanks and front, is a stafflike array The same array is called pradara breaking the enemys array when its flanks are made to project in front The same is called dridhaka firm when its wings and flanks are stretched back

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa evaatikrāntaḥ pakṣābhyām asahyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same is called asahya irresistible when its wings are lengthened

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣāv avasthāpyaurasyaatikrāntaḥ śyenaḥ // viparyaye cāpaṃ cāpakukuṣiḥ pratiṣṭhaḥ supratiṣṭhaś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, having formed the wings, the front is made to bulge out, it is called an eaglelike array The same four varieties are called a bow, the centre of a bow, a hold, and a strong hold, when they are arranged in a reverse form

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cāpapakṣaḥ saṃjayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That, of which the wings are arrayed like a bow, is called sanjaya victory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa evaurasyaatikrānto vijayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The same with projected front is called vijaya conqueror;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthūlakarṇapakṣaḥ sthūṇaakarṇaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that which has its flanks and wings formed like a staff is called sthúlakarna big ear;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviguṇapakṣasthūṇo viśālavijayaḥ // tryabhikrāntapakṣaś camūmukhaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the same with its front made twice as strong as the conqueror, is called visálavijaya vast victory; that which has its wings stretched forward is called chamúmukha face of the army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye jhaṣaāsyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the same is called ghashásya face of the fish when it is arrayed in the reverse form

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ūrdhvarājir daṇḍaḥ sūcī //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The stafflike array in which one constituent of the army is made to stand behind the other is called a pinlike array

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvau daṇḍau valayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When this array consists of two such lines, it is called an aggregate valaya;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: catvāro durjayaḥ // iti daṇḍavyūhāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when of four lines, it is called an invincible arraythese are the varieties of the stafflike array

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣakakṣaurasyair viṣamaṃ vartamāno bhogaḥ // sa sarpasārī gomūtrikā vā // sa yugmaurasyo daṇḍapakṣaḥ śakaṭaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The snakelike array in which the wings, flanks and front are of unequal depth is called sarpasári serpentine movement, or gomútrika the course of a cows urine When it consists of two lines in front and has its wings arranged as in the stafflike array, it is called a cartlike array;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparyaye makaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the reverse of this is called a crocodilelike array;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastyaśvarathair vyatikīrṇaḥ śakaṭaḥ pāripatantakaḥ // iti bhogavyūhāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the cartlike array which consists of elephants, horses and chariots is called váripatantaka ?these are the varieties of the snakelike array

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣakakṣaurasyānām ekībhāve maṇḍalaḥ // sa sarvatomukhaḥ sarvatobhadraḥ // aṣṭaanīko durjayaḥ // iti maṇḍalavyūhāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The circlelike array in which the distinction of wings, flanks and front is lost is called sarvatomukha facing all directions, or sarvatobhadra all auspicious, ashtáníka one of eight divisions, or vijaya victorythese are the varieties of the circlelike array

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣakakṣaurasyānām asaṃhatād asaṃhataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That, of which the wings, flanks and front are stationed apart is called an array in detached order;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa pañcaanīkānām ākṛtisthāpanād vajro godhā vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when five divisions of the army are arranged in detached order, it is called vajra diamond, or godha alligator;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturṇām uddhānakaḥ kākapadī vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when four divisions, it is called udyánaka Kautilyas Arthashastra park, or kákapadi crow‟s foot;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trayāṇām ardhacandrakaḥ karkaṭakaśṛṅgī vā // ity asaṃhatavyūhāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when three divisions, it is called ardhachandrika halfmoon, or karkátakasringi ?these are the varieties of the array in detachedorder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rathaurasyo hastikakṣoaśvapṛṣṭhoariṣṭaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The array in which chariots form the front, elephants the wings, and horses the rear, is called arishta auspicious

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattayoaśvā rathā hastinaś caanupṛṣṭham acalaḥ // hastinoaśvā rathāḥ pattayaś caanupṛṣṭham apratihataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The array in which infantry, cavalry, chariots and elephants stand one behind the other is called achala immovable The array in which elephants, horses, chariots and infantry stand in order one behind the other is called apratihata invincible

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ pradaraṃ dṛḍhakena ghātayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, the conqueror should assail the pradara by means of the dridhaka;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dṛḍhakam asahyena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: dridhaka by means of the asahya;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratiṣṭhaṃ supratiṣṭhena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a hold by means of a stronghold;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃjayaṃ vijayena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: sanjaya by means of vijaya;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthūṇaākarṇaṃ viśālavijayena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: sthúlakarna by means of visálavijaya;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pāripatantakaṃ sarvatobhadreṇa //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: váripatantaka by means of sarvatobhadra

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durjayena sarvān prativyūheta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may assail all kinds of arrays by means of the durjaya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pattyaśvarathadvipānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvam uttareṇa ghātayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of infantry, cavalry, chariots and elephants, he should strike the firstmentioned with that which is subsequently mentioned;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hīnaaṅgam adhikaaṅgena caiti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and a small constituent of the army with a big one

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṅgadaśakasyaekaḥ patiḥ patikaḥ, patikadaśakasyaekaḥ senāpatiḥ, taddaśakasyaeko nāyaka iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: For every ten members of each of the constituents of the army, there must be one commander, called padika; ten padikas under a senápati; ten senápatis under a náyaka, leader

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa tūryaghoṣadhvajapatākābhir vyūhaaṅgānāṃ saṃjñāḥ sthāpayed aṅgavibhāge saṃghāte sthāne gamane vyāvartane praharaṇe ca // same vyūhe deśakālasārayogāt siddhiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The constituents of the array of the army should be called after the names of trumpet sounds, flags and ensigns Achievement of success in arranging the constituents of the army, in gathering the forces, in camping, in marching, in turning back, in making onslaughts, and in the array of equal strength depends upon the Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 place and time of action

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yantrair upaniṣadyogais tīkṣṇair vyāsaktaghātibhiḥ / māyābhir devasamyogaiḥ śakaṭair hastibhīṣaṇaiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By the display of the army, by secret contrivances, by fiery spies employed to strike the enemy engaged otherwise, by witchcraft, by proclaiming the conquerors association with gods, by carts, by the ornaments of elephants;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣyaprakopair goyūthaiḥ skandhaāvārapradīpanaiḥ / koṭījaghanaghātair vā dūtavyañjanabhedanaiḥ // durgaṃ dagdhaṃ hṛtaṃ vā te kopaḥ kulyaḥ samutthitaḥ / śatrur āṭaviko vā iti parasyaudvegam ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By inciting traitors, by herds of cattle, by setting fire to the camp, by destroying the wings and the rear of the enemys army, by sowing the seeds of dissension through the agency of men under the guise of servants; Or by telling the enemy that his fort was burnt, stormed, or that some one of his family, or an enemy or a wild chief rose in rebellionby these and other means the conqueror should cause excitement to the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaṃ hanyān na vā hanyād iṣuḥ kṣipto dhanuṣmatā /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thearrow shot by an archer may or may not kill a single man;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prajñānena tu matiḥ kṣiptā hanyād garbhagatān api //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but skilful intrigue devised by wise men can kill even those who are in the womb

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (bhedaupādānāni upāmśudaṇḍāh)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and thirtyfourth chapter from the beginning

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃghalābho daṇḍamitralābhānām uttamaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Bangalore Government Press, , Kautilyas Arthashastra Book , The Conduct of Corporations CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃghā hi saṃhatatvād adhṛṣyāḥ pareṣām // tān anuguṇān bhuñjīta sāmadānābhyām, viguṇān bhedadaṇḍābhyām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE acquisition of the help of corporations is better than the acquisition of an army, a friend, or profits By means of conciliation and gifts, the conqueror should secure and enjoy the services of such corporations as are invincible to the enemy and are favourably disposed towards himself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāmbojasurāṣṭrakṣatriyaśreṇyādayo vārttaśastraupajīvinaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The corporations of warriors kshattriyasrení of Kámbhoja, and Suráshtra, and other countries live by agriculture, trade and wielding weapons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: licchivikavṛjikamallakamadrakakukurakurupāñcālaādayo rājaśabdaupajīvinaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The corporations of Lichchhivika,Vrijika, Mallaka, Mudraka, Kukura, Kuru, Pánchála and others live by the title of a Rája

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarveṣām āsannāḥ sattriṇaḥ saṃghānāṃ parasparanyaṅgadveṣavairakalahasthānāny upalabhya kramaabhinītaṃ bhedam upacārayeyuḥ asau tvā vijalpati iti // evam ubhayatobaddharoṣāṇāṃ vidyāśilpadyūtavaihārikeṣv ācāryavyañjanā bālakalahān utpādayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, gaining access to all these corporations and finding out jealousy, hatred and other causes of quarrel among them, should sow the seeds of a wellplanned dissension among them, and tell one of them This man decries you Spies, under the guise of teachers áchárya should cause childish embroils among those of mutual enmity on occasions of disputations about certain points of science, arts, gambling or sports

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: veśaśauṇḍikeṣu vā pratilomapraśaṃsābhiḥ saṃghamukhyamanuṣyāṇāṃ tīkṣṇāḥ kalahān utpādayeyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Fiery spies may occasion quarrel among the leaders of corporations by praising inferior leaders in taverns and theatres;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtyapakṣaupagraheṇa vā // kumārakān viśiṣṭacchindikayā hīnacchindikān utsāhayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or pretending to be friends, they may excite Kautilyas Arthashastra ambition in the minds of princes by praising their high birth, though they the princes are lowborn;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hīnān vā viśiṣṭair ekapātre vivāhe vā yojayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: they may prevent the superiors from interdining and intermarriage with others;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avahīnān vā tulyabhāvaupagamane kulataḥ pauruṣataḥ sthānaviparyāsato vā // vyavahāram avasthitaṃ vā pratilomasthāpanena niśāmayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: they may persuade the superiors to interdine or to intermarry with inferiors; or they may give publicity to the consideration of priority shown to inferior persons in social intercourse in the face of the established custom of recognising the status of other persons by birth, bravery and social position;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vivādapadeṣu vā dravyapaśumanuṣyaabhighātena rātrau tīkṣṇāḥ kalahān utpādayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or fiery spies may bring about quarrel among them at night by destroying the things, beasts, or persons concerned in some legal disputes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarveṣu ca kalahasthāneṣu hīnapakṣaṃ rājā kośadaṇḍābhyām upagṛhya pratipakṣavadhe yojayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In all these disputes, the conqueror should help the inferior party with men and money and set them against the superior party

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhinnān apavāhayed vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When they are divided, he should remove them from their country;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmau caeṣāṃ pañcakulīṃ daśakulīṃ vā kṛṣyāyāṃ niveśayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may gather them together and cause them to settle in a cultivable part of their own country, under the designation of five households and ten households;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekasthā hi śastragrahaṇasamarthāḥ syuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for when living together, they can be trained in the art of wielding weapons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samavāye caeṣām atyayaṃ sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Specified fines should also be prescribed against any treacherous combinations among them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājaśabdibhir avaruddham avakṣiptaṃ vā kulyam abhijātaṃ rājaputratve sthāpayet // kārtāntikaādiś caasya vargo rājalakṣaṇyatāṃ saṃgheṣu prakāśayet // saṃghamukhyāṃś ca dharmiṣṭhān upajapet svadharmam amuṣya rājñaḥ putre bhrātari vā pratipadyadhvam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may install as the heirapparent a prince born of a high family, but dethroned or imprisoned Spies, under the guise of astrologers and others, should bring to the notice of the corporations the royal characteristics of the prince, and should induce the virtuous leaders of the corporations to acknowledge their duty to the prince who is the son of such and such a king, and who is the hearer of their complaints

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipanneṣu kṛtyapakṣaupagrahaartham arthaṃ daṇḍaṃ ca preṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To those who are thus prevailed upon, the conqueror should send men and money for the purpose of winning over other partisans

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikramakāle śauṇḍikavyañjanāḥ putradārapretaapadeśena naiṣecanikam iti madanarasayuktān madyakumbhānśataśaḥ prayaccheyuḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On occasions of any affray spies under the guise of vintners, should, under the plea of the birth of a son, of marriage or of the death of a man, distribute as toast naishechanika hundreds of vessels of liquor adulterated with the juice of madana plant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caityadaivatadvārarakṣāsthāneṣu ca sattriṇaḥ samayakarmanikṣepaṃ sahiraṇyaabhijñānamudrāṇi hiraṇyabhājanāni ca prarūpayeyuḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Near the gates of altars chaitya, temples, and other places under the watch of sentinels, spies should pretend to declare their agreement with the enemy of the corporations, their mission, their rewards, and bags of money with the golden seals of the Kautilyas Arthashastra enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dṛśyamāneṣu ca saṃgheṣu rājakīyāḥ ity āvedayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when the corporations appear before the spies, they may tell the corporations that they the spies have sold themselves to the enemy, and challenge the corporations for war

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaavaskandaṃ dadyāt // saṃghānāṃ vā vāhanahiraṇye kālike gṛhītvā saṃghamukhyāya prakhyātaṃ dravyaṃ prayacchet // tad eṣāṃ yācite dattam amuṣmai mukhyāya iti brūyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having seized the draught animals and golden articles belonging to the corporations, they may give the most important of those animals and articles to the chief of the corporations, and tell the corporations, when asked for, that it was given to the chief for the purpose of causing quarrel among them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena skandhaāvāraaṭavībhedo vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the method of sowing the seeds of dissension in camps and among wild tribes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃghamukhyaputram ātmasambhāvitaṃ vā sattrī grāhayet amuṣya rājñaḥ putras tvam, śatrubhayād iha nyastoasi iti // pratipannaṃ rājā kośadaṇḍābhyām upagṛhya saṃgheṣu vikramayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or a spy may tell a selfconfident son of the chief of corporations You are the son of such and such a king and are kept here under the apprehension of danger from enemies When he is deluded with this belief, the conqueror may help him with men and money and set him against the corporations

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avāptaarthas tam api pravāsayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the object in view is realised, the conqueror may also banish him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bandhakīpoṣakāḥ plavakanaṭanartakasaubhikā vā praṇihitāḥ strībhiḥ paramarūpayauvanābhiḥ saṃghamukhyān unmādayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Keepers of harlots or dancers, players, and actors may, after gaining access, excite love in the minds of the chiefs of corporations by exhibiting women endowed with bewitching youth and beauty

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jātakāmānām anyatamasya pratyayaṃ kṛtvāanyatra gamanena prasabhaharaṇena vā kalahān utpādayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By causing the woman to go to another person or by pretending that another person has violently carried her off, they may bring about quarrel among those who love that woman;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalahe tīkṣṇāḥ karma kuryuḥ hatoayam itthaṃ kāmukaḥ iti // visaṃvāditaṃ vā marṣayamāṇam abhisṛtya strī brūyāt asau māṃ mukhyas tvayi jātakāmāṃ bādhate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in the ensuing affray, fiery spies may do their work and declare Thus has he been killed in consequence of his love A woman who has disappointed her lover and has been forgiven, may approach a chief and say This chief is troubling me when my mind is set upon you;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasminjīvati naiha sthāsyāmi iti ghātam asya prayojayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when he is alive, cannot stay here, and thus induce the former to slay the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prasahyaapahṛtā vā vanaante kriḍāgṛhe vāapahartāraṃ rātrau tīkṣṇena ghātayet, svayaṃ vā rasena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A woman who has been violently carried off at night may Kautilyas Arthashastra cause the death of her violator in the vicinity of a park or in a pleasure house, by means of fiery spies or with poison administered by herself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ prakāśayet amunā me priyo hataḥ iti // jātakāmaṃ vā siddhavyañjanaḥ sāṃvadanikībhir auṣadhībhiḥ saṃvāsya rasenaatisaṃdhāyaapagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then she may declare This beloved person of mine has been killed by such and such a person A spy, under the garb of an ascetic, may apply to a lover such medical ointments as are declared to be capable of captivating the beloved woman and as are adulterated with poison;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasminn apakrānte sattriṇaḥ paraprayogam abhiśaṃseyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and then he may disappear Other spies may ascribe the incident to an enemys action

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āḍhyavidhavā gūḍhaājīvā yogastriyo vā dāyanikṣepaarthaṃ vivadamānāḥ saṃghamukhyān unmādayeyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Widows or women, employed as spies with secret instructions, may dispute among themselves about the claim for a deposit kept with the king, and attract the chiefs of the corporations by their beauty when they present themselves before the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannān gūḍhaveśmasu rātrisamāgamapraviṣṭāṃs tīkṣṇā hanyur baddhvā hareyur vā // sattrī vā strīlolupaṃ saṃghamukhyaṃ prarūpayet amuṣmin grāme daridrakullam apasṛtam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Harlots, or a dancing woman, or a songstress may make an appointment to meet a lover in some secret house; and when the lover comes to the house with the desire of meeting her there, fiery spies may kill him or carry him off bound in chains A spy may tell the chief of a corporation who is fond of women In this village, the family of a poor man is bereaved of the householder;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya strī rājaarhā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: his wife deserves to be the wife of a king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gṛhītāyām ardhamāsaanantaraṃ siddhavyañjano dūṣyasaṃghamukhyamadhye prakrośet asau me mukhyo bhāryāṃ snuṣāṃ bhaginīṃ duhitaraṃ vāadhicarati iti // taṃ cet saṃgho nigṛhṇīyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: seize her Half a month after she has been seized, an ascetic spy may accuse the chief in the midst of the corporation by saying This man has illegally kept my chief wife, or sisterinlaw, or sister, or daughter If the corporation punishes the chief, the conqueror may take the side of the corporation and set it against wicked persons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anigṛhīte siddhavyañjanaṃ rātrau tīkṣṇāḥ pravāsayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Fiery spies should always cause an ascetic spy to go abroad at night

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatas tadvyañjanāḥ prakrośeyuḥ asau brahmahā brāhmaṇījāraś ca iti // kārtāntikavyañjano vā kanyām anyena vṛtām anyasya prarūpayet amuṣya kanyā rājapatnī rājaprasavinī ca bhaviṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, selected suitably, should accuse the chiefs by saying This man is the slayer of a Bráhman and also the adulterer of a Bráhman woman A spy, under the guise of an astrologer, may describe to a Kautilyas Arthashastra chief the destiny of a maiden who is at the point of being married to another, and say This mans daughter deserves to be the wife of a king and will bring forth a son, destined to be a king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvasvena prasahya vāenāṃ labhasva iti // alabhyamānāyāṃ parapakṣam uddharṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: purchase her with all your wealth, or seize her by force When it is not possible to secure her, spies should enrage the parties;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: labdhāyāṃ siddhaḥ kalahaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but when she is secured, quarrel will necessarily ensue

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhikṣukī vā priyabhāryaṃ mukhyaṃ brūyāt asau te mukhyo yauvanautsikto bhāryāyāṃ māṃ prāhiṇot,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A mendicant woman may tell a chief who is fond of his wife This another chief, proud of his youth, has sent me to entice your wife;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasyaahaṃ bhayāl lekhyam ābharaṇaṃ gṛhītvāāgatāasmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: being afraid of him, have taken with me his letter and jewellery for your wife;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nirdoṣā te bhāryā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: your wife is free from sin;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūḍham asmin pratikartavyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: secret steps should be taken against him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃādiṣu kalahasthāneṣu svayam utpanne vā kalahe tīkṣṇair utpādite vā hīnapakṣaṃ rājā kośadaṇḍābhyām upagṛhya viguṇeṣu vikramayed
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and am very anxious about your success Thus in these and other kinds of brawls which have originated of themselves or which have been brought about by spies, the conqueror should help the inferior party with men and money and set them against the wicked or cause them to migrate to other parts of the country

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃgheṣv evam ekarājo varteta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus he should live as the only monarch of all the corporations;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃghāś caapy evam ekarājād etebhyoatisaṃghān ebhyo rakṣayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the corporations also, under the protection of such a single monarch, should guard themselves against all kinds of treachery

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃghamukhyaś ca saṃgheṣu nyāyavṛttir hitaḥ priyaḥ / dānto yuktajanas tiṣṭhet sarvacittaanuvartakaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The chief of corporations should endear himself to all the people by leading a virtuous life, by controlling his passions, and by pursuing that course of action which is liked by all those who are his followers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (dūtakarma)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE DUTIES OF A MESSENGER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: balīyasāabhiyukto durbalaḥ sarvatraanupraṇato vetasadharmā tiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN a king of poor resources is attacked by a powerful enemy, he should surrender himself together with his sons to the enemy and live like a reed in the midst of a current of water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: indrasya hi sa praṇamati yo balīyaso namati iti bhāradvājaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Bháradvája says that he who surrenders himself to the strong, bows down before Indra the god of rain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvasaṃdohena balānāṃ yudhyeta // parākramo hi vyasanam apahanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But Visáláksha says that a weak king should rather fight with all his resources, for bravery destroys all troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svadharmaś caeṣa kṣatriyasya, yuddhe jayaḥ parājayo vā iti viśālaakṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this fighting is the natural duty of a Kshatriya, no matter whether he achieves victory or sustains defeat in battle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naiti kauṭilyaḥ // sarvatraanupraṇataḥ kulaiḍaka iva nirāśo jīvite vasati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No, says Kautilya, he who bows down to all like a crab on the banks of a river lives in despair;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yudhyamānaś caalpasainyaḥ samudram ivaaplavoavagāhamānaḥ sīdati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever goes with his small army to fight perishes like a man attempting to cross the sea without a boat

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tadviśiṣṭaṃ tu rājānam āśrito durgam aviṣahyaṃ vā ceṣṭeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, a weak king should either seek the protection of a powerful king or maintain himself in an impregnable fort

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trayoabhiyoktāro dharmalobhaasuravijayina iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Invaders are of three kinds a just conqueror, a demonlike conqueror, and a greedy conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām abhyavapattyā dharmavijayī tuṣyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of these, the just conqueror is satisfied with mere obeisance

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam abhyavapadyeta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, a weak king should seek his protection

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pareṣām api bhayāt // bhūmidravyaharaṇena lobhavijayī tuṣyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Fearing his own enemies, the greedy conqueror is satisfied with what he can safely gain in land or money

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam arthenaabhyavapadyeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, a weak king should satisfy such a conqueror with wealth

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmidravyaputradāraprāṇaharaṇenaasuravijayī // taṃ bhūmidravyābhyām upagṛhyaagrāhyaḥ pratikurvīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The demonlike conqueror satisfies himself not merely by seizing the land, treasure, sons and wives of the conquered, but by taking the life of the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām anyatamam uttiṣṭhamānaṃ saṃdhinā mantrayuddhena kūṭayuddhena vā prativyūheta // śatrupakṣam asya sāmadānābhyām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When any one of these is on the point of rising against a weak king, the latter should avert the invasion by making a treaty of peace, or by taking recourse to the battle of intrigue mantrayuddha, or by a treacherous fight in the battlefield

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svapakṣaṃ bhedadaṇḍābhyām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may seduce the enemys men either by conciliation or by giving gifts, and should prevent the treacherous proceedings of his own men either by sowing the seeds of dissension among them or by punishing them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgaṃ rāṣṭraṃ skandhaāvāraṃ vāasya gūḍhāḥ śastrarasaagnibhiḥ sādhayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, under concealment, may capture the enemys fort, country, or camp with the aid of weapons, poison, or fire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvataḥ pārṣṇim asya grāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He may harass the enemys rear on all sides;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṭavībhir vā rājyaṃ ghātayet, tatkulīnaaparuddhābhyāṃ vā hārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and he may devastate the enemys country through the help of wild tribes Or he may set up a scion of the enemys family or an imprisoned prince to seize the enemys territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apakāraanteṣu caasya dūṭaṃ preṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When all this mischief has been perpetrated, a messenger may be sent to the enemy, to sue for peace;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anapakṛtya vā saṃdhānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may make peace with the enemy without offending the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathāapy abhiprayāntaṃ kośadaṇḍayoḥ pādauttaram ahorātrauttaraṃ vā saṃdhiṃ yāceta // sa ced daṇḍasaṃdhiṃ yāceta, kuṇṭham asmai hastyaśvaṃ dadyād, utsāhitaṃ vā garayuktam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the enemy still continues the march, the weak king may sue for peace by offering more than onefourth of his wealth and army, the payment being made after the lapse of a day and night If the enemy desires to make peace on condition of the weak king surrendering a portion of this army, he may give the enemy such of his elephants and cavalry as are uncontrollable or as are provided with poison;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puruṣasaṃdhiṃ yāceta, dūṣyaamitraaṭavībalam asmai dadyād yogapuruṣaadhiṣṭhitam // tathā kuryād yathāubhayavināśaḥ syāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if the enemy desires to make peace on condition of his surrendering his chief men, he may send over to the enemy such portion of his army as is full of traitors, enemies and wild tribes under the command of a trusted officer, so that both his enemy and his own undesirable army may perish;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tīkṣṇabalaṃ vāasmai dadyād yad avamānitaṃ vikurvīta,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may provide the enemy with an army composed of fiery spies, taking Kautilyas Arthashastra care to satisfy his own disappointed men before sending them over to the enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maulam anuraktaṃ vā yad asya vyasaneapakuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may transfer to the enemy his own faithful and hereditary army that is capable to hurt the enemy on occasions of trouble;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kośasaṃdhiṃ yāceta, sāram asmai dadyād yasya kretāraṃ naadhigacchet, kupyam ayuddhayogyaṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if the enemy desires to make peace on condition of his paying certain amount of wealth, he may give the enemy such precious articles as do not find a purchaser or such raw products as are of no use in war;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmisaṃdhiṃ yāceta, pratyādeyāṃ nityaamitrām anapāśrayāṃ mahākṣayavyayaniveśāṃ vāasmai bhūmiṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if the enemy desires to make peace on condition of his ceding a part of his land, he should provide the enemy with that kind of land which he can recover, which is always at the mercy of another enemy, which possesses no protective defences, or which can be colonized at considerable cost of men and money;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvasvena vā rājadhānīvarjena saṃdhiṃ yāceta balīyasaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may make peace, surrendering his whole state except his capital

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yat prasahya hared anyas tat prayacced upāyataḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should so contrive as to make the enemy accept that which another enemy is likely to carry off by force;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rakṣet svadehaṃ na dhanaṃ kā hy anitye dhane dayā //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and he should take care more of his person than of his wealth, for of what interest is perishing wealth? [Thus ends Chapter , The Duties of a Messenger, and Request for Peace, in Book , Concerning a Powerful Enemy, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (mantrayuddha)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: BATTLE OF INTRIGUE

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa cet saṃdhau naavatiṣṭheta, brūyād enaṃ ime śatruṣaḍvargavaśagā rājāno vinaṣṭāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: IF the enemy does not keep peace, he should be told These kings perished by surrendering themselves to the aggregate of the six enemies; it is not worthy of you to follow the lead of these unwise kings;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dharmam arthaṃ caavekṣasva //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: be mindful of virtue and wealth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitramukhā hy amitrās te ye tvā sāhasam adharmam arthaatikramaṃ ca grāhayanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: those Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 who advise you to brave danger, sin and violation of wealth, are enemies under the guise of friends;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūrais tyaktaātmabhiḥ saha yoddhuṃ sāhasam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: it is danger to fight with men who are reckless of their own lives;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: janakṣayam ubhayataḥ kartum adharmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: it is sin to cause the loss of life on both sides;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dṛṣṭam arthaṃ mitram aduṣṭaṃ ca tyaktum arthaatikramaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: it is violation of wealth to abandon the wealth at hand and the friend of no mean character meaning the addresser himself;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitravāṃś ca sa rājā, bhūyaś caetenaarthena mitrāṇy udyojayiṣyati yāni tvā sarvatoabhiyāsyanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that king has many friends whom he will set against you with the same wealth that is acquired with your help at my expense, and who will fall upon you from all sides;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na ca madhyamaudāsīnayor maṇḍalasya vā parityaktaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that king has not lost his influence over the Circle of the madhyama and neutral States;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhavāṃs tu parityaktaḥ yattvā samudyuktam upaprekṣante bhūyaḥ kṣayavyayābhyāṃ yujyatām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but you have lost that power over them who are, therefore, waiting for an opportunity to fall upon you; patiently bear the loss of men and money again;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrāc ca bhidyatām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: break peace with that friend;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaenaṃ parityaktamūlaṃ sukhenaucchetsyāmaḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: then we shall be able to remove him from that stronghold over which he has lost his influence

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa bhavān naarhati mitramukhānām amitrāṇāṃ śrotum, mitrāṇy udvejayitum amitrāṃś ca śreyasā yoktum, prāṇasaṃśayam anarthaṃ caupagantum iti yacchet // tathāapi pratiṣṭhamānasya prakṛtikopam asya kārayed yathā saṃghavṛtte vyākhyātaṃ yogavāmane ca // tīkṣṇarasadaprayogaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, it is not worthy of you to lend your ear to those enemies with the face of friends, to expose your real friends to trouble, to help your enemies to attain success, and to involve yourself in dangers costing life and wealth If without caring for the advice, the enemy proceeds on his own way, the weak king should create disaffection among the enemys people by adopting such measures as are explained in the chapters, The Conduct of Corporations, and Enticement of the enemy by secret contrivances He should also make use of fiery spies and poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad uktam ātmarakṣitake rakṣyaṃ tatra tīkṣṇān rasadāṃś ca prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Against what is described as deserving protection in the chapter, Safety of his own person, fiery spies and poisoners should be employed in the enemys court

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bandhakīpoṣakāḥ paramarūpayauvanābhiḥ strībhiḥ senāmukhyān unmādayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Keepers of harlots should excite love in the minds of the leaders of the enemys army by exhibiting women endowed with youth and beauty

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahūnām ekasyāṃ dvayor vā mukhyayoḥ kāme jāte tīkṣṇāḥ kalahān utpādayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Fiery spies should bring about quarrels among them when one or two of them have fallen in love

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalahe parājitapakṣaṃ paratraapagamane yātrāsāhāyyadāne vā bhartur yojayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the affray that ensues they should prevail upon the defeated party to migrate elsewhere or to proceed to help the master of the spies in the invasion undertaken by the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāmavaśān vā siddhavyañjanāḥ sāṃvadanikībhir oṣadhībhir atisaṃdhānāya mukhyeṣu rasaṃ dāpayeyuḥ // vaidehakavyañjane vā rājamahiṣyāḥ subhagāyāḥ preṣyām āsannāṃ kāmanimittam arthenaabhivṛṣya parityajet // tasyaeva paricārakavyañjanaupadiṣṭaḥ siddhavyañjanaḥ sāṃvadanikīm oṣadhīṃ dadyāt vaidehakaśarīreavaghātavyā iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or to those who have fallen in love, spies, under the guise of Kautilyas Arthashastra ascetics, may administer poison under the plea that the medical drugs given to them are capable of securing the object of love A spy, under the guise of a merchant, may, under the plea of winning the love of an immediate maidservant of the beautiful queen of the enemy, shower wealth upon her and then give her up A spy in the service of the merchant may give to another spy, employed as a servant of the maidservant, some medical drug, telling the latter that in order to regain the love of the merchant, the drug may be applied to the person of the merchant by the maidservant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: siddhe subhagāyā apy enaṃ yogam upadiśet rājaśarīreavadhātavyā iti // tato rasenaatisaṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On her attaining success the maidservant may inform the queen that the same drug may be applied to the person of the king to secure his love, and then change the drug for poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kārtāntikavyañjano vā mahāmātraṃ rājalakṣaṇasampannam kramaabhinītaṃ brūyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A spy, under the guise of an astrologer, may gradually delude the enemys prime minister with the belief that he is possessed of all the physiognomical characteristics of a king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhāryām asya bhikṣukī rājapatnī rājaprasavinī vā bhaviṣyasi iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a mendicant woman may tell the ministers wife that she has the characteristics of a queen and that she will bring forth a prince;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhāryāvyañjanā vā mahāmātraṃ brūyāt rājā kila mām avarodhayiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or a woman, disguised as the ministers wife, may tell him that, The king is troubling me;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tavaantikāya pattralekhyam ābharaṇaṃ caidaṃ parivrājikayāāhṛtam iti // sūdaārālikavyañjano vā rasaprayogaarthaṃ rājavacanam arthaṃ caasya lobhanīyam abhinayet // tad asya vaidehakavyañjanaḥ pratisaṃdadhyāt, kāryasiddhiṃ ca brūyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and an ascetic woman has brought to me this letter and jewellery Spies, under the guise of cooks, may, under the pretence of the kings the enemys order, take some covetable wealth to the minister meant for use in an immediate expedition A spy under the guise of a merchant may, by some contrivance or other, take possession of that wealth and inform the minister of the readiness of all the preparations for the expedition

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evam ekena dvābhyāṃ tribhir ity upāyair ekaekam asya mahāmātraṃ vikramāyaapagamanāya vā yojayet iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus by the employment of one, two, or three of the strategic means, the ministers of each of the combined enemies may be induced to set out on the expedition and thus to be away from the inimical kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / durgeṣu caasya śūnyapālaāsannāḥ sattriṇaḥ paurajānapadeṣu maitrīnimittam āvedayeyuḥ śūnyapālenauktā yodhāś caadhikaraṇasthāś ca kṛcchragato rājā jīvann āgamiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Spies, under the service of the officer in charge of the enemys waste lands, may inform the citizens and country people residing in the enemys fortified towns of the condition of the officers friendship with the people, and say The officer in charge of the waste lands tells the warriors and departmental officers thusThe king has hardly escaped from danger and scarcely returns with life

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na vā, prasahya vittam ārjayadhvam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Do not hoard up your wealth and thereby create enemies;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amitrāṃś ca hata iti // bahulībhūte tīkṣṇāḥ paurān niśāsv āhārayeyuḥ, mukhyāṃś caabhihanyuḥ evaṃ kriyante ye śūnyapālasya na śuśrūṣante iti // śūnyapālasthāneṣu ca saśoṇitāni śastravittabandhanāny utsṛjeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if so, you will all be put to death When all the people are collected together, fiery spies may take the citizens out of the town and kill their leaders, saying Thus will be treated those who do not hear the officer in charge of the waste lands On the waste lands under the charge of the officer, the spies may throw down weapons, money and ropes bespattered with blood

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sattriṇaḥ śūnyapālo ghātayati vilopayati ca ity āvedayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then other spies may spread the news that the officer in charge of the waste lands destroys the people and plunders them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ jānapadān samāhartur bhedayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Similarly, spies may cause disagreement between the enemys collectorgeneral and the people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samāhartṛpuruṣāṃs tu grāmamadhyeṣu rātrau tīkṣṇā hatvā brūyuḥ evaṃ kriyante ye janapadam adharmeṇa bādhante iti // samutpanne doṣe śūnyapālaṃ samāhartāraṃ vā prakṛtikopena ghātayeyuḥ // tatkulīnam aparuddhaṃ vā pratipādayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Addressing the servants of the collectorgeneral in the centre of the village at night, fiery spies may say Thus will be treated those who subject the people to unjust oppression When the fault of the collectorgeneral or of the officer in charge of the waste lands is widely known, the spies may cause the people to slay either of them, and employ in his place one of his family or one who is imprisoned

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: antaḥpurapuradvāraṃ dravyadhānyaparigrahān / daheyus tāṃś ca hanyur vā brūyur asyaārtavādinaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spreading the false news of the danger of the enemy, they spies may set fire to the harem, the gates of the town and the storehouse of grains and other things, and slay the sentinels who are kept to guard them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (senāmukhyavadhah maṇḍalaprotsāhanam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: SLAYING THE COMMANDERINCHIEF AND INCITING A CIRCLE OF STATES

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājño rājavallabhānāṃ caāsannāḥ sattriṇaḥ pattyaśvarathadvipamukhyānāṃ rājā kruddhaḥ iti suhṛdviśvāsena mitrasthānīyeṣu
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: SPIES in the service of the king the enemy or of his courtiers may, under the pretence of friendship, say in the presence of other friends that the king is angry with the chiefs of infantry, cavalry, chariots and elephants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahulībhūte tīkṣṇāḥ kṛtarātricārapratīkārā gṛheṣu svāmivacanenaāgamyatām iti brūyuḥ // tānnirgacchata evaabhihanyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When their men are collected together, fiery spies, having guarded themselves against night watches, may, under the pretence of the kings the enemys order, invite the chiefs to a certain house and slay the chiefs when returning from the house

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svāmisaṃdeśaḥ iti caāsannān brūyuḥ // ye caapravāsitās tān sattriṇo brūyuḥ etat tad yad asmābhiḥ kathitam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Other spies in the vicinity may say that it has been the kings the enemys order to slay them Spies may also tell those who have been banished from the country This is just what we foretold;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yebhyaś ca rājā yācito na dadāti tān sattriṇo brūyuḥ uktaḥ śūnyapālo rājñā ayācyam artham asau caasau ca mā yācate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for personal safety, you may go elsewhere Spies may also tell those who have not received what they requested of the king the enemy that the officer in charge of waste lands has been told by the king Such and such a person has begged of me what he should not demand; refused to grant his request;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mayā pratyākhyātāḥ śatrusaṃhitāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he is in conspiracy with my enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām uddharaṇe prayatasva iti // tataḥ pūrvavad ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: So make attempts to put him down Then the spies may proceed in their usual way

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yebhyaś ca rājā yācito dadāti tān sattriṇo brūyuḥ uktaḥ śūnyapālo rājñā ayācyam artham asau caasau ca mā yācate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies may also tell those who have been granted their request by the king the enemy that the officer in charge of waste lands has been told by the king Such and such persons have demanded their due from me;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tebhyo mayā soartho viśvāsaarthaṃ dattaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: have granted them all their requests in order to gain their confidence

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatrusaṃhitāḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: But they are conspiring with my enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣām uddharaṇe prayatasva iti // tataḥ pūrvavad ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: So make attempts to put them down Then the spies may proceed in their usual way

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ye caenaṃ yācyam arthaṃ na yācante tān sattriṇo brūyuḥ uktaḥ śūnyapālo rājñā yācyam artham asau caasau ca mā na yācate,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies may also tell those who do not demand their due from the king that the officer in charge of waste lands has been told Such and such persons do not demand their due from me

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kim anyat svadoṣaśaṅkitatvāt, teṣām uddharaṇe prayatasva iti // tataḥ pūrvavad ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: What Kautilyas Arthashastra else can be the reason than their suspicion about my knowledge of their guilt? So make attempts to put them down Then the spies may proceed in their usual way

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena sarvaḥ kṛtyapakṣo vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the treatment of partisans

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratyāsanno vā rājānaṃ sattrī grāhayet asau caasau ca te mahāmātraḥ śatrupuruṣaiḥ sambhāṣate iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A spy employed as the personal servant of the king the enemy may inform him that such and such ministers of his are being interviewed by the enemys servants

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipanne dūṣyān asya śāsanaharān darśayet etat tat iti // senāmukhyaprakṛtipuruṣān vā bhūmyā hiraṇyena vā lobhayitvā sveṣu vikramayed apavāhayed vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he comes to believe this, some treacherous persons may be represented as the messengers of the enemy, specifying as this is that The chief officers of the army may be induced by offering land and gold to fall against their own men and secede from the enemy their king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yoasya putraḥ samīpe durge vā prativasati taṃ sattriṇāupajāpayet ātmasampannataras tvaṃ putraḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If one of the sons of the commanderinchief is living near or inside the fort, a spy may tell him You are the most worthy son;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tathāapy antarhitaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: still you are neglected;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatkim upekṣase vikramya gṛhāṇa, purā tvā yuvarājo vināśayati iti // tatkulīnam aparuddhaṃ vā hiraṇyena pratilobhya brūyāt antarbalaṃ pratyantaskandham antaṃ vāasya pramṛdnīhi iti // āṭavikān arthamānābhyām upagṛhya rājyam asya ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: why are you indifferent? Seize your position by force; otherwise the heirapparent will destroy you Or some one of the family of the commanderinchief or the king, or one who is imprisoned may be bribed in gold and told Destroy the internal strength of the enemy, or a portion of his force in the border of his country Or having seduced wild tribes with rewards of wealth and honour, they may be incited to devastate the enemys country

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitrāṇi vāasya brūyāt ahaṃ vaḥ setuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or the enemys rearenemy may be told am, as it were, a bridge to you all;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mayi vibhinne sarvān eṣa vo rājā plāvayiṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if am broken like a rafter, this king will drown you all;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatsaṃhatānām asaṃhatānāṃ ca preṣayet eṣa khalu rājā mām utpāṭya bhavatsu karma kariṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: let us, therefore, combine and thwart the enemy in his march Accordingly, a message may be sent to individual or combined states to the effect After having done with me, this king will do his work of you beware of it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ahaṃ vaḥ śreyān abhyupapattum iti // madhyamasya prahiṇuyād udāsīnasya vā punaḥ / yathāāsannasya mokṣaarthaṃ sarvasvena tadarpaṇam //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: am the best man to be relied upon Kautilyas Arthashastra In order to escape from the danger from an immediate enemy, a king should frequently send to a madhyama or a neutral king whatever would please him; or one may put ones whole property at the enemys disposal

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (śastraagnirasapraṇidhayah vīvadhāsāraprrasāravadhah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: SPIES WITH WEAPONS, FIRE, AND POISON; AND DESTRUCTION OF SUPPLY, STORES AND GRANARIES

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: grāmesu gṛhapatikavyañjanāḥ, janapadasaṃdhiṣu gorakṣakatāpasavyañjanāḥ, te sāmantaāṭavikatatkulīnaaparuddhānāṃ paṇyaāgārapūrvaṃ preṣayeyuḥ ayaṃ deśo hāryaḥ iti // āgatāṃś caeṣāṃ durge gūḍhapuruṣān arthamānābhyām abhisatkṛtya prakṛticchidrāṇi pradarśayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE conquerors spies who are residing as traders in the enemys forts, and those who are living as cultivators in the enemys villages, as well as those who are living as cowherds or ascetics in the district borders of the enemys country may send through merchants, information to another neighbouring enemy, or a wild chief, or a scion of the enemys family, or an imprisoned prince that the enemys country is to be captured When their secret emissaries come as invited, they are to be pleased with rewards of wealth and honour and shewn the enemys weak points;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / skandhaāvāre vāasya śauṇḍikavyañjanaḥ putram abhityaktaṃ sthāpayitvāavaskandakāle
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and with the help of the emissaries, the spies should strike the enemy at his weak points Or having put a banished prince in the enemys camp;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rasena pravāsayitvā naiṣecanikam iti madanarasayuktān madyakumbhānśataśaḥ prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a spy disguised as a vintner in the service of the enemy, may distribute as a toast hundreds of vessels of liquor mixed with the juice of the madana plant;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śuddhaṃ vā madyaṃ pādyaṃ vā madyaṃ dadyād ekam ahaḥ, uttaraṃ rassiddhaṃ prayacchet // śuddhaṃ vā madyaṃ daṇḍamukhyebhyaḥ pradāya madakāle rasasiddhaṃ prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or, for the first day, he may distribute a mild or intoxicating variety of liquor, and on the following days such liquor as is mixed with poison; or having given pure liquor to the Kautilyas Arthashastra officers of the enemys army, he may give them poisoned liquor when they are in intoxication

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍamukhyavyañjano vā putram abhityaktam iti samānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A spy, employed as a chief officer of the enemys army, may adopt the same measures as those employed by the vintner

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / pākvamāṃsikaaudanikaauṇḍikaāpūpikavyañjanā vā paṇyaviśeṣam avaghoṣayitvā parasparasaṃgharṣeṇa kālikaṃ samarghataram iti vā parān āhūya rasena svapaṇyāny apacārayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, disguised as experts in trading in cooked flesh, cooked rice, liquor, and cakes, may vie with each other in proclaiming in public the sale of a fresh supply of their special articles at cheap price and may sell the articles mixed with poison to the attracted customers of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: surākṣīradadhisarpistailāni vā tadvyavahartṛhasteṣu gṛhītā striyo bālāś ca rasayukteṣu svabhājaneṣu parikireyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Women and children may receive in their poisoned vessels, liquor, milk, curd, ghee, or oil from traders in those articles, and pour those fluids back into the vessels of the traders, saying that at a specified rate the whole may be sold to them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etāny eva vaidehakavyañjanāḥ, paṇyavireyeṇaāhartāro vā // hastyaśvānāṃ vidhāyavaseṣu rasam āsannā dadyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, disguised as merchants, may purchase the above articles, and may so contrive that servants, attending upon the elephants and horses of the enemy, may make use of the same articles in giving rations and grass to those animals

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karmakaravyañjanā vā rasaaktaṃ yavasam udakaṃ vā vikrīṇīran //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, under the garb of servants, may sell poisoned grass and water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cirasaṃsṛṣṭā vā govāṇijakā gavām ajaavīnāṃ vā yūthāny avaskandakāleṣu pareṣāṃ mohasthāneṣu pramuñceyuḥ, aśvakharauṣṭramahiṣaādīnāṃ duṣṭāṃś ca // tadvyañjanā vā cucchundarīśoṇitaaktaakṣān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, let off as traders in cattle for a long time, may leave herds of cattle, sheep, or goats in tempting places so as to divert the attention of the enemy from the attack which they the enemy intend to make; spies as cowherds may let off such animals as are ferocious among horses, mules, camels, buffaloes and others beasts, having smeared the eyes of those animals with the blood of a muskrat chuchundari;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lubdhakavyañjanā vā vyālamṛgān pañjarebhyaḥ pramuñceyuḥ, sarpagrāhā vā sarpān ugraviṣān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: spies as hunters may let off cruel beasts from traps; spies as snake charmers may let off highly poisonous snakes; those who keep elephants may let off elephants near the enemys camp;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agnijīvino vāagnim avasṛjeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: those who live by making use of fire may set fire to the camp, etc

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūḍhapuruṣā vā vimukhān pattyaśvarathadvipamukhyān abhihanyuḥ, ādīpayeyur vā mukhyaāvāsān // dūṣyaamitraāṭavikavyañjanāḥ praṇihitāḥ pṛṣṭhaabhighātam avaskandapratigrahaṃ vā kuryuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Secret spies may slay from behind the chiefs of infantry, cavalry, chariots and elephants, or they may set fire to the chief residences of the enemy Traitors, enemies and wild tribes, employed for the purpose, may Kautilyas Arthashastra destroy the enemys rear or obstruct his reinforcement;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vanagūḍhā vā pratyantaskandham upaniṣkṛṣyaabhihanyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or spies, concealed in forests, may enter into the border of the enemys country, and devastate it;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaayane vīvadhaāsāraprasārān vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may destroy the enemys supply, stores, and other things, when those things are being conveyed on a narrow path passable by a single man

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sasaṃketaṃ vā rātriyuddhe bhūritūryam āhatya brūyuḥ anupraviṣṭāḥ smo, labdhaṃ rājyam iti // rājaāvāsam anupraviṣṭā vā saṃkuleṣu rājānaṃ hanyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or in accordance with a preconcerted plan, they may, on the occasion of a nightbattle, go to the enemys capital, and blowing a large number of trumpets, cry aloud We have entered into the capital, and the country has been conquered After entering into the kings the enemys palace, they may kill the king in the tumult;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mlecchaāṭavikadaṇṭacāriṇaḥ sattraapāśrayāḥ stambhavāṭaapāśrayā vā hanyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when the king begins to run from one direction to another, Mlechchhas, wild tribes, or chiefs of the army, lying in ambush sattra, or concealed near a pillar or a fence, may slay him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lubdhakavyañjanā vāavaskandasaṃkuleṣu gūḍhayuddhahetubhir abhihanyuḥ // ekaayane vā śailastambhavāṭakhañjanaantarudake vā svabhūmibalenaabhihanyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or spies, under the guise of hunters, may slay the king when he is directing his attack, or in the tumult of attack following the plan of treacherous fights Or occupying an advantageous position, they may slay the enemy when he is marching in a narrow path passable by a single man, or on a mountain, or near the trunk of a tree, or under the branches of a banian tree, or in water;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nadīsarastaṭākasetubandhabhedavegena vā plāvayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may cause him to be carried off by the force of a current of water let off by the destruction of a dam across a river, or of a lake or pond;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhānvanavanadurganimnadurgasthaṃ vā yogaagnidhūmābhyāṃ nāśayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may destroy him by means of an explosive fire or poisonous snake when he has entrenched himself in a fort, in a desert, in a forest, or in a valley

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃkaṭagatam agninā, dhānvanagataṃ dhūmena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should be destroyed with fire when he is under a thicket; with smoke when he is in a desert;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nidhānagataṃ rasena,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: with poison when he is in a comfortable place;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: toyaavagāḍhaṃ duṣṭagrāhair udakacaraṇair vā tīkṣṇāḥ sādhayeyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: with crocodile and other cruel beasts when he is in water; or they may slay him when he is going out of his burning house

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yogavāmanayogābhyāṃ yogenaanyatamena vā / amitram atisaṃdadhyāt saktam uktāsu bhūmiṣu //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By means of such measures as are narrated in the chapter, Enticement of the Enemy by Secret Means or by any other measures, the enemy should be caught hold of in places to which he is confined or from which he is attempting to escape

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (yogaatisamdhānam daṇḍaatisamdhānam ekavijayah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: CAPTURE OF THE ENEMY BY MEANS OF SECRET CONTRIVANCES OR BY MEANS OF THE ARMY; AND COMPLETE VICTORY

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivatejyāyām(devatāijyāyām?) yātrāyām amitrasya bahūni pūjāāgamasthānāni bhaktitaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: CONTRIVANCES to kill the enemy may be formed in those places of worship and visit, which the enemy, under the influence of faith, frequents on occasions of worshipping gods, and of pilgrimage

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: devatāgṛhapraviṣṭasyaupari yantramokṣaṇena gūḍhabhittiṃ śilāṃ vā pātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A wall or a stone, kept by mechanical contrivance, may, by loosening the fastenings, be let to fall on the head of the enemy when he has entered into a temple;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śilāśastravarṣam uttamaāgārāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: stones and weapons may be showered over his head from the topmost storey;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kapāṭam avapātitaṃ vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or a doorpanel may be let to fall;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhittipraṇihitam ekadeśabaddhaṃ vā parighaṃ mokṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or a huge rod kept over a wall or partly attached to a wall may be made to fall over him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: devatādehadhvajapraharaṇāni vāasyaupariṣṭāt pātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or weapons kept inside the body of an idol may be thrown over his head;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthānaāsanagamanabhūmiṣu vāasya gomayapradehena gandhaudakaprasekena vā rasam aticārayet, puṣpacūrṇaupahāreṇa vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or the floor of those places where he usually stands, sits, or walks may be be sprinkled with poison mixed with cowdung or with pure water; or under the plea of giving him flowers, scented powders, or of causing scented smoke, he may be poisoned;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śūlakūpam avapātanaṃ vā śayanaāsanasyaadhastād yantrabaddhatalam enaṃ kīlamokṣaṇena praveśayet // pratyāsanne vāamitre janapadāj janam avarodhakṣamam atinayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or by removing the fastenings made under a cot or a seat, he may be made to fall into a pit containing pointed spears; or when he is eager to escape from impending imprisonment in his own country, he may be led away to fall into the hands of a wild tribe or an enemy waiting for him not far from his country;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgāc caanavarodhakṣamam apanayet, pratyādeyam ariviṣayaṃ vā preṣayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he is eager to get out of his castle he may be likewise misled or made to enter an enemys country which is to Kautilyas Arthashastra be restored to the conqueror;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: janapadaṃ caekasthaṃ śailavananadīdurgeṣv aṭavīvyavahiteṣu vā putrabhrātṛparigṛhītaṃ sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the enemys people should also be kept under the protection of sons and brothers of the conqueror in some forts on a mountain, or in a forest, or in the midst of a river separated from the enemys country by wild tracts of lands

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: uparodhahetavo daṇḍaupanatavṛtte vyākhyātāḥ // tṛṇakāṣṭham āyojanād dāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Measures to obstruct the movements of the enemy are explained in the chapter, The Conduct of a Conquered King Grass and firewood should be set on fire as far as a yojana / miles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udakāni ca dūṣayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: water should be vitiated and caused to flow away;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avasrāvayec ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the enemy may also be likewise carried off;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paraprayuktāyāṃ vā suruṅgāyāṃ parikhām udakaantikīṃ khānayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when the underground tunnel has been made by the enemy for his own use, the water in the ditch outside the fort may be made to flow into it;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kūpaśālām anusālaṃ vā // toyakumbhān kāṃsyabhāṇḍāni vā śaṅkāsthāneṣu sthāpayet khātaabhijñānaartham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: in suspicious places along the parapet of the enemys fort and in the house containing a well outside the fort, empty pots or bronze vessels may be placed in order to find out the direction of the wind blowing from the underground tunnel;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jñāte suruṅgāpathe pratisuruṅgāṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when the direction of the tunnel is found out, a countertunnel may be formed;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhye bhittvā dhūmam udakaṃ vā prayacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having opened the tunnel, it may be filled with smoke or water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yato vā mitrair bandhubhir āṭavikair vā saṃsṛjyeta parasyaamitrair dūṣyair vā mahadbhiḥ, yato vā gatoasya mitrair viyogaṃ kuryāt pārṣṇiṃ vā gṛhṇīyāt rājyaṃ vāasya hārayet vīvadhaāsāraprasārān vā vārayet, yato vā śaknuyād ākṣikavad apakṣepeṇaasya prahartum, yato vā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having arranged for the defence of the fort by a scion of his family, the enemy may run in an opposite direction where it is possible for him to meet with friends, relatives, or wild tribes, or with his enemys treacherous friends of vast resources, or where he may separate his enemy from the latters friends, or where he may capture the enemys rear, or country, or where he may prevent the transport of supplies to his enemy, or whence he may strike his enemy by throwing down trees at hand, or where he can find means to defend his own country or to gather reinforcements for his hereditary army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yataḥ saṃdhim abhipretaṃ labheta tato vā gacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may go to any other country whence he can obtain peace on his own terms

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sahaprasthāyino vāasya preṣayeyuḥ ayaṃ te śatrur asmākaṃ hastagataḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 His enemys the conquerors allies may send a mission to him, saying This man, your enemy, has fallen into our hands;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipanne hiraṇyaṃ sārabalaṃ caādadīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: under the plea of merchandise or some presentation, send gold and a strong force;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: antapālo vā durgasampradāne balaekadeśam atinīya viśvastaṃ ghātayet // janapadam ekasthaṃ vā ghātayitum amitraanīkam āvāhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having access to the enemys castle, the officer in charge of the boundaries of the enemys country may lead a part of his force and slay the enemy in good faith under the plea of destroying a people in some place, he may take the enemy to an inimical army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad avaruddhadeśam atinīya viśvastaṃ ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and having led the enemy to the surrounded place, he may slay the enemy in good faith

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitravyañjano vā bāhyasya preṣayet kṣīṇam asmin durge dhānyaṃ snehāḥ kṣāro lavaṇaṃ vā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A pretending friend may send information to an outsider Grains, oil and jaggery and salt stored in the fort of the enemy have been exhausted;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad amuṣmin deśe kāle ca pravekṣyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: a fresh supply of them is expected to reach the fort at such and such a place and time;
