oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato rasaviddhaṃ dhānyaṃ snehaṃ kṣāraṃ lavaṇaṃ vā dūṣyaamitraāṭavikāḥ praveśayeyuḥ, anye vāabhityaktāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: seize it by force Then traitors, enemies, or wild tribes, or some other persons, specially appointed for the purpose, may send a supply of poisoned grains, oil, jaggery, and salt to the fort

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena sarvabhāṇḍavīvadhagrahaṇaṃ vyākhyātam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the seizure of all kinds of supply

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhiṃ vā kṛtvā hiraṇyaekadeśam asmai dadyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having made peace with the conqueror, he may give the conqueror part of the gold promised and the rest gradually

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato rakṣāvidhānāny avasrāvayet // agnirasaśastrair vā praharet // hiraṇyapratigrāhiṇo vāasya vallabhān anugṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Thus he may cause the conquerors defensive force to be slackened and then strike them down with fire, poison or sword; or he may win the confidence of the conquerors courtiers deputed to take the tribute

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parikṣīṇo vāasmai durgaṃ dattvā nirgacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or if his resources are exhausted, he may run away abandoning his fort;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suruṅgayā kukṣipradareṇa vā prākārabhedena nirgacchet // rātrāv avaskandaṃ dattvā siddhas tiṣṭhet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: he may escape through a tunnel or through a hole newly made or by breaking the parapet Or having challenged the conqueror at night, he may Kautilyas Arthashastra successfully confront the attack;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: asiddhaḥ pārśvenaapagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: if he cannot do this, he may run away by a side path;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pretavyañjano vā gūḍhair nihriyeta // strīveṣadhārī vā pretam anugacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may be carried off by spies as a corpse; or disguised as a woman, he may follow a corpse as it were, of her husband to the cremation ground;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivataupahāraśrāddhaprahavaṇeṣu vā rasaviddham annapānam avasṛjya //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or on the occasion of feeding the people in honour of gods or of ancestors or in some festival, he may make use of poisoned rice and water, and having conspired with his enemys traitors, he may strike the enemy with his concealed army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtaupajāpo dūṣyavyañjanair niṣpatya gūḍhasainyoabhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when he is surrounded in his fort, he may lie concealed in a hole bored into the body of an idol after eating sacramental food and setting up an altar;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūḍhabhittiṃ vā, daivatapratimāyuktaṃ vā bhūmigṛham //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or he may lie in a secret hole in a wall, or in a hole made in the body of an idol in an underground chamber;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vismṛte suruṅgayā rātrau rājaāvāsam anupraviśya suptam amitraṃ hanyāt // yantraviśleṣaṇaṃ vā viśleṣyaadhastād avapātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when he is forgotten, he may get out of his concealment through a tunnel, and, entering into the palace, slay his enemy while sleeping, or loosening the fastenings of a machine yantra, he may let it fall on his enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rasaagniyogenaavaliptaṃ gṛhaṃ jatugṛhaṃ vāadhiśayānam amitram ādīpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when his enemy is lying in a chamber which is besmeared with poisonous and explosive substances or which is made of lac, he may set fire to it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pramadavanavihārāṇām anyatame vā vihārasthāne pramattaṃ bhūmigṛhasuruṅgāgūḍhabhittipraviṣṭās tīkṣṇā hanyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Fiery spies, hidden in an underground chamber, or in a tunnel, or inside a secret wall, may slay the enemy when the latter is carelessly amusing himself in a pleasure park or any other place of recreation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūḍhapraṇihitā vā rasena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or spies under concealment may poison him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svapato vā niruddhe deśe gūḍhāḥ striyaḥ sarparasaagnidhūmān upari muñceyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or women under concealment may throw a snake, or poison, or fire or poisonous smoke over his person when he is asleep in confined place;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratyutpanne vā kāraṇe yad yad upapadyeta tat tad amitreantaḥpuragate gūḍhasaṃcāraḥ prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or spies, having access to the enemys harem, may, when opportunities occur, do to the enemy whatever is found possible on the occasion, and then get out unknown

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato gūḍham evaapagacchet, svajanasaṃjñāṃ ca prarūpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On such occasions, they should make use of the signs indicative of the purpose of their society

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvāhsthān varṣadharāṃś caanyān nigūḍhaupahitān pare / āhūya dviṣatśeṣāṇi ghātayet //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having by means of trumpet sounds called together the sentinels at the gate as well as aged men and other spies stationed by others, the enemy may completely carry out the rest of his work

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (upajāpah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Translated by R

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijigīṣuḥ paragrāmam avāptukāmaḥ sarvajñadaivatasamyogakhyāpanābhyāṃ svapakṣam uddharṣayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WHEN the conqueror is desirous of seizing an enemys village, he should infuse enthusiastic spirit among his own men and frighten his enemys people by giving publicity to his power of omniscience and close association with gods

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvajñakhyāpanaṃ tu gṛhaguhyapravṛttijñānena pratyādeśo mukhyānām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Proclamation of his omniscience is as followsrejection of his chief officers when their secret, domestic and other private affairs are known;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kaṇṭakaśodhanaapasarpaavagamena prakāśanaṃ rājadviṣṭakāriṇām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: pointing out the impolitic aspect of any course of action suggested to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vijñāpyaupāyanakhyāpanam adṛṣṭasaṃsargavidyāsaṃjñāādibhiḥ, videśapravṛttijñānaṃ tad ahar eva gṛhakapotena mudrāsamyuktena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and pretensions to the knowledge of foreign affairs by means of his power to read omens and signs invisible to others when information about foreign affairs is just received through a domestic pigeon which has brought a sealed letter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivatasamyogakhyāpanaṃ tu suruṅgāmukhenaagnicaityadaivatapratimācchidrān anupraviṣṭair agnicaityadaivatavyañjanaiḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Proclamation of his association with gods is as followsHolding conversation with, and worshipping, the spies who pretend to be the gods of fire or altar when through a tunnel they come to stand in the midst of fire, altar, or in the interior of a hollow image;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udakād utthitair vā nāgavaruṇavyañjanaiḥ sambhāṣaṇaṃ pūjanaṃ ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: holding conversation with, and worshipping, the spies who rise up from water and pretend to be the gods and goddesses of Nágas snakes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rātrāv antarudake samudravālukākośaṃ praṇidhāyaagnimālādarśanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: placing under water at night a mass of seafoam mixed with burning oil, and exhibiting it as the spontaneous outbreak of fire, when it is burning in a line;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śilāśikyaavagṛhīte plavake sthānam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: sitting on a raft in water which is secretly fastened by a rope to a rock;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udakabastinā jarāyuṇā vā śiroavagūḍhanāsaḥ pṛṣataantrakulīranakraśiṃśumāraudravasābhir vā śatapākyaṃ tailaṃ nastaḥ prayogaḥ // tena rātrigaṇaś carati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: such magical performance in water as is usually done at night by bands Kautilyas Arthashastra of magicians, using the sack of abdomen or womb of water animals to hide the head and the nose, and applying to the nose the oil, prepared from the entrails of red spotted deer and the serum of the flesh of the crab, crocodile, porpoise and otter;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity udakacaraṇāni // tair varuṇanāgakanyāvākyakriyā sambhāṣaṇaṃ ca,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: holding conversation, as though, with women of Varuna the god of water, or of Nága the snakegod when they are performing magical tricks in water;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kopasthāneṣu mukhād agnidhūmautsargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and sending out volumes of smoke from the mouth on occasions of anger

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad asya svaviṣaye kārtāntikanaimittikamauhūrtikapaurāṇikaikṣaṇikagūḍhapuruṣāḥ sācivyakarās taddarśinaś ca prakāśayeyuḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Astrologers, soothsayers, horologists, storytellers, Pauránika, as well as those who read the forebodings of every moment, together with spies and their disciples, inclusive of those who have witnessed the wonderful performances of the conqueror should give wide publicity to the power of the king to associate with gods throughout his territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya viṣaye daivatadarśanaṃ divyakośadaṇḍautpattiṃ caasya brūyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Likewise in foreign countries, they should spread the news of gods appearing before the conqueror and of his having received from heaven weapons and treasure

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivatapraśnanimittavāyasaaṅgavidyāsvapnamṛgapakṣivyāhāreṣu caasya vijayaṃ brūyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those who are well versed in horary and astrology and the science of omens should proclaim abroad that the conqueror is a successful expert in explaining the indications of dreams and in understanding the language of beasts and birds

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sadundubhim ulkāṃ ca parasya nakṣatre darśayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They should not only attribute the contrary to his enemy, but also show to the enemys people the shower of firebrand ulká with the noise of drums from the sky on the day of the birthstar of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya mukhyān mitratvenaupadiśanto dūtavyañjanāḥ svāmisatkāraṃ brūyuḥ, svapakṣabalaādhānaṃ parapakṣapratighātaṃ ca // tulyayogakṣemam amātyānām āyudhīyānāṃ ca kathayeyuḥ // teṣu vyasanaabhyudayaavekṣaṇam apatyapūjanaṃ ca prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The conqueror‟s chief messengers, pretending to be friendly towards the enemy, should highly speak of the conquerors respectful treatment of visitors, of the strength of his army, and of the likelihood of impending destruction of his enemys men They should also make it known to the enemy that under their master, both ministers and soldiers are equally safe and happy, and that their master treats his servants with parental care in their weal or woe

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena parapakṣam utsāhayed yathāuktaṃ purastāt // bhūyaś ca vakṣyāmaḥ // sādhāraṇagardabhena dakṣān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra By these and other means, they should win over the enemys men as pointed out above, and as we are going to treat of them again at length They should characterise the enemy as an ordinary donkey towards skilful persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lakuṭaśākhāhananābhyāṃ daṇḍacāriṇaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as the branch of lakucha Artocarpus Lacucha broken to the officers of his army;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kulaeḍakena caudvignān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as a crab on the shore to anxious persons;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśanivarṣeṇa vimānitān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as a downpour of lightnings to those who are treated with contempt;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vidulenaavakeśinā vāyasapiṇḍena kaitavajameghenaiti vihataāśān durbhagaalaṃkāreṇa dveṣiṇāiti pūjāphalān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as a reed, a barren tree, or an iron ball, or as false clouds to those who are disappointed; as the ornaments of an ugly woman to those who are disappointed in spite of their worshipful service;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyāghracarmaṇā mṛtyukūṭena caupahitān,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as a tigers skin, or as a trap of death to his favourites;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pīluvikhādanena karakayoṣṭrayā gardabhīkṣīrāabhimanthanenaiti dhruvaupakāriṇa iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and as eating a piece of the wood of pílu CareyaArborea, or as churning the milk of a shecamel or a shedonkey for butter to those who are rendering to him valuable help

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannān arthamānābhyāṃ yojayet
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the people of the enemy are convinced of this, they may be sent to the conqueror to receive wealth and, honour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyabhaktacchidreṣu caenān dravyabhaktadānair anugṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those of the enemy who are in need of money and food should be supplied with an abundance of those things

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apratigṛhṇatāṃ strīkumāraalaṃkārān abhihareyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those who do not like to receive such things may be presented with ornaments for their wives and children

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durbhikṣastenaaṭavyupaghāteṣu ca paurajānapadān utsāhayantaḥ sattriṇo brūyuḥ rājānam anugrahaṃ yācāmahe niranugrahāḥ paratra gacchāmaḥ iti // tathāiti pratipanneṣu dravyadhānyāny aparigrahaiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the people of the enemy are suffering from famine and the oppression of thieves and wild tribes, the conquerors spies should sow the seeds of dissension among them, saying Let us request the king for favour and go elsewhere if not favoured When they agree to such proposals, they should be supplied with money, grains, and other necessary help thus, much can be done by sowing the seeds of dissension

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sācivyaṃ kāryam ity etad upajāpād bhūtaṃ mahat //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: [Thus ends Chapter , Sowing the Seeds of Dissension, in Book Kautilyas Arthashastra , Strategic Means to Capture a Fortress of the Arthasástra, of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (yogavāmanam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and fortyfirst chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: muṇḍo jaṭilo vā parvataguhaāvāsī caturvarṣaśataāyur bruvāṇaḥ prabhūtajaṭilaantevāsī nagaraabhyāśe tiṣṭhet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: AN ascetic, with shaved head or braided hair and living in the cave of a mountain, may pretend to be four hundred years old, and, followed by a number of disciples with braided hair, halt in the vicinity of the capital city of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śiṣyāś caasya mūlaphalaupagamanair amātyān rājānaṃ ca bhagavaddarśanāya yojayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The disciples of the ascetic may make presentations of roots and fruits to the king and his ministers and invite them to pay a visit to the venerable ascetic

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samāgatāś ca rājñā pūrvarājadeśaabhijñānāni kathayet, śate śate ca varṣāṇāṃ pūrṇeaham agniṃ praviśya punar bālo bhavāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On the arrival of the king on the spot, the ascetic may acquaint him with the history of ancient kings and their states, and tell him Every time when complete the course of a hundred years, enter into the fire and come out of it as a fresh youth bála

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad iha bhavat samīpe caturtham agniṃ pravekṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Now, here in your presence, am going to enter into the fire for the fourth time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avaśyaṃ me bhavān mānayitavyaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It is highly necessary that you may be pleased to honour me with your presence at the time

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trīn varān vṛṇīṣṇa(vṛṣīṣva) iti // pratipannaṃ brūyāt saptarātram iha saputradāreṇa prekṣāprahavaṇapūrvaṃ vastavyam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Please request three boons When the king agrees to do so, he may be requested to come and remain at the spot with his wives and children for seven nights to witness the sacrificial performance

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vasantam avaskandeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When he does so, he may be caught hold of

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / muṇḍo vā jaṭilo vā sthānikavyañjanaḥ prabhūtajaṭilaantevāsī vastaśoṇitadigdhāṃ veṇuśalākāṃ suvarṇacūrṇenaavalipya valmīke nidadhyād upajihvikaanusaraṇaartham, svarṇanālikāṃ vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An ascetic, with shaved head or braided hair, and followed by a number of disciples with shaved heads or braided hair, and pretending to be aware of whatever is contained in the interior of the earth, may put in the interior of an anthill either a bamboo stick wound round with a piece of cloth drenched in blood and painted with gold dust, or a hollow golden tube into which a snake can Kautilyas Arthashastra enter and remain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sattrī rājñaḥ kathayet asau siddhaḥ puṣpitaṃ nidhiṃ jānāti iti // sa rājñā pṛṣṭhaḥ tathā iti brūyāt, tac caabhijñānaṃ darśayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One of the disciples may tell the king This ascetic can discover blooming treasure trove When he asks the ascetic as to the veracity of the statement, the latter should acknowledge it, and produce a confirmatory evidence by pulling out the bamboo stick;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūyo vā hiraṇyam antarādhāya // brūyāc caenaṃ nāgarakṣitoayaṃ nidhiḥ praṇipātasādhyaḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or having kept some more gold in the interior of the anthill, the ascetic may tell the king This treasure trove is guarded by a snake and can possibly be taken out by performing necessary sacrifice

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannaṃ brūyāt saptarātram iti samānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the king agrees to do so, he may be requested to come and remain as before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sthānikavyañjanaṃ vā rātrau tejanaagniyuktam ekānte tiṣṭhantaṃ sattriṇaḥ kramaabhīnītaṃ rājñaḥ kathayeyuḥ asau siddhaḥ sāmedhikaḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When an ascetic, pretending to be able to find out hidden treasure trove, is seated with his body burning with magical fire at night in a lonely place, his disciples may bring the king to see him and inform the king that the ascetic can find out treasure trove

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: taṃ rājā yam arthaṃ yāceta tam asya kariṣyamāṇaḥ saptarātram iti samānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: While engaged in performing some work at the request of the king, the latter may be requested to come and remain at the spot for seven nights

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: siddhavyañjano vā rājānaṃ jambhakavidyābhiḥ pralobhayet // taṃ rājāiti samānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An accomplished ascetic may beguile a king by his knowledge of the science of magic known as jambhaka, and request him to come and remain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: siddhavyañjano vā deśadevatām abhyarhitām āśritya prahavaṇair abhīkṣṇaṃ prakṛtimukhyān abhisaṃvāsya krameṇa rājānam atisaṃdadhyāt
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An accomplished ascetic, pretending to have secured the favour of the powerful guardian deity of the country, may often beguile the kings chief ministers with his wonderful performance and gradually impose upon the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jaṭilavyañjanam antarudakavāsinaṃ vā sarvaśvetaṃ taṭasuruṅgābhūmigṛhaapasaraṇaṃ varuṇaṃ nāgarājaṃ vā sattriṇaḥ kramaabhinītaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Any person, disguised as an ascetic and living under water or in the interior of an idol entered into through a tunnel or an underground chamber, may be said by his disciples to be Varuna, the god of water, or the king of snakes, and shown to the king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājñaḥ kathayeyuḥ // taṃ rājāiti samānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: While going to accomplish whatever the king may desire, the latter may be requested to come and remain

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: janapadaantevāsī siddhavyañjano vā rājānaṃ śatrudarśanāya yojayet // pratipannaṃ bimbaṃ kṛtvā śatrum āvāhayitvā niruddhe deśe ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as before Kautilyas Arthashastra An accomplished ascetic, halting in the vicinity of the capital city, may invite the king to witness the person of his enemy when he comes to witness the invocation of his enemys life in the image to be destroyed, he may be murdered in an unguarded place

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśvapaṇyaupayātā vaidehakavyañjanāḥ paṇyaupāyananimittam āhūya rājānaṃ paṇyaparīkṣāyām āsaktam aśvavyatikīrṇaṃ vā hanyuḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, under the, guise of merchants come to sell horses, may invite the king to examine and purchase any of the animals

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aśvaiś ca prahareyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: While attentively examining the horses, he may be murdered in the tumult or trampled down by horses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nagaraabhyāśe vā caityam āruhya rātrau tīkṣṇāḥ kumbheṣu nālīn vā vidulāni dhamantaḥ svāmino mukhyānāṃ vā māṃsāni bhakṣayiṣyāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Getting into an altar at night in the vicinity of the capital city of the enemy and blowing through tubes or hollow reeds the fire contained in a few pots, some fiery spies may shout aloud We are going to eat the flesh of the king or of his ministers;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad eṣāṃ naimittikamauhūrtikavyañjanāḥ khyāpayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: let the worship of the gods go on Spies, under the guise of soothsayers and horologists may spread the news abroad

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṅgalye vā hrade taṭākamadhye vā rātrau tejanatailaabhyaktā nāgarūpiṇaḥ śaktimusalāny ayomayāni niṣpeṣayantas tathaiva brūyuḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, disguised as Nagas snakegods and with their body besmeared with burning oil tejánataila, may stand in the centre of a sacred pool of water or of a lake at night, and sharpening their iron swords or spikes, may shout aloud as before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ṛkṣacarmakañcukino vāagnidhūmautsargayuktā rakṣorūpaṃ vahantas trir apasavyaṃ nagaraṃ kurvāṇāḥ śvasṛgālavāśitaantareṣu
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, wearing coats formed of the skins of bears and sending out volumes of smoke from their mouth, may pretend to be demons, and after circumambulating the city thrice from right to left, may shout aloud as before at a place full of the horrid noise of antelopes and jackals;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caityadaivatapratimāṃ vā tejanatailenaabhrapaṭalacchannenaagninā vā rātrau prajvālya tathaiva brūyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or spies may set fire to an altar or an image of a god covered with a layer of mica besmeared with burning oil at night, and shout aloud as before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad anye khyāpayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Others may spread this news abroad;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daivatapratimānām abhyarhitānāṃ vā śoṇitena prasrāvam atimātraṃ kuryuḥ // tad anye devarudhirasaṃsrāve saṃgrāme parājayaṃ brūyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may cause by some contrivance or other blood to flow out in floods from revered images of gods Others may spread this news abroad and challenge any bold or brave man to come out to witness this flow of divine blood

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhirātriṣu śmaśānapramukhe vā caityam ūrdhvabhakṣitair manuṣyaiḥ prarūpayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever accepts the challenge may be beaten to death by others with rods, making the people believe that he was killed by demons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad adbhutaṃ rājñas taddarśinaḥ sattriṇaś ca kathayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies and other Kautilyas Arthashastra witnesses may inform the king of this wonder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato naimititkamauhūrtikavyañjanāḥ śāntiṃ prāyaścittaṃ brūyuḥ anyathā mahad akuśalaṃ rājño deśasya ca iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then spies, disguised as soothsayers and astrologers may prescribe auspicious and expiatory rites to avert the evil consequences which would otherwise overtake the king and his country

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannaṃ eteṣu saptarātram ekaekamantrabalihomaṃ svayaṃ rājñā kartavyam iti brūyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the king agrees to the proposal he may be asked to perform in person special sacrifices and offerings with special mantras every night for seven days

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ samānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then while doing this, he may be slain as before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etān vā yogān ātmani darśayitvā pratikurvīta pareṣām upadeśaartham // tataḥ prayojayed yogān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In order to delude other kings, the conqueror may himself undertake the performance of expiatory rites to avert such evil consequences as the above and thus set an example to others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yogadarśanapratīkāreṇa vā kośaabhisaṃharaṇaṃ kuryāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In view of averting the evil consequences of unnatural occurrences, he the conqueror may collect money from his subjects

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: hastikāmaṃ vā nāgavanapālā hastinā lakṣaṇyena pralobhayeyuḥ // pratipannaṃ gahanam ekaayanaṃ vāatinīya ghātayeyuḥ, baddhvā vāapahareyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the enemy is fond of elephants, spies may delude him with the sight of a beautiful elephant reared by the officer in charge of elephant forests When he desires to capture the elephant, he may be taken to a remote desolate part of the forest, and killed or carried off as a prisoner

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena mṛgayākāmo vyākhyātaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the fate of kings addicted to hunting

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dravyastrīlolupam āḍhyavidhavābhir vā paramarūpayauvanābhiḥ strībhir dāyanikṣepaartham upanītābhiḥ sattriṇaḥ pralobhayeyuḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the enemy is fond of wealth or women, he may be beguiled at the sight of rich and beautiful widows brought before him with a plaint for the recovery of a deposit kept by them in the custody of one of their kinsmen;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannaṃ rātrau sattracchannāḥ samāgame śastrarasābhyāṃ ghātayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when he comes to meet with a woman at night as arranged, hidden spies may kill him with weapons or poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: siddhapravrajitacaityastūpadaivatapratimānām abhīkṣṇaabhigamaneṣu vā bhūmigṛhasuruṅgaārūḍhabhittipraviṣṭās tīkṣṇāḥ param
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the enemy is in the habit of paying frequent visits to ascetics, altars, sacred pillars stúpa, and images of gods, spies hidden in underground chambers or in subterranean passages, or inside the walls, may strike him down

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhihanyuḥ // yeṣu deśeṣu yāḥ prekṣāḥ prekṣate pārthivaḥ svayam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 Whatever may be the sights or spectacles which the king goes in person to witness;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: KAKcd/ yātrāvihāre ramate yatra krīḍati vāambhasi // dhiguktyādiṣu sarveṣu yajñaprahavaṇeṣu vā / sūtikāpretarogeṣu prītiśokabhayeṣu vā /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: wherever he may engage himself in sports or in swimming in water; Wherever he may be careless in uttering such words of rebuke as Tut or on the occasions of sacrificial performance or during the accouchement of women or at the time of death or disease of some person in the palace, or at the time of love, sorrow, or fear;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pramādaṃ yāti yasmin vā viśvāsāt svajanautsave // yatraasyaārakṣisaṃcāro durdine saṃkuleṣu vā /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whatever may be the festivities of his own men, which the king goes to attend, wherever he is unguarded or during a cloudy day, or in the tumultuous concourse of people;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viprasthāne pradīpte vā praviṣṭe nirjaneapi vā / vastraābharaṇamālyānāṃ phelābhiḥ śayanaāsanaiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or in an assembly of Bráhmans, or whenever he may go in person to see the outbreak of fire, or when, he is in a lonely place, or when he is putting on dress or ornaments, or garlands of flower, or when he is lying in his bed or sitting on a seat;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madyabhojanaphelābhis tūryair vāabhigatāḥ saha / prahareyur ariṃ tīkṣṇāḥ pūrvapraṇihitaiḥ saha //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or when he is eating or drinking, on these and other occasions, spies, together with other persons previously hidden at those places, may strike him down at the sound of trumpets

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathaiva praviśeyuś ca dviṣataḥ sattrahetubhiḥ / tathaiva caapagaccheyur ity uktaṃ yogavāmanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: And they may get out as secretly as they came there with the pretence of witnessing the sights; thus it is that kings and other persons are enticed to come out and be captured

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (apasarpapraṇidhih)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and fortysecond chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śreṇīmukhyam āptaṃ niṣpātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE conqueror may dismiss a confidential chief of a corporation

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa param āśrtya pakṣaapadeśena svaviṣayāt sācivyakarasahāyaupādānaṃ kurvīta // kṛtaapasarpaupacayo vā param anumānya svāmino dūṣyagrāmaṃ vītahastyaśvaṃ dūṣyaamātyaṃ daṇḍam ākrandaṃ vā hatvā parasya preṣayet
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The chief may go over to the enemy as a friend and Kautilyas Arthashastra offer to supply him with recruits and other help collected from the conquerors territory or followed by a band of spies, the chief may please the enemy by destroying a disloyal village or a regiment or an ally of the conqueror and by sending as a present the elephants, horses, and disaffected persons of the conquerors army or of the latters ally;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: janapadaekadeśaṃ śreṇīm aṭavīṃ vā sahāyaupādānaarthaṃ saṃśrayeta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or a confidential chief officer of the conqueror may solicit help from a portion of the territory of the enemy, or from a corporation of people sreni or from wild tribes;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ svāmī hastibandhanam aṭavīghātaṃ vāapadiśya gūḍham eva praharet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when he has gained their confidence, he may send them down to the conqueror to be routed down on the occasion of a farcical attempt to capture elephants or wild tribes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etenaamātyaaṭavikā vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the work of ministers and wild chiefs under the mission of the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatruṇā maitrīṃ kṛtvāamātyān avakṣipet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: After making peace with the enemy, the conqueror may dismiss his own confidential ministers

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: te tatśatroḥ preṣayeyuḥ bhartāraṃ naḥ prasādaya iti // sa yaṃ dūtaṃ preṣayet, tam upālabheta bhartā te mām amātyair bhedayati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They may request the enemy to reconcile them to their master When the enemy sends a messenger for this purpose, the conqueror may rebuke him and say Thy master attempts to sow the seeds of dissension between myself and my ministers;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na ca punar ihaāgantavyam iti // athaekam amātyaṃ niṣpātayet // sa param āśritya yogaapasarpaaparaktadūṣyān aśaktimataḥ stenaāṭavikān ubhayaupaghātakān vā parasyaupaharet // āptabhāvaupagataḥ pravīrapuruṣaupaghātam asyaupahared antapālam āṭavikaṃ daṇḍacāriṇaṃ vā dṛḍham asau caasau ca te śatruṇā
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: so thou should not come here again Then one of the dismissed ministers may go over to the enemy, taking with him a band of spies, disaffected people, traitors, brave thieves, and wild tribes who make no distinction between a friend and a foe Having secured the good graces of the enemy, the minister may propose to him the destruction of his officers, such as the boundaryguard, wild chief, and commander of his army, telling him These and other persons are in concert with your enemy Then these persons may be put to death under the unequivocal orders of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃdhatte iti // atha paścād abhityaktaśāsanair enān ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The conqueror may tell his enemy A chief with a powerfu army means to offend us, so let us combine and put him down;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍabalavyavahāreṇa vā śatrum udyojya ghātayet // kṛtyapakṣaupagraheṇa vā parasyaamitraṃ rājānam ātmany apakārayitvāabhiyuñjīta // tataḥ parasya preṣayet asau te vairī mamaapakaroti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: you may take possession of his treasury or territory When the enemy agrees to the proposal and comes out honoured by the conqueror, Kautilyas Arthashastra he may be slain in a tumult or in an open battle with the chief in concert with the conqueror Or having invited the enemy to be present as a thick friend on the occasion of a pretended gift of territory, or the installation of the heirapparent, or the performance of some expiatory rites, the conqueror may capture the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tam ehi sambhūya haniṣyāvaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever withstands such inducements may be slain by secret means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannam abhisatkṛtyaāgatam avaskandena prakāśayuddhena vā śatruṇā ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the enemy refuses to meet any man in person, then also attempts may be made to kill him by employing his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sa ced daṇḍaṃ dadyān na svayam āgacchet tam asya vairiṇā ghātayet // daṇḍena vā prayātum icchen na vijigīṣuṇā tathāapy enam ubhayataḥsampīḍanena ghātayet // aviśvasto vā pratyekaśo yātum icched rājyaekadeśaṃ vā yātavyasyaādātukāmaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the enemy likes to march alone with his army, but not in company with the conqueror, then he may be hemmed in between two forces and destroyed If, trusting to none, he wants to march alone in order to capture a portion of the territory of an assailable enemy, then he may be slain by employing one of his enemies or any other person provided with all necessary help When he goes to his subdued enemy for the purpose of collecting an army, his capital may be captured

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vairiṇā vā saktasya daṇḍaupanayena mūlam anyato hārayet // śatrubhūmyā vā mitraṃ paṇeta, mitrabhūmyā vā śatrum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may be asked to take possession of the territory of another enemy or a friend of the conqueror; and when he goes to seize the territory, the conqueror may ask his the conquerors friend to offend him the conqueror, and then enable the friend to catch hold of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatruṃ vā mitrabhūmilipsāyāṃ pratipannaṃ daṇḍenaanugṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the enemy is desirous of taking possession of the territory of the conquerors friend, then the conqueror may, under the pretence of compliance, supply the enemy with army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato mitragatam atisaṃdadhyāt // kṛtapratividhāno vā vyasanam ātmano darśayitvā mitreṇaamitram utsāhayitvāātmānam abhiyojayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then having entered into a secret concert with the friend, the conqueror may pretend to be under troubles and allow himself to be attacked by the enemy combined with the neglected friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sampīḍanena ghātayet, jīvagrāheṇa vā rājyavinimayaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then, hemmed from two sides, the enemy may be killed or captured alive to distribute his territory among the conqueror and his friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitreṇaāśritaś cetśatrur agrāhye sthātum icchet sāmantaādibhir mūlam asya hārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the enemy, helped by his friend, shuts himself in an impregnable fort, then his neighbouring enemies may be employed to lay waste his territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍena vā trātum ichet tam asya ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If he attempts to defend his territory by Kautilyas Arthashastra his army, that army may be annihilated

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tau cen na bhidyeyātāṃ prakāśam evaanyonyabhūmyā paṇeta // tataḥ parasparaṃ mitravyañjanā vā ubhayavetanā vā dūtān preṣayeyuḥ ayaṃ te rājā bhūmiṃ lipsate śatrusaṃhitaḥ iti // tayor anyataro jātaāśaṅkaāroṣaḥ, pūrvavac ceṣteta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the enemy and his ally cannot be separated, then each of these may be openly asked to come to an agreement with the conqueror to seize the territory of the other Then they will, of course, send such of their messengers as are termed friends and recipients of salaries from two states to each other with information This king the conqueror, allied with my army, desires to seize thy territory Then one of them may, with enragement and suspicion, act as before ie, fall upon the conqueror or the friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgarāṣṭradaṇḍamukhyān vā kṛtyapakṣahetubhir abhivikhyāpya pravrājayet // te yuddhaavaskandaavarodhavyasaneṣu śatrum atisaṃdadhyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The conqueror may dismiss his chief officers in charge of his forests, country parts, and army, under the pretence of their intrigue with the enemy Then going over to the enemy, they may catch hold of him on occasions of war, siege, or any other troubles;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhedaṃ vāasya svavargebhyaḥ kuryuḥ // abhityaktaśāsanaiḥ pratisamānayeyuḥ // / lubdhakavyañjanā vā māṃsavikrayeṇa dvāhsthā dauvārikaapāśrayāś coraabhyāgamaṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or they may sow the seeds of dissension between the enemy and his party, corroborating the causes of dissension by producing witnesses specially tutored Spies, disguised as hunters, may take a stand near the gate of the enemys fort to sell flesh, and make friendship with the sentinels at the gate

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parasya dvis trir iti nivedya labdhapratyayā bhartur anīkaṃ dvidhā niveśya grāmavadheavaskande ca dviṣato brūyuḥ āsannaś coragaṇaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having informed the enemy of the arrival of thieves on two or three occasions, they may prove themselves to be of reliable character and cause him to split his army into two divisions and to station them in two different parts of his territory

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mahāṃś caākrandaḥ, prabhūtaṃ sainyam āgacchatu iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When his villages are being plundered or besieged, they may tell him that thieves are come very near, that the tumult is very great, and that a large army is required

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tad arpayitvā grāmaghātadaṇḍasya sainyam itarad ādāya rātrau durgadvāreṣu brūyuḥ hataś coragaṇaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: They may take the army supplied, and surrendering it to the commander laying waste the villages, return at night with a part of the commanders army, and cry aloud at the gate of the fort that the thieves are slain, that the army has returned victorious, and that the gate may be opened

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvāram apāvriyatām iti // pūrvapraṇihitā vā dvārāṇi dadyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the gate is opened by the watchmen under the enemy‟s order or by others in confidence, they may strike the enemy with the help of the army

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kāruśilpipāṣaṇḍakuśīlavavaidehakavyañjanān āyudhīyān vvā paradurge praṇidadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Painters, carpenters, heretics, actors, merchants, and other disguised spies belonging to the conquerors army may also reside inside the fort of the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣāṃ gṛhapatikavyañjanāḥ kāṣṭhatṛṇadhānyapaṇyaśakaṭaiḥ praharaṇaāvaraṇāny abhihareyuḥ, devadhvajapratimābhir vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, disguised as agriculturists, may supply them with weapons taken in carts loaded with firewood, grass, grains, and other commodities of commerce, or disguised as images and flags of gods

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatas tadvyañjanāḥ pramattavadham avaskandapratigraham abhipraharaṇaṃ pṛṣṭhataḥ śaṅkhadundubhiśabdena vā praviṣṭam ity āvedayeyuḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then spies, disguised as priests, may announce to the enemy, blowing their conch shells and beating their drums, that a besieging army, eager to destroy all, and armed with weapons, is coming closely behind them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prākāradvāraaṭṭālakadānam anīkabhedaṃ ghātaṃ vā kuryuḥ // sārthagaṇavāsibhir ātivāhikaiḥ kanyāvāhikair aśvapaṇyavyavahāribhir upakaraṇahārakair dhānyakretṛvikretṛbhir vā pravrajitaliṅgibhir dūtaiś ca daṇaḍatinayanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then in the ensuing tumult, they may surrender the fortgate and the towers of the fort to the army of the conqueror or disperse the enemy‟s army and bring about his fall Or taking advantage of peace and friendship with the enemy, army and weapons may be collected inside the enemys fort by spies disguised as merchants, caravans, processions leading a bride, merchants selling horses, peddlers trading in miscellaneous articles, purchasers or sellers of grains, and as ascetics

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: iti rājaapasarpāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: These and others are the spies aiming on the life of a king

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eta evaaṭavīnām apasarpāḥ kaṇṭakaśodhanauktāś ca // vrajam aṭavyāsannam apasarpāḥ sārthaṃ vā corair ghātayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same spies, together with those described in Removal of thorns may, by employing thieves, destroy the flock of the enemys cattle or merchandise in the vicinity of wild tracts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtasaṃketam annapānaṃ caatra madanarasaviddhaṃ vā kṛtvāapagaccheyuḥ // gopālakavaidehakāś ca tataś corān gṛhītaloptrabhārān madanarasavikārakāleavaskandayeyuḥ // saṃkarṣaṇadaivatīyo vā muṇḍajaṭilavyañjanaḥ prahavaṇakarmaṇā madanarasayogenaatisaṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the cowherds show signs of intoxication in consequence of their eating the above foodstuffs, spies, disguised as cowherds, merchants, and thieves, may fall upon the enemys cowherds, and carry off the cattle Spies disguised as ascetics with shaved head or braided hair and pretending to be the worshippers of god, Sankarshana, may mix their sacrificial beverage with the juice of the madana plant and give it to the cowherds, and carry off the cattle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śauṇḍikavyañjano vā daivatapretakāryautsavasamājeṣv āṭavikān surāvikrayaupāyananimittaṃ madanarasayogenaatisaṃdadhyāt
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra A spy, under the guise of a vintner, may, on the occasion of procession of gods, funeral rites, festivals, and other congregations of people, go to sell liquor and present the cowherds with some liquor mixed with the juice of the madana plant

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: athaavaskandaṃ dadyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then others may fall upon the intoxicated cowherds and carry off the cattle

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: grāmaghātapraviṣṭāṃ vā vikṣipya bahudhāaṭavīm / ghātayed iti corāṇām apasarpāḥ prakīrtitāḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Those spies, who enter into the wild tracts of the enemy with the intention of plundering his villages, and who, leaving that work, set themselves to destroy the enemy, are termed spies under the garb of thieves

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (paryupāsanakarma avamardah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and fortythird chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karśanapūrvaṃ paryupāsanakarma //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE OPERATION OF A SIEGE REDUCTION of the enemy must precede a siege

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: janapadaṃ yathāniviṣṭam abhaye sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The territory that has been conquered should be kept so peacefully that it might sleep without any fear

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: utthitam anugrahaparihārābhyāṃ niveṣayet, anyatraapasarataḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When it is in rebellion, it is to be pacified by bestowing rewards and remitting taxes, unless the conqueror means to quit it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saṃgrāmād anyasyāṃ bhūmau niveśayet, ekasyāṃ vā vāsayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may select his battle fields in a remote part of the enemys territory, far from the populous centres;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na hy ajano janapado rājyam ajanapadaṃ vā bhavatiiti kauṭilyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for, in the opinion of Kautilya, no territory deserves the name of a kingdom or country unless it is full of people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viṣamasthasya muṣṭiṃ sasyaṃ vā hanyād, vīvadhaprasārau ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a people resist the attempt of the conqueror, then he may destroy their stores, crops, and granaries, and trade

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prasāravīvadhacchedān muṣṭisasyavadhād api / vamanād gūḍhaghātāc ca jāyate prakṛtikṣayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By the destruction of trade, agricultural produce, and standing crops, by causing the people to run away, and by slaying Kautilyas Arthashastra their leaders in secret, the country will be denuded of its people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prabhūtaguṇabaddha(vaddha) anyakupyayantraśastraāvaraṇaviṣṭir aśmisamagraṃ me sainyam, ṛtuś ca purastāt, apartuḥ parasya, vyādhidurbhikṣanicayarakṣākṣayaḥ krītabalanirvedo mitrabalanirvedaś ca iti paryupāsīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the conqueror thinks My army is provided with abundance of staple corn, raw materials, machines, weapons, dress, labourers, ropes and the like, and has a favourable season to act, whereas my enemy has an unfavourable season and is suffering from disease, famine and loss of stores and defencive force, while his hired troops as well as the army of his friend are in a miserable condition,then he may begin the siege

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtvā skandhaāvārasya rakṣāṃ vīvadhaāsārayoḥ pathaś ca, parikṣipya durgaṃ khātasālābhyām, dūṣayitvāudakam, avasrāvya parikhāḥ sampūrayitvā vā, suruṅgābalakuṭikābhyāṃ vapraprākārau hārayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having well guarded his camp, transports, supplies and also the roads of communication, and having dug up a ditch and raised a rampart round his camp, he may vitiate the water in the ditches round the enemys fort, or empty the ditches of their water or fill them with water if empty, and then he may assail the rampart and the parapets by making use of underground tunnels and iron rods

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dāraṃ ca guḍena //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the ditch dváram is very deep, he may fill it up with soil

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bahulaārakṣaṃ yantrair ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If it is defended by a number of men, he may destroy it by means of machines

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niṣkirād upaniṣkṛṣyaaśvaiś ca prahareyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Horse soldiers may force their passage through the gate into the fort and smite the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikramaantareṣu ca niyogavikalpasamuccayaiś caupāyānāṃ siddhiṃ lipseta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Now and then in the midst of tumult, he may offer terms to the enemy by taking recourse to one, two, three, or all of the strategic means

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgavāsinaḥ śyenakākanaptṛbhāsaśukasārikaulūkakapotān grāhayitvā puccheṣv agniyogayuktān paradurge visṛjet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having captured the birds such as the vulture, crow, naptri, bhása, parrot, máina, and pigeon which have their nests in the fortwalls, and having tied to their tails inflammable powders agniyoga, he may let them fly to the forts

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apakṛṣṭaskandhaāvārād ucchritadhvajadhanvaārakṣo vā mānuṣeṇaagninā paradurgam ādīpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: If the camp is situated at a distance from the fort and is provided with an elevated post for archers and their flags, then the enemys fort may be set on fire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gūḍhapurṣāś caantardurgapālakā nakulavānarabiḍālaśunāṃ puccheṣv agniyogam ādhāya kāṇḍanicayarakṣāvidhānaveśmasu visṛjeyuḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, living as watchmen of the fort, may tie inflammable powder to the tails of mongooses, monkeys, cats and dogs and let them go over the thatched roofs of the houses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śuṣkamatsyānām udareṣv agnim ādhāya vallūre vā vāyasaupahāreṇa vayobhir hārayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A splinter of fire kept in the body of a dried fish may be caused to be carried off by a monkey, or a crow, or any other bird to the thatched roofs of the houses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: saraladevadārupūtitṛṇagugguluśrīveṣṭakasarjarasalākṣāgulikāḥ kharauṣṭraajāvīnāṃ leṇḍaṃ caagnidhāraṇam // priyālacūrṇam avalgujamaṣīmadhuucchiṣṭam aśvakharauṣṭragoleṇḍam ity eṣa kṣepyoagniyogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Small balls prepared from the mixture of sarala Pinus Longifolia, devadáru deodár, pútitrina stinking grass, guggulu Bdellium, sriveshtaka turpentine, the juice of sarja Vatica Robusta, and láksha lac combined with dungs of an ass, camel, sheep, and goat are inflammable agnidharanah, ie, such as keep fire The mixture of the powder of priyala Chironjia Sapida, the charcoal of avalguja oanyza, serratula, anthelmintica, madhúchchhishta wax, and the dung of a horse, ass, camel, and cow is an inflammable powder to be hurled against the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvalohacūrṇam agnivarṇaṃ vā kumbhīsīsatrapucūrṇaṃ vā pāribhadrakapalāśapuṣpakeśamaṣītailamadhuucchiṣṭakaśrīveṣṭakayuktoagniyogo
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The powder of all the metals sarvaloha as red as fire, or the mixture of the powder of kumbhí gmelia arberea, sísa lead, trapu zinc, mixed with the charcoal powder of the flowers of páribhadraka deodar, palása Butea Frondosa, and hair, and with oil, wax, and turpentine, is also an inflammable powder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśvāsaghātī vā // tenaavaliptaḥ śaṇatrapusavalkaveṣṭito bāṇa ity agniyogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A stick of visvásagháti painted with the above mixture and wound round with a bark made of hemp, zinc, and lead, is a firearrow to be hurled against the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: na tv eva vidyamāne parākrameagnim avasṛjet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a fort can be captured by other means, no attempt should be made to set fire to it;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aviśvāsyo hy agnir daivapīḍanaṃ ca, apratisaṃkhyātaprāṇidhānyapaśuhiraṇyakupyadravyakṣayakaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for fire cannot be trusted; it not only offends gods, but also destroys the people, grains, cattle, gold, raw materials and the like

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣīṇanicayaṃ caavāptam api rājyaṃ kṣayāyaeva bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Also the acquisition of a fort with its property all destroyed is a source of further loss

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (iti paryupāsanakarma)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such is the aspect of a siege

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvaārambhaupakaraṇaviṣṭisampannoasmi, vyādhitaḥ para upadhāviruddhaprakṛtir akṛtadurgakarmanicayo vā, nirāsāraḥ sāsāro vā purā mitraiḥ saṃdhatte ity avamardakālaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the conqueror thinks am well provided with all necessary means and with workmen whereas my enemy is diseased with officers proved to be impure under temptations, with unfinished forts and deficient stores, allied with no friends, or with friends inimical at heart, then he should consider it as an Kautilyas Arthashastra opportune moment to take up arms and storm the fort

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / svayam agnau jāte samutthāpite vā prahavaṇe prekṣāanīkadarśanasaṅgasaurikakalaheṣu
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When fire, accidental or intentionally kindled, breaks out; when the enemys people are engaged in a sacrificial performance, or in witnessing spectacles or the troops, or in a quarrel due to the drinking of liquor;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityayuddhaśrāntabale bahulayuddhapratividdhapretapuruṣe jāgaraṇaklāntasuptajane
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or when the enemys army is too much tired by daily engagements in battles and is reduced in strength in consequence of the slaughter of a number of its men in a number of battles; when the enemys people wearied from sleeplessness have fallen asleep;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durdine nadīvege vā nīhārasamplave vāavamṛdnīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or on the occasion of a cloudy day, of floods, or of a thick fog or snow, general assault should be made

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: skandhaāvāram utsṛjya vā vanagūḍhaḥ śatruṃ niṣkrāntaṃ ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having concealed himself in a forest after abandoning the camp, the conqueror may strike the enemy when the latter comes out

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraāsāramukhyavyañjano vā samruddhena maitrīṃ kṛtvā dūtam abhityaktaṃ preṣayet idaṃ te chidram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A king pretending to be the enemys chief friend or ally, may make the friendship closer with the besieged, and send a messenger to say This is thy weak point;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ime dūṣyāḥ samroddhur vā chidram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: these are thy internal enemies; that is the weak point of the besieger;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ayaṃ te kṛtyapakṣaḥ iti // taṃ pratidūtam ādāya nirgacchantaṃ vijigīṣur gṛhītvā doṣam abhivikhyāpya pravāsya apagacchet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and this person who, deserting the conqueror, is now coming to thee is thy partisan When this partisan is returning with another messenger from the enemy, the conqueror should catch hold of him and, having published the partisans guilt, should banish him, and retire from the siege operations

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato mitraāsāravyañjano vā samruddhaṃ brūyāt māṃ trātum upanirgaccha, mayā vā saha samroddhāraṃ jahi iti // pratipannam ubhayataḥsampīḍanena ghātayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then the pretending friend may tell the besieged Come out to help me, or let us combine and strike the besieger Accordingly, when the enemy comes out, he may be hemmed between the two forces the conquerors force and the pretending friends force and killed or captured alive to distribute his territory between the conqueror and the friend

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nagaraṃ vāasya pramṛdnīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: His capital city may be razed to the ground;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sārabalaṃ vāasya vamayitvāabhihanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and the flower of his army made to come out and destroyed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena daṇḍaupanataāṭavikā vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This explains the treatment of a conquered enemy or wild chief

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: daṇḍaupanataāṭavikayor anyataro vā samruddhasya preṣayet ayaṃ samroddhā vyādhitaḥ, pārṣṇigrāheṇaabhiyuktaḥ, chidram anyad utthitam, anyasyāṃ bhūmāv apayātukāmaḥ iti // pratipanne samroddhā skandhaāvāram ādīpyaapayāyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Either a conquered enemy or the chief of a wild tribe in conspiracy with the conqueror may inform the besieged With the intention of escaping from a disease, or from the attack in his weak point by his enemy in the rear, or from a rebellion in his army, the conqueror seems to be thinking of going elsewhere, abandoning the siege When the enemy is made to believe this, the conqueror may set fire to his camp and retire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ pūrvavad ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then the enemy coming out may be hemmed as before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paṇyasampātaṃ vā kṛtvā paṇyenaenaṃ rasaviddhenaatisaṃdadhyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or having collected merchandise mixed with poison, the conqueror may deceive the enemy by sending that merchandise to the latter

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsāravyañjano vā samruddhasya dūtaṃ preṣayet mayā bāhyam abhihatam upanirgacchaabhihantum iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or a pretending ally of the enemy may send a messenger to the enemy, asking him Come out to smite the conqueror already struck by me When he does so, he may be hemmed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratipannaṃ pūrvavad ācaret //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: as before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mitraṃ bandhuṃ vāapadiśya yogapuruṣāḥ śāsanamudrāhastāḥ praviśya durgaṃ grāhayeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies, disguised as friends or relatives and with passports and orders in their hands, may enter the enemys fort and help to its capture

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: āsāravyañjñano vā samruddhasya preṣayet amuṣmin deśe kāle ca skandhaāvāram abhihaniṣyāmi,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or a pretending ally of the enemy may send information to the besieged am going to strike the besieging camp at such a time and place;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yuṣmābhir api yoddhavyam iti // pratipannaṃ yathāuktam abhyāghātasaṃkulaṃ darśayitvā rātrau durgān niṣkrāntaṃ ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: then you should also fight along with me When the enemy does so, or when he comes out of his fort after witnessing the tumult and uproar of the besieging army in danger, he may be slain as before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yad vā mitram āvāhayed āṭavvikaṃ vā, tam utsāhayet vikramya samruddhe bhūmim asya pratipadyasva iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or a friend or a wild chief in friendship with the enemy may be induced and encouraged to seize the land of the enemy when the latter is besieged by the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vikrāntaṃ prakṛtibhir dūṣyamukhyaupagraheṇa vā ghātayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or the conqueror himself may Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 administer poison to him

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svayaṃ vā rasena mitraghātakoayam ity avāptaarthaḥ // vikramitukāmaṃ vā mitravyañjanaḥ parasyaabhiśaṃset // āptabhāvaupagataḥ pravīrapuruṣānasyaupaghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then another pretending friend may inform the enemy that the murdered person was a fratricide as he attempted to seize the territory of his friend in troubles After strengthening his intimacy with the enemy, the pretending friend may sow the seeds of dissension between the enemy and his officers and have the latter hanged

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niviṣṭam asya janapadam avijñāto hanyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Causing the peaceful people of the enemy to rebel, he may put them down, unknown to the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apakārayitvā dūṣyaāṭavikeṣu vā balaekadeśam atinīya durgam avaskandena hārayet // dūṣyaamitraāṭavikadveṣyapratyapasṛtāś ca kṛtaarthamānasaṃjñācihnāḥ paradurgam avaskandeyuḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then having taken with him a portion of his army composed of furious wild tribes, he may enter the enemys fort and allow it to be captured by the conqueror Or traitors, enemies, wild tribes and other persons who have deserted the enemy, may, under the plea of having been reconciled, honoured and rewarded, go back to the enemy and allow the fort to be captured by the conqueror

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paradurgam avaskandya skandhaāvāraṃ vā patitaparānmukhaabhipannam uktakeśaśastrabhayavirūpebhyaś caabhayam ayudhyamānebhyaś ca dadyuḥ // paradurgam avāpya viśuddhaśatrupakṣaṃ kṛtaupāṃśudaṇḍapratīkāram antarbahiś ca praviśet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having captured the fort or having returned to the camp after its capture, he should give quarter to those of the enemys army who, whether as lying prostrate in the field, or as standing with their back turned to the conqueror, or with their hair dishevelled, with their weapons thrown down or with their body disfigured and shivering under fear, surrender themselves After the captured fort is cleared of the enemys partisans and is well guarded by the conquerors men both within and without, he should make his victorious entry into it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: evaṃ vijigīṣur amitrabhūmiṃ labdhvā madhyamaṃ lipseta, tatsiddhāv udāsīnam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having thus seized the territory of the enemy close to his country, the conqueror should direct his attention to that of the madhyama king;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣa prathamo mārgaḥ pṛthivīṃ jetum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: this being taken, he should catch hold of that of the neutral king This is the first way to conquer the world

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: madhyamaudāsīnayor abhāve guṇaatiśayenaariprakṛtīḥ sādhayet, tata uttarāḥ prakṛtīḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of the madhyama and neutral kings, he should, in virtue of his own excellent qualities, win the hearts of his enemys subjects, and then direct his attention to other remote enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣa dvitīyo mārgaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This is the second way

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇḍalasyaabhāve śatruṇā mitraṃ mitreṇa vā śatrum ubhayataḥsampīḍanena sādhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: In the absence of a Circle of States to be conquered, he should conquer his friend or his enemy by hemming each between his own force and that of his enemy or that of his friend Kautilyas Arthashastra respectively

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣatṛtīyo mārgaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This is the third way

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śakyam ekaṃ vā sāmantaṃ sādhayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Or he may first put down an almost invincible immediate enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tena dviguṇo dvitīyam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having doubled his power by this victory, he may go against a second enemy;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: triguṇas tṛtīyam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: having trebled his power by this victory, he may attack a third

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣa caturtho mārgaḥ pṛthivīṃ jetum //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: This is the fourth way to conquer the world

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jitvā ca pṛthivīṃ vibhaktavarṇaāśramāṃ svadharmeṇa bhuñjīta // upajāpoapasarpaś ca vāmanaṃ paryupāsanam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having conquered the earth with its people of distinct castes and divisions of religious life, he should enjoy it by governing it in accordance with the duties prescribed to kings

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: avamardaś ca pañcaete durgalambhasya hetavaḥ //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Intrigue, spies, winning over the enemys people, siege, and assault are the five means to capture a fort

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (labdhapraśamanam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: RESTORATION OF PEACE IN A CONQUERED COUNTRY

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvividhaṃ vijigīṣoḥ samutthānaṃ aṭavyādikam ekagrāmaādikaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE expedition which the conqueror has to undertake may be of two kinds in wild tracts or in single villages and the like

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trividhaś caasya lambhaḥ navo, bhūtapūrvaḥ, pitrya iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The territory which he acquires may be of three kinds that which is newly acquired, that which is recovered from an usurper and that which is inherited

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: navam avāpya lābhaṃ paradoṣān svaguṇaiś chādayet, guṇān guṇadvaiguṇyena // svadharmakarmaanugrahaparihāradānamānakarmabhiś ca prakṛtipriyahitāny anuvarteta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having acquired a new territory, he should cover the enemys vices with his own virtues, and the enemys virtues by doubling his own virtues, by strict observance of his own duties, by attending to Kautilyas Arthashastra his works, by bestowing rewards, by remitting taxes, by giving gifts, and by bestowing honours

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathāsambhāṣitaṃ ca kṛtyapakṣam upagrāhayet, bhūyaś ca kṛtaprayāsam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should give rewards, as promised, to those who deserted the enemy for his cause; he should also offer rewards to them as often as they render help to him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aviśvāso hi visaṃvādakaḥ sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca bhavati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for whoever fails to fullfil his promises becomes untrustworthy both to his own and his enemys people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prakṛtiviruddhaācāraś ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should adopt the same mode of life, the same dress, language, and customs as those of the people

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśadaivatasmājautsavavihāreṣu ca bhaktim anuvarteta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should follow the people in their faith with which they celebrate their national, religious and congregational festivals or amusements

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: deśagrāmajātisaṃghamukhyeṣu caabhīkṣṇaṃ sattriṇaḥ parasyaapacāraṃ darśayeyuḥ, māhābhāgyaṃ bhaktiṃ ca teṣu svāminaḥ, svāmisatkāraṃ ca vidyamānam // ucitaiś caenān bhogaparihārarakṣāavekṣaṇair bhuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: His spies should often bring home to the mind of the leaders of provinces, villages, castes, and corporations the hurt inflicted on the enemies in contrast with the high esteem and favour with which they are treated by the conqueror, who finds his own prosperity in theirs He should please them by giving gifts, remitting taxes, and providing for their security

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvadevatāāśramapūjanaṃ ca vidyāvākyadharmaśūrapuruṣāṇāṃ ca bhūmidravyadānaparihārān kārayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should always hold religious ife in high esteem Learned men, orators, charitable and brave persons should be favoured with gifts of land and money and with remission of taxes

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvabandhanamokṣaṇam anugrahaṃ dīnaanāthavyādhitānāṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should release all the prisoners, and afford help to miserable, helpless, and diseased persons

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cāturmāsyeṣv ardhamāsikam aghātam, paurṇamāsīṣu ca cātūrātrikaṃ rājadeśanakṣatreṣv aikarātrikam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should prohibit the slaughter of animals for half a month during the period of Cháturmásya from July to September, for four nights during the full moon, and for a night on the day of the birthstar of the conqueror or of the national star

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yonibālavadhaṃ puṃstvaupaghātaṃ ca pratiṣedhayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should also prohibit the slaughter of females and young ones yonibálavadham as well as castration

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yac ca kośadaṇḍaupaghātakam adharmiṣṭhaṃ vā caritraṃ manyeta tad apanīya dharmyavyavahāraṃ sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having abolished those customs or transactions which he might consider either as injurious to the growth of his revenue and army or as unrighteous, he should establish righteous transactions

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: coraprakṛtīnāṃ mlecchajātīnāṃ ca sthānaviparyāsam anekasthaṃ kārayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should compel born thieves as well as the Mlechchhas to change their habitations often and reside in many places

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: durgarāṣṭradaṇḍamukhyānāṃ ca // parāupagṛhītānāṃ ca mantripurohitānāṃ parasya pratyanteṣv anekasthaṃ vāsaṃ kārayet // apakārasamarthān anukṣiyato vā bhartṛvināśam upāṃśudaṇḍena praśamayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such of his chief officers in charge of the forts, country parts, and the army, and ministers and priests as are found to have been in conspiracy with the enemy should also be compelled to Kautilyas Arthashastra have their habitations in different places on the borders of the enemys country Such of his men as are capable to hurt him, but are convinced of their own fall with that of their master, should be pacified by secret remonstrance

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svadeśīyān vā pareṇa vāaparuddhān apavāhitasthāneṣu sthāpayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such renegades of his own country as are captured along with the enemy should be made to reside in remote corners

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pratyantaaṭavīstho vā prabādhitum abhijātaḥ, tasmai viguṇāṃ bhūmiṃ prayacchet, guṇavatyāś caturbhāgaṃ vā kośadaṇḍadānam avasthāpya, yad upakurvāṇaḥ paurajānapadān kopayet // kupitais tair enaṃ ghātayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever of the enemys family is capable to wrest the conquered territory and is taking shelter in a wild tract on the border, often harassing the conqueror, should be provided with a sterile portion of territory or with a fourth part of a fertile tract on the condition of supplying to the conqueror a fixed amount of money and a fixed number of troops, in raising which he may incur the displeasure of the people and may be destroyed by them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prakṛtibhir upakruṣṭam apanayet, aupaghātike vā deśe niveśayet iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever has caused excitement to the people or incurred their displeasure should be removed and placed in a dangerous locality

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūtapūrve yena doṣeṇaapavṛttas taṃ prakṛtidoṣaṃ chādayet, yena ca guṇenaupāvṛttas taṃ tīvrīkuryāt iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having recovered a lost territory, he should hide those vices of his, owing to which he lost it, and increase those virtues by which he recovered it

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pitrye pitur doṣāṃś chādayet, guṇāṃś ca prakāśayet iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With regard to the inherited territory, he should cover the vices of his father, and display his own virtues

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caritram akṛtaṃ dharmyaṃ kṛtaṃ caanyaiḥ pravartayet / pravartayen na caadharmyaṃ kṛtaṃ caanyair nivartayet //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: He should initiate the observance of all those customs, which, though righteous and practised by others, are not observed in his own country, and give no room for the practice of whatever is unrighteous, though observed by others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: parabalaghātaprayogah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: MEANS TO INJURE AN ENEMY

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cāturvarṇyarakṣāartham aupaniṣadikam adharmiṣṭheṣu prayuñjīta //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: IN order to protect the institution of the four castes, such measures as are treated of in secret science shall be applied against the wicked

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / kālakūṭaādir viṣavargaḥ śraddheyadeśaveṣaśilpabhāṣāabhijanaapadeśaiḥ kubjavāmanakirātamūkabadhirajaḍaandhacchadmabhir mlecchajātīyair abhipretaiḥ strībhiḥ pumbhiś ca paraśarīraupabhogeṣv avadhātavyaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Through the instrumentality of such men or women of Mlechchha class as can put on disguises, appropriate to different countries, arts, or professions, or as can put on the appearance of a humpbacked, dwarfish, or shortsized person, or of a dumb, deaf, idiot, or blind person, kálakúta and other manifold poisons should be administered in the diet and other physical enjoyments of the wicked

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rājakrīḍābhāṇḍanidhānadravyaupabbhogeṣu gūḍhāḥ śastranidhānaṃ kuryuḥ, sattraājīvinaś ca rātricāriṇoagnijīvinaś caagninidhānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Spies lying in wait or living as inmates in the same house may make use of weapons on occasions of royal sports or musical and other entertainments Spies, under the disguise of nightwalkers rátrichári or of firekeepers agnijívi may set fire to the houses of the wicked

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: citrabhekakauṇḍinyakakṛkaṇapañcakuṣṭhaśatapadīcūrṇam uccidiṇgakambalīśatakanda(kardama?) idhmakṛkalāsacūrṇaṃ gṛhagolikaandhaahikakrakaṇṭakapūtikīṭagomārikācūrṇaṃ bhallātakaavalgujarasamyuktaṃ sadyaḥprāṇaharam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The powder prepared from the carcass of animals such as chitra ?, bheka frog, kaundinyaka ?, krikana perdix sylvatika, panchakushtha ?, and satapadi, centipede; or of animals such as uchchitinga crab, kambali ?, krikalása lizard with the powder of the bark of satakanda Phyalis Flexuosa; or of animals such as grihagaulika a small houselizard, andháhika a blind snake, krakanthaka a kind of partridge, pútikíta a stinking insect, and gomárika ? combined with the juice of bhallátaka Semecarpus Anacardium, and valgaka ?;the smoke caused by burning the above powders causes instantaneous death

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eteṣāṃ vā dhūmaḥ // kīṭo vāanyatamas taptaḥ kṛṣṇasarpapriyaṅgubhiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Any of the above insects may be heated with a black snake and priyangu panic seed and reduced to powder This mixture, Kautilyas Arthashastra when burnt, causes instantaneous death

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dhāmaargavayātudhānamūlaṃ bhallātakapuṣpacūrṇayuktam ārdhamāsikaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The powder prepared from the roots of dhámárgava lufta foetida and yátudhána ? mixed with the powder of the flower of bhallátaka Semecarpus Anacardium causes, when administered, death in the course of half a month

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyāghātakamūlaṃ bhallātakapuṣpacūrṇayuktaṃ kīṭayogo māsikaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The root of vyágháta casia fistula reduced to powder with the flower of bhallátaka Semecarpus A nacardium mixed with the essence of an insect kíta causes, when administered, death in the course of a month

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalāmātraṃ puruṣāṇām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: As much as a kalá th of a tola to men;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dviguṇaṃ kharaaśvānām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: twice as much to mules and horses;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturguṇaṃ hastyuṣṭrāṇām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and four times as much to elephants and camels

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śatakardamauccidiṅgakaravīrakaṭutumbīmatsyadhūmo madanakodravapalālena hastikarṇapalāśapalālena vā pravātaanuvāte
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The smoke caused by burning the powder of satakardama ?, uchchitinga crab, karavira nerium odorum, katutumbi a kind of bitter gourd, and fish together with the chaff of the grains of madana ? and kodrava paspalam scrobiculatum, or with the chaff of the seeds of hastikarna castor oil tree and palása butea frondosa destroys animal life as far as it is carried off by the wind

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūkikīṭamastyakaṭutumbīśatakardamaidhmaindragopacūrṇaṃ pūtikīṭakṣudraārālāhemavidārīcūrṇaṃ vā bastaśṛṅgakhuracūrṇayuktam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The smoke caused by burning the powder of pútikita a stinking insect, fish, katutumbi a kind of bitter gourd, the bark of satakardama ?, and indragopa the insect cochineal, or the powder of pútikita, kshudrárála the resin of the plant, shorea robusta, and hemavidári ? mixed with the powder of the hoof and horn of a goat causes blindness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pūtikarañjapattraharitālamanaḥśilāguñjaāraktakārpāsapalālaanyaāsphoṭakācagośakṛdrasapiṣṭam andhīkaro dhūmaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The smoke caused by burning the leaves of pútikaranja guilandina bonducella, yellow arsenic, realgar, the seeds of gunja abrus precatorius, the chaff of the seeds of red cotton, ásphota a plant, careya arborea, khácha salt ?, and the dung and urine of a cow causes blindness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarpanirmokaṃ goaśvapurīṣam andhaahikaśiraś caandhīkaro dhūmaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The smoke caused by burning the skin of a snake, the dung of a cow and a horse, and the head of a blind snake causes blindness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / pārāvataplavakakravyaadānāṃ hastinaravarāhāṇāṃ ca mūtrapurīṣaṃ kāsīsahiṅguyavatuṣakaṇataṇḍulāḥ kārpāsakuṭajakośaatakīnāṃ ca bījāni gomūtrikābhāṇḍīmūlaṃ nimbaśigruphaṇirjakākṣīvapīlukabhaṅgaḥ sarpaśapharīcarma hastinakhaśṛṅgacūrṇam ity eṣa dhūmo madanakodravapalālena hastikarṇapalāśapalālena vā praṇītaḥ pratyekaśo
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra The smoke caused by burning the powder made of the mixture of the dung and urine of pigeons, frogs, flesheating animals, elephants, men, and boars, the chaff and powder of barley mixed with kásísa green sulphate of iron, rice, the seeds of cotton, kutaja nerium antidysentericum, and kosátaki lufta pentandra, cows urine, the root of bhándi hydroeotyle asiatica, the powder of nimba nimba meria, sigru hyperanthera morunga, phanirjaka a kind of tulasi plant, kshíbapíluka ripe coreya arborea, and bhánga a common intoxicating drug, the skin of a snake and fish, and the powder of the nails and tusk of an elephant, all mixed with the chaff of madana and kodravá paspalam scrobiculatum, or with the chaff of the seeds of hastikarna castor oil tree and palása butea frondosa causes instantaneous death wherever the smoke is carried off by the wind

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / kālīkuṣṭhanaḍaśatāvalīmūlaṃ sarpapracalākakṛkaṇapañcakuṣṭhacūrṇaṃ vā dhūmaḥ pūrvakalpenaārdraśuṣkapalālena vā praṇītaḥ saṃgrāmaavataraṇaavaskandanasaṃkuleṣu kṛtanejanaudakaakṣipratīkāraiḥ praṇītaḥ sarvaprāṇināṃ netraghnaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a man who has kept his eyes secure with the application of ointment and medicinal water burns, on the occasion of the commencement of a battle and the assailing of forts, the roots of káli tragia involucrata, kushtha costus, nada a kind of reed and satávari asperagus racemosus, or the powder of the skin of a snake, the tail of a peacock, krikana a kind of partridge, and panchakushtha ?, together with the chaff as previously described or with wet or dry chaff, the smoke caused thereby destroys the eyes of all animals

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śārikākapotabakabalākāleṇḍam arkaakṣipīlukasnuhikṣīrapiṣṭam andhīkaraṇam añjanam udakadūṣaṇaṃ ca //
