Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The ointment prepared by mixing the excretion of sáriká maina, kapota pigeon, baka crane, and baláka a kind of small crane with the milk of kákshiva hyperanthera morunga, píluka a species of careya arborea and snuhi euphorbia causes blindness and poisons water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / yavakaśālimūlamadanaphalajātīpattranaramūtrayogaḥ plakṣavidārīmūlayukto mūkaudumbaramadanakodravakvāthayukto hastikarṇapalāśakvāthayukto vā madanayogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The mixture of yavaka a kind of barley, the root of sála achyrantes triandria, the fruit of madana dattúra plant?, the leaves of játí nutmeg?, and the urine of a man mixed with the Kautilyas Arthashastra powder of the root of plaksha fig tree, and vidári liquorice, as well as the essence of the decoction of musta a kind of poison, udumbara glomerous fig tree, and kodrava paspalam scrobiculatum or with the decoction of hastikarna castor oil tree and palása butea frondosa is termed the juice of madana madanayoga

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / śṛṅgigautamavṛkakaṇṭakaaramayūrapadīyogo guñjālāṅgalīviṣamūlikaiṅgudīyogaḥ karavīraakṣipīlukaarkamṛgamāraṇīyogo madnakodravakvāthayukto hastikarṇapalāśakvāthayukto vā madanayogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The mixture of the powders of sringi atis betula, gaumevriksha ?, kantakára solanum xanthocarpum, and mayúrapadi ?, the powder of gunja seeds, lánguli jusseina repens, vishamúlika ?, and ingudi heartpea, and the powder of karavira oleander, akshipiluka careya arborea, arka plant, and mrigamáríni ? combined with the decoction of madana and kodrava or with that of hastikarna and palása is termed madana mixture madanayoga

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samastā vā yavasaindhanaudakadūṣaṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The combination of the above two mixtures poisons grass and water when applied to them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛtakaṇḍalakṛkalāsagṛhagolikaandhaahikadhūmo netravadham unmādaṃ ca karoti // kṛkalāsagṛhagolikāyogaḥ kuṣṭhakaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The smoke caused by burning the mixture of the powders of krikana a kind of partridge, krikalása lizard, grihagaulika a small houselizard and andháhika a blind snake destroys the eyes and causes madness The smoke caused by burning the mixture of krikalása and grihagaulika causes leprosy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: manuṣyalohitayuktaḥ śoṣam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same mixture, wetted with human blood causes consumption

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dūṣīviṣaṃ madanakodravacūrṇam apajihvikāyogaḥ // mātṛvāhakaañjalikārapracalākabhekaakṣipīlukayogo viṣūcikākaraḥ // pañcakuṣṭhakakauṇḍinyakarājavṛkṣapuṣpamadhuyogo jvarakaraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The powder of dúshívisha ?, madana dattúra plant ?, and Kautilyas Arthashastra kodrava paspalam scrobiculatum destroys the tongue The mixture of the powder of mátriváhaka ?, jalúka leech, the tail of a peacock, the eyes of a frog, and píluká careya arborea causes the disease known as vishúchika The mixture of panchakushtha ?, kaundinyaka ?, rájavriksha cassia fistula, and madhupushpa bassia latifolia and madhu honey? causes fever

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhāsanakulajihvāgranthikāyogaḥ kharīkṣīrapiṣṭo mūkabadhirakaro māsaardhamāsikaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The mixture prepared from the powder of the knot of the tongue of bhája ?, and nakula mongoose reduced to a paste with the milk of a shedonkey causes both dumbness and deafness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kalāmātraṃ puruṣāṇām it samānaṃ pūrveṇa //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The proportion of a dose to bring on the desired deformities in men and animals in the course of a fortnight or a month is as laid down before

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhaṅgakvāthaupanayanam auṣadhānām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Mixtures become very powerful when, in the case of drugs, they are prepared by the process of decoction;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cūrṇaṃ prāṇabhṛtām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and in the case of animals, by the process of making powders;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarveṣāṃ vā kvāthaupanayanam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or in all cases by the process of decoction

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śālmalī vidārīdhānyasiddho mūlavatsanābhasamyuktaś cucchundarīśoṇitapralepena digdho bāṇo yaṃ vidhyati sa viddhoanyān daśapuruṣān
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever is pierced by the arrow prepared from the grains of sálmali bombax heptaphyllum and vidári liquorice reduced to powder and mixed with the powder of múlavatsanábha a kind of poison and smeared over with the blood of chuchundari muskrat bites some ten other persons who in their turn bite others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ballātakayātudhānāvaanudhāmārgavabāṇānāṃ puṣpair elakaakṣigugguluhālāhalānāṃ ca kaṣāyaṃ bastanaraśoṇitayuktaṃ daṃśayogaḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The mixture prepared from the flowers of bhallátaka semecarpus anacardium, yátudhána ?, dhámárgava achyranthes aspera, and bána sal tree mixed with the powder of elá large cardamom, kákshi red aluminous earth, guggulu Kautilyas Arthashastra bdellium, and háláhala a kind of poison together with the blood of a goat and a man causes biting madness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatoardhadharaṇiko yogaḥ saktupiṇyākābhyām udake praṇīto dhanuḥśataāyāmam udakaāśayaṃ dūṣayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When half a dharana of this mixture together with flour and oilcakes is thrown into water of a reservoir measuring a hundred bows in length, it vitiates the whole mass of water;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: matsyaparamparā hy etena daṣṭāabhimṛṣṭā vā viṣībhavati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: all the fish swallowing or touching this mixture become poisonous;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yaś caetad udakaṃ pibati spṛśati vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and whoever drinks or touches this water will be poisoned

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: raktaśvetasarṣapair godhā tripakṣam uṣṭrikāyāṃ bhūmau nikhātāyāṃ nihitā vadhyenauddhṛtā yāvat paśyati tāvan mārayati, kṛṣṇasarpo vā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: No sooner does a person condemned to death pull out from the earth an alligator or iguana godhá which, with three or five handfuls of both red and white mustard seeds, is entered into the earth than he dies at its sight

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / vidyutpradagdhoaṅgāro jvālo vā vidyutpradagdhaiḥ kāṣṭhair gṛhītaś caanuvāsitaḥ kṛttikāsu bharaṇīṣu vā raudreṇa karmaṇāabhihutoagniḥ praṇītaś ca
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, on the days of the stars of krittiká or bharaní and following the method of performing fearful rites, an oblation with a black cobra emitting froth at the shock of lightning or caught hold of by means of the sticks of a tree struck by lightning and perfumed is made into the fire, that fire continues to burn unquenchably

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karmārād agnim āhṛtya kṣaudreṇa juhuyāt pṛthak /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: An oblation of honey shall be made into the fire fetched from the house of a blacksmith;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: surayā śauṇḍikād agniṃ mārgatoagniṃ ghṛtena ca // mālyena caekapatnyagniṃ puṃścalyagniṃ ca sarṣapaiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: of spirituous liquor into the fire brought from the house of a vintner; of clarified butter into the fire of a sacrificer ?; Of a garland into the fire kept by a sacrificer with one wife; of mustard seeds into the fire kept by an adulterous woman;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dadhnā ca sūtikāsv agnim āhitaagniṃ ca taṇḍulaiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: of curds into the fire kept during the birth of a child; of ricegrain into the fire of a sacrificer;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caṇḍālaagniṃ ca māṃsena citaagniṃ mānuṣeṇa ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Of flesh into the fire kept by a chandala; of human flesh into the fire burning in cremation grounds;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samastān bastavasayā mānuṣeṇa dhruveṇa ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: an oblation of the serum of the flesh of a goat and a man shall be made by means of a sacrificial ladle into the fire which is made of all the above fires;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: juhuyād agnimantreṇa rājavṛkṣasya dārubhiḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Repeating the mantras addressed to the fire, an oblation of the wooden pieces of rájavriksha cassia fistula into the same fire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eṣa niṣpratikāroagnir dviṣatāṃ netramohanaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 This fire will unquenchably burn deluding the eyes of the enemies

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adite namaste, anumate namaste, sarasvati namaste,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Salutation to Aditi, salutation to Anumati, salutation to Sarasvati and salutation to the Sun;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: agnaye svāhā, somāya svāhā, bhūḥ svāhā bhuvaḥ svāhā //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: oblation to Agni, oblation to soma, oblation to the earth, and oblation to the atmosphere

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (pralambhanam, tatra adbhutautpādanam)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and fortysixth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER WONDERFUL AND DELUSIVE CONTRIVANCES

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śirīṣaudumbaraśamīcūrṇaṃ sarpiṣā saṃhṛtyaardhamāsikaḥ kṣudyogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A DOSE of the powder of sirísha mimosa sirísa, udumbara glomerous figtree, and sami acacia suma mixed with clarified butter, renders fasting possible for half a month;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kaśerukautpalakandekṣumūlabisadūrvākṣīraghṛtamaṇḍasiddho māsikaḥ // māṣayavakulatthadarbhamūlacūrṇaṃ vā kṣīraghṛtābhyām,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the scum prepared from the mixture of the root of kaseruka a kind of watercreeper, utpala costus, and sugarcane mixed with bisa waterlily, dúrva grass, milk, and clarified butter enables a man to fast for a month The powder of másha phraseolus radiatus, yava barley, kuluttha horsegram and the root of darbha sacrificial grass mixed with milk and clarified butter;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vallīkṣīraghṛtaṃ vā samasiddham, sālapṛśniparṇīmūlakalkaṃ payasā pītvā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the milk of valli a kind of creeper and clarified butter derived from it and mixed in equal proportions and combined with the paste prepared from the root of sála shorea robusta and prisniparni hedysarum lagopodioides, when drunk with milk;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: payo vā tatsiddhaṃ madhughṛtābhyām aśitvā māsam upavasati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: or a dose of milk mixed with clarified butter and spirituous liquor, both prepared from the above substances, enables one to fast for a month

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvetabastamūtre saptarātrauṣitaiḥ siddhaarthakaiḥ siddhaṃ tailaṃ kaṭukaālābau māsaardhamāsasthitaṃ catuṣpadadvipadānāṃ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The oil prepared from mustard seeds previously kept for seven nights in the urine of a white goat will, when used externally after keeping the oil inside a large bitter gourd for a month and a half, alter the colour of both biped and quadruped Kautilyas Arthashastra animals

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: takrayavabhakṣasya saptarātrād ūrdhvaṃ śvetagardabhasya leṇḍayavaiḥ siddhaṃ gaurasarṣapatailaṃ virūpakaraṇam // etayor anyatarasya mūtraleṇdarasasiddhaṃ siddhaarthakatailam arkatūlapataṅgacūrṇapratīvāpaṃ śvetīkaraṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The oil extracted from white mustard seeds mixed with the barleycorns contained in the dung of a white donkey, which has been living for more than seven nights on a diet of butter, milk and barley, causes alteration in colour The oil prepared from mustard seeds which have been previously kept in the urine and fluid dung of any of the two animals, a white goat and a white donkey, causes when applied such white colour as that of the fibre of arka plant or the down of a white bird

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvetakukkuṭaajagaraleṇḍayogaḥ śvetīkaraṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The mixture of the dung of a white cock and ajagara boaconstrictor causes white colour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvetabastamūtre śvetasarṣapāḥ saptarātrauṣitaastakra(?) markakṣīralavaṇaṃ dhānyaṃ ca pakṣasthito yogaḥ śvetīkaraṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The pastry made from white mustard seeds kept for seven nights in the urine of a white goat mixed with buttermilk, the milk of arka plant, salt, and grains dhánya, causes, when applied for a fortnight, white colour

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kaṭukaalābau valīgate gataṃardhamāsasthitaṃ gaurasarṣapapiṣṭaṃ romṇāṃ śvetīkaraṇam // alojuneti yaḥ kīṭaḥ śvetā ca gṛhagolikā /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The paste, prepared from white mustard seeds which have been previously kept within a large bitter gourd and with clarified butter prepared from the milk of valli a creeper for half a month, makes the hair white A bitter gourd, a stinking insect pútikíta, and a white houselizard;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etena piṣtenaabhyaktāḥ keśāḥ syuḥ śaṅkhapāṇḍarāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: when a paste prepared from these is applied to the hair, the latter becomes as white as a conchshell

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gomayena tindukaariṣṭakalkena vā marditaaṅgasya bhallātakarasaanuliptasya māsikaḥ kuṣṭhayogaḥ // kṛṣṇasarpamukhe gṛhagolikāmukhe vā saptarātrauṣitā gujjāḥ kuṣṭhayogaḥ // śukapittaaṇḍarasaabhyaṅgaḥ kuṣṭhayogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When any part of the body of a man is rubbed over with the pastry kalka prepared from tinduka glutinosa and arishta soapberry, together with the dung of a cow, the part of the body being also smeared over with the juice of bhallátaka semecarpus Kautilyas Arthashastra anacardium, he will catch leprosy in the course of a month The application of the paste prepared from gunja seeds kept previously for seven nights in the mouth of a white cobra or in the mouth of a houselizard brings on leprosy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kuṣṭhasyapriyālakalkakaṣāyaḥ pratīkāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: External application of the liquid essence of the egg of a parrot and a cuckoo brings on leprosy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kukkuṭakośaatakī(?) śatāvarīmūlayuktam āhārayamāṇo māsena gauro bhavati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever eats the mixture of the powders of the roots of kukkuta marsilia dentata, kosátaki duffa pentandra, and satávari asparagus racemosus for a month will become white

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaṭakaṣāyasnātaḥ sahacarakalkadigdhaḥ kṛṣṇo bhavati // śakunakaṇgutailayuktā haritālamanaḥśilāḥ śyāmīkaraṇam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever bathes in the decoction of vata banyan tree and rubs his body with the paste prepared from sahachara yellow barleria becomes black Sulphuret of arsenic and red arsenic mixed with the oil extracted from sakuna a kind of bird and kanka a vulture causes blackness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khadyotacūrṇaṃ sarṣapatailayuktaṃ rātrau jvalati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The powder of khadyota firefly mixed with the oil of mustard seeds emits light at night

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: khadyotagaṇḍūpadacūrṇaṃ samudrajantūnāṃ bhṛṅgakapālānāṃ khadirakarṇikārāṇāṃ puṣpacūrṇaṃ vā śakunakaṅgutailayuktaṃ tejanacūrṇam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The powder of khadyota firefly and gandúpada earthworm or the powder of ocean animals mixed with the powder of bhringa malabathrum, kapála a potherb, and khadira mimosa catechu, and karnikára pentapetes acerifolia, combined with the oil of sakuna a bird and kanka vulture, is tejanachúrna ignition powder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pāribhadrakatvanmaṣī maṇḍūkavasayā yuktā gātraprajvālanam agninā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The ball prepared from the powder of the charcoal of the bark of pílu careya arborea can be held in hand and burnt with fire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paribhadrakatvaktilakalkapradigdhaṃ śarīram agninā jvalati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the body of a man is smeared over with the serum of the flesh of a frog, it burns with fire with no hurt

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pīlutvanmaṣīmayaḥ piṇḍo haste jvalati // maṇḍūkavasādigdhoagninā jvalati // tena pradigdham aṅgaṃ kuśaāmraphalatailasiktaṃ samudramaṇḍūkīphenakasarjarasacūrṇayuktaṃ vā jvalati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the body of a man is smeared over with the above serum as well as with the oil extracted from the fruits of kusa ficus religiosa, and ámra mango tree, and when the powder prepared from an ocean frog samdura mandúki, phenaka seafoam, and sarjarasa the juice of vatica robusta is sprinkled over the body, it burns with fire without being hurt When the body of a man is smeared over with sesamum oil mixed with equal quantities of the serum of the flesh of a frog, crab, and other animals, it can burn with fire without hurt

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: maṇḍūkakulīraādīnāṃ vasayā samabhāgaṃ tailaṃ siddham abhyaṅgaṃ gātrāṇām agniprajvālanam // veṇumūlaśaivalaliptam aṅgaṃ maṇḍūkavasādigdham agninā jvalati // pāribhadrakappatibalāvañjulavajrakadalīmūlakalkena maṇḍūkavasāsiddhena tailenaabhyaktapādoaṅgāreṣu gacchati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The body which is smeared over with the serum of the flesh of a frog burns with fire The body of a man, which is rubbed over with the powder of the root of bamboo venu and saivála aquatic plant, and is smeared over with the serum of the flesh of a frog, burns with fire Whoever has anointed his legs with the oil extracted from the Kautilyas Arthashastra paste prepared from the roots of páribhadraka erythrina indica, pratibala ?, vanjula a kind of ratan or tree, vajra andropogon muricatum or euphorbia, and kadali banana, mixed with the serum of the flesh of a frog, can walk over fire without hurt

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eteṣāṃ mūlakalkena maṇḍūkavasayā saha // sādhayet tailam etena pādāv abhyajya nirmalau /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Oil should be extracted from the paste prepared from the roots of pratibala, vanjula and páribhadraka, all growing near water, the paste being mixed with the serum of the flesh of a frog

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aṅgārarāśau vicared yathā kusumasaṃcaye //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having anointed ones legs with this oil, one can walk over a whitehot mass of fire as though on a bed of roses

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: haṃsakrauñcamayūrāṇām anyeṣāṃ vā mahāśakunīnām udakaplavānāṃ puccheṣu baddhā naladīpikā rātrāv ulkādarśanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When birds such as a hamsa goose, krauncha heron, mayúra peacock and other large swimming birds are let to fly at night with a burning reed attached to their tail it presents the appearance of a firebrand falling from the sky ulká

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaidyutaṃ bhasmaaṅgiśamanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Ashes caused by lightning quench the fire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: strīpuṣpapāyitā māṣā vrajakulīmūlaṃ maṇḍūkavasāmiśraṃ culluyāṃ dīptāyām apācanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, in a fireplace, kidney beans másha wetted with the menstrual fluid of a woman, as well as the roots of vajra andropogon muricatum and kadali banana, wetted with the serum of the flesh of a frog are kept, no grains can be cooked there

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cullīśodhanaṃ pratīkāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Cleansing the fire place is its remedy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pīlumayo maṇir agnigarbhaḥ suvarcalāmūlagranthiḥ sūtragranthir vā picupariveṣṭito mukhyād agnidhūmautsargaḥ //E kuśaāmraphalatailasiktoagnir varṣapravāteṣu jvalati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By keeping in the mouth a balllike piece of pilu careya arberea or a knot of the root of linseed tree suvarchala with fire inserted within the mass of the ball and wound round with threads and cotton pichu, volumes of smoke and fire can be breathed out When the oil extracted from the fruits of kusa ficus religiosa and ámra mango is poured over the fire, it burns even in the storm

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samudraphenakas tailayuktoambhasi plavamāno jvalati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra Seafoam wetted with oil and ignited keeps burning when floating on water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: plavamānānām asthiṣu kalmāṣaveṇunā nirmathitoagnir naudakena śāmyati,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The fire generated by churning the bone of a monkey by means of a bamboo stick of white and black colour kalmáshavenu burns in water instead of being quenched

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / śastrahatasya śūlaprotasya vā puruṣasya vāmapārśvaparśukaasthiṣu kalmāṣaveṇunā nirmathitoagniḥ striyāḥ puruṣasya vāasthiṣu manuṣyaparśukayā nirmathitoagnir yatra trir apasavyaṃ gacchati na caatraanyoagnir jvalati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: There will burn no other fire where the fire generated by churning, by means of a bamboo stick of white and black colour, the left side ribbone of a man killed by a weapon or put to the gallows; or the fire generated by churning the bone of a man or woman by means of the bone of another man is circumambulated thrice from right to left

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: cuccundarī khañjarīṭaḥ khārakīṭaś ca piṣyate / aśvamūtreṇa saṃsṛṣṭā nigalānāṃ tu bhañjanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the paste prepared from the animals such as chuchundari muskrat, khanjaríta ? and khárakíta ?, with the urine of a horse is applied to the chains with which the legs of a man are bound, they will be broken to pieces

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ayaskānto vā pāṣāṇaḥ kulīradardurakhārakīṭavasāpradehena dviguṇaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The sunstone ayaskánta or any other stone will break to pieces when wetted with the serum of the flesh of the animals kulinda ?, dardura ?, and khárakíta ?

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nārakagarbhaḥ kaṅkabhāsapārśvautpalaudakapiṣṭaś catuṣpadadvipadānāṃ pādalepaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The paste prepared from the powder of the ribbone of náraka ?, a donkey, kanka a kind of vulture, and bhása a bird, mixed with the juice of waterlily, is applied to the legs of bipeds and quadrupeds while making a journey

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ulūkagṛdhravasābhyām uṣṭracarmaupānahāv abhyajya vaṭapattraiḥ praticchādya pañcāśadyojanāny aśrānto gacchati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a man makes a journey, wearing the shoes made of the skin of a camel, smeared over with the serum of the flesh of an owl and a vulture and covered over with the leaves of the banyan tree, he can walk fifty yojanas without any fatigue

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śyenakaṅkakākagṛdhrahaṃsakrauñcavīcīrallānāṃ majjāno retāṃsi vā yojanaśatāya, siṃhavyāghradvīpakākaulūkānāṃ majjāno retāṃsi vā // sārvavarṇikāni garbhapatanāny uṣṭrikāyām abhiṣūya śmaśāne pretaśiśūn vā tatsamutthitaṃ medo yojanaśatāya //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the shoes are smeared over with the pith, marrow or sperm of the birds, syena, kanka, káka, gridhra, hamsá, krauncha, Kautilyas Arthashastra and vichiralla, the traveller wearing them can walk a hundred yojanas without any fatigue The fat or serum derived from roasting a pregnant camel together with saptaparna lechites scholaris or from roasting dead children in cremation grounds, is applied to render a journey of a hundred yojanas easy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: aniṣṭair adbhutautpātaiḥ parasyaudvegam ācaret /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Terror should be caused to the enemy by exhibiting these and other wonderful and delusive performances;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ārājyāyaiti nirvādaḥ samānaḥ kopa ucyate //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: while anger causing terror is common to all, terrification by such wonders is held as a means to consolidate peace

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (pralambhanam, tatra bhaiṣajyamantrayogah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and fortyseventh chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / mārjārauṣṭravṛkavarāhaśvaavidvāgulīnaptṛkākaulūkānām anyeṣāṃ vā niśācarāṇāṃ sattvānām ekasya dvayor bahūnāṃ vā dakṣiṇāni vāmāni caakṣīṇi gṛhītvā dvidhā cūrṇaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE APPLICATION OF MEDICINES AND MANTRAS HAVING pulled out both the right and the left eyeballs of a cat, camel, wolf, boar, porcupine, váguli ?, naptri ?, crow and owl, or of any one, two, or three, or many of such animals as roam at nights, one should reduce them to two kinds of powder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato dakṣiṇaṃ vāmena vāmaṃ dakṣiṇena samabhyajya rātrau tamasi ca paśyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Whoever anoints his own right eye with the powder of the left eye and his left eye with the powder of the right eyeball can clearly see things even in pitch dark at night

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ekaāmlakaṃ varāhaakṣi khadyotaḥ kālaśārivā /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: One is the eye of a boar; another is that of a khadyota firefly, or a crow, or a mina bird

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etenaabhyaktanayano rātrau rūpāṇi paśyati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having anointed ones own eyes with the above, one can clearly see things at night

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puṣyeṇa śastrahatasya śūlaprotasya vā puṃsaḥ śiraḥkapāle mṛttikāyāṃ yavān āvāsyaavikṣīreṇa secayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having fasted for three nights, one should, on the day of the star, Pushya, catch hold of the skull of a man who has been killed Kautilyas Arthashastra with a weapon or put to the gallows Having filled the skull with soil and barley seeds, one should irrigate them with the milk of goats and sheep

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato yavavirūḍhamālām ābadhya naṣṭacchāyārūpaś carati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Putting on the garland formed of the sprouts of the above barley crop, one can walk invisible to others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: triratraupoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa śvamārjāraulūkavāgulīnāṃ dakṣiṇāni vāmāni caakṣīṇi dvidhā cūrṇaṃ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having fasted for three nights and having afterwards pulled out on the day of the star of Pushya both the right and the left eyes of a dog, a cat, an owl, and a váguli ?, one should reduce them to two kinds of powder

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato yathāsvam abhyaktaakṣo naṣṭacchāyārūpaś carati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then having anointed ones own eyes with this ointment as usual, one can walk invisible to others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trirātraupoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa kālāyasīm añjanīṃ śalākāṃ ca kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having fasted for three nights, one should, on the day of the star of Pushya, prepare a roundheaded pin saláká from the branch of purushagháti punnága tree

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato niśācarāṇāṃ sattvānām anyatamasya śiraḥkapālam añjanena pūrayitvā mṛtāyāḥ striyā yonau praveśya dāhayet // tad añjanaṃ puṣyeṇauddhṛtya tasyām añjanyāṃ nidadhyāt // tenaabhyaktaakṣo naṣṭachāyārūpaś carati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then having filled with ointment anjana the skull of any of the animals which roam at nights, and having inserted that skull in the organ of procreation of a dead woman, one should burn it Having taken it out on the day of the star of Pushya and having anointed ones own eyes with that ointment, one can walk invisible to others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: / yatra brāhmaṇam āhitaagniṃ dagdhaṃ dahyamānaṃ vā paśyet tatra trirātraupoṣitaḥ
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wherever one may happen to see the corpse burnt or just being burnt of a Bráhman who kept sacrificial fire while alive, there one should fast for three nights;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: puṣyeṇa svayaṃmṛtasya vāsasā prasevaṃ kṛtvā citābhasmanā pūrayitvā tam ābadhya
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and having on the day of the star of Pushya formed a sack from the garment of the corpse of a man who has died from natural causes, and having filled the sack with the ashes of the Bráhmans corpse, one may put on the sack on ones back, and walk invisible to others

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naṣṭacchāyārūpaś carati // brāhmaṇasya pretakārye yo gaur māryate tasyaasthimajjacūrṇapūrṇāahibhastrā paśūnām antardhānam // sarpadaṣṭasya bhasmanā pūrṇā pracalākabhastrā mṛgāṇām antardhānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The slough of a snake filled with the powder of the bones and marrow or fat of the cow sacrificed during the funeral rites of a Bráhman, can, when put on the back of cattle, render them invisible The slough of prachaláka a bird? filled with the ashes of the Kautilyas Arthashastra corpse of a man dead from snakebite, can render beasts mriga invisible

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ulūkavāgulīpucchapurīṣajānvasthicūrṇapūrṇāahibhastrā pakṣiṇām antardhānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The slough of a snake ahi filled with the powder of the bone of the kneejoint mixed with that of the tail and dung purísha of an owl and a váguli ?, can render birds invisible

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: ity aṣṭāv antardhānayogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Such are the eight kinds of the contrivances causing invisibility

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: baliṃ vairocanaṃ vande śatamāyaṃ ca śambaram /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: bow to Bali, son of Virochana; to Sambara acquainted with a hundred kinds of magic;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhaṇḍīrapākaṃ narakaṃ nikumbhaṃ kumbham eva ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: to Bhandírapáka, Naraka, Nikumbha, and Kumbha

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: devalaṃ nāradaṃ vande vande sāvarṇigālavam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: bow to Devala and Nárada; bow to Sávarnigálava;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eteṣām anuyogena kṛtaṃ te svāpanaṃ mahat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: with the permission of these cause deep slumber to thee

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā svapanty ajagarāḥ svapanty api camūkhalāḥ / tathā svapantu puruṣā ye ca grāme kutūhalāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Just as the snakes, known as ajagara boaconstrictor fall into deep slumber, so may the rogues of the army who are very anxious to keep watch over the village;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhaṇḍakānāṃ sahasreṇa rathanemiśatena ca /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: With their thousands of dogs bhandaka and hundreds of ruddy geese and donkeys, fall into deep slumber;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: imaṃ gṛhaṃ pravekṣyāmi tūṣṇīm āsantu bhāṇḍakāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: shall enter this house, and may the dogs be quiet

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: namaskṛtvā ca manave baddhvā śunakaphelakāḥ / ye devā devalokeṣu mānuṣeṣu ca brāhmaṇāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having bowed to Manu, and having tethered the roguish dogs sunakaphelaka, and having also bowed to those gods who are in heaven, and to Bráhmans among mankind;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: adhyayanapāragāḥ siddhā ye ca kaulāsa tāpasāḥ / etebhyaḥ sarvasiddhebhyaḥ kṛtaṃ te svāpanaṃ mahat //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To those who are well versed in their Vedic studies, those who have attained to Kailása a mountain of god Siva by observing penance, and to all prophets, do cause deep slumber to thee

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atigacchanti ca mayy apagacchantu saṃhatāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The fan chamari comes out; may all combinations retire

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: alite, valite, manave svāhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Oblation to Manu, O Aliti and Paliti

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etasya prayogaḥ // trirātraupoṣitaḥ kṛṣṇacaturdaśyāṃ puṣyayoginyāṃ śvapākīhastād vilakhaavalekhanaṃ krīṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The application of the above mantra is as follows Having fasted for three nights, one should, on the fourteenth Kautilyas Arthashastra day of the dark half of the month, the day being assigned to the star of Pushya, purchase from a lowcaste woman svapáki vilikhávalekhana finger nails?

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tanmāṣaiḥ saha kaṇḍolikāyāṃ kṛtvāasaṃkīrṇa ādahane nikhānayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having kept them in a basket kandolika, one should bury them apart in cremation grounds

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvitīyasyāṃ caturdaśyām uddhṛtya kumāryā peṣayitvā gulikāḥ kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having unearthed them on the next fourteenth day, one should reduce them to a paste with kumári aloe ? and prepare small pills out of the paste

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tata ekāṃ gulikām abhimantrayitvā yatraetana mantreṇa kṣipati tat sarvaṃ prasvāpayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Wherever one of the pills is thrown, chanting the above mantra, there the whole animal life falls into deep slumber

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etenaeva kalpena śvāvidhaḥ śalyakaṃ trikālaṃ triśvetam asaṃkīrṇa ādahane nikhānayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Following the same procedure, one should separately bury in cremation grounds three white and three black dartlike hairs salyaka of a porcupine

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvitīyasyāṃ caturdaśyām uddhṛtyaādahanabhasmanā saha yatraetena mantreṇa kṣipati tat sarvaṃ prasvāpayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, having on the next fourteenth day taken them out, one throws them together with the ashes of a burnt corpse, chanting the above mantra, the whole animal life in that place falls into deep slumber

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: suvarṇapuṣpīṃ brahmāṇīṃ brahmāṇaṃ ca kuśadhvajam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: bow to the goddess Suvarnapushpi and to Brahmáni, to the god Bráhma, and to Kusadhvaja;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sarvāś ca devatā vande vande sarvāṃś ca tāpasān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: bow to all serpents and goddesses; bow to all ascetics

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaśaṃ me brāhmaṇā yāntu bhūmipālāś ca kṣatriyāḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: May all Bráhmans and Kshattriyas come under my power;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vaśaṃ vaiśyāś ca śūdrāś ca vaśatāṃ yāntu me sadā // svāhā amile kimile vayucāre prayoge phakke vayuhve vihāle dantakaṭake svāhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: may all Vaisyas and, Súdras be at my beck and call, Oblation to thee, O, Amile, Kimile, Vayujáre, Prayoge, Phake, Kavayusve, Vihále, and Dantakatake, oblation to thee

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukhaṃ svapantu śunakā ye ca grāme kutūhalāḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: May the dogs which are anxiously keeping watch over the village fall into deep and happy slumber;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śvāvidhaḥ śalyakaṃ caetat triśvetaṃ brahmanirmitam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: these three white dartlike hairs of the porcupine are the creation of Bráhma

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prasuptāḥ sarvasiddhā hi etat te svāpanaṃ kṛtam /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: All prophets siddha have fallen into deep slumber

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yāvad grāmasya sīmāntaḥ sūryasyaudgamanād iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: do cause sleep to the whole village as far as its boundary till the sun rises

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etasya prayogaḥ // śvāvidhaḥ śalyakāni triśvetāni, saptarātraupoṣitaḥ kṛṣṇacaturdaśyāṃ khādirābhiḥ samidhāmir(?) agnim etena mantreṇaaṣṭaśatasampātaṃ kṛtvā madhughṛtābhyām abhijuhuyāt // tata ekam etena mantreṇa grāmadvāri gṛhadvāri vā yatra nikhanyate tat sarvaṃ prasvāpayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Oblation! The application of the above mantra is as follows Kautilyas Arthashastra 00 When a man, having fasted for seven nights and secured three white dartlike hairs of a porcupine, makes on the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month oblations into the fire with 0 pieces of the sacrificial firewood of khadira mimosa catechu and other trees together with honey and clarified butter chanting the above mantra, and when, chanting the same mantra, he buries one of the hairs at the entrance of either a village or a house within it, he causes the whole animal life therein to fall into deep slumber

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: baliṃ vairocanaṃ vande śatamāyaṃ ca śambaram / nikumbhaṃ narakaṃ kumbhaṃ tantukacchaṃ mahāasuram //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: bow to Bali, the son of Vairochana, to Satamáya, Sambara, Nikumbha, Naraka, Kumbha, Tantukachchha, the great demon;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: armālavaṃ pramīlaṃ ca maṇḍaulūkaṃ ghaṭaubalam / kṛṣṇakaṃsaupacāraṃ ca paulomīṃ ca yaśasvinīm //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: To Armálava, Pramíla, Mandolúka, Ghatodbala, to Krishna with his followers, and to the famous woman, Paulomi

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhimantrayitvā gṛhṇāmi siddhyarthaṃ śavaśārikām / jayatu jayati ca namaḥ śalakabhūtebhyaḥ svāhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Chanting the sacred mantras, do take the pith or the bone of the corpse savasárika productive of my desired endsmay Salaka demons be victorious; salutation to them;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukhaṃ svapantu śunakā ye ca grāme kutūhalāḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: oblation!May the dogs which are anxiously keeping watch over the village fall into deep and happy slumber

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sukhaṃ svapantu siddhaarthā yam arthaṃ mārgayāmahe / yāvad astam ayād udayo yāvad arthaṃ phalaṃ mama //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: May all prophets siddhártháh fall into happy sleep about the object which we are seeking from sunset to sunrise and till the attainment of my desired end

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etasya prayogaḥ // caturbhaktaupavāsī kṛṣṇacaturdaśyām asaṃkīrṇa ādahane baliṃ kṛtvāetena mantreṇa śavaśārikāṃ gṛhītvā pautrīpoṭṭalikaṃ badhnīyāt
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Oblation! The application of the above mantra is as follows Having fasted for four nights and having on the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month performed animal sacrifice bali in cremation grounds, one should, repeating the above mantra, collect the pith of a corpse savasárika and keep it in a basket made of leaves pattrapauttaliká

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tanmadhye śvāvidhaḥ śalyakena viddhvā yatraetena mantreṇa nikhanyate tat sarvaṃ prasvāpayati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When this basket, being pierced in the centre by a dartlike hair of a porcupine, is buried, chanting the above mantra, the whole animal life therein falls into deep slumber

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: upaimi śaraṇaṃ caagniṃ daivatāni diśo daśa /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: take refuge with the god of fire and with all the goddesses Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 in the ten quarters;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: apayāntu ca sarvāṇi vaśatāṃ yāntu me sadā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: may all obstructions vanish and may all things come under my power

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svāhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Oblation

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etasya prayogaḥ // trirātrauposṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa śarkarā ekaviṃśatisampātaṃ kṛtvā madhughṛtābhyām abhijuhuyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The application of the above mantra is as follows Having fasted for three nights and having on the day of the star of Pushya prepared twentyone pieces of sugarcandy, one should make oblation into the fire with honey and clarified butter;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tato gandhamālyena pūjayitvā nikhānayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and having worshipped the pieces of sugarcandy with scents and garlands of flowers, one should bury them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dvitīyena puṣyeṇauddhṛtyaekāṃ śarkarām abhimantrayitvā kapāṭam āhanyāt // abhyantarm catasṛṇāṃ śarkarāṇāṃ dvāram apāvriyate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, having on the next day of the star of Pushya unearthed the pieces of sugarcandy, and chanting the above mantra, one strikes the doorpanel of a house with one piece and throws four pieces in the interior, the door will open itself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturbhaktaupavāsī kṛṣṇacaturdaśyāṃ bhagnasya puruṣasyaasthnā ṛṣabhaṃ kārayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having fasted for four nights, one should on the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month get a figure of a bull prepared from the bone of a man, and worship it, repeating the above mantra

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: abhimantrayec caetena // dvigoyuktaṃ goyānam āhṛtaṃ bhavati // tataḥ paramaākāśe virāmati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Then a cart drawn by two bulls will be brought before the worshipper who can mount it and drive in the sky and tell all that is connected with the sun and other planets of the sky

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caṇḍālīkumbhītumbakaṭukasāraoghaḥ sanārībhagoasi svāhā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: O, Chandáli Kumbhi, Tumba Katuka, and Sárigha, thou art possessed of the bhaga of a woman, oblation to thee

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tālaudghāṭanaṃ prasvāpanaṃ ca //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When this mantra is repeated, the door will open and the inmates fall into sleep

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trirātraupoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa śastrahatasya śūlaprotasya vā puṃsaḥ śiraḥkapāle mṛttikāyāṃ tuvarīrāvāsyaudakena secayet //(?)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having fasted for three nights, one should on the day of the star of Pushya fill with soil the skull of a man killed with weapons or put to the gallows, and, planting in it valli vallari ? plants, should irrigate them with water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jātānāṃ puṣyeṇaeva gṛhītvā rajjukāṃ vartayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having taken up the grownup plants on the next day of the star of Pushya ie, after days, one should manufacture a rope from them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tataḥ sajyānāṃ dhanuṣāṃ yantrāṇāṃ ca purastāc chedanaṃ jyācchedanaṃ karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When this rope is cut into Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 two pieces before a drawn bow or any other shooting machine, the string of those machines will be suddenly cut into two pieces

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: udakaahibhastrām ucchvāsamṛttikayā striyāḥ puruṣasya vā pūrayet,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the slough of a watersnake udakáhi is filled with the breathedout dirt uchchhvásamrittika? of a man or woman and is held before the face and nose of any person, it causes those organs to swell

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nāsikābandhanaṃ mukhagrahaś ca // varāhabhastrām ucchvāsamṛttikayā pūrayitvā markaṭasnāyunāavabadhnīyāt, ānāhakāraṇam // kṛṣṇacaturdaśyāṃ śastrahatāyā goḥ kapilāyāḥ pittena rājavṛkṣamayīm amitrapratimām añjyāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the sacklike skin of the abdomen of a dog or a boar is filled with the breathedout dirt uchchhvásamrittika of a man or woman and is bound to the body of a man with the ligaments of a monkey, it causes the mans body to grow in width and length ánáha, When the figure of an enemy carved out of rájavriksha cassia fistula is besmeared with the bile of a brown cow killed with a weapon on the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month, it causes blindness to the enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturbhaktaupavāsī kṛṣṇacaturdaśyāṃ baliṃ kṛtvā śūlaprotasya puruṣasyaasthnā kīlakān kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having fasted for four nights and offered animal sacrifice bali on the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month, one should get a few boltlike pieces prepared from the bone of a man put to the gallows

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: eteṣām ekaḥ purīṣe mūtre vā nikhāta ānāhaṃ karoti,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When one of these pieces is put in the feces or urine of an enemy, it causes his body to grow in size ánáha;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: padeasyaāsane vā nikhātaḥ śoṣeṇa mārayati, āpaṇe kṣetre gṛhe vā vṛtticchedaṃ karoti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and when the same piece is buried under the feet or seat of an enemy, it causes death by consumption; and when it is buried in the shop, fields, or the house of an enemy, it causes him loss of livelihood

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etenaeva kalpena vidyuddagdhasya vṛkṣasya kīlakā vyākhyātāḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The same process of smearing and burying holds good with the boltlike pieces kílaka prepared from vidyuddanda tree

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: punar navam avācīnaṃ nimbaḥ kāmamadhuś ca yaḥ / kapiroma manuṣyaasthi baddhvā mṛtakavāsasā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the nail of the little finger punarnavam aváchínam ? nimba nimba melia, káma bdellium, madhu celtis orientalis, the hair of a monkey, and the bone of a man, all wound round with Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 the garment of a dead man

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nikhanyate gṛhe yasya dṛṣṭvā vā yat padaṃ nayet / saputradāraḥ sadhanastrīn pakṣān naativartate //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Is buried in the house of, or is trodden down by, a man, that man with his wife, children and wealth will not survive three fortnights

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svayaṃguptā manuṣyaasthi pade yasya nikhanyate // dvāre gṛhasya senāyā grāmasya nagarasya vā / sadhanastrīn pakṣān naativartate // ajamarkaṭaromāṇi mārjāranakulasya ca /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the nail of the little finger, nimba nimba melia, káma bdellium, madhu celtis orientalis, and the bone of a man dead from natural causes are buried under the feet of, Or near the house of, a man or in the vicinity of the camp of an army, of a village, or of a city, that man or the body of men with wife, children, and wealth will not survive three fortnights

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: brāhmaṇānāṃ śvapākānāṃ kākaulūkasya caāharet / etena viṣṭhāavakṣuṇṇā sadya utsādakārikā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the hair of a sheep and a monkey, of a cat and mongoose, of Bráhmans, of lowcaste men svapáka, and of a crow and an owl is collected, And is made into a paste with fæces vishtávakshunna, its application brings on instantaneous death

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pretanirmālikā kiṇvaṃ romāṇi nakulasya ca / vṛścikaāly(?) ahikṛttiś ca pade yasya nikhanyate /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a flower garland of a dead body, the ferment derived from burning corpse, the hair of a mangoose, And the skin of scorpion, a bee, and a snake are buried under the feet of a man, that man will lose all human appearance so long as they are not removed

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: trirātraupoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa śastrahatasya śūlaprotasya vā puṃsaḥ śiraḥkapāle mṛttikāyāṃ guñjā āvāsyaudakena secayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having fasted for three nights and having on the day of the star of Pushya planted gunja seeds in the skull, filled with soil, of a man killed with weapons or put to the gallows, one should irrigate it with water

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jātānām amāvāsyāyāṃ paurṇamāsyāṃ vā puṣyayoginyāṃ guñjavallīr grāhayitvā maṇḍalikāni kārayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On the new or full moon day with the star of Pushya, one should take out the plants when grown, and prepare out of them circular pedestals mandaliká

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: teṣv annapānabhājanāni nyastāni na kṣīyante //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When vessels containing food and water are placed on these pedestals, the food stuffs will never decrease in quantity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rātriprekṣāyāṃ pravṛttāyāṃ pradīpaagniṣu mṛtadhenoḥ stanān utkṛtya dāhayet // dagdhān vṛṣamūtreṇa peṣayitvā navakumbham antarlepayet //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When a grand procession is being celebrated at night, one should cut off the nipples of the udder of a dead cow and burn them in a torchlight flame A fresh vessel should be plastered in the interior with the paste prepared from these burnt nipples, mixed with the urine of a bull

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: taṃ grāmam apasavyaṃ pariṇīya yat tatra nyastaṃ navanītam eṣāṃ tat sarvam āgacchati //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When this vessel, taken round the village in Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 circumambulation from right to left, is placed below, the whole quantity of the butter produced by all the cows of the village will collect itself in the vessel

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛṣṇacaturdaśyāṃ puṣyayoginyāṃ śuno lagnakasya yonau kālāyasīṃ mudrikāṃ preṣayet // tāṃ svayaṃ patitāṃ gṛhṇīyāt //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: On the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month combined with the star of Pushya, one should thrust into the organ of procreation of a dog or heat an iron seal kataláyasam mudrikam and take it up when it falls down of itself

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tayā vṛkṣaphalāny ākāritāny āgacchanti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When, with this seal in hand, a collection of fruits is called out, it will come of itself before the magician

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantrabhaiṣajyasamyuktā yogā māyākṛtāś ca ye / upahanyād amitrāṃs taiḥ svajanaṃ caabhipālayet //E
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: By the power of mantras, drugs, and other magical performances, one should protect ones own people and hurt those of the enemy [Thus ends Chapter , The Application of Medicine and Mantras, in Book , Secret Means, of the Arthasástra of Kautilya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (svabalaupaghātapratīkārah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: End of the hundred and fortyeighth chapter from the beginning] CHAPTER

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: svapakṣe paraprayuktānāṃ dūṣīviṣagarāṇāṃ pratīkāraḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: REMEDIES AGAINST THE INJURIES OF ONES OWN ARMY

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: śleṣmātakakapitthadantidantaśaṭhagojiśirīṣapāṭalībalāsyonāgapunarnavāśvetavāraṇakvāthayuktam(?) candanasālāvṛkīlohitayuktaṃ nejanaudakaṃ rājaupabhogyānāṃ guhyaprakṣālanaṃ strīṇām, senāyāś ca viṣapratīkāraḥ // pṛṣatanakulanīlakaṇṭhagodhāpittayuktaṃ mahīrājīcūrṇaṃ sinduvāritavaraṇavāruṇītaṇḍulīyakaśataparvaagrapiṇḍītakayogo
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: WITH regard to remedies against poisons and poisonous compounds applied by an enemy against ones own army or people When the things that are meant for the kings use, inclusive of the limbs of women, as well as the things of the army are washed in the tepid water prepared from the decoction of sleshmátaki sebesten or cordia myk, kapi emblica officinalis, madanti ?, danta ivory, satha Citron tree, gojigi gojihva ?elephantophus scaber, visha aconitum ferox, pátali bignonia suave olens, bala lida cardifolia et rombifolia, syonáka bignonia indica, Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 punarnava ?, sveta andropogon aciculatum, and tagara tabernæmontana coronaria, mixed with chandana sandal and the blood of salávriki jackal, it removes the bad effects of poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: sṛgālavinnāmadanasinduvāritavaraṇavāraṇavalīmūlakaṣāyāṇām anyatamasya samastānāṃ vā kṣīrayuktaṃ pānaṃ madanadoṣaharam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Among the decoctions of the roots of srigála bignonia indica, vinna ?, madana, sinduvára vitex trifolia, tagara tabernæmontana coronaria, and valli, a creeper ?, any one or all mixed with milk removes, when drunk, the effects of the mixture of madana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kaiḍaryapūtitilatailam unmādaharaṃ nastaḥkarma //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The stinking oil extracted from kaidarya vangueria spinosa removes madness

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: priyaṅgunaktamālayogaḥ kuṣṭhaharaḥ // kuṣṭhalodhrayogaḥ pākaśoṣaghnaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The mixture prepared from priyangu panic seed and naktamála galedupa arborea removes, when applied through the nose, leprosy The mixture prepared from kushtha costus and lodhra symplocus removes consumption

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kaṭaphaladravantīvilaṅgacūrṇaṃ nastaḥkarma śirorogaharam // priyaṅgumañjiṣṭhātagaralākṣārasamadhukaharidrākṣaudrayogo rajjuudakaviṣaprahārapatananihsaṃjñānāṃ punaḥpratyānayanāya
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 The application of the mixture prepared from priyangu panic seed, manjishtha rubia manjit, tagara tabernæmontana coronaria, lákshárasa the juice or essence of lac madhuka ?, haridrá turmeric, and kshaudra honey to persons who have fallen senseless by being beaten by a rope, by falling into water, or by eating poison, or by being whipped, or by falling, resuscitates them

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: manuṣyāṇām akṣamātram,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The proportion of a dose is as much as an aksha ? to men;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: gavaaśvānāṃ dviguṇam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: twice as much to cows and horses;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturguṇaṃ hastyuṣṭrāṇām //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and four times as much to elephants and camels

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: rukmagarbhaś caeṣāṃ maṇiḥ sarvaviṣaharaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A round ball mani prepared from the above mixture and containing gold rukma in its centre, removes the the effects due to any kind of poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: jīvantīśvetāmuṣkakapuṣpavandākānām akṣīve jātasyaaśvatthasya maṇiḥ sarvaviṣaharaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: A round ball mani prepared from the wood of asvattha holy fig tree growing wound round with the plants such as jívantí a medicinal plant, sveta andropogan aciculatum the flower of mushkaka a species of tree, and vanadáka epidendrum tesseloides, removes the effects due to any kind of poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tūryāṇāṃ taiḥ praliptānāṃ śabdo viṣavināśanaḥ /
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The sound of trumpets painted with the above mixture destroys poison;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: liptadhvajaṃ patākāṃ vā dṛṣṭvā bhavati nirviṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: whoever looks at a flag or banner besmeared with the above mixture will get rid of poison

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: etaiḥ kṛtvā pratīkāraṃ svasainyānām athaātmanaḥ / amitreṣu prayuñjīta viṣadhūmaambudūṣaṇān //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Having applied these remedies to secure the safety of himself and his army, a king should make use of poisonous smokes and other mixtures to vitiate water against his enemy

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: (tantrayuktayah)
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: PARAGRAPHICAL DIVISIONS OF THIS TREATISE

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: manuṣyāṇāṃ vṛttir arthaḥ, manuṣyavatī bhūmir ity arthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: THE subsistence of mankind is termed artha, wealth; the earth which contains mankind is also termed artha, wealth;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthaāpattiḥ, saṃśayaḥ, prasaṅgaḥ, viparyayaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: that science which treats of the means of acquiring and maintaining the earth is the Arthasástra, Science of Polity

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: atikrāntaavekṣaṇam,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It contains thirtytwo paragraphical divisions;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: niyogaḥ, vikalpaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the book adhikarana, contents vidhána, suggestion of similar facts yoga, the meaning of a word padártha, the purport of reason hetvartha, mention of a fact in brief uddesa, mention of a fact in detail nirdesa, guidance upadesa, quotation, apadesa, application atidesa the place of reference pradesa, simile upamána, implication arthápatti, doubt samsaya, reference to similar procedure presanga, contrariety viparyaya, ellipsis vakyasesha, acceptance anumata, explanation vyákhayána, derivation nirvachana, illustration nidarsana, exception apavarga, the author‟s own technical terms svasanjá, prima facie view púrva paksha, rejoinder uttrapaksha, conclusion ekánta, reference to a subsequent portion anágatávekshana, reference to a previous portion atikrantávekshana, command niyoga, alternative vikalpa, compounding together samuchchaya, and determinable fact úhya

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: samuccayaḥ ūhyam iti // yam artham adhikṛtyaucyate tad adhikaraṇam // pṛthivyā lābhe pālane ca yāvanty arthaśāstrāṇi pūrvaācāryaiḥ prasthāpitāni prāyaśas tāni saṃhṛtyaekam idam arthaśāstraṃ kṛtam
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: That portion of a work in which a subject or topic is treated of is a book, as for example This Arthasástra or Science of Polity has been made as a compendium of all those Arthasástras which, as a guidance to kings in acquiring and maintaining the earth, have Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 been written by ancient teachers A brief description of the matter contained in a book is its contents, as the end of learning;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vṛddhasamyogaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: association with the aged;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: indriyajayaḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: control of the organs of sense;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: amātyautpattiḥ ity evaṃādikam iti // vākyayojanā yogaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: the creation of ministers, and the like Pointing out similar facts by the use of such words as „These and the like,‟ is suggestion of similar facts;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: caturvarṇaāśramo lokaḥ iti // padaavadhikaḥ padaarthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example The world consisting of the four castes and the four religious divisions and the like The sense which a word has to convey is its meaning;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mūlahara iti padam // yaḥ pitṛpaitāmaham artham anyāyena bhakṣayati sa mūlaharaḥ ity arthaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example, with regard to the words múlahara Whoever squanders the wealth acquired for him by his father and grandfather is a múlahara, prodigal son What is meant to prove an assertion is the purport of reason;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: arthamūlau hi dharmakāmau iti // samāsavākyam uddeśaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example For charity and enjoyment of life depend upon wealth Saying in one word is mentioning a fact in brief;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vidyāvinayahetur indriyajayaḥ iti // vyāsavākyaṃ nirdeśaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example It is the control of the organs of sense on which success in learning and discipline depend Explanation in detached words is the mentioning of a fact in detail;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: karṇatvagakṣijihvāghrāṇaindriyāṇāṃ śabdasparśarūparasagandheṣv avipratipattir indriyajayaḥiti // evaṃ vartitavyam ity upadeśaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Absence of discrepancy in the perception of sound, touch, colour, flavour, and scent by means of the ear, the skin, the eyes, the tongue, and the nose, is what is meant by restraint of the organs of sense Such statement as Thus one should live, is guidance;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dharmaarthavirodhena kāmaṃ seveta, na nihsukhaḥ syāt iti // evam asāv āhaity apadeśaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Not violating the laws of righteousness and economy, he should live Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 Such statement, as „he says thus,‟ is a quotation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: mantripariṣadaṃ dvādaśaamātyān kurvītaiti mānavāḥ ṣoḍaśaiti bārhaspatyāḥ viṃśatim ity auśanasāḥ yathāsāmarthyam iti
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example The school of Manu say that a king should make his assembly of ministers consist of twelve ministers; the school of Brihaspati say that it should consist of sixteen ministers; the school of Usans say it should contain twenty members;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kauṭilyaḥ iti // uktena sādhanam atideśaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: but Kautilya holds that it should contain as many ministers as the need of the kingdom requires When a rule dwelt upon in connection with a question is said to apply to another question also, it is termed application;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dattasyaapradānam ṛṇaādānena vyākhyātam iti // vaktavyena sādhanaṃ pradeśaḥ // sāmadānabhedadaṇḍair vā, yathāāpatsu vyākhyāsyāmaḥ iti // dṛṣṭenaadṛṣṭasya sādhanam upamānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example What is said of a debt not repaid holds good with failure to make good a promised gift Establishing a fact by what is to be treated of later on is „place of reference;‟ for example By making use of such strategic means as conciliation, bribery, dissension, and coercion, as we shall explain in connection with calamities Proving an unseen thing or course of circumstances by what has been seen is simile;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nivṛttaparihārān pitāivaanugṛhṇīyāt iti // yad anuktam arthād āpadyate sāarthaāpattiḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Like a father his son, he should protect those of his subjects who have passed the period of the remission of taxes What naturally follows from a statement of facts, though not spoken of in plain terms, is implication;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: lokayātrāvid rājānam ātmadravyaprakṛtisampannaṃ priyahitadvāreṇaāśrayeta
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example, Whoever has full experience of the affairs of this world should, through the medium of the courtiers and other friends, win the favour of a king who is of good character and worthy sovereign

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: naapriyahitadvāreṇaāśrayeta ity arthād āpannaṃ bhavatiiti // ubhayatohetumān arthaḥ saṃśayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: It follows from this that no one should seek the favour of a king through the medium of the kings enemies When the statement of a reason is equally applicable to two cases of circumstances, it is termed doubt;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṣīṇalubdhaprakṛtim apacaritaprakṛtiṃ vā iti // prakaraṇaantareṇa samānoarthaḥ prasaṅgaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Which of the two should a conqueror march against one whose subjects are impoverished and greedy, or one whose subjects are oppressed? Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 When the nature of procedure to be specified in connection with a thing is said to be equal to what has already been specified in connection with another, it is termed reference to similar procedure;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: kṛṣikarmapradiṣṭāyāṃ bhūmau iti samānaṃ pūrveṇa iti // pratilomena sādhanaṃ viparyayaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example On the lands allotted to him for the purpose of carrying on agricultural operations, he should do as before The inference of a reverse statement from a positive statement is termed contrariety;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viparītam atuṣṭasya iti // yena vākyaṃ samāpyate sa vākyaśeṣaḥ // chinnapakṣasyaiva rājñaś ceṣṭānāśaś ca iti // tatra śakuneḥ iti vākyaśeṣaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example The reverse will be the appearance of a king who is not pleased with the messenger That portion of a sentence which is omitted, though necessary to convey a complete sense, is ellipsis; for example With his feathers plucked off, he will lose his power to move Here „like a bird‟ is omitted

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paravākyam apratiṣiddham anumatam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: When the opinion of another person is stated but not refuted, it is acceptance of that opinion;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: pakṣāv urasyaṃ pratigraha ity auśanaso vyūhavibhāgaḥ iti // atiśayavarṇanā vyākhyānam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Wings, front, and reserve, is the form of an array of the army according to the school of Usanas Description in detail is explanation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: viśeṣataś ca saṃghānāṃ saṃghadharmiṇāṃ ca rājakulānāṃ dyūtanimitto bhedas tannimitto vināśa ity asatpragrahaḥ pāpiṣṭhatamo
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Especially amongst assemblies and confederacies of kings possessing the characteristics of assemblies, quarrel is due to gambling ; and destruction of persons due to the quarrel

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasanānāṃ tantradaurbalyāt iti // guṇataḥ śabdaniṣpattir nirvacanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: Hence, among evil propensities, gambling is the worst evil, since it renders the king powerless for activity Stating the derivative sense of a word, is derivation;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vyasyaty enaṃ śreyasa iti vyasanam iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example That which throws off vyasyati a king from his prosperous career is propensity vyasana

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: dṛṣṭaanto dṛṣṭaantayukto nidarśanam //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: The mentioning of a fact to illustrate a statement, is illustration;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: vigṛhīto hi jyāyasā hastinā pādayuddham ivaabhyupaiti iti // abhiplutavyapakarṣaṇam apavargaḥ //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example In war with a superior, the inferior will be reduced to the same condition as that of a footsoldier fighting Kautilyas Arthashastra with an elephant Removal of an undesired implication from a statement is exception;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: nityam āsannam aribalaṃ vāsayed anyatraabhyantarakopaśaṅkāyāḥ iti // parair asamitaḥ śabdaḥ svasaṃjñā //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example A king may allow his enemys army to be present close to his territory, unless he suspects of the existence of any internal trouble Words which are not used by others in the special sense in which they are used by the author are his own technical terms;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: prathamā prakṛtiḥ,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example He who is close to the conquerors territory is the first member;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya bhūmyanantarā dvitīyā,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: next to him comes the second member;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: bhūmyekaantarā tṛtīyā iti // pratiṣeddhavyaṃ vākyaṃ pūrvapakṣaḥ // svāmyamātyavyasanayor amātyavyasanaṃ garīyaḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: and next to the second comes the third The citation of anothers opinion to be refuted, is prima facie view; for example Of the two evils, the distress of the king and that of his minister, the latter is worse Settled opinion is rejoinder;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasya nirṇayanavākyam uttarapakṣaḥ // tadāyattatvāt,
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example The distress of the king is worse, since everything depends upon him;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tatkūṭasthānīyo hi svāmī iti // sarvatraāyattam ekaantaḥ // tasmād utthānam ātmanaḥ kurvīta iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for the king is the central pivot, as it were That which is universal in its application is conclusion or an established fact for example A king should ever be ready for manly effort Drawing attention to a later chapter is reference to a subsequent portion;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: paścād evaṃ vihitam ity anāgataavekṣaṇam // tulāpratimānaṃ pautavaadhyakṣe vakṣyāmaḥ iti // purastād evaṃ vihitam ity atikrāntaaveṣkaṇam // amātyasampad uktā purastāt iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example We shall explain balance and weights in the chapter, „The Superintendent of Weights and Measures‟ The statement that it has been already spoken of is reference to a previous portion for example, The qualifications of a minister have already been described „Thus and not otherwise‟ is command;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: tasmād dharmyam arthyaṃ caasyaupadiśet, naadharmyam anarthaym ca iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Hence Kautilyas Arthashastra he should be taught the laws of righteousness and wealth, but not unrighteousness and nonwealth „This or that‟ is alternative;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: duhitaro vā dharmiṣṭheṣu vivāheṣu jātāḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example or daughters born of approved marriage dharmaviváha „Both with this and that‟ is compounding together;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: anena caanena caiti samuccayaḥ // svayaṃjātaḥ pitur bandhūnāṃ ca dāyādaḥ iti //
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Whoever is begotten by a man on his wife is agnatic both to the father and the fathers relatives That which is to be determined after consideration is determinable fact;

oṃnamaḥśukrabṛhaspatibhyāṃ: yathā ca dātā pratigrahītā ca naupahatau syātāṃ tathāanuśayaṃ kuśalāḥ kalpayeyuḥ iti
Óm Salutation to Sukra and Brihaspati: for example Experts shall determine the validity or invalidity of gifts so that neither the giver nor the receiver is likely to be hurt thereby
